description:
3.5 stars for overall pretty good dim sum! 

Ton Kiang gets major bonus points for not having a wait at around 10:30 AM on a Sunday. My party of 4 was seated right away, and were served food immediately -- this restaurant isn't cart style, but "tray style" (waiters come around with trays of dim sum). However, when we left around 11:30, the restaurant was about 80% full.

Out of everything we tried, the char siu cherng fun was my favorite, along with the lo mai gai (sticky rice in lotus leaf, though it didn't have enough meat and other fillings inside). They also had xiao long bao dumplings, which were pretty good too but lacked a good amount of soup in some of the dumplings.

Overall, service was quick, food was better than average, no wait, and ample parking. I'd come here again if I needed a quick dim sum fix!
author: Victoria L.

description:
I love that they walk around with the trays of dim sum - more traditional way.  Pretty average food though. One thing that was really unexpected was how much this place caters to tourists. Menu was completely in english (so I got really confused trying to read it) and they would speak to you in English first too. 
But to the food. 
Lo mai gai was not great cause there was way too much rice and not enough filling so the rice was kinda hard and bland. 
The chicken feet was pretty good. Wasn't super saucy and was flavorful and meaty. 
Some of the other dumplings were good, but the Shanghai dumpling was not. It was semi cold, skin was hard, and didn't have the runny soup in the center. 
So the dishes were kinda a hit or miss for me.
author: Rachelle C.

description:
Good location, but hard to find parking. When you enter the restaurant, you can immediately see how crowded it is but there's also seating upstairs. The waiters/hosts are attentive and quickly talk through their walkie-talkies to see how long the wait is.

For a table for 3, we got seated within 10 minutes upstairs. We also preferred eating upstairs because it was more open and less hectic. Right when we sat down, they asked us what type of tea we preferred (good customer service). There's a menu on the table that shows some dim sum you can ask to order immediately, but there's also people walking around with various dishes. 

We ordered a total of 7 dishes (siu mai not pictued), and the dishes were more expensive than I thought. Their portion size was also smaller, esp their custard tarts (3 small pieces). After tax, the total was $40.50 and while that was enough to leave us satisfied, I've been to many dim sum places that cost way less. While most of the dim sum tasted normal, I feel like the rice noodle rolls lacked flavor. Despite having the soy sauce, something else was missing. Also, they were cut into weird sizes (wasn't even fully cut. I feel like it's usually just half, but this one was into quarters too. 

Overall, while this place had decent dim sum...I would not come back because of their portion size and price.
author: Aileen J.

description:
Good dim sum place in Richmond district. 
The $45 for 9 dim sum is really a good choice. The they have dim sum all day.
The xo sauce fish is so good!
author: Yantong Z.

description:
Dim sum: 4/5
Service: 3.5/5
Ambiance: 4/5
Overall: my usual dim sum place of choice.  I'm a fan of the little custard mochi which makes it more desirable.

The extended review...

Dim sum: id say that for the most part the dim sum is just a step higher than most of the places I've gone too.  Pretty fresh in taste.  Again if you are into sweets go with the custard mochis...it's unique to this particular restaurant.

Service: typical Chinese place.  Kind of hit or miss as the ladies can be nice one day and not so much the other.  

Ambiance: definitely one of the cleaner Chinese places I've been to.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
Ok so here's the thing. In person is a great departure from delivery. 

Yeah yeah - don't say "Obviously" because I know a lot of restaurants that I get delivery and the food is identical to what I get when I visit in person. 

Ton Kiang - no. 

The delivery I received was bad. Really bad. Things were either swimming in grease (eggplant) or the item tasted ...old (turnip cake and lo mai gai) 

I spent over $100 for dimsum that no one really liked.

The winner? Dry fried beef chow fun. 

That didn't make the entirety of the order worth it. 

So sad. Such is life. 

Shrugs.
author: Jennifer C P.

description: We went for a late weekday lunch and were pleasantly surprised! It is wonderful that you do not feel rushed because dimsum restaurants close at 2:30pm and their kitchens shut down before that. Here, it serves all day dimsum. The dimsum are freshly made...not reheated and offered in trays. We also ordered assorted dimsum from their menu and it came straight from the kitchen. Whatever we ordered, the would make 2-3 others and pass them around the restaurant. Service was polite, friendly and efficient. When we were growing up, we always went to this restaurant for Sunday dimsum. Happyto say their quality is still there!
author: Georgina S.

description:
Amazing food, really decent prices. Looks and feels like a traditional Chinese restaurant. I had the Peking duck and it was delicious.
My girlfriend had Mixed Vegetables Fried Noodles.
We also got a nice little starter as well as a complimentary tea and cookies. 
Highly recommend it!
author: Jacek P.

description:
Not bad dim sum -- nothing, other than the sesame balls, stood out to me. Mediocre food in my honest opinion. Overall, the price tends to come out pretty low once you divide it between your group. 

I wish they had a sign you could put on your table if you're taking a break from food, like they do at all-you-can-eat steakhouses.
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
I love me some dim sum so I was looking forward to trying Ton Kiang since I haven't been before. We ordered a variety of dishes about fifteen in total. The vegetable dishes were cooked well, but the popular dim sum dishes: sui mai and chicken feet were disappointing. I've had better. The sui mai just didn't have the flavor profile like it should and the chicken feet were undercooked. The meat should fall off the bones, but it didn't.

My favorite dish was the har gow. The wrapper was thin so you can taste and enjoy the shrimp folded inside. Unfortunately I don't think I'll be returning here. I have to give it to them though when it comes to service especially for a Chinese restaurant. I'd rather eat on Clement Street which has lots of yummy dim sum delis.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Anything else I say other than "I found a cockroach in my wonton soup!" is irrelevant. So, here it is Ton Kiang, tonight's delivery included this off-the-menu topping.
author: Rob D.

description:
Le bf and I came here on a Saturday morning at 9:30am. After reading the mixed reviews on Yelp, I still hoped that I would have a good experience here. There was only one other person in the restaurant and plenty of street parking, right outside of the restaurant. When we left, an hour later, about 80% of the tables were occupied. 

Between the 2 of us, we ordered:
1. Shrimp dumpling
2. Shrimp and chive dumplings
3. Potstickers
4. Scallion pancake
5. Baked pork buns
6. XLB
7. Sticky rice in the lotus leaf
8. 2 orders of the shrimp crepe
9. Tea for 2

We ordered a total of 9 items because we saw at the bottom of the dim sum side of the menu that if you ordered 9 items, it would be $45. It isn't much of a discount, but it was still about $1.75 discount for us. But at the end of the day, the lady who gave us the bill didn't give us the discount. There is something a bit shady about that. Our total came out to be around $65 for the 2 of us (including tax and tip), so not exactly cheap. We did leave with a few leftovers, but not much.

Back in the day, I remember when all the dim sum/Chinese restuarants used to provide tea for free (shows how old I am). Nowadays, it feels like every Chinese/dim sum place charges for tea. It was $1/person, so not much at all, but still, when you grew up getting it for free, it still feels weird to pay for it. The tea was also not as fragrant as other dim sum places. 

I think the biggest disappointment was the scallion pancake. My dad makes scallion pancake so I know how they should taste, and this one lacked flavor and didn't have those layers that you would typically find. Feel free to skip those. 

The potstickers weren't pan fried for long enough. There was barely a sear on ours. Flavor wise, it was very meh. Edible, but would skip the next time, if there is a next time. 

Out of the 4 XLB, only 3 had soup in it, and le bf didn't think the XLB were worth ordering again. It was edible, but out of all the XLB he has ever eaten in his life, these quickly made it to the bottom of his best XLB list. 

I really enjoyed both the shrimp dumplings and the shrimp crepes (2 of my favorite dim sum dishes). Though the shrimp dumplings were on the smaller end, I liked how there weren't many fillers in there (like those cheaper dim sum places). I also really liked how the shrimp crepe had very thin skin and filled with a lot of shrimp. I would definitely recommend you get these 2 items. 

Bf is a huge fan of baked pork buns. Though they were small, he liked how they brushed honey on the top and said it came out super hot. He thought they tasted good at the restaurant, but he said the real test would come when he would eat some cold ones, so verdict is still out on the buns. 

The shrimp and chive dumplings were very small, compared to what you get at other dim sum places. I enjoyed them, but boy were they small. 

I thought the sticky rice had flavor, but le bf disagreed. The sticky rice was barely sticky, and there weren't real chunks of anything in there (like shrimp, mushroom, meat). I think I would have preferred 1 big one instead of 3 little ones. 

Overall, the food wasn't that good. There were a few things that I really enjoyed, like the shrimp dumplings and the shrimp crepe, but everything else was kind of underwhelming. I guess the only positive thing about this place is that there aren't long lines on the weekends, unlike places like Hong Kong Lounge 2. I wished that this place was a hidden gem, but it wasn't. I don't think we would come back. I would rather pay a bit more to get better food.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
This is totally my favorite dim sum
In San Francisco - the veggie steamed dumplings  ( I don't have a pic- put like a pot sticker only a cuter white round lighter creation with water chestnuts and bursting with flavor) and we of course got hot and sour soup, my husband and sis got a bunch of shrimp dumplings - they got Pork potstickers and we got a bunch of Chinese veggies! I only got a pic of some Chinese veggies- finished with Chinese donut! Yes this place is always busy and there was at line at 925 am to get in!  Eat here
author: Monica S.

description:
I love DIM SUM. After going to Golden River next door (It's ok sand cheap) I wanted to see how this one paired up. Amazing food here. Staff was helpful, the food is constantly circulating, and looking delicious. My girlfriend and I had many items that were awesome. If they look full downstairs there is an upstairs also. They have all sorts of award stickers on there windows including Zagat.  It's now my quick in and out choice. I love impressing my gf. If you want it, they probably will make it for you.

Parking - Come early. Limited street parking.
Greeted/Seated - Met immediately at the door.
Atmosphere - Open and not over decorated. The upper area is open.
Décor - casual, comfortable.
Service - Fast and friendly.
Cleanliness - They clear tables and clean immediately.
Menu Selection - Lots of items offered, but Dim Sum is King.
Presentation/Portion - Presentation is basic. Visually appealing.
Unique - Manager organizes staff and things run with communication.
Bar - No Bar.
Patio - No patio.
Pet Friendly - No pets.
Music - I didn't hear any.
TV - None that I saw
Dress -  Casual
Value -Great food $$
Cash/Credit - Both ok
Wi-Fi - Not sure
author: Thomas B.

description:
Ton Kiang continues to be one of my favorite dim sum spots in San Francisco because it's reliable. It's  a bit out of the way in terms of location but, the quality of food and service is worth the trek. 

The main reason I keep coming back is for the onion pancake. It's amazing. Don't get me wrong, the steamed dumplings, eggplant, and varieties of shrimp are all great but, the pancake puts it over the top. It soaks up the soy, chili sauces nicely and is loaded with flavor. 

The service is fast, attentive and it's also white tablecloth. You know you've had an awesome time when sauces are dropped all over the linens and you're completely stuffed from dim sum. 

Check this place out.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
OMG yelpers, deceiving photos & reviews of 1+ star when their dim sum was no bueno & expensive!!!!!

If their food was that delish & worthy the price they're charging then I wouldn't be giving them 1 star; just saying!
author: Katy N.

description:
This review is specifically for the nai wong sui ben! We were visiting San Francisco for the afternoon and a friend said we needed to try the nai wong sui ben. Our friend placed a take-out order just for this. After calling it in we arrived outside of the restaurant and waited for what I didn't know was going to be an amazing food venture. These must take a while to make because even though we called them in, when we arrived they still weren't ready and we had to wait. 15 minutes after arrival, our friend comes back to the car with these amazing bites of heaven. 

So what is nai wong sui ben you ask? If I had to describe it they are like soft, mini pancake pillows. Pancake because they are lightly browned like pancakes, not even sure how they prepare this. Anyway, when you bite into one, it is soooo soft, almost like mochi but has the flour like element, like a pastry. The inside is soft custard with just the right amount of sweetness. Also, they were warm when we ate them. All over a wonderful little confection! Not sure how the dim sum is here but would definitely return for these!
author: Lauren A.

description:
Our go-to dim sum restaurants. We always eat any dumplings with shrimp and they never disappoint. 

The place is unassuming and feels relaxed. While you may have to wait for a table at peak hours the wait is quick and the dumplings yummy.
author: Courtney M.

description:
Inefficient style of serving where the waiter carries around dishes on a tray and asks if you want some.  It's almost never the dish you want, especially since they can only carry a few items at a time.  What happened to carts (that carry many more items) or a menu where you can mark exactly what you want on it (both are accepted formats at dim sum)?  We had to request a waiter to come to our table and write down the dishes we wanted, which I could tell was not their normal procedure.

They forgot some of the dishes we ordered on top of that , and we had to remind them.

The dishes were not exceptional and a bit pricey.  They charged us for tea as well (who does that at dim sum)?  I think this place was made for non-Asians new to the dim sum scene looking for ambiance....
author: Ryan L.

description: This place is consistently excellent. We've been customers for decades and the quality has been maintained all along. Their dim sum is terrific across the board, and if you've never tried their salt baked chicken you're really missing out. Ton Kiang beats the trendy upstarts and the old stalwarts in my humble opinion. Can't really see going anywhere else unless I'm coming into The City on BART.
author: Jack K.

description: It was good dim sum but it was not great and it was more pricey than I expected. I liked it just fine, but I wouldn't go back unless I was in the area.
author: Tera K.

description:
This is my "go-to" place for dim sum in San Francisco.  As I live in Santa Clara, it is a trek.

I really like the variety.  I usually order specific dishes as soon as I sit down as they are some that don't seem to come around often.  For the rest, we just pick and choose as the servers come by.
author: A B.

description: Ate lunch here. Dim sum served all day so ordered some. Service excellent. Dim sum came out hot. Entrees chosen were very good.
author: Clifford W.

description:
1.I found long hair in my shrimp dumpling.

2.One of the waitresses is very rude to us.

3.Foods aren't very delicious yet they are too expensive compared to other dim sum places.

We never come back!
author: Food L.

description:
Real solid.

This place is a hybrid of other dim sum arrangements, in that they bring the food around on trays, but not on those big carts. 

The variety is very good, we had a set number of dishes we wanted to order, and nearly all of them came around on the trays without us even asking. For the few dishes that did not come out, we asked for them directly from our server. 

Great house chili sauce, solid chive dumplings, stuffed eggplant, and other shu mai.

Interior is very simple, but clean and a bit nicer than many other dim sum places in this part of the Richmond.
author: Marcel M.

description:
Was a little skeptical when i arrived at around 10:20 AM on a Sunday and the restaurant was not very busy. When i drove by competitors there were people waiting in line, but i was like, hmm ok it's cool i haven't tried this place so I wanna give it a chance! 

You can already tell that it is a very Americanized place by looking at its menu on the table. As someone who is used to reading the Chinese stuff at Chinese restaurants, it was a little disappointing to see that it doesn't really cater to Chinese people unless you ask for their actual menu. I would like to think people go to dim sum for the food and the cultural experience, and that totally takes it away.

Very dissatisfied with the food quality too. It wasn't bad, but it was very mediocre. I think a part of it is also that the food is taken out on a tray from the kitchen, so as servers make their round thru the restaurant, the food gets a little cold. Also, some of their dishes are the smallest i have ever seen! Like the egg tarts & the pan fried dumplings, so not worth it. The calamari looked good tho, but i didn't try it.

Overall their service was great, but the food just doesn't make up for it. Won't be back.
author: Jen K.

description:
Drove around for 5-10 minutes and eventually found parking right outside, this on a Sunday at 1:30PM.  Not bad for the inner Richmond!

Seated immediately.  Service is very quick, not personable more table service meets quick serve.

Dim Sum was good but not great.  We tried a lot of dishes, no standouts, I think TK is living a little on past glories.

There are better Dim Sum restaurants very close by - Dragon Beaux.
author: Des D.

description: Craving some dim sum so walked in and luckily there was a table open so no wait.  They do take reservations which is nice and they usually seat them upstairs.  There are no carts and instead they walk around with trays. You'll have to flag down the good items so they don't run out by the time they get to your table but that's part of the fun right?  They have all of the usual dishes and everything was tasty. Some non-usual items are calamari, chinese donut, and I guess chicken wings but I feel like that's more common now.  You can order off their main menu too. This place is a little more expensive than the other ones nearby but we like to switch up which places we go to instead of going to the same one every time.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Couldn't leave San Francisco without eating some dim sum! We were on a tight schedule and couldn't afford to wait too long for a table at some other dim sum spots in the city, so we called ahead to see how long the wait was for a party of 3 for Sunday lunch - they said it was only 20 min so we cruised on over. In reality, we waited probably 10 min and got a nice table by the window upstairs. 

The waiters come around with trays so be aware when you're maneuvering around the dining room. I noticed that they bring the food in waves. So for example, there was a time when it was all siu mai but no turnip cakes. So, plan on staying awhile to get the full array of dishes that they serve. My favorites were the green beans, siu mai, and sesame balls. 

The service was pleasant, albeit a little slow. We had to wait around for water refills and to get our check, but it was no big deal. The restaurant is clean and there's restrooms both upstairs and downstairs. 

Tl;dr - Yummy dim sum that I will go back to whenever I come back to SF
author: Carmina C.

description:
Any SF native knows that Dim Sum places are either heros or zeros, and Ton Kiang is definitely the former. The best part is that it's not jam packed with excessive wait times like the other decent Dim Sum restaurants. I'm worried that this secret will get out in the years to come, and think wait times will get longer real soon...

It caters towards a more American audience so you'll find all your stereotypical favorites (probably why the wait times aren't too bad). Not sure my friends that are full-Chinese would love it, but I'm only a little bit Chinese and so it meets my needs just fine. Decent service and the restaurant is pretty clean. There's only one small bathroom, so that's the only caveat. 

The Peking duck is excellent too (it's not a dim sum dish; they do offer crispy duck as a dim sum option though), but we always insist on ordering a whole one so we get the steamed buns + plum sauce + crispy duck skin. Favorite Chinese dish ever, and you don't normally get to eat with Dim Sum.

Favorite Dim Sum dishes: Chinese Broccoli w/ Oyster Sauce, steamed pork buns, spicy green beans, crispy duck
author: Jessica B.

description: Unlike other dim sum restaurants, Ton Kiang serves dim sum for dinner as well! This is the only restaurant in SF I know that has this option. They don't push the carts around at night though, you have to place your orders from their menu. My favorite dishes from here are the sticky rice with lotus leaf, green onion pancake, and crab claws!
author: Victoria T.

description:
Go here if you'd like to be yelled profanities and if you are well trained in martial arts.  Otherwise avoid at all cost!!! 

Yesterday, we were faced with an unbelievably hostile attitude as a family (with two school age kids)  just because we respectfully requested a four-person table that can accommodate our family.  When we requested to speak with a manager, a waiter with a ponytail (I believe his name is Weasley but not sure)  used the F word several times!  

We could not believe our ears and a few of the customers looked at us in disbelief. When we requested to speak with the owner, they said the owner is not in. Frankly, I am not upset at the waiter but I am disappointed at the management that allows this type of mistreatment of customers. We ended up leaving the restaurant without finishing our lunch. I know this is hard to believe but we did not receive a single apology after this waiter yelled profanities at us. If someone had told me this I would not believe it.  We have been eating out at many establishments in San Francisco at all different price points for the last 20 years and have never seen anything remotely close to this before!

If we did not leave the restaurant yesterday, we were concerned about our safety because they have mentally unstable staff! I am considering escalating this further and evaluating my options at this point so that what happened to my family does not happen to other customers in the future.
author: bora o.

description: Ok so this place was busy and the food was very yummy however a good review isn't only about the food. Customers service was just rude and inappropriate.  You have to ask more than three people to get anything .  Will not return just because the customer service.
author: Skip W.

description: Someone fire the cook? I have been going to this restaurant for the last 8 years. 1st Time I have been sooo disappointed in the quality of the food. Vegetables were not seasoned and salted. Sweet and sour chicken was drowned in sauce. They forgot to separate the sauce. Common sense was lacking for this green ear cook.
author: Jim L.

description: The beast Dim Sum I have ever had. I have been coming to Ton Kiang for 17 years and have never been disappointed. Always fresh and hot. The food taste delicious, the dough is never thick, and such a large assortment. I have tried many different Dim Sum places in the Bay Area and SoCal and non come close.
author: Kamilla G.

description: So this is my first time coming here.  I came here on Monday, 06/11/18, to celebrate my Godbrother's 50th birthday.  Everything was perfect from the Wine down to the dessert.  I felt very comfortable.  I will definately come back.
author: Monica D.

description:
Fail...we got to Dragon Beaux too late and didn't want to wait 1-hour.   So hungry!
Ton Kiang for the Yelp save!  Let me start with the "YES"s first:

* YES - Clean resto with 2 levels (recommend upper for better lighting)
* YES - No wait right at Sunday prime dim-sum time
* YES - Fast, friendly service
* YES - Menu has pics & translations for those whose 1st language is not Chinese/Cantonese
* YES - Large menu extends to non dim-sum Chinese dishes as well

* DRK - Hot Tea = I'd rec diners always get this when eating dim sum...it helps settle digestion when you're eating so much oily, heavy foods!
* GET - All of below dishes were tasty & authentic :
           - Har Gow (shrimp dumplings)
           - Siu Long Bao (Shanghai pork dumplings)
           - (Don't know the name) - (mini chewy sweet white bun bites) 
           - Xia Chang (shrimp rice noodles)
           - Niu Chang (beef rice noodles)
           - Xien Jian Jiao (fried glutinous pork dumplings) 
           - Gao Choy Got (shrimp chives dumplings)
           - Fun Gor (meat dumplings)
           - Wah Tip (fried potstickers)
           - Char Siu Bao (BBQ pork bun)
           - Luo Buo Gao (pan-fried turnip cake)
           - Dan Tah (egg tart dessert)
* AOK - Custard cream bun = It was tasty but too coconut-y for my liking
* AOK - Mango pudding = meh, not the best I've had

* FYI - Accommodates large groups, ample seating
* FYI - No reservations needed
* FYI - Street parking only
* FYI - Accepts credit cards
author: Sandee T.

description: Not nearly as good as it used to be. Bland and overpriced. What a disappointment! Better off going to Hong Kong Lounge 2 or Dragon Beaux.
author: Lily L.

description: Used to be the best. Now they are lackluster and use a ton of filler vegetables in place of the ingredients that you are ordering. Spent $60 on take out last week and I will NEVER order anything from there again. In addition, their website doesn't work and every menu I found online is waaay cheaper than the actual prices of the yucky dishes they are serving. Talk about adding insult to injury.
author: SO P.

description: Our favorite Chinese restaurant in the Bay Area. Love the food... something for all of the different tastes in our extended family.  We usually order from the extensive menu, but dim sum is also an option. Very pleasant inside. Reasonable prices. Parking is a challenge...patience is required.
author: John F.

description:
The pros and the cons of TK revolve around the fact that caters more to non-Chinese diners. On the upside, the servers are exceedingly polite (and speak English), and the interior is clean, comfy, and calm. On the downside, it is pricier for what it's worth, and the menu is more restricted since there is a significant portion devoted to Americanized items such as crab claws, egg rolls, pot stickers, and fruit salad.

Nonetheless, the dim sum is decently authentic, with enough variety that there was no shortage of items to order. In a blind taste test, I think some of the more basic dim-sum-cart places would be superior, but TK is good enough to satisfy my expectations (which are rather high, thanks to my many dim sum excursions in Hong Kong).

(+++) Shrimp dumplings (蝦餃) | $4.50: Mmm, explosively juicy, meaty shrimp. Probably my favorite dim sum here.
(+) Pork dumplings (燒賣)  | $4: Quite good, but I've had better. I think it needs more broth.
(+) Chinese broccoli (芥蘭) | $6.25: Nice crunch, fresh veggies, but a bit too oily.
(+) Stuffed eggplant | $5: Tasty, but the eggplant soaked up a lot of oil.
(-) Beef crepe (牛肉腸粉) | $4.50: Probably the most unimpressive, the texture was the beef seemed a bit like meatloaf. Also, the rolls were oddly very flat.
(++) Dried bean curd roll (鮮竹捲) | $4.50: Delicious, though the pork seems fattier than other places I've had this dish.
(+++) Wasabi mustard sauce | I'm almost never a fan of sauces, but this was a highlight of the meal! The wasabi was strong, synergized well with the mustard, and was an excellent addition to essentially all of the dim sum.

TK is not as gimmicky as the juggernaut Koi Palace/Dragon Beaux duo, whose multicolored XLB and the like may be more appealing to foodies/Instagrammers. TK is halfway between upscale fancy d down-to-earth good food, resulting in satisfying dim sum in a cozy environment but at slightly marked-up prices. 

The verdict: 4 stars for those with a YOLO'ers, hard-core foodies, and rich people who work in tech; 3 stars for anyone on a grad student budget like myself :3
author: Edna C.

description:
Came here a few times before a few years back, so I knew Ton Kiang had some amazing dim sum.

The wait was not too bad for a Sunday morning. Took approximately 20 mins to get seated. The great thing about dim sum is once you're in, food is handed to you immediately.

We made our rounds through some plates of food. These are the standout ones:

- the eggplant/shrimp dish is fantastic!
- the breaded pork buns are super incredible!

The only dish that we felt was OK, was the fried calamari - it was just too salty.

I think our total bill came out to $58.00 or so, which is perfectly reasonable for being that full.
author: James D.

description:
It's been at least 20 years since our last visit.  We are staying 5 nights in SF for my younger son's BD trip, we were going to eat at all of our good picks of restaurant from 20 years ago, the first pick was Ton Kiang.  We had so much positive experience with this one and we were almost shocked of how one restaurant could change.  They got so famous and quality went downhill.  We tried 4 items including pot sticker and Chive dim sum, they both came out room temperature, we did not want to order any dim sum dishes.  Ton Kiang Special Seafood hot Pot, even though the same suggest mainly seafood, but deep fried tofu and seafood were 60/40% combo.
Soup was also not very hot, at that point, we had enough of it.  We will probably never going to return here, as much extensive competitions out there, not sure if I even see this establishment in business a few years from now.
author: Sam M.

description: I went to Ton Kiang for the first time for dim sum brunch on Saturday. We showed up around noon and were seated upstairs immediately. I am really surprised this place is not more busy than it was. The dim sum was carried around on trays and they showed us what each one was. Service was great at this place as well. The water and tea was flowing. Always a plus. The dim sum was also great. I will be back here for sure!
author: Kam L.

description:
It seems like a lot of good dim sum restaurants get mixed reviews because they have delicious food but people don't like the service, so I was stressed out about finding the BEST place. I'm also mildly allergic to shrimp so I wanted to find somewhere with a lot of non-shrimp options. This place was great for that.

Delicious food! I was really hungry so I pointed to the first food that came around-- chicken in foil, which was crispy and browned. It turned out to be my favorite. I also loved the pork noodle roll, baked pork buns, and sesame balls. We had some steamed pea shoots, which were a delicious fresh vegetable to round out all the doughy goodness. The potstickers were fine, and the short ribs were too sweet for me. 

They bring food around on trays, and there was a big variety the whole time we were there. Everything we wanted came around more than once. You can also order from the menu if you want something in particular.

It was busy, but we were seated right away both times we came.
author: Scout S.

description: Just moved to the area and so happy to have found this awesome Dim Sum spot. We ordered 6 plates and everything was delicious. Highly recommend!
author: Lauren M.

description: I have been coming here for 8 years! The customer service has completely gone to shit, it was never really great but now they don't even pretend. I ordered 40.00$ worth of takeout for lunch a decent size order. When I asked for two extra hot sauces he yelled (younger Asian man) at me and said he'd have to charge me 5$ no way! You are rude, your food is ok, and your service is subpar. Will not be returning!!
author: Chela A.

description:
Honestly, I wasn't impressed. The selection being showcased around wasn't much to my liking. Even the things I did pick up weren't that impressive. The flavors just did not come to life at all. Everything looks very nice, but the flavors were just ordinary to me. 

I don't see Ton Kiang having any redeeming qualities. Especially when other awesome dumpling houses exist within a close vicinity. Naw, I won't be back anytime soon.
author: Aren A.

description:
This spots claim to fame is all day dim sum. Now if you are OK with this concept that basically negates the idea of dim sum you will do just fine here.
Things haven't changed over the years and this spot churns out acceptable dim sum. Just beware that they are geared towards regular mainstream items so if you are OK with those you will do just fine. There are better offerings nearby but they do get slammed during prime time. 
I would rate them 2.5 stars for what they offer.
author: Elvis A.

description:
I have been to Ton Kiang many times.  Today we were there for lunch and  I need to emphasize that the quality of the food and the flavor are 100% improved (and it was already delicious).  The service was great too!

Great dim sum!
author: Emilia G.

description:
I've been to Ton Kiang many, many years ago before yelp...they used to have 2 locations and Ton Kiang is a special restaurant for me as I spent many, many times with my grandmother having dim sum, lunch or dinner here. This was our "Go To" Chinese restaurant. 

Now that I finally came back and checked in, here's my review...
The dimsum has plenty of choices and taste really good. My favorites are:
Shrimp balls - just perfectly fried
Steamed Spareribs - has actual meat instead of usual bones only
Shanghai Dumpling - sweet
Sticky rice - perfect sauce of pork meat & some shrimp
Pork Siomai - ohhhhh....myyyyyyy...goshhhhhh soooo good!
Pan fried Chive dumpling - yummy

We also tried some of the following:
Shrimp & Spinach - so good
Shrimp & Cabbage - definitely a must try
Shrimp dumpling - okay
Shrimp noodle - okay
Chicken feet (don't eat it but parents said it was tender, juicy)
Crab claw - it's okay not my favorite 
Pork Bun - more please...yummy
Peking duck - it's okay there was some burned skin

I still want to come back for some "non-dimsum" food too. Try to come before 11:00am as it gets pack fast; otherwise, you have to wait a while. Parking can be a problem too (well, it's SF so what do you expect...right?) :0
author: CJ B.

description: Best dim sum and some of the best Chinese food in SF proper. Everything is absolutely delicious. It can get a little busy but they turn tables quick. Don't neglect this gem if you know what's good for you. Trust me.
author: David S.

description: This wonderful intimate dim sum restaurant is such a treat. It's a relief to be in a lovely quiet, neighborhood family restaurant environment instead of in a huge, noisy, factory style place for dim sum. I kind of don't want people to know about it, so it doesn't get over-crowded. We booked a table for a graduation lunch, and were so delighted!  Good food. Parking very feasible. We'll be baaack...
author: Marla P.

description:
This restaurant has been around for decades and we were regular customers, given the convenient location for us. However, the service here is terrible and the quality of the food has deteriorated. When you order your dinner choices, everything comes out at the same time. You also have to "grab" a waiter to get his/her attention. They are super unresponsive and arrogant about providing good service. I recently had an issue with the service and brought it to the attention of the owner who was seated at a dinner table. His response to my complaint, "I'm having dinner here"! I said to him, "I guess you really don't care that you are giving your customers the best service..."
Bottom  line: if the owner doesn't care about the service provided to his customers, don't eat here! There are plenty of other great Chinese restaurants to choose from, eg, go to the Hong Kong Lounge II restaurant nearby. The food is excellent, reasonable prices, and the service is outstanding.
author: Priscilla M.

description:
Open Christmas day! This is a must for our family. 

This is a great experience and a chance to try a lot of unique foods and its always delicious. 

The pork buns, donuts and all the delicious dumplings were a huge hit. Great and fun for kids too. Greans beans are awesome too!

We have always been able to be seated easily and they have two levels. Authentic and delicious. 

The service was great. Price is a little high for dim sum but, you get a great experience. Come hungry!
author: Heather R.

description:
This is a full on dining dim sum experience but the food wasn't up to par. Out of all the things, my favorite item was probably fried shrimp balls that were served with a crab claw handle. It was clever use of what would normally be throwaway claws, but who am I to say it wasn't throwaway in the first place. All other items we ordered were bland and the signature items felt like they were frozen and not fresh. I ordered Chinese donut wrapped in rice paper that wasn't available in the carts the dim sum ladies pushed around and that really disappointing. The donut was overly fried and had way too much oil remnants. 

For a Saturday brunch, it ended up costing about 90 dollars for 3 people. Even for San Francisco standards, that seemed a bit excessive to me and they likely had an up charge for the weekend. I normally don't mind paying a pretty penny for great food, but this was not great by any stretch of the imagination. I would save your money and go experience better dim sum at the many smaller hole in the wall type places around Sunset and Richmond.
author: Quoc N.

description:
Ton Kiang is reliable, reasonably priced and excellent in taste and quality of their Dom Sum.
I have gone their for pickup, delivery and dining in since 2013. Never disappointed!
author: Lars R.

description:
Most frikking amazing great experience today at
Ton Kiang-not only was the dim sum fresh, tasty and wonderful the service was excellent( dim sum with a smile???) you gotta try the soup dumplings , soy sauce noodle, pork buns, spicy prawns.... and much Minh more, try coke-bo
Tea.
Really made the day great- loved it especially cause spending time with my kid ( Becc')
Really , really great !!!
author: Dean K.

description: This review is only for their dim sum. It was OK. The quality of ingredients was poor.  It wasn't the freshest and the preparation was such that it was either over steamed (so texture was weird) or poorly fried (too oily).  While most of the dumplings and rice rolls were meh...the chicken feet were really not tasty.  Sorry but with so many dim sum places on Clement, I would not go back.
author: Monica K.

description: Love this spot. I didn't even know there was an upstairs, so the seating went fairly quickly. Virtually no wait. I like any of the variations of shrimp dumplings here and the fried crab claw with shrimp is so good. Can't go wrong. They bring all the dishes by so you can take a look. Great for me because I always forget what the names of different dishes are. Must try!
author: Sophia N.

description: Ton Kiang is OG.  Before people were flocking to Hong Kong Lounge, this was the dim sum spot to be.  In my opinion, it still is the best in town.
author: Alan S.

description:
Good: there duck was pretty tasty. Not dry and the sauce that came with it was good. Their fish soup was also really good. Put a little chili oil in it and it's king. 

Bad: service was mediocre and was nothing special. I had their soup dumpling that barely had any soup. It was more like a regular dumpling. Has their crab claw thing and tasted like imitation crab. Would not come here again cause it's pricey and not worth the money
author: Rick H.

description: Great experience. The shrimp dumplings are definitely worth the wait. Great spot for a family dinner.
author: Christopher F.

description: Americanized but pretty authentic dim sum which is clearly accustomed to the American tastebuds :) Food selections brought to the tables by foot rather than by carts which is the extinct tradition. Therefore be sure to have some spare time in hand as you never know when will the dish u have in mind be brought to your table. Overall, decent but not amazing food at a slightly above average price. Not bad but not fantastic.
author: Chean L.

description: Came here for Dim Sum and I looked at price, cool okay decent. Then when they actually served us... I was like okay... that's it? What the fuck. How would I pay so much for so little? I ate here with my girlfriend, they gave us 3 small ass egg clusters, atleast give us 4. 2 for each. You are already scamming us? Why not give us an even amount. It's just Dim Sum, everything looked fancy but dayumm such a rip off of you compare the portion size from this place and any other dim sum restaurant! Not coming back again, way too expensive. Quantity over quality
author: William F.

description: Good food, bad service ! The waitress ignored us most of the time, when I finally yelled- she came to out table with an attitude. Anyway - the whole deep fried fish is the must ! So good ! Honey walnut prawns, combination chow fun good - but overpriced ! Good choice of dim sum, always fresh and tasty.
author: Victoria A.

description: Love this place because you can get pretty good dimsum anytime. The only downside - PARKING! I mean lack of it, but well - it's worth it!
author: TATIANA D.

description:
I haven't had dim sum in about a decade, and boy was this place worth it! You can barely understand what the servers are saying, but the amazing thing is, you can look at it and portions are small so you've got nothing to lose! 

It's so simple, but their cucumber salad, and the Chinese broccoli were so yummy!  Their shrimp stuffed snow crab claws were so awesome too! I wish they had more dessert type stuff though! 
All of their dumplings were so good and they just kept on coming. 

Word of advice, don't come here for a date, it needs to be at least a double date or triple date. The more people the better so that you can try multiple things. We probably tried 7 items because it was just the two of us, and trust me, I wanted to try at least 4 more items!
author: CJ B.

description:
Food has gone steadily downhill since longtime manager William
retired. Today was the last straw. Went for dim sum lunch- salt and pepper shrimp so greasy and over battered that I threw up immediately after eating. The waitress wanted me to pay for the shrimp!
Never going back or ordering delivery. The food has deteriorated in so many ways that its become a real loser.
author: Nancy D.

description: We knew we'd chosen well when the locals next to us asked how we'd discovered Ton Kiang and picked it over the tourist packed lines of nearby Hong Kong Lounge and Dragon Beaux.  We were seated right away and before long our table was piled with small plates!  What I really loved about this place were the many veggie options they had coming around regularly, like cucumber salad and sauteed pea shoots.  It just made for a great mix along with the standard pork buns, sticky rice, and dumpling fare.  Highly recommend.
author: Lauren D.

description:
I have always wanted to check this place out but it's normally really busy, we got here right when it opened and got the first seat. This meant we had to order the stuff we wanted off the menu as they were not bringing dim sum out to the tables yet. 

The crowd of patrons is a little more well rounded here than some of the other places I frequent and that's alright. I like white people dim sum. As far as the food is concerned it's totally legit, not super expensive and the portions of the special items is good sized. 

This is what we got:
Shanghai meat dumpling (balance of flavors is exceptional)
Green beans (Awesome)
Vegetable Egg rolls (killer)
Fun got (Mushrooms and shrimp) (killer)
Sticky rice (killer)
Hargow (just okay)
Siumai (just okay)
Sticky rice (killer)
Fried shrimp balls (bland)
Salt and pepper shrimp (whole unpeeled deep fried - not a fan)

Mustard and chile vinegar are brought to the table after you sit down, really good flavor and a nice touch. That will bring me back again.

I always go to the place right next door, I always order about the same amount of food and let's just say it's a trade off, price or quality,
author: Ben M.

description:
Giving one star for the horrible service and mediocre food. Came here for dinner with my family on a Saturday night.

Parking sucked. Had to park a few blocks down, so make sure to have someone drop in and get a reserved seat.

When we ordered, our waitress was super rude when we were asking what was popular. It seemed like she didn't want to wait up for us to order, which I get, but at the same time she showed no willingness to try to be patient at all. 

Everything came out after 1 hour of waiting. 
It was really frustrating because during that 1 hour of waiting, we weren't brought water or checked on by the waitress. So we pretty much sat there almost completely ignored by the staff. Note, there were 6 of us. When we finally tagged our waitress down and asked if we could have waters for all of us, she came back with 3. We thought she would come back to give the rest... but she didn't lol. We had to tag them down again to give us the other 3 water glasses. When we asked the waitress if our food would be ready soon (after already 40 minutes of waiting), she said it was coming. We asked the manager after 50 minutes where the food was, and he was pretty much saying he was busy and pointed us to our waitress. After an hour, the food started trickling in. The dishes didn't come together though, it was plate-by-plate. We got our vegetable dish first, then 5 minutes later another dish, then 5-10 minutes another dish and so on. So we didn't even start our meal or get everything until an hour or more later. And it was not even very busy, there were definitely some empty tables so we had no reason why it took so long.

The food itself was mediocre. Nothing exceptional about it. We got fried rice, crispy noodles, spinach, Mongolian beef, broccoli beef and walnut shrimp. Portions weren't the biggest. The noodles were actually pretty good, but everything else was overpriced for the portion and quality of the food. The walnut shrimp did not even come out until we were already finished with our food (one and a half hours in). The walnut shrimp was also super disappointing. The portion was super small (half of a large sized plate), and it seemed poorly prepared. The taste also didn't offset the poor quality in presentation or the long wait.

Overall; I could understand if they were understaffed, if the waitress had a bad day, or if the managers were really just busy. But some things could have been avoided... (3 water cups for a family of 6- really?) (checking up on us, etc)
From a customer's perspective, it was a horrible experience and the food did not make up for it in the slightest bit, so we left extremely disappointed.
author: Zac B.

description:
Pretty standard dim sum spot been here a few times when in the area. 

**parking can be troublesome but there is parking spaces nearby if you're lucky

Perks:

Serve dim sum all day
Not too long of a wait depending on what time you come
Friendly service 
Shrimp and chive dim sum very good
Great spicy mustard sauce 
Only place in the area that didn't have a notification of a poor health rating (thanks Yelp for the lookout)
author: Janessa H.

description: My friend and I went there for dinner and I was truly blown away. Best I've had since moving to San Francisco! Ordered pot stickers, veggie chow mein, lemon chicken, sweet and sour pork, and fried rice. The pot stickers were the best I've ever had. The food came out super fast, and was hot and fresh. They give you enough food to feed a small army, so arrive hungry or bring a few friends.
author: Joey A.

description:
I've been there twice and everytime I'm in there, I feel like a minority in a dimsum joint. I believe this place is catering to Americans. They have pictures of their food to show what you're ordering. When you're in a table with a few non-speaking chinese folks, they actually say their dimsum dishes in English. I don't know some of their stuff in English and expect them to say it in Chinese. 

There were 10 of us when we went and I thought the service was okay. I felt they didn't attend to us as much as we liked especially when we wanted our check, it took awhile. The total was about $220!!!

Meh, we were about to go to Tong Palace, but they were doing construction. 

MEHHH!!! It would have been better if it were a little cheaper and the service was better.

Parking is okay, still have to find it and it's metered, unless you know the area and you can park in the residential areas.
author: Eugenia W.

description:
Finally found a quality dim sum place within SF that's worth mentioning. We were a party of 9, found reservation on a Sunday afternoon without any problem. 
Loved everything we tried. Our top favorites were snow peas and shrimp dim sums. The boys liked the steamed pork buns- sweet, juicy and not too salty. 
The sweet stuff we tried was on point! The sesame halls were not too oily and the mango puffing was refreshing and not too sweet. 
Great service, good ambience. Perfect family lunch. 
Will definitely go back!!!
author: Divya K.

description: Yummy! Amazing dim sum here but it's a little too fancy here. You have to get the soup dumplings and their sugar dumplings!
author: Miguel E.

description:
Usually this place is amazing but today was frustrating. 

We got put on the second floor in the back. If they put you here, refuse. You will be at the end of the rounds and will likely only see what everyone else has turned down. 

We never see pot stickers or pork dumplings there. We specifically ordered them and then waited 45 minutes and never seen them. 

Several people in our area were similarly upset by the lack of service up there. After complaining they got rude. Just not worth it when they are busy but they can't deal.
author: Zac B.

description:
Six of us went on a recent Saturday morning--getting there a bit before 11. No waiting! By the time we left the second floor--which they opened to accommodate us--was nearly full, but there still didn't seem to be any waiting. We stuffed ourselves until we couldn't see straight and the bill came to about $25 each. 

We got a lot of different dishes, and while we aren't dim sum experts, most was quite tasty and well prepared, we thought. The servers don't come around with carts, but with trays holding, usually, several kinds of dishes. 

One piece of advice would be to not fill up on the first things that come around. There were some scrumptious-looking dishes that didn't show up until we were too full to get more. 

I read the reviews saying this place was a little pricey for what you get. I think it's not pricey considering we didn't have to wait an hour to get in, which is common on Saturday mid days. And I didn't think $25 per person was bad at all for the quantify and quality we got.

We also found the service to be fine. Most of the servers don't speak a lot of English, but it's enough, especially considering that the food is right there in front of you. The floor boss speaks good English if you have special questions. 

Bottom line is we would go back happily. The second floor also features a large bay window that gives an airy feeling to the place--very pleasant even if you aren't right by the window.

Note that a party of 6 is optimal. Many of the dishes come in 3s, which the server has scissors to cut the bun or dumpling or whatever in half, giving you six portions. And with 6 you can try a larger variety of things. 

One of our group was a vegetarian+seafood eater and he was able to stuff himself as well, though he complained about the "seafood" mostly meaning "shrimp." Which he likes, but he likes other kinds of seafood as well. There was a scallop dish that we didn't try. 

Is it Americanized? Not as far as I could tell, and I have eaten in the other dim sum joints in Chinatown. Maybe in the sense that nobody came around with the things that most Americans won't touch, such as chicken feet and jellyfish/sea cucumber dishes. But there was still vastly more variety than a party of six could sample in one sitting. And the dishes they did have, including the traditional sticky rice with bits of meat wrapped in a banana leaf, seemed pretty down home to me (unless you insist on thousand year egg being in it). 

And the location is great for going to the attractions in Golden Gate Park afterwareds--the De Young Museum, Academy of Sciences, Botanical Garden Etc. We parked in the park on the main drive at around 23rd Ave., walked to this restaurant, then to the De Young, then to the car. Long walk but hardly a death march.
author: Lee T.

description: This place used to be very good.  Not sure what happened.  Everything is so bland now.  Disappointed, but now we know...
author: Patrick R.

description: We had dimsum here on Memorial weekend. Spacious and clean. Food was good. Parking was a little more convenient than Chinatown.
author: Jean G.

description: Been coming here for a few years and have always had a good experience with their dim sum. Their other food is ok but their dim sum has always been tasty and consistent and not too doughy like other dim sum places in the area. Service is the usual Chinese restaurant service.
author: Papo G.

description: Been coming here for a couple of decades and it's always excellent. Dim sum consistently well-crafted and tasty. We almost always order the salt-baked chicken because it's a masterpiece of simplicity and deliciousness. New favorite: oxtail clay pot. But don't miss the spicy jellyfish appetizer and fried tofu stuffed with shrimp. And, in season, the ong choy, especially if you can get them to make it with fermented shrimp or bean paste sauce. Yum.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: As someone who has eaten dim sum their whole life, I can honestly say that this place was okay. Came to try this place after seeing how many reviews there are on Yelp. We walked in around 2 PM on a Tuesday and there was a fair amount of people. All of the waitstaff were able to speak both Cantonese and English and were friendly enough. Upon looking at the menu you could tell that this restaurant is very Americanized. The menu for dim sum was not very extensive and was in the same menu as the normal dinner menu. They didn't have different types of tea to offer either- which I thought was odd since most dim sum places do. I thought that the flavors of the dishes we ordered were okay, some dishes were more flavorful than others, but it wasn't bad. The prices for the dishes wasn't bad either, the total for the 5 of us was about $60. The good thing about this restaurant is that dim sum is served all day, so if you are ever craving dim sum at 7 PM- this is the place to go. All in all I thought this place was okay but not great or memorable.
author: Ashley W.

description:
My mom and I go to Ton Kiang every time I get to SFO. It's one of the very few dim sum restaurants serving at dinner time and the food is GREAT. I like that at night you order off the menu so everything is fresh and cooked to order. The shrimp crepe, shrimp balls and scallop/chives dim sum are not to be missed - actually everything they make is delicious. 

It's a bit out of the way so this is truly a locals place. Enjoy! We've been going a couple times a year for about 15 years. Yum!
author: Carolina F.

description: Delicious and fast! 5 people dining and our bill was less than $100!!! The place was packed
author: Melissa S.

description: I have been coming here for years. Lunch is fun astounding have the experience of trays passing, food delivered immediately to your table. Their dim sum is phenomenal. I order the potstickers, and Tye ginger is perfection. Their foil wrapped chicken is also a winner. If ordering from the menu, the orange chicken and chow mein are musts. Oh, and they deliver!
author: Sarah E.

description:
I was just gonna give this place two stars, cause it's aight. BUT, our bill for a party of six was under 70 dollars and that's a steal, so three stars for you! 

I prefer Hong Kong Lounge down the street, but I wouldn't mind coming back here.

As my friends say: it's a place you take people you don't really care about that much cause it's not too expensive.
author: Laverne N.

description: As someone who has had quite a bit of dim sum, this place was great! I was concerned about the reviews, but service was great and fast, lots of variety, fresh veggies, delicious dumplings and good seafood. Portions were good and atmosphere was nice although a little pricey.
author: Addi W.

description:
I've been a fan of Ton Kiang for at least 15 years. They make wonderful Dim Sum, and have a lot of delicious chef specialties. The food has high quality fresh ingredients and lots of good seafood options.  
I've eaten Dim Sum all over the City and Ton Kiang is one of my top 3 favorites. Plus, delivery is a bonus. 
It's pricey but worth it!
author: Rachel D.

description: I love the food here! We try and go to Dim Sum Sundays as much as we can. The service is kind and helpful and the food is THE BEST!!! The price is very reasonable. We love this place!!!
author: Cat C.

description:
Always a line here because it's the nicest neighborhood dim sum in the Richmond. It's pricier than other ones in the area but it's cleaner so it's better for when you want to have a nice sit down dim sum. 

Unlike the place in Chinatown, they walk around with trays of dim sum rather than pushing a cart around. They have a menu on the table in case you want something in particular and didn't want to wait until they come around.
author: Nicharee S.

description: I've lots of things about Ton Kian over the years but I wasn't overly impressed. We came on Sunday night just as it started to get busy, although there is an upstairs seating area too. We shared a number of plates including duck, noodles, pork buns but I felt that the whole thing was a bit of a grease fest. I'd try another place in future.
author: Matt B.

description: Traditional white tablecloth and hot tea sit-down dim sum setup. The dim sum kept coming around and had some tasty dishes! The variety seemed good and found pretty much everything we wanted/expected. Enjoyed sitting upstairs.
author: J K.

description: I really wanted to like this place. We got a table for 5 right away. Service was strange. Seemed like they were all on sedatives. I had to ask for water 3 times. We were trying to get the egg tarts, asked 3 times, and waited over 20 minutes. They finally arrived, after we were leaving. The spareribs were all fat, and they used too much cornstarch. The dumplings were just ok. The food was mediocre at best. Not going back.
author: Bernice B.

description: We are having lunch here. Dim sum seems tasty and good and not too salty. However, one thing really bothers me and I do hope restaurant can improve it. This is kind of hygiene concern. They have staff carrying dim sum to sell you around the restaurant but half of the food being passed is not covered, so if the staff sneezes how he /she can avoid contaminating food in front of he or she.
author: Bel L.

description: We just had another stellar experience at Ton Kiang. Roast Duck, so good. Irresistible skin, savory meat. Soup dumplings, crisp asparagus with garlic, it was all good. Huge line across street at equally good Dragon Beaux but why wait? This place is very good--there's a reason it's an SF institution
author: Laura S.

description:
In observance of Lent me and my little group of friends for the day couldn't eat meat. So we literally ordered shrimp (minus one plate of calamari) in so many different ways. We got shrimp dumplings, shrimp fried balls, shrimp flat noodle, and their honey walnut prawns. Ordered appetizer calamari and rice too. SO MUCH FOOD but we were absolutely starving. Ended up finishing everything actually... Lol back to the food, calamari was delicious. Their honey walnut prawns were good but it kinda looked like we got skimp cause there were 4 of us and we only got 2-3 prices each. They separate the walnuts and the shrimp on the plate, which was beneficially since I don't like the walnuts and two of the other eaters loved them. Made it easier to access and easier for me to get away from. The dim sum was the typical, nothing amazing but not gross or bland either. One thing that was disappointing was that they didn't give us the rice till half way through out meal so we were kinda passed that point and over eating rice. 

We got there at about 3:30 and they were still open and taking orders for dim sum. As many of you may know, not all dim sum places are open all day or serve dim sum all day so that's a plus! I'm assuming that they do the dim sum carts during the morning but only take it by order during the day. At least that's what it sounded like when we spoke to the waitress. 

The food is good, it's clean, and service was nice too. Bathrooms located in the back and I saw stairs so they may have an upstairs too!
author: Mariel Ashley S.

description:
+sizzling veg rice soup
+bok choy w garlic
+crispy squid w ginger sauce
+sugar coated egg puffs

====== great happiness, sweet dreams, long life
author: Libra J.

description:
I last visited 2 years ago and I couldn't fathom how far this restaurant has slid.  I have 30+ years of experience with dim sum. I have had great har gow (shrimp dumpling) and bad har gow, but I have never encountered what I had today.  The har gow skin was very chewy and tasted powder-like. All of the har gows looked identical.  I am not sure if they came off of a machine or was store bought.  Something is terribly wrong with the formulation. It was a surreal experience and our lunch was pretty much ruined after that.  We stopped after 3 more plates and never ordered dumplings again.

I hope someone can prove me wrong, at which point I will revise this post.

In any case, we will never visit this establishment again.
author: The T.

description:
The dim sum here is fine; I certainly wouldn't venture out of my way to come here, but the food overall met my own minimum standards of tastiness. Anyway, here's a run down of pros and cons I made while eating here:

Pro #1: It's open from 9 to 9 (well, 10 to 9 on weekdays), which means it's open during that dining twilight between 2:30 and dinnertime, when Hong Kong Lounge is closed.

Pro #2: The staff all speak great English*

Pro #3: Restaurant is very clean*

Pro #4: Service is good/attentive*

Pro #5: All but one dish we got was served piping hot, a pretty rare experience for me when I'm not ordering dim sum off the menu

*NB: In comparison to other Chinese restaurants only

Con #1: The best dishes were things that appealed to a more American palate, such as the shrimp paste ball stuffed with a crab claw, or the shrimp paste ball stuffed with scallops. The classic dim sum items (dumplings, chicken feet, etc) were more disappointing.

Con #2: Not super cheap...definitely not expensive, but not as cheap as I would have liked.

Observation #1: When I came here, majority of the customers were non-Chinese (take from that what you will).

A good summary would be that Ton Kiang is fine, but probably best for those just getting introduced to dim sum. For those of us who prefer better (and cheaper) food at the expense of service and cleanliness, there are plenty of other options in the Richmond area.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Decided to try TK because it was a favorite of an acquaintance I know at a place I volunteer who has been going for years.  Unfortunately after trying half a dozen dim sum places in the city from fancy to ordering at the counter and going home with a plastic bag of dim sum TK didn't impress.  It was no better than the latter.  There are two places in the city we go for a quick dim sum if we don't want to wait for hours in Chinatown and Richmond.  TK isn't any better.  It was nice that there is virtually no wait.

I was nostalgic for the carts that go around the tables which seems to be disappearing. So when we got to TK and saw that they go around the tables with a tray of dim sum but without the carts I thought I would like it but I find that I actually don't.  I guess I'm a convert.  Food arrived cold.  I guess ordering from a list and them making it is best because they can make it to order and it arrives pretty warm, less waste?  The downside is you don't get to see the dish before you order, so you have to know what your ordering or know Chinese.  Either way I think i like ordering from a list if my food arrives warm or the temp its best served.

Food is actually not bad but comparable to cheaper places not worth it.  Probably not coming back since there are lots of alternative.
author: Naty D.

description:
Hmm. I was surprised that this place wasn't more outstanding than it was. A few friends raved about it, and it seems that according to Yelp, over 600 people "might read my review" next week, so it's definitely generating a lot of interest.

But at the end of the day, it was really a pretty standard Chinese-restaurant-dim-sum place.

Enjoyable. But nothing special. At all. Basic, tasty, enjoyable, and forgot about it ten minutes after dinner ended.

Not quite sure what excited people about this place. Meant seriously; if you're a person who LOVES this place, message me and say what to order. I'm totally willing to give it another try. But as far as my experience went, it was literally the middle of the bell curve. Mean, median, and mode.
author: Sean B.

description:
Finally I've found my San Francisco dim sum spot!  A friend who lives in Tennessee MUST have his dim sum fix whenever he visits our coast, so we've been on the hunt since moving up from LA more than a year ago.  This is it!

LOTS of veggie options which thrills me, kid-friendly, clean, no line even at 10am on a Sunday.  Appropriately grumpy service.  DO NOT BOTHER with Chinatown unless you have the stomach for truly authentic (I do not, which I'm not sorry for).  I'm sure there are other lovely dim sum options, but this one fits the bill so nicely that I have no intention of looking elsewhere.
author: Kali M.

description: Many amazing spots around town, but I must say this spot just sticks out from the rest. Get here quick as it does get quite busy during lunch and dinner. Amazing service, great food I couldn't reccomended one thing in particular as I was a fan over everything. Can't go wrong with the soup dumplings and the glazed pork buns. Oh, the rice cakes! So good.
author: Sunny E.

description: I have eaten here many times over the years, and always enjoyed it. Nice atmosphere, good service, very good food, and reasonably priced. One unusual feature is that dim sum is available throughout the day, including for dinner.
author: Jethro B.

description: A staple for my Singapore family who likes all the seafood dim sum. Luckily, the crowds seem to have abated due to Dragon Beaux opening nearby. Shorter wait for me? Yes, please.
author: Anjolie C.

description: As a Chinese American, I have eaten my share of Chinese food with my family. This is the worst place ever. Not only is the service not that great here but the food is so salty and the food takes half an hour to an hour to come, and this is just only one dish out of like 5. There's so many white people here who come here and get served first. Seeing tables that come after us and get their food before us is not fair at all. Talk about white privilege. Never want to come here ever again. This is ridiculous.
author: Teresa W.

description: My chinese, native SF friend recommended this place and it's a hit.  I hosted a group of 12 people and we ordered crab/lobster/peking duck.  Everything was fresh and flavored authentically.  One person in my group said it was the best meal of his life!  What a compliment.
author: albert c.

description:
Fair dim sum spot but tastier since I'm coming from the east bay,
Parking is tough, came on a Sat morning and was very busy.

Perks:
Serve dim sum all day
chicken wings very good
Great spicy mustard sauce
Tea delicious
xiu mai very good

Would visit again
author: Le P.

description:
Their great reputation is well deserved. Ingredients are fresh and top quality. Flavors are vibrant, complex and complementary on the palate. 
It is heaven to enjoy Ton Kiang's dim sum and entrees by delivery! Their timing is magic: everything is hot, fresh off the stove and clearly hasn't been sitting under heating lights or in a delivery vehicle. 
NB: In the last several months prices have gone up (again) approx %15-20 overall, as portion sizes have decreased slightly. That said, I'm still hooked on their delicious Loy Han veggies, chive & shrimp dumplings and shrimp stuffed eggplant. 
Don't take it personally if the staff isn't particularly friendly. I've been going there and ordering from there for years without much of a thaw.
author: Adam R.

description: One of our first sit-in dim sum experiences. Have had many since then and this review is in retrospect. Most waiters do not speak English. We were overwhelmed with all the food. Did not taste up to par. A local recommended it and we thought we should try it. I am glad we did but unlikely to return.
author: Jc B.

description:
The Dim Sum here was very good, as was the service. 

Wait staff was english friendly and the menu had several pictures. I'm not completely new to dim sum, but I appreciate the help. 

Price may be a bit high, but the food and service are worth it.
author: Will T.

description:
The food is really tasty. My family and I used to celebrate anniversaries here. And basically every single time the service made us feel uncomfortable. The personnel was just disrespectful and arrogant. It almost felt that we bothered them or that we aren't really welcome. And that was going on and on every time we visited. 
So we decided to look for something else. A place where we (and our obligatory 20% tip) are appreciated. So thumbs down!
author: Susi E.

description: Ton Kiang could do much better representing this favorite Cantonese past time that is dim sum.  Alas, the dishes we had this past weekend, standard fares like lotus wrapped sticky rice and shrimp with some kind of veg dumpling were subpar.  (We also had others but they were so forgettable, we can't remember anymore.)  The former was basically all rice with only a smattering of meat; the rice was actually hard.  The dumpling was very small and not memorable.  The only decent thing we had were the baked BBQ buns.  Don't skip the line at Dragon Beaux to come here like we did.  It's not worth the calories.
author: Jen W.

description: This is a place that never disappoints me, I have been going for three years and always I leave the restaurant delighted with the food! Always very fresh but my favorite is the baked pork barbecue buns, the best!!!!!
author: Flavia K.

description:
On a lazy Sunday afternoon, Mr. Dubs, Emmett L. and I decided to go for a dim sum brunch. Since we didn't feel like waiting an hour for a table, we decided to check out Ton Kiang. After all, how bad can dim sum get? BIG MISTAKE!

We should've left the moment we saw the dim sum "menu" which consisted of drawings and English pin yin names for dim sum. The menu resembled the back "Learn Chinese" portion of a fortune cookie fortune. We also should've known better when we saw platters of fruit bowls being carried around. There's no fruit bowls in dim sum!

But we were too hangry to see the sign. Instead, we ordered beef rice roll, ha gow, sui mai and Shanghai dumplings before making the ultimate decision to grab the check and finish up our meal at a real dim sum spot. 

I've never been snooty about Chinese food-- authenticity doesn't matter as long as the food is delicious. Unfortunately for Ton Kiang, it's neither authentic nor delicious. I will never be back.. no matter how hangry or how long the wait it is at real dim sum spots.
author: Tiffany U.

description: Came for a birthday and the service was terrible. Food was coming out but waitress didn't know which table what went to. They couldn't understand what we were saying and just felt as if they wanted us to hurry up, pay @ leave. It took a while for the table to be cleaned off for the dessert that we brought. I won't be Bk!
author: Rena K.

description:
Pretty great dim sum. They actually take reservations!!!! Unheard of for dim sum!

Everyone knows that the best dim sum isn't in Chinatown, so save your parking nightmares and overpriced, touristy experience and go to the Richmond District instead.

Our party had 9 people on a Sunday at noon..we had 3 vegetarians, and still managed to get great service, and better yet, SO many options (even veggie options)!

We had garlic asparagus, veggie spring rolls, Chinese broccoli, calamari, spareribs, green beans, egg yolk tarts, sesame balls, BBQ pork buns, shrimp and chive dumplings, sweet creamy tofu, veggie dumplings -- then more shrimp, more beef, and a lot more than I can remember.

Every dish was great; there was so much more I wanted, but was so full. My one complaint: no cocktail buns here! But not to worry...walk up to 23rd and Geary and get a dozen cocktail buns from the bakery on the corner.
author: mary r.

description: Food was ok, but most waitstaff were not very friendly to us. They did not explain options for ordering dim sum and just assumed we had been there before. We felt judged and uncomfortable.
author: Kristen P.

description: Having been here twice (but spread out over the course of a few years), Ton Kiang is really just OK for dim sum.  It isn't going to blow your mind, but it doesn't suck and I didn't get food poisoning. A bunch of girlfriends and I came here this past weekend, were seated relatively quickly, and got our fix of dim sum items to the point where we were satisfied.  No one raved about anything in particular (I think the highlights were discovering what Ham Sui Gok (deep fried pork dumplings) was, whereas the low point was easily the Shanghai soup dumplings), and service was reasonable but certainly not outstanding.  All in all, if you're an impatient person and don't like the idea of waiting at some of the more popular (but probably more delicious) places in the area, Ton Kiang is a good place to settle on.
author: Lisa I.

description: Mid afternoon dim sum.  Yummy!  Waves of nicely steamed dim sum came our way.  Heavy on shrimp dumplings, but that was fine with me.  Efficient, if not engaging, service.  The prices were reasonable.
author: Jerry H.

description: Its so wonderful and amazing that you can enjoy dim sum anytime at Ton Kiang. The dim sum is so good, fresh and tasty.
author: H L.

description:
My friend is a regular here so we get fast service and seated even if there's a line.

I love the pork buns, wonton soup (shared) and almost all of their dishes I've tried from duck to shrimp to vegetables and Xiao long Bao.

It's definitely a classic San Francisco Chinese restaurant and institution. 

Worth it for Dim Sum on the weekends and dinner at night.
author: Michael R.

description: We went there for Christmas dinner. The place was packed. We ordered a wide selection of dishes, including vegetarian pot stickers, ginger scallion lamb, etc. Then we waited. and waited. and waited. We almost got some food after an hour, but we realized the waitress made a mistake, and that wasn't our dish. We even got the check delivered to our table before we had eaten. We started looking in around the table and in our bags for anything edible. After about 80 minutes of waiting, we finally starting receiving the dishes we had ordered. We were ravenous by that point. The food was delicious, but the service was absolutely abysmal.
author: Chu W.

description: Above average diem sum...Fresh, hot, not greasy...good portions at fair prices.  There really isn't a dish that stands out..Parking is difficult..downstairs has a better vibe, more intimate and you can watch the food roll out of the kitchen.  Upstairs is a banquet room that they oftentimes use for seatings...
author: Mark S.

description: Went on a Saturday just before noon and walked right in.  (Our usual place had a long line and we were starving.)  Everything was fine, just a lot pricier than we expected.
author: Josie O.

description: Food is delicious. Great dim sum and menu items are great as well. Just know service is interesting. Don't expect much, be ready to ask for everything twice. Be ignored regularly and lots of attitude.
author: Nikolette S.

description: If you love Chinese food this is the best for me. They are top 5 in the Bay Area. I would recommend them. Love all their food . Specially the dimsum.
author: Pia O.

description:
One of our go to place for chinese cuisine when we have out of town friends. 

Tip: if you  plan to enjoy the Baked Seabass, order it early since it will take 40mn...but totally worth the wait.
author: tuan t.

description:
I have to agree with a previous reviewer: the place has gone downhill.
-Soggy tasteless roast duck (it tasted like they had heated it up in the microwave, skin was not crispy but chewy and disgusting)
-Siu mai were under cooked and bland
-Overpriced and they charge for tea (was $60 for a few mediocre plates, no wine)

Don't do it!

Hint: if you want the real deal dim sum go to the little holes in the wall on Clement street: $1.80 for 3 so you can get a decent lunch for under $6...
author: Monkey B.

description: So EVERYONE knows about this place and EVERYONE says you have to try it at least once in your life for dim sum. I did, and it's overhyped. I went for lunch and was seated in the front of the restaurant. Figured that this priority seating zone would be best for catching lots of plates as they walk by, right? Wrong. It was pretty long before even the first dishes walked out of the kitchen. I ordered the dim sum regulars: har gow, siu mai, shrimp balls and wasn't impressed. The dumplings were on the smaller side and lukewarm. What the heck? Plus the meal was expensive for the amount of food that I ordered, $24+ for four dishes?? No thanks.
author: Nick C.

description:
When I drill down to a handful of favorite dim sum spots in SF, Ton Kiang, old and reliable out in the Richmond, makes my short list.
