For me, if its not a big ol' downtown splurge at Yank Sing, then Ton Kiang is next on my quest for a satisfying SF dim sum stuff-fest. 

This two story temple painted in 80s pink and grey on Geary is an old reliable for wandering trays of delicate mushroom and shrimp dumplings, giant pork shumai, soft shell crab with hot peppers, pea shoot and mushroom dumplings, crispy duck and sweet sauce, shrimp and chive dumplings, steamed pork buns, greens with garlic, asparagus, and all manner of desserts, including my go-to dim sum dessert order, fried sesame balls with red bean paste.  When I see them cutting those beauties into fourths, I have to smile because I know my dim sum meal is ending perfectly.

I'm not sure if its a San Francisco thing, but being raised on the hot mustard, vinegar and soy combo that is the wasabi of the SF dim sum world, I find myself at home at a place with these accompaniments.  I usually get a dirty look when I ask for hot mustard in Vancouver B.C. (maybe its an insult to the chefs, drowning out the delicate deliciousness of a perfect dim sum, but its how I came up in dim sum loving San Francisco.)

The service here is not super friendly, but its mostly efficient and things move fairly quickly (with the exception of special orders off the menu, so order kitchen items early, if you want those not to arrive too late in your meal.). A great spot for a Sunday brunch and is there a New Year on record that should start off without some form of Chinese food?
author: Rachel H.

description: Love this place! We got their orange chicken/broccoli beef (huge portions), steamed rice, egg rolls (meat and veggie). Super tasty and the sweet&sour sauce was delicious! We got seated right away on a Saturday night around 8pm. Our waitress wasn't very friendly but I'd still go back.
author: Katie P.

description:
The food is alright and the food is very small.  You will have to ask twice for napkins and water.  Soy sauce with jalapeños in a space bowl with barely any jalapeños that cost $2.  They never said that there will be a cost.  They spoke in Chinese thinking that we don't understand.

Best place to go for dim sum are:  DRAGON BEAUX and KOI PALACE.
author: Vicky C.

description: Ton Kiang still one of my favorite dim sum places in the Richmond.  Seems to be easier to get a table now that Dragon Beaux has opened up.  All their standards are still great like foil wrapped chicken and their walnut cookie
author: Michael C.

description: Dim Sum rather than Rice-a-Roni is my San Francisco treat, and Ton Kiang is my place for Dim Sum when I visit my heart that I left here.  Each dish outdoes the last in taste and goodness.  The egg custard pastries are divine. The spicy fried prawns cannot be beat--my dining partners each took one and I hogged down the rest.  Every other of the many dishes we shared exceeded all our expectations.  May have to buy the house for sale around the corner so i don't have to travel so far to get there.
author: Eugene R.

description: Great dim sum, quick service, and really well priced. Will be back next time I'm in the city.
author: Rebecca F.

description: Best Dim Sum ever!!  Favorites:  Duck; Shrimp Dumplings; Hot pork buns; Fried Calamari;  asparagus; onion pancakes; Mango Pudding.  Lived in San Francisco and Sausalito for decades.  Dined with friends and family at Ton Kiang many, many times over the years.   Now, when I visit, Ton Kiang is on my must-do list.
author: Susan H.

description: Excellent, tasty dim sum, along with lunch and dinner menu items. Arrive early to find street parking.
author: Christopher B.

description: This is my go-to spot for dim sum. Even on weekends there really doesn't seem to be a line wrapping outside the door because they have two levels. You can order dim sum even in the evening (some spots don't). Everything is well priced and delicious and you get your food quick.
author: A R.

description:
The worst. Do not order take out from them. Ordered delivery... got some else's order and they refused to take it back or replace it. DO THEY UNDERSTAND CUSTOMER SERVICE???
They offered to take another order and let us pay half?? Crazy? They blamed us....despite the fact we have been ordering from them for the last 15 years...
author: E E.

description:
Not gonna lie no sir. Is it greasy? Yes sir. Is it salty ....um why yes. Is it healthy...well as healthy as a Michael Jackson sleep clinic!

But......Ton Kiang still serves up some really tasty Americanized Chinese food.

Chicken Chow mein is actually really good....tons of thick noodles with chunks of wok grilled chicken in a delectable sauce.

Orange Chicken.....oh yeah.....crunchy chicken with sweet orange sauce and chuncks of pineapple ( I feel like walkin over to trader sams for a scorpion bowl with this dish)

BBQ pork rice...now weez talking....lovely fried rice (not too greasy), tiny chunks of fried pork, egg, onion.....oh how I love thee.....even cold the next day.

Finally and lastly their Salt and pepper spare ribs...brother can you spare a Lipitor?
So tasty and flavorful....oh so bad for you....but worth the darn sin...each and every heavenly bite.


Yes I could drool on about the shrimp balls, rock cod fillet clay pots, their pretty good dim sum....but than I must get back to eating.

Not cheap but I still think worth a visit once in a while!
author: David G.

description:
We Did not enjoy our first visit to this place. There was a little communication barrier from the staff. The food was OK not all that exciting from all the hype. 

We sat upstairs. Dim sum was flowing for 20-30 mins. We were somewhat enjoying ourselves. Then all of a sudden without any warning from the staff, all the food stopped. For 30 mins we waited until we can't wait any longer. We asked one of the staff( young male) about why did the food stop coming. He said " you should have ordered quicker, they are taking their breaks right now". WTH! !! They should have informed us about it. We have to ask for the menu and place an order. They should have informed us about it. We weren't the only ones affected. There were at least 5 -7 tables confused and irritated! Really Poor customer service. Bad management!  We could have gone elsewhere! UGH! There is NO WAY we will return to this Place. Is there a ZERO star option?!?!
author: Shane T.

description: This is a standard dim sum place that serves the normal staples but not really anything beyond it.  The shrimp balls, steamed riblets, and egg custard were all very good, while the shrimp dumplings and BBQ pork buns were just OK.  The string beans were disappointing, however.  Considering the two of us didn't really wait on a Sunday morning and were pretty full with a $40 bill (pre tip), this will definitely be on our short list the next time we want dim sum.
author: Simon L.

description:
I wouldn't recommend eating here when there are just so much better dim sum or seafood restaurants within walking distance. 

Overpriced and skims out on food quantity and quality.

This place charges you for tea which simply shows how stingy this place is. 

Ordered egg tarts and a couple other steamed plates. Egg tarts were literally the size of a quarter for $4. What a rip off. Just like the other dishes.

The only redeeming dish was the salted fish and chicken fried rice which tasted like some effort was put in.
author: Brendan M.

description: Very decent, good food and CLEAN dimsum place in the Richmond district. Would def recommend for those who have a slight germophobia
author: Sylvie W.

description: Great Dim Sum! Good pricing. It might be busy on weekends but wait times are usually 15-20 minutes and it's always worth the wait!
author: Nadia S.

description: Delicious dim sum.  This is a two floor restaurant and is quite crowded.  It definitely is catered towards non-Cantonese speaking groups which is awesome.  Come early as it can get a bit crowded at times.
author: Richard L.

description:
I been eating this place for over thirty years,the first Restaurent in china town on Broadway and Stockton there father open some time in the 80,and the second in Geary near spuce,this is the lated one and only one now,(Ton Kiang)and I been a good customer since,and alway good and happy.
But today I went to the eat with my three other good friends,the service is terrible,I have to keep asking for more water,hot water for the tea,been careless on the job,and the food quality it down,I did ask the waiter,did you guy change the owner,he say NO.
We have lunch and dim sum ,the salt bake chicken it over cook or using microwave,the chicken skin it all wrinkle up and the dish it very dirty with oil all over the side,then the waiter say no micro wave,you already eat the chicken,now what you want,and mumble in chinese to other waiter,this is not professional in term of food service,after 5 minutes later, the second waiter have argument with the other table on one of the dish that mistake,at the other end.
By the way four of us all in the Restaurent business for more the 40's years,and every one retire.
Well I believe ether need to change the management or need to change the new worker.
I PERSONAL WILL NOT GO BACK AGAIN.
author: Songsak M.

description:
I'm not a dim sum expert but I do enjoy it from time to time.   I went to Ton Kiang with a group of family/friends, none of whom were Chinese so we did not go for the more exotic (at least by Caucasian standards) items like chicken feet. 

However, what we did get was very nicely done...the veggies were crisp and well seasons, the duck had crackling good skin and was juicy, the chicken dishes were great, and the pork bao fluffy and delicious.  on the advice our our friend who comes  here regularly we avoided the Chinese donuts but did for the sesame balls and custard puffs.  The sesame balls were scorchingly hot so be careful...despite that they were so good!  The custard was the best however, lightly sweet and creamy good.

What I liked best about this particular dim sum experience was that even though i did experience something of a dim sum coma afterwards I did not experience the moderately ill sensation of being overloaded with salt, meat, and oil that is so often the after effect of eating dim sum...at least for me.  Hence this is probably my new go to dim sum  place, as good as dim sum can be it's not worth feeling sluggish the whole rest of the day!
author: Alan S.

description:
Yawn.

In a sea of dim sum in S.F. this restaurant may have once been good but is now just "meh".

Frankly, and I don't know this, I suspect Sysco or US Foods plays an integral part of preparation.
author: Josh D.

description:
Well, the Mighty has fallen.....................but not that much!
Chin Boon Wong ruled the roosts of Hakka cuisine with 3 Ton Kiangs about 35 years ago, with the preserved mustard greens with pork belly being a singular dish. However, even though the help is courteous and polite ( RARE for Chinese eateries ) and the restrooms are clean ( even rarer ), the food has gently become "gentrified" towards a non-Chinese clientele; that is, westernized.

If this is OK with you, you will love this establishment.

I did prefer the original one on Broadway, though..............
author: George T.

description:
Delicious!!! Came here late one night looking for some good dim sum and I was pleasantly surprised. Service was quick, and the waiters were very attentive, friendly and helpful. 

Definitely want to come back and order more. The menu has dim sum and entrees so you can enjoy a little bit of everything. Each plate we tried was extremely flavorful and came out quickly. My only complaint was the chow main was a little greasy for me (but that's to be expected). 

I would recommend 2 orders of pork buns, shrimp dumplings, pot stickers and the sesame balls. Oh and come hungry with lots of friends.
author: Annelise G.

description:
I don't know why it's taken me so long to review Ton Kiang since I used to come here for dim sum with some regularity about a decade ago when Martha Stewart was extolling its virtues prior to her prison sentence. It was good, and I'm sure it still is, but the reason Jamie W. and I came back after all these years was to try the $10.50 Ton Kiang Steamed Salt-Baked Chicken (see photos). Now I may be the only person not Chinese, not a grandma and under eighty who likes to eat steamed chicken. That's at least what they tell me at Hunan Homes, but this turned out to be a specialty dish at Ton Kiang.

It was pretty good, just not great simply because they lacquered a sesame oil on the skin which for me, defeats the purpose of ordering chicken steamed. It was tasty, but the ginger-garlic sauce on the side would have been enough for me. Jamie preferred the $10 Chicken in Curry Sauce with Green Peppers, though he wasn't shouting from the rooftops about it (see photo). It was certainly hearty enough with plenty of peppers and onions along with the stir-fried chicken. He's definitely not an eighty-year-old Chinese grandma. It was another split decision when it came to the $11.50 Spinach with Pith of Bamboo Shoots and Golden Mushrooms, which was an odd concoction served on a glass pie plate (see photo).

The spinach was covered in a gooey mix of the bamboo shards and wood mushrooms making for an odd consistency. We were more generally satisfied with the $10 bowl of Wor Won Ton Soup, which was abundant with pork and chicken as well as won ton, bok choy and snap peas (see photo). There was barely enough room for the broth in our bowls, but we had no complaints. We were certainly sated after four dishes, but we were a bit meh given my fond memories of their dim sum selections. Guess we'll just stick to those the next time. The place is certainly popular with families on the Friday evening we went. Hope you don't mind a sometimes chaotic day-care ambiance while you dine.

FOOD - 3 stars...their dinner dishes don't match up to my memories of their dim sum
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...pretty standard except when the toddlers run riot in the aisles...where are their leashes?
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...surly sometimes but the dishes came out like clockwork
TOTAL - 3 stars...guess it's back to Hunan Homes for my steamed chicken
author: Ed U.

description: I ordered the beef chow fun. It was ok with a side of sweet and sour sauce (salty without it). The food was ok. I was surprised that they did not have side dishes of rice for the entree.
author: Tracy P.

description: Good array of options, my favorites are the chilled asparagus, baked pork buns, soup dumplings, and pea pod dumplings. They come around to tables with dishes and you take what you want vs ordering off the menu. About $100 to fill up four people. Can be a wait on weekends at peak times.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Bottom line: Decor is dirty. Tea is fine. Service is mediocre. Food is unappealing and bland. Read more for details. 

I stand at the door for several minutes watching the backs of waitstaff who are engaged in conversation.

I'm seated at a booth - the walls are filthy. This is Monday at lunch. I assure you that there was no end-of-week cleaning performed in this section of the restaurant last night. 

I wait for 2 minutes for tea. It's served in a large pot with a tiny cup. They don't match. 

I don't want dim sum, I want a menu. 
My waiter seems disappointed. 

Several times I'm offered dim sum. I just want chicken fried rice. And a fork. 

I order. I get my fork. I place the dim sum placard in front of the grossest part of the unclean booth wall. 
I look at the floor. It's dirty. 

I get my rice. It's greasy. There's not much chicken. There's a total of one - yes one - tiny cube of carrot in
the entire dish. There's also finely chopped celery & green onions. There's a little egg. The cook didn't get the oil hot enough because the entire dish has that consistency when the oil soaks into the rice rather than having that lightness that it has when cooked at a high enough heat. The dish is bland tasting and wilted looking. If I wasn't famished I'd send it back and leave.
author: Matt V.

description:
Celebrated an extension of my Mom's Birthday ... 2 words to describe ... Awesome Dimsum !!!

Place was packed when we arrived. Glad we made a reservation so we were told to go upstairs for our table. Food came quickly. To sum it all up here are the food the we ordered ...

Roasted Duck x2
BBQ pork ribs x2
Steamed Pork Ribs x3
Pork Sui Mai x3
Xiao long Bao x2
Har Gao (Shrimp Dumpling) 
Chicken Feet
Tofu Skin
Sweet and Sour Pork
Lemon Chicken
Chicken Dumpling x2
Sesame Balls
Pot sticker
Chinese Donuts
Chinese Broccoli
Shrimp and Scallops Balls
BBQ Pork Bun x2
Steamed Rice x3

Price is very reasonable for the quality of food they served. No wonder the place is full. Definitely will be back. The only drawback is parking. But who cares? Just go there early enough to look for a parking space. There's actually a small public parking a block away from the restaurant. Very satisfied customer. Everybody enjoyed the food
author: Kristina A.

description: I am usually not the biggest fan of Chinese food but I LOVED this place. Service was really great, will bring you chili sauce and water when asked right away. Amazing selection of dimsum and they're not greasy!! Mustard spicy sauce was delicious as well. Thank you for satisfying my dimsum craving. I will definitely be back!
author: Kristina T.

description: Came here for dim sum w/my girls..I think we were the first ones early morning to come in.  Their selection was pretty tasty & filled us pretty quickly! I will come back again.  This place is better than Chinatown!
author: Cris M.

description:
This is the problem.  I was trying to go to Hong Kong Lounge, but my boy wasn't feeling too hot at 9:30 AM.  By the time I convinced him to roll with me at 10:30 AM, I knew we were screwed.  Because if there's one thing I know about Asian people, it's that they will wake up INSANELY early for dim sum.  I can't even explain why this is the case, but given the long line at Hong Kong Palace (and pretty much any other decent dim sum place I've been to), it's just a fact.

So why did I just spend an entire paragraph talking about another place?  Because this wasn't even on the radar initially.  I mean, I'm in San Francisco...there's gotta be another decent place around here right?  My boy suggests here.  And he's definitely my man, but the food wasn't good.  Especially considering I'm paying full dim sum prices for this stuff.  The basics (shau mai, har gow)...I mean, I could've went to a take-out dim sum place and gotten the same quality for a better price.  I think the only thing that I really liked was the duck, and I guess the chicken feet weren't too bad either.  But I was really regretting not going to Hong Kong Palace.

And then I decided to actually look around...and I saw zero Asians.  And in my head I'm thinking...yo, what kinda decent dim sum place has ZERO Asian people in it?  That pretty much sealed it for me.  Which is kinda harsh because the service wasn't too bad.  But facts are facts, I got high levels of expectations for dim sum.  I can't be going to places where restaurants can throw out something passable enough for the non-Asians.  Not gonna fly with this Taiwanese guy.
author: Alexander Y.

description: I came for Sunday lunch with a friend. Parking took awhile to find. There is only street parking available. The food was really good. I really enjoyed the ha gao (shrimp) and the duck! For the two of us, we ordered about 9 plates and it came out to about $50. We were definitely stuffed!
author: Eunice L.

description:
It's not bad, but I feel like it just wasn't as good as some of the other places I've been to in the Bay Area.

The only plus here is that the servers will explain to you what they're bringing, in English. Good for dim sum novices!
author: Kazu O.

description: When we arrived to ton kiang the restaurant was packed. We had a 5-10 minute wait, but were seated as quickly as possible. As soon as we were seated we were brought tea, and the food began to arrive soon after. Everything we ordered was delicious, especially the sticky rice (of which my younger cousin are 4 packets), sesame balls, and fried crab claws. All in all the food was delicious, and filling, and the wait staff was polite and helpful.
author: Hannah L.

description: This place really needs to step up its game with all the amazing dim sum in San Fran. A friend recommended this place and I am disappointed that this was our only opportunity for dim sum on this short trip. The service is quick and pretty rude and the dim sum itself lacked flavor and variety.
author: Julie D.

description:
Solid dim sum fare - get here early to get a table.  Otherwise, they'll open up the 2nd floor where there is plenty of space.

The egg tarts were delicious -perfect bite-size mouthfuls! Yum..
author: Jade B.

description:
I'm obsessed. No other dim sum compares after coming here. Sucks that it's so far from the east bay!! Love the all day dim sum. Here's what I always get: 

Pan fried chive and shrimp dumplings 
Spinach and shrimp dumplings 
Scallop and shrimp dumplings 
Hargow (Shrimp dumplings) 
Rice Custard cakes 

I'm convinced that there is some addictive drug laced in the dim sum. I can eat it seriously a whole week straight and still want more. Okay I'm done sounding crazy. Experience for yourself.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
Yum yum! Clean restaurant, fast getting a table, friendly and  efficient  service!!
The  dim sum was served hot and fresh.  Huge variety of dishes. I'll come here anytime!!
author: Linda A.

description:
I've been to Ton Kiang several times including dim sum on Christmas Day, but today was extra-special since it was my little boy's first dim sum dining experience.

The wait was predictable but not unbearable and the service a little choppy since it was packed on Christmas Day with a large crowd outside all waiting for tables. The quality and variety of dim sum more than made it worthwhile.

Clams in black bean sauce, har gao, baked pork buns (so delicious with just the right amount of sweetness and not too doughy), shrimp with chives and shrimp with mushrooms, Shanghai dumplings, shrimp with pea shoots, all delectable.

The standouts were the steamed items although the only fried item we had was fried calamari (very greasy and a little too sweet). The jury's out on the beef with basil which we did as takeout and I haven't broken into just yet.

Over the years, I've eaten several very good meals at Ton Kiang and today, because of it being a new tradition with my little boy, was special. 

In a toss-up between Yank Sing and Ton Kiang, Ton Kiang wins: Both restaurants have award-winning dim sum but Ton Kiang is much gentler on the wallet and they offer a full menu of Chinese entrees, side dishes and soups/appetizers.

A true winner- and worth the effort searching for parking in the outer Richmond.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Great (and relatively cheap) dim sum! Service was okay. Came here with the parents at the recommendation of my aunt. They have an awesome deal of twelve dim sum dishes for $55, which was perfect for the three of us.

Dishes described below (quantity included):
- baked barbecue pork buns (3): delicious, filling had enough meat and mild but pleasant bbq taste without being that weird red color you get some places
- steamed bbq pork buns (3): delicious, see above comment about filling, bun was super fluffy
- shrimp and scallop dumplings (4): delicious, had some cilantro hidden inside yum
- potstickers (3): delicious, nice touch of ginger
- shumai (4): delicious, large chunks of shrimp and pork inside yay. For some reason they called these pork dumplings on the menu if I remember correctly
- shrimp dumplings (4): delicious as always
- shrimp and chive dumplings (4): delicious, really liked the flavors in this one, perfect proportion of shrimp and chive
- onion pancakes (2): meh. I've had much better, I would pass on these. Too much flour, not enough scallion/onion, chewy rather than crispy. 
- shrimp crepes (3): a little cold but still delicious. Wrapped in rice paper and steamed, cut for your convenience.
- beef crepes (3): also delicious, beef was well-seasoned
- shrimp balls (3): delicious and crispy and stuffed with shrimp 
- Shanghai meat dumplings (4): delicious. Juicy and served with the customary vinegar, I believe. 

Veggies aren't on the initial menu but they come around with the usual (Chinese spinach, Chinese broccoli, bakchoy, snow peas) as well as less usual (asparagus). We didn't pay the extra for it but it looked good!

Overall a very positive dim sum experience. :) Basically almost everything was delicious. (You probably noticed!) Would definitely come again!
author: Janice P.

description:
I always have this on my list of places to hit when I'm on vacay in San Fran.  The food is excellent and way better than anything we can get in Hawaii.  

As for the dim sum menu, the must haves are: 
stuffed crab claw
shrimp stuffed mushrooms
siu mai (pork dumpling)
har gau (shrimp dumpling)

and for the grand finale: egg custard rice cakes!!  (they didn't come around with this so you should ask for it if you don't see it)
author: Nat N.

description: I got takeout, so I can't speak for the restaurant service, but the food is delicious! I'm used to less spicy chinese food at my local favorite, but the spiciness was a nice change
author: Emily B.

description:
We were sat pretty quickly on a Sunday around noon. The service of dim sum is traditional in a sense that the servers bring around the plates and you signal to receive the one's you want. 

Quality of the dim sum is decent compared to other places I've tried. I think it's a bit pricey for my taste. My favorite plate I tried was the shu mai dumplings and the fried shrimp balls. 

One of my friends love going to this place because they serve dim sum all day. So if you have some spontaneous cravings for dim sum...come here and consider it satiated.
author: Vincent L.

description:
This place used to have lines out the door from when I remembered growing up in the area.  Being ethnic Chinese in the area, we mostly ended up frequenting other dim sum places local to the area because the wait used to be insane at Ton Kiang.  Well...we decided to finally come by here on a whim a few weeks ago on a Saturday morning/afternoon. The biggest thing that stood out was its clientele.  You have two dim sum restaurants right beside eachother, and you can see a distinct difference in the patrons between the two restaurants, even though they're essentially serving the same fare.

Ok, I'm going to come right out and say it, and then I'm likely going to regret it as soon as I hit "Post" on this review.  Ton Kiang caters to a predominantly large non-Asian clientele, whereas all the Chinese are going to the dim sum place right next door.  This isn't a slam against the food, but I think it's largely due to how this restaurant has been marketed thanks to Zagat and Frommer's and newspaper reviews and whatnot.  The light and bright decor and restaurant design is also atypical of your usual dim sum joint, so I'm pretty positive the restaurant itself coupled with good marketing is what is driving its predominantly non-Asian clientele.  I mean...for once...I'm pretty positive our little table of asians was outnumbered by the number of non-asians in a Chinese restaurant.  (My aunt, who lives a few blocks from this place, said all the asians were next door.)  

Ok...before this review goes any further downhill and I get clobbered for seeming racist, let's get to the food.  The food was ok!  Selection was decent.  The restaurant is prepared for those unfamiliar with dim sum, so it has a pictorial menu to assist.  The dim sum wasn't large by any means, but it was still tasty.  The food is reliable, prices are ok (although you'll find cheaper dim sum elsewhere), and the service was good.  The restaurant is also quieter, so if you want to avoid the loud aggressive Cantonese banter in typical Chinese restaurants, this place will be less of an assault upon your ears.
author: Viva C.

description: This is my absolute favorite place to go for dim sum. All the dim sum is soooo delicious. The location is perfect, there is plenty of parking on the street. Usually easy to find a spot. It's a 2 story restaurant so there's plenty of seating. You have to go on a weekend day when they are serving dim sum with the push carts and trays. It's much quicker and you get to see everything being served where as with menu ordering during the week, you don't have a visual. Only hang up they have is they do not like to be asked for forks. I asked for a fork for my little one and the server huffed and puffed the whole time. Really??? Just bring the damn fork. No big deal. Sheesh. When busy it's a little hard to get a drink but eventually it comes along. Other than those minor set backs it's a great dim sum place to visit. Everyone is nice and attentive for the most part. Must try!!
author: Melissa R.

description:
I met friends here for a Saturday post-Thanksgiving dim sum breakfast. 

We were worried that the lines would be out the door, but were assured that for a party of three, no reservation would be needed at around 10 am. Sure enough, we walked right in and were seated immediately. (An hour or so later, the place was totally packed, so I guess our timing was auspicious!)

Having had some of the best dim sum that Los Angeles has to offer, I have to admit that Ton Kiang leaves them all in the dust. 

I mean, the sheer quality and variety of the food can't be topped. Everything was delicious. 

A week later, here's my recollection of the dishes we liked best:
- Pea shoots, simple and garlicky
- Scallop and shrimp dumplings
- Lotus-leaf-wrapped rice parcels
- Rice noodle rolls filled with shrimp
- Salt-and-pepper shrimp, deep fried with their heads and tails still on (crunchy!)
- Succulent roast duck
- Sweet buns filled with condensed milk
- Mango pudding
.... and several more items. 

There were three of us, and the per-person total was only around $30. What a deal! 

If only LA dim sum were quite so dependable. 

Note on parking: I didn't find any free parking, though if you're patient enough, I'm sure you can. Instead, I parked at a metered spot, and had to keep running out and feeding the darn thing $2/ hour (thankfully, Ton Kiang was nice enough to change as many dollars as I could hand over to them; clearly, giving customers change for parking was a regular courtesy).
author: Suzie Q.

description:
WHAT? What was that you say... Dim Sum served in the evening??! GET THE HECK OUTTA HERE! 

But I did not stutter and it was good too! Shrimp Balls, Sui Mai, BBQ Pork Buns, Sesame Balls, Potstickers, Har Gow, Shaomai all of it good but you will have to ask for sweet and sour sauce for like MORE of it. They also serve beer and wine as well. 

Service was fine

Respectfully Reviewed
author: Pam S.

description:
Lovely Surprise..
All the dim sum was very authentic.. had a wonderful meal w friendly waitress. 
Good service 
Good food
author: j b.

description: Excellent flavors in the food. Shared 7 dishes with friends, all very good. Great prices and wait staff. $10 corkage fee, best in town. Not just for dim sum. Not to be missed. Great health score.
author: Robin V.

description:
This place is decent, but not the best. They really cater to more of an americanized taste. The ambiance inside is nicer than your average hole in the wall dim sum spot...but if you want the real deal chinese dim sum dishes I wouldn't necessarily pick this spot. They have the standards...steamed noodle roll dishes and the regular dumplings which aren't bad at all. But when we went, I was looking for the chicken feet, the tripes, the pineapple buns, etc...and all that kept coming to our table was tray after tray of eggrolls that we kept having to wave away. I have never desired to eat eggrolls in my life for dim sum...but hey if that's what your other customers like..then whatevs. But that poor waitress offering the eggrolls...she made a lot of rounds only to be turned away with every attempt. That's not to say they don't have other offerings...maybe they did and they just never came around or maybe they just didn't have them that day. But compared to other places, the selection here was not as abundant, nor did they frequently come around to offer stuff like they would compared to other dim sum spots I've been to. We felt like we were waiting a lot for specific dishes that never came out or that they didn't even have. On the plus side, there was no wait time on a Saturday for lunch so at least we didn't have to wait around for an hour to be seated. The service was friendly, too, so I'll give them that.

With so many other options in the area, I probably wouldn't frequent this joint again given the types of dishes I look for in a dim sum experience. But for others who aren't that adventurous and are just looking for some standard choices, it's ok.
author: Melissa C.

description: Definitely more of an authentic vibe then the ones in China Town. We came a little early, but they let us in anyways. The food was great and the servers were very friendly.
author: Lindsey K.

description: Yes of course this place is open on Easter. There was no line at 11am so we thought we beat the crowd. The moment we peered inside, we knew we were screwed. There was not an Asian person in sight and of course if the place is legit then the Asians will be all over it. We felt so out of place and thought we were in an alternate universe. I think this is geared more toward a white crowd as it was all white. The portions were small and it wasnt as jam packed with MSG so it was definitely not as Asian as it could be. It is straight up Americanized up here and when my friend spoke Canto, I think the waiters were confused since they are so used to speaking English..I derno. I was just looking around the room for days trying to figure out how this place has over 1k reviews. There is an upstairs but I didnt see that area. There are no pushy carts but people walk around with dishes. The ones that threw me off were the green onion pancake, potstickers, cucumber slices, and the friggin fruit salad. I knew I was screwed then. Well we got the basic dishes like shrimp dumpling, noodles, pineapple custard bun and the usual. Nothing stood out as being good. I did like the pea sprouts but meh I wont be coming back here even though there was no wait. I will gladly take the Hong Kong lounge wait for the better quality and experience.
author: Amy H.

description: Love this place! Amazing dim sum and a nice environment! The sesame balls, and egg custards are awesome for desert
author: Kli M.

description:
Positives:
-Serve Dim Sum all day
-Dim Sum is pretty good but nothing really special
-Restaurant is cleaner than most Chinese restaurants

Negatives:
-Not as many Dim Sum dishes offered as I've seen in other Chinese restaurants
-Price is slightly more than most Chinese restaurants
author: Rose A.

description:
3.5 stars.

I know it's telling when more than half of the patrons are not Asian.  However, Ton Kiang serves decent dim sum ALL DAY!  That's all I care about.  Where else will you go when you're craving for shrimp dumplings at 7pm?

Prices are definitely higher than average.  I once had the $38 special where you can choose any 9 plates of dim sum.  That comes out to over $4 for a basket of four pieces of dim sum when you can get shrimp dumplings for less than 50 cents a piece elsewhere.  But when options are scarce, people get desperate.  Plus, the food isn't bad; I enjoyed my meals here.
author: Vivian H.

description: Haven't been to this restaurant for a while , almost impossible to get a parking space ,however we were lucky last night and got a parking space right in the front ! Its our lucky night . Walked into the restaurant around 6pm , not even busy , told the waiter table for 5 , took them a minute before the three of them to decide which table to give us . Sat us down , we were all ready to order , the waiters were too busy to clean tables than to take our order , had to waved one down to come to take our order . WE ordered the usual Hakka Cuisine  , salt baked chicken , preserved vegetable with steam pork , steamed tofu with shrimp and a vegetable dish . There signature chicken dish was a real disappointment ! The meat was dry and rough , the steam pork was not even tender ! Wow ! I remember back in the days , I came over to the Richmond to this restaurant just to have these two dishes ! Hakka restaurant , how can you mess up on these two signature dishes ? By the way , I am Hakka myself so these two dishes are like Turkey and Yams in our Thanksgiving dinner ! One thing I found out about this restaurant , we are the ONLY Asians in there !!!! That is not a good sign ! I guess things changes thru the years ! Wont be back for a long long time . Disappointing food , lousy service and a lot of restaurant choices ! I have to say the only person who give us good service , keeping our water filled and keeping our teapot fill with hot water was this Hispanic gentleman , service with a smile and very efficient . Could not say much to the rest of the crew !!!
author: Eric C.

description: I'm pleasantly surprised at the vegetarian dim sum choices they have - vegetarian egg rolls, dumplings and crepes (or rice noodle) and they are delicious! Filled with mushrooms, and vegetables. It would have been a 5 star but I found lard in a peas sprouts dish. I'd also love to see more healthy options in the future.
author: Carl E.

description: First visit for me and wife. Sunday about 2 pm. Seated quickly. We had a number of dishes all well prepared. Prices were reasonable. Would return
author: Guy R.

description:
Maybe I'm a glutton for punishment, but I've never been here for dim sum, so I thought I'd try it.  Most of the reviews are true.  They don't have much of a selection.  And their dim sum is on the pricier side.

We were seated upstairs right by a partition in the front and I have to say that's probably the worse table to sit at.  About half of the people walking around with dim sum trays skipped our table, made their way round the floor and then headed downstairs.  Plus I was starving when I got here and the only things they kept bringing out at first was the fried food.  What happened to har gow and sui mai?!  I think eventually I had to ask for it since I never saw it.

Maybe if you're looking for an intro to dim sum this may be a good place to go since hey don't have a huge selection so you won't be overwhelmed, but for this Chinese girl that grew up on dim sum, I need more!
author: Elena N.

description:
Love this place! A family staple for years. We love sitting upstairs by the big window and enjoying dim sum while looking out at the street. Service is great here- they really want to make you happy so if you don't see what you want all you have to do is ask for it which is great. The variety is good here too, I've tried many new things. Must-orders are chive dumplings, Chinese broccoli, and har gow. Prices are reasonable as well.

Popular on weekends and a bit of a wait for a table. Parking can also be tricky.
author: Alyssa J.

description:
DONT GO HERE!!!! 

If I could. I'd give this place 0 stars. So I was on my trip to SF and I made it a mission, dim sum on Sunday! Unfortunately we all know how hard parking is when it's Sunday and you're trying to park in Chinatown. So I looked up multiple restaurants, decided to give this place a try. WORST DECISION! So we got lucky found parking on the street from across the church. Walked over and was seated fairly quickly. The food is mediocre, I've had way better where I'm from (Hawaii). I was hoping to see some carts but it's fine they all go around with trays and put them down. Similar but not that usual carts with all the steamers in em. ANYWAYS back to my experience. First off my gf wanted tea so we got her tea. I didn't touch it (but I still got charged -_-)
The dim sum like I said was okay. Then I needed water. They did not bring me or my gf any water! I had to ask for it at least 10x (literally no exaggeration) 
THIS IS WHAT PISSED ME OFF!!!
So I asked the lady for water, she said okay. I got nothing. I brush it off. Then I ask another waitress who tells the same lady and she looks at me. STILL NOTHING. 4 other parties come in and they all get water. Okay now I'm fricken pissed! 20 minutes later and asking pretty much the whole staff. I finally get some damn water. And mind you it's a tiny glass -_- I like how they judged me based on my appearance and did not even care to pay any attention to our table. THANKS! And you know what took the cake. When it came time to pay and get the check. The check came I put down my card, not even a minute after, the lady is more than willing to come by and run my credit card. Un-freakin-believable! The only saving grace this restaurant had, the guy that came by (looks like he just started his shift), was super polite and very attentive. Where da heck was he during my whole visit?! NEVER coming here again. Lesson learned.
author: Jenn L.

description: Way overpriced, it was 35 a person for dim sum, that's beyond crazy on the bill. Food was okay, but no way worth that
author: Angus M.

description:
Plenty of food....but almost everything that cane our way had seafood in it. I felt like I was in the film Forest Gump...Mostly shrimp. Shrimp stuffed crab claws, shrimp dumplings, shrimp and scallions, shrimp and snow peas....you get the idea....not a whole lot more. Oh wait,  I forgot about the shrimp tempura with the shell still on!! SHELL....STILL...ON! Ew. Tea was great, as was service but there was just not many options, plus, this place was old and kinda dirty. 
Food, 2 stars
Service and tea 3 stars.
author: Christina M.

description: Good food served 'family style.' A bit cramped and busy, but family-owned so why not. Loved the sweet lemon chicken and mango pudding dessert with coconut milk on top.
author: Callie C.

description:
A great dim sum place, if you don't mind spending a lot of money. This place has been a fixture for years. I come here often. The dim sum is good. The noise is quite loud, but not as loud as some Chinese restaurants.

My favorites are the sesame ball, shrimp dumpling and dim sum duck.

Metered parking out front is available. I often have to circle a few times but it's not as bad as some places in the city.

Staff are attentive and polite for the most part.

Food is always consistent but as I said, not the cheapest.
author: Emily C.

description:
This place really disappointed me. It was one of the best dim sum places in the city about five years ago, and every time I've been there in the last two years, the food quality has been low. I ordered baked pork buns, and they came doughy and raw 15 minutes after the rest of my meal. The sesame balls came chewy, as if they'd been sitting out for hours. The shumai are big and rubbery. The XLB have thick skin, too much meat, and no soup to speak of. I used to go here a lot and I really wanted to keep liking it, but the food quality is inconsistent at best, and just bad at worst. 

Meanwhile, it's also more expensive than a lot of dim sum. The price combined with the decline in food quality makes this place no longer worth my time.

The most recent time I went, I went by myself when I asked for the check, they told me I hadn't met the $15 MINIMUM BILL requirement. Not minimum for credit--minimum for BILL! I wanted to leave but was forced to order something else, which then took another twenty minutes. There was no information about minimum bill when I was ordering, and I didn't find out that I hadn't met it until AFTER I asked for the check (and really wanted to leave because the food was so bad). 

There really are better dim sum places.
author: Allxie C.

description: Family friendly restaurant. Nice big tables and friendly service. I've never actually had their dim sum b/c we usually go for dinner, but the food is very good. Oh, get the potstickers. They come with this green chili sauce that I like to add to the wonton soup. The Chinese sausage fried rice and bbq pork chow mein are part of our usual order as well. Plates are around $10 each so it adds up fast, but the serving sizes are large.
author: Hanster P.

description:
The dim sum here is overall pretty legit, but they are too stingy.  Who substitutes finely chopped carrot for the roe atop siu mai?!!  Also, the portions are TINY!  I don't like HK Lounge but Ton Kiang's har gow and siu mai are 2/3 the size of those at HK Lounge!  Moreover the steamed pork dumpling that was described to us as xiao long bao lacked even the slightest amount of soup -- it's all a lie!  To my disappointment, the scallop dumpling did not have much seafood flavor and was kind of bland.  The tofu skin roll and BBQ pork buns were both good.  We also tried the pea shoots (kong jing tzai as I know it in Mandarin) and it was sauteed with garlic and lightly seasoned.  Decent, but my grandma's is better.  

Our bill came out to $38 for 7 dishes before tip - pretty pricey.  And the service was poor - the servers were not friendly and acted like we were a nuisance when we asked to have the tofu skin rolls cut in half.  Uhh you do realize that most dim sum places cut those without the customer asking right??!?  

Overall, Ton Kiang's execution is pretty good, but their lousy attitude and small portions for a big price will keep me from returning.
author: Beatrice W.

description: Food was good , one of the lobsters balls was not good at all wasn't cook but other then that is was fine . They kinda rush you Our the door especially family with kids .
author: Lili L.

description: REALLY DO NOT RECOMMAND CHINESE TO COME!   the service is so bad.  we keep asking them for some dishes, but they just passed by and did not reply to us.   Also,  the food is not good for Chinese people！！ it is made for Americans, everything tastes so non-tranditional!    it did not have 流沙包  榴莲酥  ，连黑醋都没有！
author: Jie W.

description:
Come here if you hate authenticity and/or have a similar palate for dimsum as do all the orange-chicken-adoring non-asians that fill the restaurant (in the middle of asian-capital-richmond).

No intestines of any kind on the dimsum menu.

I got neck cramps from turning my head too many times trying to get some of their terrible service.

I'm really curious about the stoned fucker who recommended this place for dimsum on the 7x7 list.
author: Tian Q.

description:
Ton Kiang is one of my favorite places to have dim sum in San Francisco. It's relatively quick and has good dim sum, and the line is pretty manageable before 10:30 a.m.

For dim sum, I always get my normal items - turnip cake, sticky rice in lotus leaf and the shrimp in rice noodles which are all good. But Ton Kiang has some great non-traditional dim sum items like the garlic pea shoots (I rarely get vegetables at dim sum but these are awesome) and the fried calamari.

I also like the fact that you can order dim sum for dinner - most people don't want dim sum at night but in case you do, you have the option. I've had dinner here a number of times, and it's pretty good. My favorite is the crispy noodles which you can also get for lunch.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Been here a couple of times for lunch this year.

Only been sat upstairs which is their Siberia - quiet and roomy compared to the main event downstairs.

Generally friendly service.  Decor non-existent other than mid-70's pastiche.  Street parking usually ok within a few blocks.

I'm not enough of a dim sum aficionado to render food quality judgement but will say we've enjoyed pretty much everything that is presented.  The carts come fast and frequent, unrelenting.  Be prepared to firmly wave-off until you're ready to consider next choices otherwise you'll feel like you're in the dining equivalent of a 100-yd sprint.

Figure you'll pay about a third less than Yank Sing.
author: David P.

description:
I honestly only chose to come here because of its proximity to where I live, and the fact that its open late on Sundays. Aside from that I don't think I would return here for dim sum. 

My boyfriend and I ordered 5 things: 

1. Stuffed eggplant:  Excessively oily and over cooked. The skin was so hard and crunchy it was inedible and the flesh was like apple sauce.

2. Shrimp rice roll:  It was OK. The noodle wasn't soft, in fact it was a bit on the hard side and shrimp weren't particularly impressive.

3. Fried Rice dumplings with pork inside:  These fried football things are my FAVORITE things to get at dim sum, and the ones I got from here were a letdown. 

4. Siu mai: These were actually decent, probably the only thing I would consider ordering again.

5. Steamed Pork baos:  Texture of the dough was nice, and the bbq pork filling was ok..


If you find yourself absolutely CRAVING dim sum and its Sunday night and everywhere else is close and this is literally the only thing thats excessively convenient to satisfy your craving, then sure...stop by. If Not, then I would definitely say Keep On Yelping! You're bound to find something better
author: Katie 2.

description: The only negative I can think of is the hunt for parking and that is out of their control. We had a wonderful late lunch there last Saturday. I stress the word late because most other places serving decent dim sum would have been closed by the time we got there. Service was great, food great, prices not so great, but you get what you pay for.
author: Stan B.

description: Had a small sample of the dim sum and wasn't totally blown away. The pork buns were decent, the crab claws not so much, short ribs were cold and rubbery, pot stickers ok. I will say the service was excellent and professional. It was actually very quiet and not loud and bustling like other dim sum places. Not sure I would come running back without exploring all of other amazing places in the city.
author: Trish P.

description:
I've been coming here off and on for the past 20 years or so - usually when my parents come into town as this has been my dad's favorite restaurant for some time.  A few years ago I would have rated it a solid 4 stars, but my last few visits have been inconsistent.  Dim sum continues to be their strong suit, with a fine variety of offerings that go beyond the standard fare that you find in wannabe dim sum restaurants.  The food off their regular menu, however, is hit-or-miss.  Dishes can be heavily sauced to the point that native flavors are masked.  I used to love their clay pot dishes but the last seafood clay pot had mostly vegetables and some overcooked pieces of squid and shrimp.  In general, however, their seafood options are better than the meat and poultry.

You'll come away feeling satisfied here.  It is still better than average (I'd like an option to give 3.5 stars), but I'll be more selective about my entree choices in the future.
author: Lee L.

description:
Nothing super unusual/pretty much the standard fare, but VERY well done!  Everything we had tasted fresh, nothing was excessively greasy, and the price was reasonable.  

Some highlights: 
- the chili fried squid
- the pea shoots with ginger (YUM)
- the scallop and shrimp ha gao
- shrimp cheung fan
- roast duck
- congee

Like I said, it wasn't *blow your socks off* great, and nothing was really out of the ordinary...but you know what?  If the "ordinary" is done really well, that's fine with me!
author: Susannah H.

description:
I really liked this place! I came here for dimsum with a large party and almost everyone seemed to enjoy what we had. The Shanghai style Xiao Long Bao was probably my favorite thing. They didn't overdo it on the ginger or make the wrapper too thick, so it came out really good. 

Service was speedy and friendly, the place was clean, and the prices were very fair. 

The desserts were noteworthy, in my opinion, as they were served fresh like I have never had them before. The sesame balls and egg custard tarts were actually warm and tasted as though they were just made. This especially surprised me because I had NEVER tasted these things warm before. (After consulting my Chinese friends, these are supposed to be warm and fresh!) Because of this I am going to say that Ton Kiang is the first place that has given me really GOOD Chinese desserts, and for that I have to give them my highest praise. Thanks, Ton Kiang!
author: Stephen D.

description: As much as I wanted to dislike this tourist trap...  The food was actually okay.   I wouldn't say it's my favorite by far - but if you have friends who are vegetarian in the group, this place does accommodate their needs as well - which most dim sum places don't.
author: Edgar C.

description:
Where do I start with this place?  

Bringing it back old school, grade school to be more specific, TOPIC SENTENCE: Ton Kiang wasn't my cup of tea.    

A tell tale sign of what you're going to get from a restaurant is certainly defined by their clientele.  The majority I noticed were non Asian folks.  Throwing out the obvious, "nothing wrong with that, but...," the disappointment on my visit to Ton Kiang left me with major buyer's remorse.  I'm not saying it wasn't good for that reason.  Establishments such as Yank Sing cater toward more a non-Asian market, yet provide a slightly more than delectable selection of dim sum.  My only qualm with Yank Sing is the identity per se.  Ton Kiang attempts at the same appeal but misses its mark like a blind folded archer who hasn't ever shot an arrow before.       

At this point in juncture, I would run down highlights of what we ate.  That is, if there really was.  Burn... Most of the food was very plain.  Lacking quality, the portion size which usually compensates didn't.  Since much of the same dim sum was brought out over and over, "sesame balls? sesame balls? sesame balls?" (Multiply that 2 second loop to what seemed 1,000 times), freshness took a big hit.  I felt bad for the unknowing guy that ended up with them.  He just came in and wanted some sesame balls.  Just didn't know...  

There were a couple things that are worth mentioning.  In a semi-desperate move due to hunger, took the fried calamari.  While greasy, It was the best of the meal.  Other positive traits were the service.  They were accommodating to the customer and friendly as well.  

I see handfuls of people coming here still.  I don't really get it.  Am I the crazy one?  Is there something great I'm missing?  I doubt it.  I rather wait a year in line at Hong Kong Lounge than come back here.  Over the course of time, did authenticity slowly wane in turn deteriorate quality?  I can't really give a fair assessment on that since my other visit was too far in the past.  My guess presently is Ton Kiang wasn't that good in the first place.
author: Arnold T.

description: WARNING....These guys are FRAUDS!!!  After eating Dim Sum here with friends this past Sunday (the Dim Sum was just alright, nothing to write home about), we finished and payed.  The server then apparently swiped our credit card #s and used them over the past 3 days to rack up over $200 in Lyft rides and other shopping sprees.  Fraud Protection said they probably took pictures of our cards to steal the info.  Lunch-goers be warned!
author: Paul M.

description:
Ton Kiang was my neighborhood Chinese rest for many years, many years ago. I even remember ( fondly) the store that was much further down near Geary & Spruce. Vegetarian dumplings pretty good but it went downhill fast from there. We ordered off the menu and it was all pretty disgusting, greasy oily food. The worst was the whole steamed sea bass that tasted like mud.  Yuk. 

Maybe the better strategy is to stick with dim sum, or skip it altogether- which for me is a trek so that is my option and the parking was horrible.
author: Jeff D.

description: Getting decent dim sum at night is like trying to pick up a drunk girl at a bar at 11 AM - the pickings are likely to be slim, the quality dubious. Ton Kiang is one of the rare places that can satisfy my 9 PM pork sui mai cravings. While the dim sum itself is of the 3.5 star variety, the nice atmosphere and crazy cheap prices (my last meal was $13 per person) push it easily into 5 star territory. I'm newly single, so if you're the type of gal who likes evening dim sum - or getting wasted and making bad decisions before noon - don't hesitate to PM me.
author: Nick C.

description:
Ton Kiang is really hit-or-miss for me, and it seems to be the same for most others on Yelp. I think the quality and service has really gone downhill the last year or so, and it's gotten to the point that we're just going to stop going. 

The dim sum is really a mixed bag, and while I've sometimes had great items, most of the time the dim sum does not taste fresh and the wrappers are sticky and hard from over-steaming or sitting out to long, or being frozen. 

The highlights are the little dish of pickled vegetables they give you when you sit down, the green beans, and the whole roasted chicken. The low-lights are the noodle dishes, the "classic" americanized Chinese items, and the service; it's been slow and forgetful and the tables were not clean the last 3 times we went.

Once great, with the potential to be so again, Ton Kiang is suffering from a lack of care from the staff and kitchen, and the price vs. quality ratio just isn't worth it anymore.
author: Laura J.

description:
No. Walk away. Eating here might be a health hazard during less busy times. The food they circulate has clearly been rejected and reheated many times, resulting in dried-out chicken wings, foil-wrapped chicken that had gone bad (one piece of three tasted really sour and off -- it wasn't the "sauce" like the manager insisted), and the worst sin of all: shanghai dragon dumplings with NO SOUP. But around the bottoms, whiter, bloated regions in the dumpling skin indicating that there was soup once upon a time, but it had already been absorbed into the skin. 

Oh yeah: and there were about 10-15 tables of diners and besides me, NOT A SINGLE ASIAN. That should be your red flag: go to Hong Kong Lounge or any other place. This is NOT the best dim sum in San Francisco by any measure.
author: Diane Y.

description:
When we asked for the best dim sum in SF's Chinatown, we got way too many answers so we settled on this place, and my friend's Chinese Mom gave it a big thumbs up. She even ordered something to go for dinner so you know, it's legit.

All the basic dim sum selections with a pretty mean chicken foot that was a bit spicier than what we're normally used to but it was good.

The place is tiny so they don't use carts but have the poor waitresses carry around the dim sum which is why I'm docking a star. I like my dim sum piping hot coming from a cart; there's something comforting about it. 

Otherwise, good food, better prices, and you're seated right away. What's not to like?
author: Cecilia D.

description: Ton Kiang is the best Chinese Restaurant we've tried in the Bay Area! Dim Sum is excellent, everything is great too! Food is tasty, authentic, fragrant and delicious, and it isn't too salty or oily. The house cookies served are a bonus and a pleasant surprise too! We totally loved this place and will be back for more Dim Sum!! Only wish to find this place earlier! Haha. No wonder it is said that Richmond is the real "Chinatown"!
author: Christina T.

description:
We attended a memorial service banquet here yesterday, our second time in the last year and a half.  Overall, a good, competent, but perhaps not spectacular experience.  Our group of about 50, all Asian-Americans of various persuasions except for little moi, was accommodated at six adjacent round tables upstairs, each with a lazy Susan.  Dishes, in order of appearance, included:

Tea
Crisp roast pork.
Squab.  (This was something I hadn't tried before, dark, beef- or ostrich-like--I wouldn't have thought squab until someone pointed out the, er, head on the platter.
Mixed seafood and egg flower soup..
Ginger chicken.  (Another head to stare down.)
Whole lobster in a garlic butter sauce.  The lobster meat seemed a bit dry, and seemed insufficiently integrated with the sauce.
Bok choy and mushrooms.  Bok choy, however tender, is perhaps a bit difficult to deal with without a knife.
Peking duck, with excellent fluffy buns, but Julienne cucumber slices instead of the traditional onion brushes.
Sea bass.  Star of the show, in a lovely sauce.  When I get back here, this will be my entrée order.
Seafood fried rice, served only at the end of the meal.
Mango pudding; very nice, with crunchy chunks of fresh, tart  mango, and a light  cream topping.

Service (a single waiter for all the tables) was competent and unobtrusive; replacement plates just materialized as needed, and leftovers from the lazy Susan were moved to smaller plates as needed to make more room.

Liquor menu was a very limited wine and beer selection.  Best beer option, perhaps Singha, from Thailand.

Parking--well, this is the Richmond:  scarce, and guarded by ferocious parking enforcement officers.  If you can possibly get here by public transportation, do so.
author: Alan F.

description: Fantastic dim sum, lots of parking, and staff is friendlier than most dim sum restaurants I've been to.
author: Alyssa H.

description: I have been coming here for over 15 years.  The quality of their food has really dropped off.  We ordered dim sum (ok) the salt & pepper shrimp (not good) and the orange chicken (awful).  Won't be coming here again.
author: Ceejars J.

description:
Probably my favorite outside of Hong Kong  

Steamed and baked bbq buns are great, bbq pork blankets, green beans and asparagus are great, and the egg yolk steam bun is an amazing finish. 

Always a great meal, very consistent, high quality.
author: Boaz N.

description:
We always come here for Dim-Sum, it's tasty and fresh. 
Join them especially during the week, it's not busy and food serves at its best.
I personally recommend their fried rice and seafood.
author: Ray D.

description:
Simple decor and big space, two floors. Food is very yummy, waiters can be a lil pushy. Water and hot sauce seem not to be the way they roll. After 5 times asking we had success! 
Note: the sauces come in very small bowls; if you have some pig-like specifications in your genes, beware. :-)
author: Styn V.

description:
Was there yesterday with 3 others.  This place used to be good but has gone downhill fast.  The place is not clean, fruit flies all over your food.  Waitresses  kept coming by our table with Dim Sum to sell but we wanted to order off of the menu.  Took forever to get someone to take our order.
One of our group ordered a prawn dish and she got nothing but cheap, white fish----not one prawn.  Greasy was the word for the day for each of our entrees.

Never going back.
author: Peter F.

description: Good dim sum and went pretty early on a Sunday am.  Food is good but not as good as Yang Sing granted much better price.  Service was friendly and a fun experience.  I will go back.
author: mike s.

description:
We were supposed to eat at a restaurant across the street, but they weren't open, despite me making a reservation there the afternoon before. Hmm....

In search of an alternative restaurant and the discovery of the perfect parking place on Geary led us to Ton Kiang.  I've been there a couple of times previously, and figured ti was as good a place as any.

Fortunately, all five of us came with a tremendous appetite and the carts kept coming and coming.  Favorites included the potstickers - loved the wrapping, the tofu skin rolls - so delicious, taro  (a little greasy as were the crab claws), har gao, and my group also went nuts for both steamed and baked pork buns. 

The only real fail was the soup dumpling, which contained no soup, leading me to believe it might've been sitting around a while, which another reviewer mentioned.

We got about ten other items, but I won't bore you with the details.  Service was pleasant, water and tea refilled frequently.  I think the bill was around $115, which isn't bad for five very hungry people constantly eating for around an hour.
author: .Hon H.

description: Great Dim Sum in SF. Small place but very cozy. Servers were very attentive. They bring out the small dishes to your tables. Good variety. Portions were perfect bite size. Quality was very fresh, especially the steamed dumplings. Prices were very decent for SF too.
author: Heather L.

description:
If this is what is called "the best dim sum in all of SF" by the SF Weekly, then it certainly doesn't speak much about dim sum in SF. The food here was consistently average at best. The portions were small much like dim sum in Hong Kong (but this is America). The "Pu Er" tea was tasteless but a tad better than a packaged Lipton tea. And $64 for two people (9 dishes and a salted fish fried rice) is really breaking the bank by dim sum standards.

Siu Mai - Tasted like an over-steamed pork ball (at the very least it was warm); however, it just does not taste like a bundle of juicy spare ribs.

Har Gow - I must say this was probably their best dish. The shrimp was steamed right and had the right crisp and neither did the skin rip apart.

Shrimp Chang Fun - The noodle was just not fresh and neither did it have the chewiness that I was accustomed to eating. It was pretty much confirmed once the cover was lifted off that this dish was going to be an utter failure.

Fu Pei Juen - I love eating meat but I'm accustomed to eating this dish stuffed along with mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and wood-ear (mu-er). This dish was just the cousin version of the Siu-Mai but wrapped in tofu skin. 

Deep-Fried Salt and Pepper Shrimp - Tasted like shrimp deep-fried from the night before. It was literally served cold. The shrimp was a bizarre combination of mushiness and dryness. Even if it was not deep fried the night before, serving a deep fried dish thirty to forty-five min after is just going to taste like crap.

Salted fish and chicken fried rice - This dish was average. It wasn't bad neither was it good. The presence of salted fish can improve this dish a lot; however, they were diced into tiny pieces and were very much hard to taste. So they were pretty much missing the uniqueness of the dish (salted fish).

As for the other dishes that we ordered, they were decent and average.

I'm pretty sure there are some better dim sum places in SF, but it is difficult to fathom the attention that this establishment was garnering (SF Weekly, Zagat, Travel & Leisure). And I want to add that should anyone make their way out to LA, please be sure to try Lunasia, Elite, and/or Sea Harbor in the San Gabriel Valley area.
author: Eddy T.

description:
why would a person from the east bay go across the bridge, through most of san francisco and end up at the outter richmond? TON KIANG!

true there are many worthwhile restaurants serving up all sorts of deliciousness but if you are craving DIM SUM then you would make the trek too. i still haven't perfected my timing, there are days when i go and the place is packed with a long line in the front and then there are days when i have no problems getting seated as i walk through the door.

to some folks it's not DIM SUM without the carts and i must agree i do miss them. then again there are other places where they make you order it. this place makes a good compromise in that they come around in trays :) see something you like- go on and ask for some. they keep a tab on your table. 

try the... heck try it all if you are adventurous enough. i'm still working my way through eating my way down the menu. however i do have my favorites, the pork sho mai, the shrimp dumplings are DIM SUM musts. it's like appetizers just to get you started. then make your way to the steamed buns, calamari, eggplant stuffed shrimp, and crab claws.
they also have this awesome rice with mushrooms/pork wrapped in leaves. i didn't try it until recently and now i add it to my usual list which is slowly growing. although no matter what and however many different plates i get i always end with the sesame seed balls. that's my sweet treat to complete the meal.

until next time

cheers
author: Jerico P.

description: So yummy and kid friendly. Went w my aunt mom and baby on a Sunday around 11am got seated right away upstairs great selection of items veggie and meat. The steamed chicken dumplings, potstickers and congee were my fav. My baby also loved the congee
author: Jiemei G.

description:
I've been here both for dim sum and for dinner. 'What's the difference?' you ask. Well, dim sum can be best described as bite-sized portions of delectably savory food served in baskets/steamers. What makes dim sum unique is the way it is carted/carried around to all the tables, and you choose what you see before your eyes. Don't like the way a dumpling looks? Choose the basket next to it instead. 

The dim sum here is very reasonably priced. Now you can try everything. Score!

DIM SUM FAVORITES:
- Char siu bau - steamed fluffy white or baked golden-brown and filled with delicious, tender BBQ pork
- Har gow - steamed dumpling filled with shrimp, thin skin
- Siu Maai - steamed dumplings filled with pork and/or shrimp, slightly thicker wheat skin
- Lo Mai Gai - sticky rice wrapped in a lotus leaf and steamed with pork, chicken, egg, mushrooms
- Lo Baak Gou - pan-fried turnip cakes mixed with daikon radish
- Mango Pudding - one of my favorite desserts EVER (I've had this at various dim sum places, and this place gets it right)
- Egg Tart - flaky crust with egg custard filling
- Dou Fu Fa - very popular sweet soup of soft tofu (This may be an acquired taste item, but I recommend trying it for a taste. Maybe you'll like it!)

DINNER FAVORITES:
- Peking duck - This is served dipped in a special sauce that makes the crispy skin absolutely delicious. Typically this comes with white buns that you put the meat in along with some hoi sin sauce.
- Lobster - You get quite a large portion of quality lobster meat here. The lobster comes still shelled, but broken into manageable pieces. It is served in a buttery-garlic sauce. Mmmm... 

The peking duck, lobster, and 1-2 vegetable dishes are more than enough to fill up 5-6 people. 

TIP: This place gets packed and parking is tough (as always in the Richmond district), but it's worth the wait. Another option is arriving later for the dim sum (closer to 2-3 pm on weekends).

TIP 2: You can ask the waiters if you can order from a menu. They might be able to bring specific items to your table if you don't see the items in the circulating carts/trays. This has saved me many a time when I almost passed out from hunger!
author: Denise L.

description: This place just made my go-to list of places for dim sum in the city. I have been on a mission since I moved here to find the perfect spot and this is it. I think we got really lucky and were seated right away, but soon after there was a line out the door. Their selection has all the classics, plus a few things I have never had before. I also really appreciate the vegetable dishes that were being circled around to balance out all the dumplings. I used to only choose places with traditional carts, but this place is an exception. We ordered everything we wanted and just had tea and it was $70 for four people. It's also probably one of the cleanest dim sum places I have been to as well.
author: Sonia S.

description:
This place continues to slide down hill.   Went to give this place a try after a few years.   All this visit proves is that we will never return.

To all of you foodies that followed Martha Stewart, beware.  This place was way better before her visits and reviews.   Has become too commercial with very bland mass produced food.   Certainly not like it was in the early 90s.
author: V. R.

description: Will travel for Ton Kiang. Clean, prompt and courteous service, delicious fresh food & a level consistency that is hard to find. We are happy with the menu selections, as I've heard/read it's "mainstream," but we absolutely love eating here, as does my 5 year old son. The parking can be a pain, but it's worth it. Always recommending this place to friends and always looking forward to our next visit. We usually do two days in a row, as our out-of-town treat!
author: Julie M.

description:
A good experience. Dim sum is fun to eat because it all looks so amazingly well prepared and who knows what little treat you are going to find inside? They buzz by your table often with a wide range of delectables. I felt bad for the gals with the asparagus or the cucumber, though. Those seemed to be a no seller.

I would happily come back.
author: N'olo J.

description:
I've heard about this place for years, but it isn't a place I would go and check out on my own.  It just so happened that an out of town friend was visiting and she was craving dim sum and her friend recommended this place. Had she asked me, I would've suggested another place.
 
There were 13 of us who sat upstairs at this large table. That's fine, dim sum is often better with more people as you can try more items.  The dim sum came on trays versus little carts since the servers had to walk up a flight of stairs to bring the dim sum to folks on the 2nd floor.

The dim sum whether it be dumplings or egg custard tarts (dan tat) were tiny.  I wish I had taken a photo to prove it.  The turnip cake (lor bak goh) was edible, but nothing to rave about. They had these pretty fruit bowls, chicken salad and blanched asparagus that obviously geared towards "dim sum virgins" or perhaps tourist not familiar with traditional dim sum. 

I noticed that most of the servers spoke decent English and were able to tell the patrons what the item was. I suppose that's a good thing, but then it also tells you who their clientele they are catering to. 

Parking is metered parking on the streets.

I had extremely low expectations coming here and for valid reasons. The food was unimpressive and it just reiterates the reason why I never did want to come here in the first place.  With so many choices in the area and also in Chinatown, I would suggest that you go elsewhere to get better quality dim sum.

If you feel like having American Chinese food that serves mediocre miniaturized dim sum items, then this is your place.  If you are a "dim sum virgin" someone who has never experienced dim sum and asks, "What's that?" as each dish passes by, then perhaps this may be a good ice breaker.
author: Drea L.

description:
Best dim sum ever! 
We sat in da back corner foods always hit ours table first hot & fresh 
Steam chicken is Delicious too.  We will come back
author: jason t.

description: real deal dim sum. perfect hangover meal, and obviously dim sum is best if you go with a group. pork buns, sticky rice, soup dumplings, potstickers, all of it was fantastic, service was good, they ask you once if you want something, then they stop bugging you if you say no, but always checking in to see if you need anything else. and the price is surprisingly good when the damage is done.
author: Kevin B.

description:
I came here many times and my experience has been very different. The first time that I came here, it was about 5 years ago. Back then this place  was very popular because of their dim sum.  They always had a long line, esp, on the weekend.  But it's worth waiting... because it was really good. Since  then, I kept coming back for a number of times. 

  However, the last time that I was here. I was surprise that the line was pretty short and  furthermore the quality of their food. 


Don't get me wrong, it wasn't terrible or anything but I had a better dim sum here before and now it's just very average for me.
author: Dom G.

description: The food and service were great!  A bit abrupt at the entrance, we were invited to go upstairs and the whole experience shifted - open, airy and filled with the aromas of goodness headed our way.  The view of Geary is grand, allows us to see our car, parked in the spot we circled the block for several times.  The parking challenge is worth it!
author: Lindsay A.

description:
Wow I seriously don't understand why people keep labelling this place a "white people" joint, because the time I went, the second floor (where my party was seated) was innundated with this huge cantonese family who I can only presume were either celebrating someone's graduation or someone's marriage since there were about twenty of them there.

Anyway onto the real review... yes, the restaurant is expensive for a "dim-sum" restaurant, but the food here doesn't disappoint! Their har gow, siu mai, gao choy got, and my favorite cha siu bao were all excellent, and best of all, I actually burned my tongue eating the xiao long bao's they had here--a feat that hasn't been accomplished by the three other XLB specialty restaurants in the city.

Ton Kiang also  has a moderate selection of beer, alcohol, and tea from the motherland, and although I didn't even bother peeking at the "real menu" because all of the items on it were 12 dollars and up, it does also seem to have a wide array of non-yumcha dishes.

I had no idea that this restaurant was featured on FN or recommended by Martha Stewart or whatever, but think of this restaurant as one of those dim sum restaurants at the top floor of a department store/shopping complexes in Causeway Bay back in HK--they're expensive, yes, but you're getting what you pay for.
author: Scott S.

description:
We wanted to go to Hong Kong Lounge for dim sum, but the line was too long (an hour wait) so we went to Ton Kiang instead (no line and we were seated immediately). 

There's a reason why there was no line at Ton Kiang! I bet it is because of their foods on average are not very good and after our lunch, it is confirmed! I see it as a trade-off between bland dim sum without waiting for a table or good dim sum but waiting in long line. 

I was a little grumpy at first at Ton Kiang because their so-called dim sum menu only got 10 items on it, and it is by no means a regular dim sum menu! They got people carrying trays and walked around with foods and bothered us each time they walked by our table. Many of the items are the same. Foods don't taste good and doesn't seem fresh neither, and a very limited variety to choose from. I am disappointed at what they offer there. 

Pros: No waiting for a table. My boyfriend doesn't understand Chinese, and the people there are more English friendly because they call out dim sum names in English. It helps him in choosing what foods to order. Most of the dim sum restaurants call out dim sum names in Chinese, and it is hard to know what you are eating sometimes. 

Cons: average and bland dim sums. Prices are relatively higher than other dim sum restaurants that have better foods. So pricier and not-as-good dim sum is what you will get.  

Well, if you don't feel like waiting an hour (at least on weekends) for a table and still satisfied with average dim sum, give it a try. 

I'd rather wait a little and hope the line move quicker next time for a delicious dim sum lunch. Not worth going back to Ton Kiang for dim sum.
author: Lena H.

description:
We made reservations for x-mas day, confirmed twice, and when we arrived they could not find them. They then tried to seat our party of 12 at a table for 8. We ended up at 2 tables, one which was a table for 4, which ended up housing the 6 kids in our party.
