Food arrived in dribs and drabs, after having to chase after the waitress and 2 other waiters constantly. They never ordered our fried rice, and realized it after two hours.... 

Food was ok except for the sweet and sour chicken, which felt like all chicken fat and grease.

Of course, they added a 15% tip to our check... Definitely not coming back
author: M S.

description:
I have mixed feelings about Ton Kiang. I used to come here as a kid with my dad and so it holds some memories for me.  Food is good, if not great.  XLB are good, but are a bit too thick skinned for my taste.  The first order came without vinegar and I had to ask for it.  

I do like the bao here.  They are not too sweet.  I love bao but I think I like the dough and the pork better than the bbq part.  Chinese chicken salad was sickly sweet; I would not order this again.  We ordered a bunch of items, but they kept coming to offer us different items and we not good at making sure we got what we initially ordered.  We were here for a late lunch on a weekday, so it was more of an ordering experience than the typical dim sum cart experience. 

Bill was high for Dim Sum.  I will be back if I am in the area, but I don't think I'd go out of my way to eat here again.  There are better places.
author: Katharine A.

description:
I wish we could give half stars on yelp :( this place would be a three and half stars for me. The food is pretty hit and miss.

I thought the har gow and shrimp and chive dumplings were fantastic. The size of the dumplings are smaller than most dim sum places, which I personally prefer. The chive dumplings have a perfectly crispy skin, and the har gow skin was really nice and thin.

The vegetables (we got gai lan and snow peas) were also cooked pretty well. But besides that, I wasn't super impressed with the rest of the dishes. We tried the turnip cake, shrimp rice noodles, crispy calamari, and xiaolongbao. I didn't really feel like the xiaolongbao was soupy enough and I didn't really like the meat pieces in the turnip cake. Personally, I also thought it was a bit more mushy than I would like.
author: Jean J.

description:
I ventured to Ton Kiang to meet with friends who had made reservations.  There were 8 of us on a Saturday mid-morning.  We were all seated promptly and were met with very polite servers who brought us hot tea and cups.  Then the real fun began.  I had never had dim sum before, so was not sure what to expect.  My boyfriend is pescetarian, so he was really wary of trying anything, unless he could be assured there was no meat in the items. He was not disappointed.
 We started out having a dish of greens that had halved garlic cloves fully roasted.  It was phenomenal.  Next came green beans lightly seasoned which were also just fantastic.  So far, so good! By the time we left we had tried so many dishes that my head was spinning.  I probably looked drunk walking out of there; I was so full!  We loved it so much that the following weekend we dragged a friend with us just to visit again.  Both times we were not disappointed and are already looking forward to our next visit.
 I believe the prices are very reasonable.  For our second visit, for three people, we had so much food that they had to push another table to us and our bill was just over $100.  They mark the items you receive (when they are bringing items table to table) in categories of how  much each item costs.  So, for the entire meal you too can follow the bill and stop when you see the figure is reaching the point of no return.

 Food Hero Tip: Do not leave until you have had the egg custard buns.  SIT BACK DOWN!  Order those buns STAT.  Side note? They sell them to-go as well.  Yeah, there may have been about 6 of those bad boys in my car for indulging later.  :)
author: Melissa T.

description: Consistently amazing dim sum.  I always take friends and family here that are visiting from out of town so that they can experience incredible dim sum and this place never ever disappoints.  I've tried dozens of dim sum spots since moving to the Bay Area and this place is still #1 by far.
author: Deni I.

description:
Best Dim Sum in SF. 

Though I can only speak to about 5-6 places, this one is definitely my favorite! BIG pots of tea, delicious spicy cucumber salad, unique green chile sauce and that doesn't even go into the dumplings!!

Most notably: 

Sui Lung Boa (Shanghai soup dumplings) - Super juicy and piping hot
Gao Choy Got (shrimp and chive dumplings) - Mostly shrimp but the chives were full of flavor
Jin Doy (sesame balls) - Warm and crunchy, so tasty!
Free cookies - A great sweet way to end the evening :)
author: Talia R.

description:
Many of the dishes are too overpriced.  Why would they charge $14 for some chicken lettuce cups.  It's the highest i have ever seen in any restaurant for lettuce cups.

Their chinese food is some of the best in the city: Hot & Sour soup, Sizzling rice soup, veggie potstickers, green bean chow mein.
author: Hyla S.

description: Not my favorite dim sum place as there are a number of other places not too far from here , but it's ok in a pinch. Usually less of a wait. Its pretty large and the food is decent. The few times i went it did seem a little pricy though,
author: Grant O.

description: This place has gone down hill. It's sad too. I had been coming here since I was a kid! The service has never been worse, food just mediocre (was once great), and the the place feels run down. Ton Kiang has ran it's course.
author: Charlie A.

description: I don't have any complaints about the food here. The Dim Sum is always fresh and delicious. They are pretty busy on the weekends, and on weekdays it gets packed during the lunch hour and dinner. My only gripe is that it can be difficult to find parking because it's all street and metered. Otherwise, if you love Dim Sum, then this place is a must go if you are in the area!
author: Alex U.

description:
Maybe one star ~
This spot has earned a Double Black-Diamond downhill, crash and burn rating as of today!  I buy better frozen dim sum at my local asian market in the freezer burn section!  Waiter with a dirty uniform just smiles and then asks if you want a box to take the crap home... Ay carramba!!!

Bottom line: Sucks, don't eeeeven bother...
author: T C.

description: Good for a quick dim sum run. Fast, good service.  Not a huge selection but the salt and pepper shrimp looked good.
author: Jeff D.

description: We come here every time we're in SF. And every time we come here, we just order the dim sum so I can't comment on the other foods.  The dim sum, however, is one of the best I've had on the mainland.  Hasn't disappointed me yet.  The service is always fast and friendly. As far as prices, I kinda expected it to be a little on the high side considering it's the Bay Area.
author: Elle Elani Whatever C.

description:
Varied and complete selection on the new dinner menu. Five of us ate nine dishes and everything was yummy. Service is good, although the dining room can get hectic and a little noisy.

I was surprised how enjoyable were the orange chicken and breaded chicken wings. The eggplant dish and the chow fun seafood were a bit blah. There doesn't appear to be much range between mild and spicy, so be aware if either one is a priority.

Parking is very limited locally, and TK doesn't take reservations. Dinner time during the week is generally easy to get a table, but arrive in the area early to find parking. Best is to cruise around 6:00 when the meters and commercial zones become free.

We have eaten here many many times, always something different, both lunch and dinner. There are plenty of reasons TK is both a neighborhood and regional favorite, especially for dim sum.

Bring some friends. This food is ideal for a group.
author: John N.

description: Ate here the other day and was pleased but I've definitely had fresher dim sum. Ate the custard flavored donuts which were great. Greens were good. A bit overpriced.
author: Flavia D.

description:
Oh man, this was such a waste of a meal in San Francisco.  We should've left as soon as we realized that we were the only Asian people in the whole restaurant.

The selection was very limited, and had very odd things like foil wrapped chicken substituted out for some of the more traditional dim sum dishes.  The food... well, quite honestly, I've had better dim sum in Cleveland.  I think I've said enough.
author: Kenny Y.

description:
The BF had a craving for some dim sum, so I remembered about this old standard. We had some steamed pork buns, BBQ pork buns, shrimp balls, shrimp and spinach dumplings, shrimp and scallops dumplings, sticky rice, pork mushroom ginger type dumpling (these last two were not to my liking), egg custard pastry type item, and tea. 

Overall good food, good service, lots of food constantly circulating. Total bill for two here goose for about $20-$25 per person as long as you aren't one if those that says yes to everything that comes by!!!
author: Amelia M.

description:
So, food quality is non-negotiable. Ton Kiang is very-good to excellent, consistently. The pastry shell is flaky and the steamed bun's pork is creamy and a little smoky. The Shanghai dumplings are juicy without being explosive.

The selection is outstanding. They offer more than a few vegetable dishes like cucumber salad, garlic asparagus, broccolini, and fruit combos. The mushroom dumplings are fantastic, and the curry beef turnovers are the best I have every had, and I make special trips for these things.

The staff are patient. At a dim sum place. Think about that. The restaurant is not huge (it has an upstairs, so don't assume that it is tiny), and it has enough staff that that have time to be patient and pay attention.
author: Richard H.

description:
Ton Kiang is on the 7x7 List: 100 Things To Eat list, so I finally made it out here for the dim sum. Everything was decently good, I would say SKIP on the BBQ Pork Buns and go to Lung Fung after. Some things were better (siu mai, egg tart, har gao ) than others (shrimp noodle, shanghai dumplings blech). 

Overall it is pretty good and I'd rather come here for quicker service, and no lines. But I think the food is overall better and more diverse at HK Lounge.
author: Jess C.

description: I can't believe that it has taken me this long to write this review. I have been coming here for almost 15 years and have loved every visit. The dim sum is consistent and always good. I always end up asking for some of the walnut cookies to take home with me. Parking can be a pain in the arse. Be sure to come with change for the meters. If you forget, the cashier is always ready with some quarters for change making.
author: Jenny M.

description:
This used to be our families go to chinese restaurant location for all occasions. Birthday, anniversaries, relatives visiting? We took them here. 

It was wonderful. Every dish was delicious. It was 3x cleaner than any other spot we went to. The staff wasnt pushy and rude because we didnt speak the language. Well, that was then. 

Now, the food is so overtly oily it gives me a stomach ache to look at. The dishes are all chipped and scratched. Probably because they are some ones from the opening. The dim sum which used to be the best here just isnt. So much dough. Not enough filling. 

Please please change. I loved you. We all really did. Go back to the former glory of yesteryear!
author: Michelle I.

description:
We came here because it was on The Big Eat list of 100 things to try in sf before you die. We mostly had dim sum but also got a pan friend seafood noodle. The pan fried noodle could have done with a little more seafood and a little more seasoning. The vegetable spring rolls which are on the dim sum menu were kind of bad. I've had a lot of spring rolls in my life and I'm normally pretty indifferent to them, but these I didn't enjoy at all. 

What really bumps this up to 3 stars is the Char siu baos. Without a doubt my favorite dim sum dish at most places, and they do them right here. Also they were only I think 43.75 for 3 of them and I normally pay around $5 for two when I get them from takeout places. I could eat 5 orders of these things. The sesame balls were also a win.
author: Christine U.

description: Great place for Dim Sum in the Richmond. Barbecued Pork Buns were my favorite also liked the shrimp dumplings. Returned for a dinner but was a little disappointed with the Steamed Salt Bake Chicken, it was a little undercooked and not very flavorful. Better to stick with Dim Sum.
author: Peter A.

description: Best places to get dim sum in the city! Excellent service and extremely tasty. A bit pricy but worth every penny. Add Ton Kiang to your list!
author: Nicole P.

description:
Um...okay I'm ridiculous. I came here again today for more dim sum (what is going on with me this week!?).

So for the third time, I came for dim sum and loved it. I think this will be the last time since well...the new week is starting.
author: Julia P.

description:
Really good dim sum! I've always griped about NY's lack of good Chinese food, so I'm glad this SF gem beats NY!

All the staples are good: chicken feet, shu mai, dumplings of all kinds. The black bean pork chops are good too! Totally worth the trip out to Richmond!
author: Sherry L.

description:
I was a little hesitant about this place after reading the yelp reviews. However the michelin stickers on their window reassured me that their food must be decent. We were seated at a big table upstairs. Service was good compared to other Chinese restaurants. Our food came out in a reasonable amount of time.  So we ordered:
Hot and sour soup: 5/5 great tasty soup to warm you up on a cold day!
Mapo tofu with pork: 3/5 on the sweet side, I have had better.
Crab with garlic sauce: 5/5 very tasty
Stir fried chicken: 3/5 average
Fried rice: 3/5 ok
Braised string beans: 4/5 good but very skinny
Big sprout veggies: 5/5 crispy, fresh, good flavor
Beef chow fun: 4/5 not bad
author: Kim l.

description:
Open all day is a huge plus!
$38 for 9 items of dim sum which is enough to take home. 
Mushroom and shrimp dumplings are to die for.
:( asked for more tea but didn't get any. Dim sum is made fresh and takes time.
author: Amy W.

description:
Expensive prices for some mediocre dim sum. This dim sum restaurant is for those who are either unfamiliar with dim sum, tourists who are looking for a safe trap to eat "Chinese" food in, or for those who  get really turned off by a unexpected yellow stain in a carpet. 

We tried the chicken feet, lotus leaf wrap (zongzi), egg custard, and various other standard fair dim sum dishes. Suffice to say. You are paying through the nose for ambiance and comfort. The take out dim sum hole in the wall on Clement is so much better and cheaper that I don't even understand why anyone would want to pay for this place's probably frozen and incredibly small portions just to feel less visually perturbed when eating. 

The zongzi was missing salted egg. The egg custards were a fraction of the size they should have been. The chicken feet tasted frozen and was missing every spice usually found in that dish. The jelly fish salad was missing vinegar, sesame seeds, sesame oil, soy sauce, and even proper mixing.

Please save yourself from bland dim sum feel pleasant because you should be paying for good food and not upholstery.
author: Alan H.

description:
Never understood the hype with this place. I had to try this place when I first moved to the Richmond after seeing it mentioned several times by food critics in Zagat and 7x7 and also the hoards of people waiting to get in each time I passed by. Ton Kiang has got to have some outrageously yummy dim sum. 

Not what I thought after my first visit. In typical dim sum fashion, my bf and I went to town and ordered enough food to feed a baseball team so we got to try a bit of everything on their menu. None of the food tasted good at all, nothing was fresh and portions were small (even for dim sum). We left feeling confused about the place as we were expecting something spectacular. Did we catch them on an off day? 

We decided to go one more time and it was the same experience, if not worse than before. Never will step foot here again. Do yourself a favor and visit Golden River next door where the dim sum is tasty and the wait much shorter
author: Pauline T.

description:
Oh happy tummy!!! It's been forever since I have done dim sum, and I can't tell you how much I have missed it. The shrimp balls were to die for, in fact everything that had shrimp in it was fantastic. The steamed BBQ pork buns were standard, but my hubby really enjoyed the baked BBQ buns. Dad of course ate all the Sui Mai. I really like the chicken feet *I know I'm weird* 
But my favorite item was the warm walnut cookie and the mango pudding. The mango pudding had bits of mango in it and every time I came across a piece it was like finding buried treasure. Now the walnut cookies were a religious experience. Even dad fell in love, ( he's a hard man to please)!

We got there about 9:30-9:45, we were able to get good seats and great parking. But the staff were taking orders, as there were not enough people to start the tray run. So we sat for a moment and discussed our plans for the day (my birthday) before we knew it there was an influx of people and trays were coming around. The wait staff were really nice, especially the busboy/man. He made sure that our water glasses were never empty. I thing it helped that I was really polite and smiled at him each time he did it.

All in all it was a tasty superfantasimigoric meal.
author: Katlyn P.

description:
Came here on a Sunday for dim sum with some friends. All the standard fare is available and done pretty well. The only disappointment was the Shanghai soup dumplings were all dried out. :(

I didn't think the prices were too outrageous for the dim sum. The service was fast and even though we were sitting in a corner, we were never ignored by the servers pushing/carrying the food around.
author: Neftalí J.

description:
This dim sum restaurant is often rated in the top ten in San Francisco. We visited on a Saturday around 12:30 p.m. 

I've eaten a lot of dim sum in Los Angeles, so was excited to try out San Francisco's best. While this place was fairly packed, the Asian crowd was down the street at Hong Kong Lounge waiting for 20-30 minutes for a table. We decided to try Ton Kiang instead of wait, since it was in walking distance. 

The dim sum was pretty good. Excellent pork bun, shrimp dumplings were good.  Excellent sticky rice which is always what I judge dim sum places by. Not impressed with the shrimp and rice noodle. Lots of vegetable choices, unlike other dim sum places. Green beans were flavorful and yummy. Green onion pancake tasty, but dry. 

All in all very good, excellent service, lots of choices. No carts, which was disappointing since I was introducing a midwestern to their first dim sum. But my friend didn't seem to notice because the pork buns were so good.
author: Joe S.

description:
Came here for the first time in quite a few years for Christmas Day dinner with the family. The food, service and ambiance was as good as I remembered it to be.

I absolutely love the fact that they serve Dim Sum all day! The Har Gow, Sui Mai and Fried Shrimp Balls were all hot, fresh and delicious. My favorite Dim Sum dish was the Eggplant w/Shrimp. The eggplant was cooked just right! Other places tend to either over/undercook the eggplant or the dish is super greasy. We also ordered from the dinner menu and were quite pleased with the food. The Seafood Fried Rice, Crispy Noodles w/meat & Seafood and Honey Walnut Prawns were ridiculously good! Our order of Fried Scallops was the only subpar dish we ordered. 

Although very busy on Christmas Day, our server was attentive and ensured our food came out in a timely manner. Prices are reasonable for San Francisco dining. Lots of street parking but always a hassle with how busy this section of Geary is. Overall, two thumbs up!
author: Paul C.

description: Food was decent, the vegetarian egg rolls were very good. The service was terrible, it took 20 minuets for us to get the check, when there were waiters standing around doing nothing.
author: Emilie D.

description:
UGH. I really do not know how this place even made the 7x7. Comparing this to real dim sum in Hong Kong is like eating trash. Even Koi Palace isn't this expensive and it's much better. 

Wanted to grab some dim sum since we were in the area. We literally sat down ordered 2 things an left. WITHIN 15 minutes. Terrible food, too much MSG and way too overpriced. There's so many better places in SF
author: Jenn Y.

description:
So I guess this place is one of THE spots for dim sum or something like that.... I don't know, but the dim sum restaurant right next to this place looked like that was place to be as that place was lined up by a whole bunch of Asians while Ton Kiang's patrons were mostly made up of non-Asians.  Not that I'm trying to hate, but... if I'm going to eat Asian food I'd rather go where all the local Asians are herding towards. 

Ordered the usuals like: cheng fun, siu mai, har gow, char siu bao, lotus leaf wrapped sticky rice & pai gwut.  Pretty much nothing special... I'd rather go to Koi Palace where they have chili paste and not chili oil.
author: Priscilla C.

description:
Great Chinese food... if you are not a SF local!

This is not a very good chinese restaurant considering all the great food that you can get close-by.  

However, if you have guests who are not ... ahem.... culturally diverse, they may enjoy this place and their Lemon Chicken.
author: D. T.

description:
Ton Kiang, what happened?  You were so good a decade ago.

I used to come here probably every other week or so (dragged by parents... dim sum always reminded me of the Calvin and Hobbes strip where Calvin puts his entire lunch--PB&J sandwich, possibly chips--in his Thermos and shakes it up with milk).  It was pretty good back then.

The go to spot in SF now is Hong Kong Lounge.
author: Erika C.

description:
I LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE

If you want dimsum anytime of the day - this is the place to be.

Its not that expensive and the dimsum is pretty decent.

I love this place.

If your friends want some quick dimsum thats good, this place is worth checking out.
author: Joaquin A.

description: I came here this afternoon for lunch and was able to find seating very quickly which I was surprised by. Immediately after sitting down servers began coming up to our table offering us vegetable dishes and dumplings. I like this style of service because you get to see all the dishes, but at the same time it is easy to spend a lot of money because you lose track of what you've already ordered and how much everything is adding up to. I will say that the food was delicious in my opinion- the Shanghai dumplings, shrimp filled mushrooms, asparagus, rice cakes, and mango pudding are some of the things that stick out for me. Overall, I appreciated the speediness of the service and I would say the food was pretty good, but I was a little put off by the final bill.
author: Brendon P.

description: Pricey dimsum. On a smaller portion on their dimsum and a little bit more than the average as far as how much they cost. A little bit upscale. Inside is nice, clean, and not a huge banquet dining hall type of space. I am fan of the quality and taste of their dimsum. I am drooling just thinking about them. I had the staple; pork bun, shrimp dumpling, Chinese broccoli, mushroom etc. I am diggin this place. Would love to come back again. Glad I tried this place!
author: J C.

description:
It's hard to read reviews of dim sum in SF. Too many groups trying to optimize different things. The visitors from out of town/out of state are either easily impressed or weirded out by such things as chicken feet and semi-authentic Chinese flavors. Asian reviewers often neglect to mention you need to order in Mandarin or Cantonese. Some regulars don't mention that a place is only take-out, which is fine if you live in the neighborhood, but not worth crossing the city for. 

That said, Ton Kiang has decent dim sum, with their basic offerings leaning heavily to shrimp dumplings and things stuffed with shrimp. 

The setting is a pleasant restaurant in the Richmond, with white tablecloths and fairly pleasant service for dim sum. Most of the customers are non-Asian, with some mixed groups. Staff mostly speak English. The logo represents it as Hakka cuisine, though we couldn't identify anything specifically Hakka on the dim sum menu. 

The asparagus was probably the surprise standout: braised or steamed with a touch of sesame and garlic and served cold, great complement to the dumplings and duck. The soup dumplings are cooked in individual tins; this preserves the soupiness but leaves the dumpling wrapper more doughy and less slippery. I liked them but it is a variation from the classical soup dumpling. 

The rice noodle with beef was deliciously chewy with a hint of cilantro. Shrimp-stuffed mushrooms in a scallion gravy were delicious. 

All in all, I liked it and would happily eat here again if in the neighborhood, but probably wouldn't make a special trip here for the dim sum.
author: Cage H.

description:
Pretty standard Chinese food here.  We came here to enjoy a family style meal and were not disappointed.  The food was good, service ok and the ambiance was accommodating of an 80+ year old man and infant.

POT STICKERS
EGG ROLLS 
WAR WON TON
TON KIANG SEAFOOD CLAY POT
SHREDDED CHICKEN FRIED RICE
SPICY EGGPLANT  
SPICY OKRA

The spicy eggplant stole the show with the okra a distant second.  The pot stickers, egg rolls, wonton soup and chicken fried rice were all decent, about what you would expect from American style Chinese food.
author: Nicole R.

description:
Have been coming here for years. Sadly the quality has gone down significantly over the years.

It's ok ... But nothing great.
author: Ankur V.

description:
Besides the food being flavorless and greasy this one star review goes to the awful and rude service. There was actually a moment in the restaurant where I thought I was going to cry. The restaurant is very disorganized and dumpy inside. Some times a dumpy interior is offset by awesome food but that was not the case here. Also, their online menu is inaccurate and many of the cool dishes online are not available (ex. Spicy Szechuan Chicken with Red Chili Peppers).

We ordered the veggie dumplings, bbq pork buns, shrimp stuffed eggplant,  salted fish fried rice, peking duck.

Never had a chance to eat the pork buns or the duck.

The veggie dumpling filling was a very strange texture. Couldn't really identify what was in it. something stringy. The shrimp stuffed eggplant had an awesome looking sauce on it but it was pretty flavorless, i guess the oil they use is rarely changed so the dish just tasted like old grease. The salted fish fried rice was okay. It was the only dish of substance we received. very boring.

The server basically refused to give us the pork buns we ordered and the peking duck.  I asked why we never received ours, yet everyone around us who ordered after us did and they said they weren't going to give them to us. 1.are you kidding me? 2. why did you even take our order? Peking duck was brought to our table but the server made a mistake, took it away and then never corrected it. Sat there for about 2 hours 
 
Server never checked on our table. Just occasionally came by to bring us the wrong order or lie about what was happening to our orders. Worst of all, their was "no manager" to talk to about the situation.

Never, ever again.
author: Leuwam T.

description: This place has a ok dimsum food but it was way too expensive. In addition, it wasn't as good as it used to be. For a party of 6, we ordered 4 items from the menu and ~8 dimsum dishes. We were shocked that the bill  came to $153(not including tips).
author: Elena H.

description:
Dim sum fix at 9:00 pm? Why not!

I know that authentic and legit dim sum places are in the morning/lunch time, but you know, sometimes you just want dim sum at night.  A little shrimpy dumpling or a bbq pork bun is a good night cap.

This place does serve up dim sum at night by menu.  While we stumbled into this place after we discovered that Shanghai Dumpling Kind was closed, it ended up workng well.

Its the general dumplings, and there are no carts for you to order from, but you can get the basic ha gao, bbq pork bun, sticky rice, shu mai, and that taro cake thing.  So if you need this fix, this is a definite place to grab it.
author: Natalie G.

description: This place is like a beginner's guide to dim sum. It's a quiet sit down restaurant that serves dim sum all day so if you're in the mood for dim sum during non-brunch hours this might just be the place for you. When sat, my friend and I were given a couple of menus and some tea. They have a menu that provides pictures of all the different dim sum options and they break up the different options by category. You have baked, steamed, pork, seafood, etc. They also have a smaller menu that is specifically just for dim sum and tells you what all the options are and provides a picture next to each option. This is actually separate from the larger menu because the larger one also includes all the other non-dim sum options that they have including fried rice, etc. They're very quick to take your order here. This isn't one of the rolling cart places so you won't get that instant gratification of having a steaming small tray of dim sum right in front of you after you order. In fact, even if you order all your dumplings at once they will still bring them out to you one by one. This style of serving and eating makes sense to me at Italian restaurants maybe but for dim sum I like to be able to eat from different dishes in one large course. The pork buns were delicious. The sesame balls included a lotus flavor as opposed to the red bean flavor that I initially asked for. The sui mai's flavor was only just ok. The shrimp dumplings were quite small and they didn't have very many sweet options including no taro buns. Again, this is definitely more of a starter dim sum place and if you're bringing someone who has no idea what it is or what to expect they probably won't be disappointed but if you're a seasoned dim sum goer I would probably recommend exploring a few more options in the area. What's one great thing about this place? The price! My friend and I were super full after having our share of dim sum and our bill totaled to $20. We were in and out the door pretty quickly. Cheap prices and dim sum served all day are probably the best aspects of this particular dim sum place.
author: Julie H.

description:
My wife and I wanted to have some Dim Sum for lunch. My wife is Chinese and she really didn't like the restaurant at all. We were greeted by a command of '2nd floor' then we had to squeeze through tables on the first floor to get to the stairs of the restaurant. I'm surprised the Fire Department allows them to have no clear path to the front door. If there were a fire, people would have problems to get to the exit. 

During our lunch, two waitresses standing next to our table were talking about who had got fired because of something.  One of them was trying to pursue more information even though the other one said let's talk later on. 

One man (did not serve us at all) picked up the check pad right in front of us to find out how much tips we left and then we notices there was some kind of body motion to express his opinion about the amounts of tip in the pad. 

The Dim Sum came out of the kitchen was carried by hand instead of carts. The restaurant needs a good cleaning, carpet was dirty. The food overall was pretty good. But, the restaurant itself was overall needing cleaning.
author: Gregory M.

description:
My favorite dimsum restaurant in the city.   Usually there on the weekends for lunch and so they have quite the line to get in but always worth it and never feel like we're waiting too long. 

Lunch is great as they're walking around with every tempting dish imaginable. 

This Sunday ended up there in between lunch and dinner so didn't have to wait at all.  We got Gao choy got, siu  mai, wah tip. Dao Miu Gao, and pork buns.  Stuffed by  the time we were finished.  Check them out!
author: Michele R.

description: Good dim sum! Nothing too extreme so I liked that. Had pot stickers, pork buns, won ton soup and hot tea. Perfect and not too much.
author: Veronica W.

description: I haven't been to this place in year, and after seeing the 2.5 hour wait at Hong Kong lounge, we decided to stop by Ton Kiang. This was Christmas Day and the wait was only about 15 minutes for a table of 8. The place was very busy as expected, but the service here is much better than most Chinese restaurants in the city. We tried a lot of the dim sum that they had, and it was all very good! I do not have a complaint on any of the food really. I did not particularly like the mango pudding they gave us, but other than that I thoroughly enjoyed all the dim sum they had. I will be back for sure. Very reasonable prices here too.
author: Nikita K.

description: Excellent dim sum, and it's really a fun experience at this restaurant. Minus one star because their a la carte options are slightly lackluster compared to their flavorful dim sum options.
author: Sal K.

description:
Ton Kiang is certainly one of my favorite places to eat dim sum. It's in a safe area with plenty of parking. It has an open and clean dining area and a lighter vibration than most Chinese restaurants. It's not a spot to go to for candlelit romantic atmosphere but it's definitely an upbeat, interactive dining experience. Great place to go with a group of friends, perfect for sharing. 

People complain about some of the recipes lack traditional techniques but for me, this place serves delicious food made with fresh ingredients and each bite is packed with flavor. The trick is knowing what to order. 

My must haves are the baked bbq pork buns, which are just the perfect amount of sweet and savory, and the fried shrimp balls. In terms of dumplings, I favor siu mai pork, spinach & shrimp, and scallop & shrimp. Definitely also some of the best potstickers and egg rolls I've ever tasted as well. I typically order a side dish of vegetables.  My personal favorite is bok choy with garlic. 

I always finish off the meal with the egg custard tarts. Warm, delicious custard within a stiff but flaky crust. Only downside is their miniature size. Excellent portions for a dieter, a calorie counter, or a model but not for a foodie like me. 

Needless to say, I'll be back soon.
author: Ruby G.

description:
On the verge of being a 5 star dim sum restaurant.

Believe you me I've been in and out of a good number of dim sums in my time.  Loved everything chicken feet, pot stickers, sho mai, Chinese donuts, all.

Be careful with the pastries/deserts though.  They can be a little heavy on the pastry crust.  But other than that try everything, eat everything, and taste it all.  I hope next time I get to sit upstairs though.  We sat downstairs and were seated within about 20 seconds of walking into the door.  I was flabbergasted. shocked.  

The most helpful thing about the restaurant was the tiny instruction sheet in the middle of the table telling you what everything is and whats in it. 

TOP 5 FAVORITE THINGS:

1) Chicken Feet
2) Chinese Donut (it's okay, it's supposed to be cold)
3) Rice noodle
4) Pot stickers (fat fat fat)
5) The dumpling with the shrimp center (not sure what its called but that special rice paper the use really makes it freakin' amazing)
author: Hazel K.

description:
We've been coming to Tong Kiang for many years.  The price to quality is fantastic here. The deem sum is tasty and the servers come out often. 

Their rice noodles and egg custard cakes are particularly good. 

I strongly recommend you try them if you are in the mood for reasonably priced deem sum.
author: Dan Q.

description:
I have been going here weekly since I have lived in San Francisco.

It wasn't until I moved to Davis that I began to really appreciate the quality dim sum and chinese food here. Lately I have only been going for dim sum and find that it gets packed around 1pm. If you want to avoid the loud crowd, I suggest going either earlier in the day or later in the afternoon.

If you do go for dim sum, I suggest getting a chinese donut for dessert, definitely worth it. It has a nice sugar coated exterior, but a smooth interior. Delicious
author: Karma B.

description:
I really wanted Dim Sum and a friend suggested I come here.
Saturday 11am, NO LINE? OPEN TABLES?
uhoh. I was already worried.
we got seated upstairs.  one table was filled, but the rest were empty.  during the meal- the place really filled up.  the crowd was older (white haired) white people. it was so cute, but so not typical of what i consider a dim sum crowd. it was quiet, clean, and no yelling. all of the servers spoke english and once you're done eating they don't rush you out the door.

very interesting experience.  food wasn't bad, but wasn't great either. would i come here again? probably not, because i live too far, but if i lived next door...maybe
author: Skye W.

description:
You know this place is good when it's packed with Chinese people in it!  

Anyhoo, this place gets REALLY busy, especially on those "special days" (ie. father's day, mother's day, etc).  Be prepared to wait.  It's two floors deep and they offer a variety of dim sum. You won't be disappointed - it's a really good spot.  

BUT!!! I do think it's a bit overrated.  JUST BE PREPARED to spend money!  Pretty pricey for dim sum and can add up when you're ordering 3 of the same dishes.

Also, parking can be of an issue.  That's why it's not getting more than 3 stars from me.
author: Diana M.

description:
Friends organized a lunch for Chinese New Year so I was looking forward to trying a new dim sum place. We had the standard items and everything was average.

The sub par review is for the service. They'd forget our orders so we'd have to ask them multiple times:
- shrimp noodle rolls 2 times
- siu Mai 3 times
- diet cokes 3 times
- XLBs 3 times, 30min and then twenty minutes in between the last two times. We finally gave up, asked for the bill and cancelled the orders. The waiter said, good, it wasn't coming anyways.

Good thing it all came out to only $20! There are other dim sum places that have better food and attentive service. If it wasn't for a great time with new and old friends, this place would be one star.
author: Yoko H.

description:
Too doughy.  The service was missing.  Something between a nice fast-food restaurant and a college cafeteria.

SF Weekly rated Ton Kiang as the #1 place for beginners.  We ordered the dinner for 2 (9 dim sum orders).


Overall, left full but still hungry for flavor.
author: Gregarious B.

description:
My favorite place for dim sum. Hands Down... Not just cause it's across the street from my old grade school. St Monica's REPRESENT. But it has for MANY MANY years been consistently very good. I may long for meals here because I'm no longer in The City or The Richmond for that matter but I'm certain Ton Kiang will be as good as ever when I return.
I like the foil wrapped chicken, crab claws, steamed & bbq pork buns, har gow, siu mai, porridge with century egg plus chinese doughnut, the sesame balls and the egg custard tarts just to name a few.
Took my friends from LA here once and we ate like kings. They LOVED it. Try it, you just might too...

ps - foil wrapped chicken doesnt seem to be available in LA dimsum places, so order it , for me... lucky bastards.
author: Chuck D.

description:
I used to love this place! It used to be our go to place whenever anyone arrived from the airport. Now I am sad to report it is in urgent need of a facelift, or at the very least a good cleaning! 
The food is good, but the hand bannister leading upstairs is forever sticky, the floors are filthy, and don't even go near the bathroom! 
 I wonder if the restaurant itself is so dirty what must the kitchen look like?  I don't want to know. 
There are too many other good dim sum restaurants to eat at such a dirty establishment. If you do go, bring your hand sanitizer and stay away from the bathroom!
author: June W.

description:
We wanted good, hot, fresh dim sum for ourselves and our guest from Japan. As an international traveler, Yoshi had been all over the world including many countries we have yet to visit such as Norway, Sweden, Vietnam, Thailand and Spain. His passion for food is great and we did not want to embarass ourselves by providing him with mediocre food. 

We arrived on Sunday just soon after the restaurant opened. Everything that we tried was served at the correct temperature after coming fresh from the kitchen. Because this restaurant is not huge, they don't push steam carts around. Instead, they carry up to six servings of one or two items on a tray as they go around. 

There were three dishes that I don't remember seeing at dim sum before. The first was a cold asparagus dish. Long spears that had their outer skin peeled off leaving just the tenderest morsels, lightly seasoned served over a lightly pickled julienned carrot and daikon salad. Perfect way to start a meal. Second was a dumpling filling with chicken and veggies. Our dessert was a small sculpture of cut fresh fruit including grapes, watermelon, honeydew, pinepple and mango. 

Service was quick and efficient. Empty plates were promptly removed from the table and the stream of fresh dishes from the kitchen was non-stop. The only misgiving that we had was that the steamed oysters on the half shell came out after we had our fruit. Guess we'll have to wait until next time!

Our guest enjoyed himself and we had great conversation in the now crowded restaurant as we finished our second pot of tea.
author: Dexter D.

description:
Food: I had read this was some of the best dim sum in the city. I've never had dim sum before, so take this with a grain of salt...we ordered almost all the shrimp options, and they all pretty much tasted the same to me. Perhaps that's because I'm uneducated, but my dinner companion who is quite well versed in dim sum was unimpressed. He was also disappointed that they didn't have chicken feet, and that they didn't include soup with the meal. Putting aside comparisons though: there were many options in dim sum, food seemed healthy and was filling, and prices seemed reasonable. Really liked the tea. 

Price: Ended up $30/person (we got the dim sum for two with 2-3 glasses of wine) which I think is pretty good. Btw, soup was pretty expensive (almost $10 for one serving?!). Tea was included with meal. 

Ambience: Casual, mediocre dinner restaurant ambience. Not overly intimate or inviting, but quite clean and proper looking. 

Service: Decent. Waitress was pretty nice, we were seated quickly. However, it took us a while to be taken care of at first. After that it was fine though. 

Location: Seemed to be in a safe location. On a bus line down Geary St, on the way to Legion of Honor. Not too bad but not the most convenient for tourists.
author: Farheen Q.

description:
Food quality has gone down.  Came for a late (2PM) dim sum and everything was dirty.  The floor was dirty, the walls were dirty, several plates were dirty, the soy sauce pitcher was covered with dried blotches of soy sauce.  I asked for another, and they brought me another that was similarly blotched.

The taro root ball was over-fried, shrimp and chive dumplings didn't have a lot of taste, shrimp noodles too soft, and the eggplant meat sandwiches were pretty good.  We were going to order the Peking duck but decided that instead of setting ourselves up for a disappointment we'd head across the park and finish the meal with some boba tea and take-out sushi.  Much better.

I don't know what they're thinking.  They've got tremendous name recognition and goodwill.  Some people are still coming here from the memories or an old tourist guide.  All they'd have to do is keep the place clean and make better food, how hard is that?  They just don't seem to try anymore.
author: Gil S.

description:
OK, so I was a little concerned after reading several lukewarm reviews of this place, but my husband had eaten here before and insisted that the dim sum was to die for.

Reviews are right, it is pricier than a lot of dim sum places and the ambience, while not really elegant, is a notch above some of the ethnic dives I favor...BUT the dim sum kicked butt!

We had just finished the Bay to Breakers foot race and were starving so we ordered a LOT of food. Like, probably enough to feed three people. So maybe it doesn't always cost $60 (plus tip) to fill up two people at this place. I was a little shocked but hey, I'd just walked about 10 miles and tomorrow is my birthday and the food was really good, so OK.

The top snack of the day was deep-fried oysters with spicy peppers on top. Holy crap! Crispy-light on the outside and melt-in-your-mouth ocean-y goodness inside. Pea tips with garlic were fresh and not stringy and balanced out the richness of the oysters. Sesame balls here were really good, too. Super-crispy and not oozing oil.

All the steamed dumplings were nice. Firm inside, tender skins, and flavorful. I probably should not have ordered the roast duck. Just so fatty, although the taste was delicious. The fat is not the fault of the restaurant. Ducks are just built that way.
author: Patti I.

description:
The freshest dim sum I've eaten outside the Far East. Go for the scallop and shrimp, the chive and shrimp and the pea tip dumplings. Classic har gau were great, but not huge. All the fillings tasted fresh and were beautifully made, a great selection for those who don't don't eat meat. We also enjoyed the shrimp stuffed aubergine and a plate of sprouted peas. We ate a good amount and didn't feel greasy or sick as the steamed dishes tasted clean and delicious. 
Service was mixed but we we didn't mind as the food was very good. Will definitely go here again.
author: Y A.

description: This place is getting worse and worse. Came here for dinner a few nights ago (they were open and close by). Had 4 ppl - ordered wonton soup, eggplant/shrimp dim sum thing, cod in black bean sauce, chicken fried rice, chicken&shrimp dish, salt&speller shrimp. Total was ~ $100. Soup was not great and came with rotten zucchini. Cod tasted and smelled horrible-like canned/rotten fish. Chicken and shrimp dish tasted and smelled horrible-also came with rotten veggies and seemed like they fried it in old ketchup. Rice was ok but really greasy. Didn't try the shrimp. The eggplant/shrimp thing was really good, really oily but really good. Brought leftovers home -since no one really are this junk. Made my fridge smell ssoooooo bad the next day that dumped everything. Don't go here
author: Lena T.

description: While street parking is tricky, it is worth the wait. As soon as we sat down, the wait staff started bringing dim sum to the table - though to my understanding this is a weekend thing and you would usually have to order first before they bring food to the table. The wait staff is pretty on point and friendly. The dim sum is exceptional, probably the best I've had in the US. I'd recommend waiting to see what you would like to eat first because they bring everything out frequently - within seconds of sitting down. Take a good look at what they have then decide, unless you're really hungry, because then you can see the full range of what they serve.
author: Naomi C.

description:
Unfortunately I consider this one of the MISSes on 7x7's 100 to Try Before You Die List. I came on a Friday for lunch a few weeks ago and there wasn't much selection. The dim sum was nothing to write home about, and don't bother ordering the xiao long bao because you'll wait awhile for it and there won't be any soup in the dumplings. I was actually so disinterested/unmoved by my meal that I asked for the bill before I was even full, and that hardly ever happens. 

Verdict: my bf says he'd suggest this place if you have someone in your party who doesn't know much about dim sum. But if you're no stranger to dim sum, there are much better places for you to get your dim sum fix.
author: Caralisa L.

description:
Came here today with the bf just because they are on the 7x7 list. It was the shrimp shuima. 

I was expecting a huge wait seeing how its on the list and its father's day weekend. NO WAIT and PLENTY of free tables. It was around 11.10am. Prime time. 

They don't have much variety and it is extremely expensive. 55 dollars for two!!! The same things kept going around. We only saw the wrapped noodles once! 

Sadly, the shrimp shuimas weren't that great and everything else was average. Definitely not worth the extra bucks. We will be getting our dim sum from chinatown from now on. They also use a lot of msg. We were really thirsty later. 

The waitresses all speak English and the food descriptions aren't that descriptive.  

Only plus is that its clean and quiet here compared to the ct restaurants. One bathroom for men and one bathroom for women.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I always get excited for dim sum at Ton Kiang and always leave disappointed.  The dim sum made the Big Eat SF list but it's not worthy.  There are a dozen spots in and around Chinatown that surpass this spot in the Outer Richmond.

Service is fine, variety is nice, but the quality is subpar.
author: Chad S.

description: This place is the bomb for bao! Great noodles and buns loaded with seafood, meats, veggies and spiced up with ginger, garlic and forward flavors. No nonsense service. Plates hit the table before you sit down. Don't get this stuff in New Orleans so I drink it up when in SF. This was the best by far and priced right of my dim sum excursions while in the fog city.
author: Dana D.

description:
I have withdrawals if I go too long without dim sum. I came here to get my fix - and I did. But it was nothing memorable.

Maybe my skepticism started from the minute I walked in the door and I was 1 of 2 asians in a room of around 25 people. That's just  unheard of when you're in Outer Richmond....

Instead of the typical cart experience, they carry the dim sum on trays - which is fine. Sometimes it can get frustrating because the waitresses like to frequent and return to tables often, and the act of rejecting a dish so many times can start to  feel awful/awkward. (I don't like conflict :/ ) But the waitresses do have constant smiles on their faces which is a relief!

I'm rewarding 3 stars because some of the dishes were cold and because I felt a little sick afterwards. It's also on the pricier same for dim sum. For 5 people, the total came out to 20 bucks a person, which isn't bad for a meal. However, I definitely have had better dim sum for 12-15 dollars.

Tip: Avoid the Sunday crowd and go on a Saturday. We went at 11:30am and our party of 5 was seated immediately.

Extra Tip: There's plenty of metered parking, but most have a 1 hour limit. I learned to use the pay by phone app so that I can just add money to my meter via iphone instead of running too my car - perfecto!
author: May I.

description:
Okay. Used to be better. 

Years ago was crammed full of Chinese diners. Now is half full of everyone but. Not a good sign.
author: Petunia The P.

description:
I'm so sorry I made 10 of my friends come here. Over-priced sub-standard Chinese food. South Sea prices, less than China First quality. 

http://www.yelp.com/biz/south-sea-seafood-village-millbrae

http://www.yelp.com/biz/china-first-restaurant-san-francisco

I will stick with HKL2 and South Sea Seafood Village.
author: DANIEL T.

description: A really good neighborhood spot to enjoy either dim sum or dinner. My wife and I rented the top floor for our Chinese Tea Ceremony for the Chinese side of my family prior to our wedding last October too, it was a blast!  The dumplings, sticky rice and desserts for dim sum are very tasty. For dinner, it's all about their soups, salt baked chicken, salt & pepper fried crab, fried rice w/Chinese sausage and any of their noodle dishes. However, their signature dish is the Chilean sea bass (which takes 45 minutes to prepare so order it when you sit down) as it is smoked and then roasted to sublime flakyness. Service can be fast or slow at times, depending on how busy they get, but the food is always really good.
author: Jared C.

description: Food quality excellent. You end up spending more than you think since small plates add up, even during lunch! Overall a traditional Chinese food experience
author: Diana F.

description:
Great dim sum without the hassle of Chinatown.

We've been here many times, and Ton Kiang never disappoints. They have a large selection of dim sum, especially seafood. If you don't see what you want being brought around ask for it, and they'll make it fresh. Some of our favorites: Steamed barbecue pork buns, foil wrapped chicken, green beans, crab claws and spring rolls. Don't miss the warm walnut cookies or mango pudding. The fresh fruit bowl is quite refreshing.

Try to go on off-peak hours as it's easier to get a table. Parking in the area can be tricky, as it's a busy part of the Richmond. Again, going during off hours helps.
author: Monarch B.

description: This place sucks!!!! Came in for early dinner Sunday around 5 place is not that busy yet. I ordered right away then food came in installment. I asked the waiter after 40 min when will the rest of our orders will come he just looked at us no answer & no aplologies either. 10 min passed i asked the other waiter if its ever going to come othrwise im cancelling the other orders cause we were full already from drinking too much  tea.  Few minutes later the other order came after cancelling  WTH is wrong with this place?!!! no customer service at all.  It totally ruined our special ocassion. There are way other better chinese retaurants around & for the price not worth to come to this place.
author: Marleen L.

description: Had dim sum a few days back.  All very tasty and fairly priced.  My only complaint is that the won ton wrappers after being steamed stuck to the paper and so the dim sum was always in pieces which impacted the full flavor of each piece.  I would definitely go back.  Loved the sesame donuts, custards, the leaf wrapped sweet rice, the har gaw and actually each and every thing we ordered (about 7 dishes).  The only other not perfect pieces were the shanghai pork balls which seemed to be lacking soup inside and wasn't served with ginger or any of the other stuff which makes it so perfect. The service was five star, the food four star, and the price....under $40
author: Carol F.

description:
egg custard rice cakes. green chives & shrimp dumplings.

and that's all you need to know :)
author: CeCe C.

description:
Why is this place on the 7x7 2010 Big Eat SF List???!

I went at 9am on Sunday and the restaurant was pretty much empty. (strange) The service was pretty bad, considering the restaurant was half empty, it filled up later though.  My aunt spoke chinese to the waitress who ignored her.  Then we asked another waiter if he could speak Chinese, and he said NO.

We were all a little shocked. Authentic dim sum served by people who don't even speak Chinese?  What is going on? What kind of dim sum is this? Then we asked for a chinese dim sum menu.  They told us they didn't have one.  No menu in CHINESE? This is dim sum! 

Very sad. Food was just okay, sort of greasy, not the best dim sum I've had. Overall, just didn't feel like authentic.
author: Gloria C.

description:
When we first sat down at our table at this dim sum restaurant I had a feeling of nostalgia, it reminded me of how dim sum restaurants used to be when I was a kid. Very different from how most places are now where you just order what you want off a menu this place has people walking around with dishes asking tables if they would like what they are serving. However;

This is one of the most disappointing dim sum place I've had:
1. Some of the food is cold and not fresh
2. Portions are extremely tiny
3. It's the same food selection walking around
4. Not typical Chinese dim sum
5. It's not even food SERIOUSLY!!!!!!
6. It took so long for our food to come 
7. Over use of white pepper, it's on everything!!


The worse part of it all, one of the must haves during dimsum, shanghai dumplings was not thoroughly cook...Ahhhhhhhhhhhh!!!!!!!!!!   
 
Avoid, avoid, avoid!!!!!

Services is not good either but that had no affect on rating, solely based on the food.
author: Diana L.

description:
Not the best dim sum in the city.

For one, I was turned off when I saw two buckets by our table because of the leaky roof.  The dim sum was room temperature and not even that fresh.  Everything was really bland.  The sesame ball was dry and chalky.  The cha siu bao (barbeque pork bun) was almost too sweet for my liking, plus pork was hard.  The only dim sum that was decent was the shanghai dumplings.  Did I mention that the shanghai dumplings didn't even come with the vinegar sauce?  What?!  That's like eating french fries with no ketchup! The place is overrated and definitely overpriced.

To top it all off, the last time I went here I was hungover.  You would think it would taste significantly better than normal.  Not the case.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description: My Kung Pao Chicken was good, a little spicy with good sauce and peanuts.  My wife's cashew chicken was good, but it didn't have a lot of flavor.  Portions were large and filling.  Nice setting with white tablecloths and attentive service.
author: Kirk M.

description:
I've been to many dim sum places in the bay area and Ton Kiang is definitely at the end of my list.  Ton Kiang definitely caters to the outsiders meaning the tourists.

 It was subpar; the food was definitely lacking quality.

I must say it was quite a disappointment as I've never left a dim sum joint feeling uneased.

The straw that broke the camel's back was when I ordered the egg yolk bun.  To say the least, the egg yolk filling was still frozen hard yet the bun was piping hot. Yep, that shows the buns were not made fresh at all. 

Ton Kiang when it comes to taste, quality, and price you are definitely a thumbs down on my list regardless if you're a hit on the 7x7 list.
author: Sophia S.

description: Went to Ton Kiang last night because it was Chinese New Year and wanted to eat a special dinner with my family. It was 6pm and the restaurant was relatively full but not busy yet. The service attendant was really great. He sat us in a booth and gave us menus, very attentive. We ordered fried squid, greens beans, wor won Ton soup and beef chow fun. Normally when you order food at a Chinese restaurant, it comes out steaming hot and is always so impressive and delicious. This was not the case at all at Ton Kiang. It seemed like we waited for our food longer than usual and when the food arrived, it was not hot...at all.  None of the dishes we ordered were temperature hot. The server just dropped the food down and never came back to check on anything, NEVER!!! The reputation and high prices should have secured excellence but that was not the case at all. We had dined at Yank Sing the week before and they were FLAWLESS in every way, food and service. When the check came, they gave it to my guest and my name was on the card...female name hence I should have gotten the credit card signature voucher. No acknowledgment at all. No conversation from the server, EVER. The best part of the experience was the Hispanic service attendant. Where has the hospitality training gone???? We will not be back.
author: Veronica L.

description: My favorite mid-priced dim sum / Chinese restaurant in San Francisco.  Ton Kiang is known for its dim sum - and the dim sum is high quality (no gristle or random animal parts) with distinct flavors.  Food is not too greasy.  I don't think that they use MSG.  So yes, more appealing to American or Americanized palates - which I think is appropriate - since we're in America, people!  The place is clean and slightly more "upscale" than a lot of other Chinese restaurants.  This counts for something from me.  I've also had a lot of their regular dishes, and to my pleasant surprise, they were delicious.  Not cheap, but not expensive.  Definitely worth the wait...
author: PT B.

description:
Maybe I've been spoiled by Koi Palace in Daly City, but I was disappointed by the high prices for the size of the portions, as well as the quality of the food compared to Koi Palace or Yank Sing.  In the dim sum hierarchy, this is definitely lower on my list.

The reason I am giving it a 3 rather than a 2?
There was no wait on a Sunday, and unlike other reviewers, I thought the service was good, and that there actually was a variety of dishes.  We sampled the shrimp dumplings, egg custard tarts, shrimp and chive dumplings, pork dumplings, snow pea shoots, and a few other dishes.  

Unfortunately, I had a terrible stomachache almost immediately after digesting the food, which lasted well into the night.  My husband did not, so maybe I just have a sensitive stomach.

Was I glad I tried this place?  Yes.  (It validated why I wait in line 2+ hours at Koi Palace)
Would I come back here again?  Probably not.  If I wanted more expensive dim sum without having to travel too far, I woud probably go back to Yank Sing.
author: Nina B.

description: Pretty standard dim sum. Per usual, they bring things out quickly. Nothing too out of the ordinary, so it's probably quite Americanized but everything tasted good and they had all the necessities (pork buns, pot stickers, etc.).
author: Michael M.

description:
This was one of our favorite Chinese restaurants since it opened about 30 years ago. However, we were there last night and it's definitely not up to the old quality. We didn't have the dim sum which is usually our lunch fare. The Chicken Won Ton soup was in a very watery, tasteless broth, very undercooked vegetables, absolutely no seasoning. The Mu Shu pork was over cooked and extremely salty - they do not fix it for you, you have to do it yourself. Our other 2 dishes - dry fried beef with noodles and scallops with 3 kinds of mushrooms were totally without seasoning. 

The service was non-existent unless you nearly tripped a server, and the place was only half full. 

Either new management (it was a new menu), or no one cares anymore.
author: Ron M.

description:
I have to admit, my family and I were forced to come here for mothers day because we had arrived late in going to Hong Kong Lounge and the wait was over 2 hrs there. My mother was still craving dim sum and thus ended up here since it was the closest option. 

We were able to get a table with relative ease as we beat the lunch crowd on Mother's day. However, that was the extent of our good luck. The food was somewhat lacking today despite the good reviews yelpers had of this place. Of the variety of dim sum plates we received, the custard pastries was the only thing I really enjoyed. 

My family usually orders shao mai and shrimp dumplings as those are our favorite dishes, but 20 minutes into our stay there none of the servers brought it out. We stopped one of the waiters to order both dishes, but they only brought out shao mai to us. Not very great service if you ask me. The shrimp dumplings did eventually come out, but by then my family was full already.

No wonder everyone was lining up to go to Hong Kong Lounge, this place just does not live up to it's dim sum reputation.
author: Carlo D.

description:
Disappointed at best.  Recommended by a friend who is a fairly regular patron--egads!!  Why?  There are many better dim sum restaurants in the area and certain within a decent distance.  Nothing special here and the service did not make up for the mediocre at best food.  Vegetable noodles we cold, too salty and flavorless. UGH.  The shrimp/chive dumplings lacked any flavor at all.  The Shanghi style dumplings which are a favorite of mine elsewhere were dry, no liquid at all inside--really???  What's up with this???  The pot stickers were fairly good and ended up being the only thing we liked.  

We would not go back and do not recommend anyone give this a try.  One wet fish slap to wake you up in the kitchen!
author: Jeff P.

description: The dim sum was great. I ordered the shrimp dumpling, scallop dumpling (which came out as shrimp and scallop--oops), and barbecued pork bao--all steamed. Also got a plate of Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce- the sauce came on the side. The sweet and sour soup was huge and too thick for my taste.
author: Reiko B.

description: i prefer this place over hong kong lounge.  They keep it pretty simple here and I enjoy having people come around with the items rather than picking it from a menu.  They don't use carts (at least when I've been here) but instead the waitresses just swing by with little trays every few minutes.  I'm hoping this means the items are fresher seeing as they wouldn't have been idling at the bottom of the cart for a while, but who knows.  The duck here is AWESOME.  it's really fatty, which is how i like it and there is little bone.  The snow peas, eggplant, and siu mai are also good, but not the best.  Service is marginally better than at other dim sum places, but I've always sat in the corner for some reason and every once in a while a waitress would kind of pass by without stopping.  It's also considerably cheaper than HKL.
author: Mason T.

description:
After years of suffering through terrible dimsum, Ton Kiang was a breath of fresh air, even though it is far away. The quality of the food is great, but I still thought they were a bit more expensive than I'd like for dim sum.

We did come a bit late so I felt that the variety was a bit lacking (a lot of shrimp dishes, but few pork, chicken, or beef). I would come back if I had a car.
author: Shang S.

description:
I love dim sum and looked forward to trying this place recommended by my brother. I really wanted to like it as much as he did, but I guess my expectations were too high because the experience was just OK.

The place was crowded, so that's always a god sign. Thankfully, it was just the fiance and I so we were able to get a table fairly quickly. The service was sloooow though. I guess I'm just spoiled by my go-to dim sum spot in San Jose, where the moment I'm seated, I'm bombarded by all the ladies pushing the carts around, even when the restaurant is busy.

The steamed dim sum wasn't very impressive - tasted mediocre/bland to me. What I DID like very much was the Hong Kong style chow mein, shrimp balls, and deep-fried taro.

The chow mein noodles were crispy and the sauce was very flavorful & had just the right consistency - I don't it like when the sauce is watery, blah. The deep-fried taro was very good! It was super crispy and the filling inside was tasty. The shrimp balls - pretty standard at most dim sum places, so this was good/edible; I still enjoyed them nonetheless.

I don't know if I'll come back for the dim sum; maybe if some friends wanted to try it out some time. However, the dishes I enjoyed I could easily get at my favorite, local dim sum spot in San Jose (Grand Fortune Seafood Restaurant - Monterey Road). I'd most likely come back to try their entrees.
author: Janis A.

description:
Great Dim Sum IN SF they just keep bringing out plate after plate.
Great.
author: James H.

description: My first Dim Sum experience and I loved it!  Ton Kaing has great service and great food that kept rolling the entire time we were at the table.  Can't wait for another day trip to San Fran.  First stop, Ton Kaing!!!
author: Brian J.

description: Best in SF.  Better & Cheaper than Yank Sing for sure.
author: adam m.

description:
Stopped in for a late lunch around 2p on Saturday.  No wait, we were seated pronto.  This was our first time here, but we are not new to dim sum so we had a pretty good idea of what we wanted.

The BBQ pork buns were excellent as were the shrimp stuffed mushrooms.  We had 3 other seafood items plus the sesame balls.  Also just one beer and I think the total with tip was about $42.00.  Neither of us thought that was overpriced.  We were hungry, but knew when to stop and left satisfied with our stomachs full and wallet just a bit lighter.  

Service was fast for the most part, we had to wait for one item-but all were piping HOT.  I did not mind the tray service vs. carts.  The servers were fine-no better/worse than any other dim sum restaurants.

We both used the restrooms.  Sketchy at best.  Ugh.
author: Teri X.

description: Fair and decent.  We came for dinner and brought our one year old.  They had a high chair so we were in business.  Food was good but the dim sum tasted like it was made that morning and had been sitting out all day.  Our pork buns weren't even hot.  It was also hard to get service.  We ordered our dessert to go and had to wait an additional 20 minutes after we checked out.  I don't see what all the fuss is about.  The staff was very nice to our son though.
author: Matt C.

description:
Very disappointing! I came to this restaurant 5 years ago and returned today in spite of rekindling the delicious food I had back then. 

We ordered the Shanghai dumplings first which were not bad, a little pricey though for 4 small dumplings for $4. The sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaves were pretty good, not very flavorful, and one shrimp crepe noodle and one beef crepe noodle (the one thing I came for!)

We received the first 3 relatively quickly, however the beef crepe noodle took FOREVER. we constantly asked the 'Auntie' to see when it would be out and she replied "they're making it" 3x. 

We waited a good 45 minutes until we gave up and got ready to go, and asked for the 4th time what happened to it. The waitress replied with some made up answer that she couldn't remember who our server was who took the order and said they skipped past it (even though they were talking to one another about it). 

tl;dr, okay food, poor service, definitely will NOT return. Try Hong Kong Lounge a few blocks over...
author: Alissa M.

description: we went on a sat morning and it was dead quiet...the decor really is old and doesnt look clean, which affected our appetite.   the food is fine but way too greasy..
author: Shuting Z.

description: Oh my god I love this place. I love the cart dim sum and the fact that the dim sum is piping hot when it gets to the table! I usually come here with a hoard of my guy friends who tend to eat like it's Thanksgiving everyday and even with their tendency to say yes to every single cart that comes by, our bill is never expensive. Ever. Any restaurant with tasty shrimp har gao that can fill my friends but not empty our wallets is a win in my book. They also always seem to be able to seat us, even when it's crazy busy!
author: Alexandra M.

description: We loved our time here!! The good was amazing and so inexpensive! My only regret was that we hadn't found this place sooner. The location was clean and there's plenty of parking.
author: Jasmin F.

description: My friend insisted that this place was better than Hong Kong Lounge so we decided to check it out one Sunday morning. No lines at all at 11:30, very strange for a Dim sum joint. The dimsum dishes were small and there was nothing special. The place could use an update as well. I remember reading someone else's review on here and they said there were no Asians at this place, which is not a good sign if you want really good dim sum. For 2 people our bill came out to 30 bucks and we really did not order much. Save your money and go down the street to Hong Kong lounge for some good dimsum.
author: Matthew L.

description: First off, I'm not a really big fan of dim sum... go figure.  While in San Francisco, our friend took us to one of her favorite dim sum places in the city and wow, I enjoyed it very much. Their approach to serving is different from what I've experienced here, instead of carts, they just carry the various dishes and offer them to the diners. I don't know if it's just because we were upstairs and access was difficult or what, but all I know is the servers work really hard to please everyone. My personal favorite there was the hai kim or stuffed crab claws. There was a bunch of meat in it and the crust was crispy. Very tasty. Another one was a mushroom stuffed with shrimp and covered with a sauce. That was very tasty. But the one dish that set itself apart from all the rest, although it was kind of a dessert , was the nai wong siu ben. Its a soft mochi with a custard inside and they brown it on the outside. That was so delicious! Thanks to my good friend and fellow Yelpie, Nat N for turning us on to that!! If dim sum places here made dishes that taste like Ton Kiang, I'd go more often!!
author: Dave F.

description: The best dim sum I've had, whether in a crusty little dive or a schmancy brassy place. So many tasty sauces to compliment each dish, so many strange delectables being paraded about, it's fun and filling for the whole freakin' family.
author: Jaina D.

description:
I'm not ashamed to admit that I'm a dim sum newbie. I can count the number of times I've had it with my right hand, and have 2 fingers left over. You do the math. 

Dim sum for lunch. Highlights included the pea shoots and pot stickers. Unfortunately, I wasn't too crazy about the pork buns, which were just too darn doughy (doh!). I look forward to trying other SF dim sum establishments. Do you want to join me?
author: Scott G.

description:
Been here once, but ate so many different things, it's worth the review. 

Great dim sum hours: 10:30am - 10:00pm.

Food: Average Overall
1. Gai Lan is a "must have" for me any time I am eating dim sum. This place cooks the broccoli perfectly. Al dente. Only *heh* is that the oyster sauce is served in a side dish. I like my oyster sauce served on the gai lan as soon as it's done cooking, so that the heat from the vegetable heats up the sauce, so you do not have cold sauce on hot veggies. Make sure you add a bit a chili oil. 

2. BBQ Pork steam buns, pot sticker, prawns w/ glazed walnut : Standard. No complains, no raves. 

3. Fried rice: Has a lot of flavor. It's worth ordering. 

4.Hai Kim (Shrimp Stuffed Crab Claw): The meat inside is flaky, not soggy and very hot (to the touch). Be careful when you bite into it. The outside; very crunchy. Overall; Pretty good.   

5.Shrimp stuffed eggplant:
This dish is very good. The skin on the eggplant is thick and a little tough and hard to cut with your teeth. Make sure you get both the eggplant and the shrimp in one bite. The two together taste very unique and very good; sweet from the eggplant and savory from the shrimp. On their own, the eggplant is eggplant and the shrimp is shrimp. Again, very hot, be careful. 

6. Vegetarian Egg Rolls: Slightly Below Average. These are extremely hot when you bite into them if they have cooked them fresh. I burnt my tongue. Whoops! They are also very greasy. I've had better. 

7. I was not impressed that this place did not have a birds nest.

Service and Tips: Slightly below average.
~ The waiters are not as fast as a traditional dim sum place with carts and what not. 
~ Order as many dim sum dishes as you can and try everything. 
Ask for as many dishes of chili oil before you get your food. If you ask for chili oil while you are eating, they only bring one small flat dish. They should already have this as a standard table item along with white pepper, but they don't, so ask for it before you get your food.

Enjoy!
author: Rox T.

description: Wow. Here is some delicious and classy Chinese cuisine from the Hakka region of Southern China. I prefer vegetarian, and they have plenty to choose from. The okra was cooked to perfection; we chose to have it with the garlic sauce. But there were other options like bean sauce and spicy sauce. The vegetarian lettuce wraps are bar none awesome, with a plum sauce that is seriously addictive. I ordered another side to have with the veggie fried rice which was plain, but it's supposed to be in order to highlight the dishes served with it. Top quality food. Highly recommended.
author: Zena B.

description:
More like a 3.5

I hate to do this, but for those of you who are familiar with PF Chang's, well Ton Kiang is like the southern chinese version.  

Yes, I pretty much liked it.  They had all the dishes I grew up with, but for 5X the normal price.  I wouldn't go out of my way to come here.
author: Lauren C.

description: Worst experience ever, the waiter ignores us for almost 15 minutes and by the time we order it's been one hour since our first order of food came. After raising my hand for them I finally left without waiting for the other food, I told them to cancel all my orders and I left and yet after eating only two dishes it was over $100. I'll never come back here again and I will not recommend anybody to come here at all
author: Timothy W.

description:
We have been coming here for more than 20+ years already either to Celebrate for Birthdays, Graduations etc. etc. or just to eat out for Family Bonding. My Parents know the Owner (Family) Very Well.My Family and I are Pretty much a Regular Customers in this place for Numerous Years and once in a while we can even Park in front of the Restaurant when it's Reserved.

We were here on May 29 for my Mom's Birthday. Ordered:  Salt & Pepper Spareribs, Sweet & Sour Pork, Rock Cod Fillets w/Dried Tofu, Mongolian Style Beef, Chinese Broccoli, Crispy Noodles w/ Mixed Seafood and Meat, Glazed Walnut Prawns and Peking Duck Served with Steamed Bun. It was a weekday and Early Lunch but the Place is still has a Decent Size of Customers Eating. We waited like approximately 40-45 minutes for our food!!! That was the First Time in any Given Restaurant that we had to wait for such a long, long time for our food! Crazy! and it was not even that busy yet??? We were there on a Weekday and the Placed just opened like 1 1/2 hour ago. 

So, the food Finally came in and wouldn't you know it! All the Food that Came are Cold! I'm not talking about Lukewarm or even Warm I am Talking about COLD!!! It seems like our Food was Ready but no one had bothered to put it on our table, and had just been sitting there! We even had to ask and Remind them about our White Rice and of course the White Rice are also COLD!! 
The Clay Pot Rock Cod Fillets w/Dried Tofu was the only Item that's Warm but when we Stirred the Clay Pot - The Rock Cod Fillets and Vegetables are all Burned and was Sticking at the Bottom of the Clay Pot! 


The Peking Duck NEVER Arrived in our Table on Time. The Peking Duck was to be Served BEFORE all the other Food but they ended up serving it after were almost done eating!!! UNBELIEVABLE!!! I think they Probably forgot that we ordered the Peking Duck!!! WE ENDED UP TAKING IT HOME!!! And when we got home we noticed that the Bun that's served with the Peking Duck is Doughy and Raw Inside and The Peking Duck is not FRESH!!! It Taste and Looks Like it had been a Left over from the Night Before!

Before that incident, the past three years or so we already Noticed that the Food Quality and Quantity are Seriously LAGGING!! Because of this Incident, We won't be back in this place for a LONG, LONG TIME. It was my Mom's Birthday, her Special Day and we want Everything to be PERFECT for her. But the restaurant SERIOUSLY DISAPPOINTED Us! Big Time!
