My Dad Talked to the Woman (Part Owner-Family Business) of The Restaurant about The Food and The Service. She Apologized and she said something about the restaurant being so busy and someone called in sick that day. But I ask you??? Is that OUR FAULT that the Restaurant is BUSY and Someone CALLED IN SICK??? We are There to Eat and CELEBRATE My Mom's Birthday!
author: myra a.

description:
Luck seemed like it was definitely favoring our interest earlier this grey afternoon when we decided on this place for Dim Sum and were immediately seated with absolutely no wait..  it seems like such a rareity for places that offer great Dim Sums for that to be even possible.  One thing I noticed about this place asides the awards placarded up which boasts their inclusion in Michelin reviews along with awards they've won for former consecutive years, is that the service is absolutely exceptional.  The waiters make their rounds in evenly paced increments, and the water is always being topped off endlessly.   
 
I was happy with the selection they had, which is modest in comparison to some bigger places but still is diverse in the range of items offered.  The only disappointment today was the Filo on the pork pastry was really doughy, and not baked long enough.. However, I don't think i'll hold it against them because everything else was so tasty.

I realized when writing this that I was probably in the mood for shrimp today seeing as my top picks mostly have shrimp in them.. 
-Ha Yeung -Shrimp Balls with crispies 
-Gao Choy Got -Green Chive & Shrimp Dumplings
-Hai Kim -Shrimp Stuffed Crab Claw
-Don Tahiti -Egg Custard Tart
author: Ty T.

description:
so my experience has changed a bit. 

The food is good but then I realized that it's good because their appealing to American tastebuds. All very safe tastes and textures. Deep fried this, steamed that, shrimp this, and stuffed veggies that. It's safe, a tourist/hipster hotspot, they all speak English and not a single Chinese family in sight; which equals expensive. $90 for 6 people (not including tip) and still left hungry! At any other down home authentic dim sum house that would be a feast. 

The thing I love about dim sum is the adventure. I love the classics (gold mountain), the old school (Asia pearl), the new tastes coming from HK (Koi palace) and the downright kick ass dumplings (kingdom of dumplings). I love the energy of a good dim sum house; family centered, loud, pushy, the clink of tea cups, and rattling of carts, the yelling of dishes in canto and everyone eating while keeping an eye out for the next dish or what everyone else is eating. 

Ton kiang does not have the energy of a dim sum house. It's quiet, only English can be heard, everything is the same but packaged differently, staples aren't offered (hello where are my chicken feet?) and people are like super excited to try deep fried squid. Let's go to Pier 39 after this kind of folks.  

The veggies were on point, the dumplings were average, duck small for the price, deep fried shrimp were good and xlb sadly lacking any soup inside (one big ball o' meat). 

This is the place to come if you're a novice, scared of squiggly bits, are insecure about ordering at a traditional dim sum house whether because of language barriers or tastebud barriers. If you think head on shrimp are adventurous come here it will leave one less person in my long ass lines at any great dim sum house in the city. 

Last time here.
author: Jade W.

description: Baked BBQ Pork buns are sublime. Turnip cakes are awesome.  shrip crepe was amazing too.  Taro was ok, chinese broccoli was ok.  Shui mai was very good and har gow was also very good.
author: Michael L.

description:
Ton Kiang used to be a 5 star experience but being non-Asian, I don't get the same clout here as when I dine with my Asian friends.  
Imagine that.

Anyway, another hyphenated American friend and I grubbed on their dim sum after I raved it was the best in SF.  He thought it was well priced (12 for $50) and the authenticity was good not great.  He also has upward of 7 stamps in his passport from Asian countries and a couple dozen from others. The man wasn't exactly reared on MacN'Cheese or white bread/American Cheese and balogna(aka baloney) sandwiches.  

I still think they're a solid 4 despite him.  :)

His fave:  dai dze gao (scallop dumplings), boring siu mai

My fave: hai kim (shrimp stuffed crab claw), ha yeung  (shrimp balls), shrimp stuffed eggplant (forgot the Chinese name)

Heads up: Regular menu offers autentic Hakka specialties.
They serve dim sum all day but dim sum on carts (which is SO much funner, in my opinion) everyday before 3 or 4 pm.  
And you WILL wait on a Sunday. Except once when I was sat in front of about 20 others waiting.  How I did that is  my secret.
author: Athena S.

description:
I came here because we were craving dim sum and this place had some really good reviews. They sat us upstairs and we seriously did not get food for a long time. The dim sum dishes they brought over did not look appealing and they kept bringing the same dishes every time. We seriously sat there what felt like 15 minutes and only ordered one item. I was so upset. We paid for our one dish and walked out. 

How do you go eat dim sum and not get any food? It was the same 4 dishes coming out of the kitchen and on top of that, the servers ignored us. We did not get any help. We were not even acknowledged. This has to be one of the worst dim sum experiences I've had. Hong Kong Lounge is sooooo much better. I really did not get the hype over this place. Very disappointing.
author: Caroline L.

description:
Decent location, spacious restaurant and good service. 

My reasons for 1 star: Horrible quality food. My boyfriend and I both came here to eat to give this place a try. The shrimp in the shrimp dumplings tasted way too shrimpy, or maybe even too salty, and the dumpling was hard as if it was microwaved.  We ended up leaving after 20minutes, and left with horrible stomach aches. 

Never again.. please eat with caution.
author: Samantha B.

description: Went with 5 other people. It was our first time at a dim sum restaurant but won't be our last. The food was great and is it also a fun way to dine with a lot of people!
author: elise k.

description:
Food poisoning!!!

Greasy, typical Chinese dim sum place.  We would give it a 3 or 4 stars except my husband got food poisoning the last time my family ate there.  There was a small dish of 3 beef balls that were pink inside.  He ate one before realizing the rawness.  The rest of us luckily did not eat it.  He got sick that night with nausea, stomach pain and diarrhea.  We have not been back ever since.
author: G D.

description: Great lunch or dinner time place. They're great for take out to come to think of it. This is always a great place to take the family for dim sum. Most recently we went around 2:30 and there was almost nobody there. We enjoyed a nice quiet dim sum lunch for 3. The food here is always good. When they get busy the service does take a little bit of a hit but as expected.
author: Anthony M.

description: Watch out if you order a pick up from their online menu. The website prices are the old prices but you find out the new prices when you get there to pay for and pickup your meal.  Complained at the time and he said, "oh that's our old website." "Check our updated website." The only website I got was the one with the lower prices. Didn't offer to pay me different....which was a considerable amount of $. What a scam!!!!!
author: Sandra B.

description:
Enjoyed the dim sum, very tasty.  Especially liked the shrimp and chive.
Had to wait 20 minutes for a seat.  It's a very busy place.
author: L V.

description:
Yo where all the Asians at? Hahaha

It was strange because most of the patrons eating here where white folk or white folk related. They charge a bit more than other dim sum places and not much variety. I was surprised they served chicken feet but I only saw it once and they brought it directly to our table (they must know pinoys love chicken feet LOL). We kept ordering the same items after that and they served the items in trays instead of carts. Service was really good though and the place is clean.
author: Christian C.

description: Good tasting Chinese food. A little on the expensive side, but you know what they say, you get what you pay for.
author: Andrew W.

description: I'm sitting here now. I've been here for 30 min and I've asked for water 3 times before it came to me. I ordered the shrimp and spinach dumplings and they were awesome. The shrimp stuffed crab claws were ok. The pork buns were also really good. Over all, my experience was ok. Food decent, service stinks.
author: Dabrielle L.

description:
What happened to you Ton Kiang, your food is terrible!! I've been coming to your restaurant since the 80s, granted I haven't been to your restaurant in the last 5/7 years... But I expect everything to be if not the same very similar.  Boy, were we WRONG!  
We order chicken soup with watercress and tofu, it was a little too much stuff and not enough broth but overall good..
Then we had rock cod with black bean sauce,  salt big chicken, and stir fry veggies.  In addition to a few dim sum dish.  
The steam beef ball was overly marinate in baking powder which had a weird gummy consistency and overall terrible aftertaste.. (Restaurant use baking powders as a meat softener, if done correctly it can be very well use and standard practice ). 
Rock cod with  blackbean sauce again marinated in baking powder and it tasted disgusting why did you have to do that it's fish for God sake you do not need to soften it.  
The salt bake chicken, overcooked, need I say more!  
Only thing that was decent was the stir-fry vegetable of course, how can you screw that up.  
Most of the food was just left behind because it was just not appetizing and nor edible. 
A very disappointing dining experience at least the company was good...
author: Jeni F.

description: An A-OK dim sum place. This place has authentic cooks and waiters (i.e. they're Asian and Cantonese speakers), but they cater to westerners by having their waiters speak English. I my opinion, being Chinese, it detracts from the authentic experience of having a crowded/bustling restaurant, rude service, and predominantly Asian clientele.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Our friend who is new to the city insisted on going to Ton Kiang since she heard that it had great dim sum.  We got to the restaurant first and immediately noticed several things.  First, in a city that is 35% Asian, the fact that there was not a single Asian patron was suspect.  Second, the servers all spoke English.  Third, they were surprisingly attentive.

Three strikes and you're out!  Do you know the golden rule about how to pick a *good* Cantonese dim sum restaurant in SF?  If the restaurant doesn't look dingy, is not filled with Asians, and doesn't have constantly loud shouting voices--which coincidentally is just normal Cantonese conversation--then the food cannot possibly be good.

The interior was pretty decent, but dim sum is all about the food...  Problems: Shrimp dumplings that were rather dry and not very warm, lotus sticky rice lacked flavor, and the Westernized menu sorely lacked dim sum essentials like chicken feet.  (Note: you can order off-menu and request traditional dim sum items because the dinky English menu at the table barely suffices.)

After telling some SF Cantonese residents where we went, they were shocked and said, "You really went there?  That place caters to the non-Asians."  I don't think we'll be making it back anytime soon...
author: LandJ S.

description:
I have been here a few times,both have been great.However last time they seemed a little skimpy on certain things. 

The dim sum is definitely good, not the best.I ts rated in Zagat as one of the best in S.F. I don't know if I completely agree with that.The dim sum was not as good as the first time I went but still tasty.We also ordered an order of general Tao chicken last I was there,I thought it was very good but it was hardly any actual chicken, definitely was not enough for 2 people( I still don't think it compares to the General chicken at Tai Chi off Polk street)but it was still very satisfying taste wise. 

Service is good,it can get a little busy in there and sometimes it takes a while to get certain dishes,however that's understandable.The restaurant is clean and they maintain it very well. 

I still think this is a great place and would want to come back particularly with a larger group to try different dishes and dim sum.
author: Shannon H.

description: Not sure why this place is so positively reviewed. Dim sum was below average for the area and pricey. Hong Kong Lounge I or II is a much better experience!
author: Pearl L.

description:
Ton Kiang isthe fall back Dim Sum restaurant when my parents come down from Oregon.

The place is clean (though seemingly stuck in 1983), and all the staff speak English.  This is not usually something that I look for, but I also don't need to have a staring contest between the staff and my parents, because they don't understand each other.

The food is like a greatest hits of Dim Sum.  Rarely do I find anything on the menu that's unoffensive.  If its a shrimp dumpling, it looks and tastes like a shrimp dumpling.

If you want something of a nice intro to Dim Sum (especially for out of towners), you could do a lot worse!
author: Michael M.

description:
Baby are you down, down, down, down, down? Downnnnnn? Downnnnn? 

Been coming here for 10 years, and sadly, Ton Kiang has very much gone downnnnnnn over the past few years
author: R C.

description:
I am so happy to have visited my first dim sum restaurent in The Richmond, and think that Ton Kiang was an excellent first choice!  My friend and I went for their Meal 1 option, which allowed us to pick 9 options from the menu. I have never been surrounded by such a plethora of delicious food! In the end, we couldn't finished it all, no matter how much we wanted to.

I guess I have to pick some favorites, although I loved it all. I would go for the shanghai meat dumplings, pork buns, and the mushroom and shrimp dumplings...phew, that was hard! Decently priced, and oh so delicious. Such a fan!
author: Bridget B.

description:
Super duper expensive for dim sum place that is not even as elegant as Koi Palace.
The har gow was a joke. Miniature size, there were not even a single whole shimp inside because it was mashed up mixed with other fillers.
Ha cheung fun had small shrimps but outrageous price!

Most patrons were non-Chinese and most waiters speak perfect English - really the opposite of many other dim sum places (Mayflower Hong Kong Lounge, Koi Palace, King Wah, etc)

The worst thing is: This place seem to be the only dim sum place that hides their price. No menu list. No price shown. Don't people have the right to know the price of any item they would like to purchase?

I don't speak Chinese but my partner who speaks it told me that the waiters spoke loudly in Chinese complaining about the big group table of white family being stingy on tips.
I do not condone bad tipping but why complained loudly for others to listen?

I am not sure why this place still exists with numerous competitors around.

Crazy price but mini portions!

Gotta try Golden River dim sum next door one day.
author: H M.

description:
I don't like to think that I'm particularly picky about food. I grew up eating dim sum every weekend in Chicago. It all tastes great and pretty similar to me, but since I'm forcing myself to make distinctions between the various dim sum places in SF, here goes:

This is one of those touted "must try" places in SF in the ranks of Hong Kong Lounge, Mayflower, and Great Eastern.  Out of all of those, this place was probably my least favorite.

I always get chicken feet everywhere I go. If there was only one dish I could order, this would be it. Here, it was flavorful, with a nice mild touch of spiciness. The meatiness was substantial on the bone. My only qualm is that the marinade it was in was a tad too gelantinous.

Jelly fish is also another dish that I like to order, usually not on the standard dim sum menu. Here it was a bit too thick, and chewy. It didn't feel right to me.

The service here was good. Maybe it helps that I speak Cantonese? ::shrugs:: They don't have pushcarts of dim sum, but instead the servers carry trays with just 3 to 4 dishes of each item.  It's still as fun as choosing items off of pushcarts, but with the perceived benefit of it being fresher.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Delicious!

Pea Shoots still felt very fresh, not too heavy on the sauce. Yum.
Shu Mai were the best I have ever had. So were a couple other things I don't know the name of.

Unimpressed with the pancakes (greasy) but then I never really seem to be fond of them anyplace...so maybe that's just me. 

Pork Bow was also not the best I've had. I usually want 2 for myself and I was happy with half of one.

Most things very very yummy and we had a great Sunday brunch. Definitely would go back but also will switch it up with other Dim Sum places so I can have some of the items that I didn't think were of the same caliber here.
author: M B.

description: We recently ordered take out from Ton Kiang.  Dim sum and a vegetable dish and orange chicken.  We were enjoying our meal until we found hair and many bugs in the vegetable dish and orange chicken.  Small winged bugs and little beetles.  I called the restaurant to let them know...  They were polite and asked me would I like a credit back for these bug infested dishes.  I felt they should have taken my name and number and had the owner talk to me if the owner was not available presently. I had the feeling, it was just ok thanks for telling us and good bye.  I hate to say it will not be coming back after many years of going to Ton Kiang.
author: Nikita F.

description:
Ton Kiang does not need my review, but they are getting it anyway.  My favorite dim sum place in our Gray Area thus far (from San Jose to Oakland to SF).  It is unfortunate that I can never remember their name when sharing this information with friends.  Luckily, my phone can always help me with my memory.

     (tip #1) It is a good day for dim sum when our bottoms are parked at a table right outside the kitchen where all the carts must go by our table first. 
  
    Who am I kidding?  EVERYDAY IS A GOOD DAY FOR DIM SUM!

     Yank Sing can suck it!!  Don't like their prices anyways.  Dim sum should be affordable, and this place is. (tip #2) Don't blow your wad on the first few carts that roll by either.  Pace yourself for the varieties of yumminess that will follow eventually.  

     Everyone seems to judge Dim Sum places by their ha gao (har gow, ha gau-spellings seem to vary greatly).  If this is the case, then TK should be pleased with their offerings.  I love the supple texture of that dough between my teeth as I  gingerly bite into the little pillow of shrimp happiness.  Myself, I use the siu mai as the litmus test for quality.  My biggest complaint is usually size.  In my opinion, larger is not better in this category. Siu Mai that requires 2 bites of my petite-in-stature mouth do not make me happy.  TK does not disappoint with their bite sized dumplings.  I love popping those porky morsels into my gaping maw whole!  Size=just right.

Yeah,  and their other Chinese food ain't bad neither.
author: C B.

description: We love this place - this is the place for dim sum, and we come here every time when we fly up to SF for a short visit.  We found TK, because it was highly rated by the Lonely Planet Guide when we first visited the City.  And it has never disappointed us either!  Everything cooked at this restaurant tastes fresh and is made with lots of care and attention.  It's definitely busy with large groups wanting to eat at this establishment, so get there before the usual eating hours; otherwise, be patient and expect a longer wait time.  But you will be rewarded for the wait, because the food is SO GOOD!  I've eaten dim sum in Chinatowns in Chicago, Boston, San Diego, and this place is one of the top best.  And it is not super greasy and filling like other typical Chinese restaurants, which suggests that they use good cooking oils.  Their sesame balls with red bean paste filling are so delicious at the end of lunch - it makes you want to do the Snoppy dance.  Keep up the good work!
author: Susie D.

description: Very inexpensive, pretty standard dim sum offerings, fast turnaround, overall liked most of what I tried. Cons: too much shrimp in everything - more variety in the filling of the dumplings would've been nice. Also had to ask for water. Will probably go back if I have a hankering for dim sum, but it didn't blow my mind and I don't think I'd wait for a table if I came back at a really busy time. It was good, glad I tried it, might be back, but overall I won't go raving about it to friends.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Very greases

Base only on thier dim sum which was fablous ,an tastes was so fresh 

But thier chow maien was way too greasy which I would give half star ....
author: Seaera T.

description:
My favorite dim sum place in SF.  

Fast, not greasy, served with carts like traditional dim sum.. still authentic (you can get chicken feet) excellent sauces that go with stuff.  some staff even speaks english so if you forgot your Cantonese you can still get what you want.
author: Gabriella C.

description: Not sure why I always come here on Sunday. Its always busy on sunday morning especially after 12pm when the after church crowd arrives.  I like the little placard on the table that shows you the ingredients and shape of the dim sum they offer. Workers come by your table and show you what they have. The atmosphere/crowd is a mixture of Caucasian and Asian people. It's a little higher class and the prices are not cheap. However, i would recommend coming here because the quality and taste is good.
author: Jeff C.

description: Far too small of a menu for dim sum. Pricing was good, service was decent, food was ok... Not a bad option if you're local, but I won't be coming back in a city with a ton of options.
author: Kenny S.

description:
EHHHH overrated, imo. 

The inside is very clean and nice - which kind of already made me think it wasn't going to be delicious. Dim Sum always tastes better when you're in a dirty hole in the wall. no? 

We ordered dim sum - the any 12 items for $50. Overpriced. Not that great. There wasn't absolutely nothing special about the dim sum.  The only thing i thought that was better than other dim sum places was the shrimp stuffed crab claw. mmmmm. but honestly, it wasn't bad - it just wasn't delicious as hell. 

Oh, the service was really slow as hell too.  One of the worse chinese services I've experienced. 

Especially for the price, I don't think it's worth it.  Why not go down to clement and get some better, cheaper dim sum.  

YAY for CLEMENT ST!!
author: Anna C.

description:
I've been eating at Ton Kiang and ordering takeout from them  since 1989   and after last night's meal..I feel compelled to write and say that something has changed drastically....
maybe its the chef or they are cutting costs...but .the lemon fried chicken and the shrimp walnuts which were always my favorites were limp, lukewarm and greasy. We had one other dish....a vegetable dish and it was greasy and limp too.  

Very sad because I always thought it was a little expensive yet I would keep buying their foot occasionally on weekends cause it was so good.  

It was really bad last night....I hope they fix their problems....not good now.  Owner take note!
author: Marcy M.

description: Frankly, I'm hard-pressed to understand why this place is so popular.  The dim sum is I suppose only average and in general the larger dishes off the menu are drowning in oil and/or disappointing.  I am not difficult to please, nor am I a whinger, but I give Ton Kiang ZERO stars for service.  Welcoming?  Friendly?  Polite?  Forget it!  You'd think wait staff might demonstrate a modicum of good manners and civility if for no other reason than the hefty prices, but sadly no.  p.s.  Be prepared to pay an additional $1 for your cup of tea.
author: Tree C.

description: Our go to place for great Chinese delivery! Always hot and delicious!
author: Chris C.

description:
Came back to try more shrimp dumpling items.  

On the Big Eats SF list is:

#62 Shrimp and Chive dumplings -- GOOD!

* putting a check mark next to that *
author: Janice C.

description:
Don't want to sound racist, but only white people would pay these prices for dim sum; hence all the white patrons here. Us frugal (read: stingy) Chinese folk would never pay this much for dim sum, regardless of how delicious it is.

I mean, Ton Kiang does have pretty good dim sum, but very overpriced. I forgot exactly how much I paid, but I do remember wanting to throw my wallet at the waiter's head, because it was so ridiculous.

The service was pretty decent for this place -- they were all pretty attentive and there were tons of Chinese ladies running around with trays of chicken feet, shrimp dumplings, and egg tarts. 

Definitely not worth the price, though.

The food was actually above average for dim sum. The chicken feet (my favorite) had a good texture and sauce. The shu mai and shrimp dumplings all came out steaming-hot and delicious. The sauteed pea sprouts w/ garlic had a great flavor. 

Definitely not worth the price, though.

I will give it 3 stars because if you just received your annual work bonus and are willing to splurge like a king, then you may very well enjoy this place. For me, however, I can get better dim sum for half the price.
author: Roy C.

description: This is by far the BEST Dim Sum restaurant I've had the pleasure to dine at.  Well worth the wait at any time!
author: Toni S.

description:
Funny, little place. Let's start with the dim sum: mediocre, definitely no msg, kind of under seasoned. Adequate selection. Not over steamed (source: does not stick). 

It's true. There are barely any people with canton heritage or even Asian heritage here. It's actually quite hilarious. I saw a girl scoff at me from the table next to us when we got an order of shrimp crab claws. Obviously they're on the fence about "authenticity." 

The servers were attentive. Though, they would direct all attention at me while speaking Cantonese.

Quite hilarious indeed.

I suggest to never come here at 2pm. Wont be seated until 3, and the selection of food becomes more scarce. People seem to get seated immediately as they trickle in after 3, too. Ah, it's just my luck, i guess.
author: Margaret S.

description:
I ate hear a long time ago, and now I remember why I haven't been back.  The dim sum was just meh.  Portions are small and its expensive compared to much better dim sum places in the city.  

The selection was ok, but they didn't seem to have as many items as other restaurants.  I didn't see any bean curd, intestines, or tripe...you know...the regular weird stuff that Asian people like to eat.  They did have chicken feet( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/amU3hEJke5anv35WJ6zwnA/l ) which I finally tried, and I must say I'm not a fan...its just a bunch of chicken skin with bones....I'll pass.

I was very disappointed in the Shanghai pork dumplings( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/KAITYSAwXty5ILsmIrWdTw/l ).  The skins were too thick, and there was barely and juice inside.  The two dishes that I liked the most were the crispy noodles with beef( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/UPZ3fbtc1qxgglYy3Iowsg/l ) and the egg custard rice cakes( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/kRJKEueUalumpmIaWe_igg/l ).  Nothing else stood out to me...just your average, overpriced dim sum.

Three hours and $18 later, I'm hungry again.  Look at how small these dumplings look in the steamer( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/u7-nvqgy1gPf5EvrOMh6TA/l )....you could fit 4 more in there!  

Service wasn't that great either.  Every time we wanted something, we had to ask twice!  I won't be back here unless someone drags me kicking and screaming.
author: Patra I.

description:
The Dim Sum is a tad above average but nothing amazing. The Dim Sum menu is limited but the service just sucks! I enjoy going to eat here because their normal menu is quite appeasing to me, but i am lucky if i can get out of their having had 2 glasses of water. I dont know what it is about drinks that they just lag on but dont plan on satisfying your thirst here. Beer, water, sake, dont plan on having a drink for 15 minutes after you have sat down. 

The chicken wraps are amazing and I do thoroughly enjoy the Chinese food here, but the service is horrible. If you don't have patience I wouldn't bother going.
author: Derek F.

description:
This is my favorite place to take people for dim sum on the weekends (for sit down--for take out, we like Good Luck Dim Sum). 

Here's why:
- ingredient quality, while not out of the ballpark, is much better than other Dim Sum & Chinese restaurants
- they have a huge selection of items and they consistently come around often with different choices--no deadzone, even upstairs
- they have a lot of vegetable choices--I like to get my greens on and not just stuff up with pork and bread
- egg yolk custard rice cake pancake thingies. they're way too sweet like a marshmello for some people, but I love them, and they're always served warm

It's not cheap per say, but if you have four or more people, it's very affordable. I wouldn't recommend bothering for less than four for dim sum service.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Funny, I had forgotten I'd gone here almost 2 years ago, and I actually have a Yelp review on it!?!

Well, I went again. It was super expensive. Siu Mai and Har Gow was decent, but over all, the price greatly exceeds what you are getting, and I guess in the past 2 years, I've ate at several other places around the world, and I've gotten pickier, or I would better characterize it as more discerning, so I'm dropping it a star.

Also, the xiao long bao came in little foil cups, ewww. I hate that.
author: Boris C.

description: I came in the morning for their dim sum and was quickly seated for two. Nothing was too out of the ordinary or below standards. Sadly, I have nothing more to add about the food, but if you my suggestion is that it's worth a try.
author: Danny P.

description:
You know how sometimes you go somewhere to eat and the food is pretty tasty but the company is pretty rocking, so the overall experience gets bumped up a notch? That's what Ton Kiang was for Richard, John and myself. After waiting 10 minutes and wondering if they would come outside to call our names, they eventually did and sat the three of us at a huge round table all by our lonesome selves. 

Within *seconds* of sitting down, a woman approaches us and asks "fried calimari?" Yes, please. 

5 seconds later: "Pork buns?" Yes, please. 

25 seconds later: "Eggrolls?" Yes, please. 

1 minute later: "Shrimp (something)?" Yes, please. 

Dim sum was invented for hungry and open-minded eaters. Everything came in quantities of 3 or 4 so they're the perfect size for small groups. A bill stays on your table that they mark every time they deliver a dish so you can keep track of the total as you go. 

The variety here was pretty great. We only saw a few repeats go by; otherwise everything was new and fresh. But of course soon as we pay and get up to leave, they start busting out some crazy fruit dishes and fried shrimp. Where were those earlier, Ton??

I wish there were more sauces at our disposal (Sriracha, Hoisin, Plum) but we only got small amounts if they were paired with the dish we selected. 

I also wish they kept the front door closed. After much deliberation, I realized the gusts of wind weren't coming from between my legs. 

And I wish they sent me home with someone. Wouldn't that be the best Dim sum slogan ever? "Come and eat more, leave with a whore."

Hmm... I might be alone on this one.
author: Jared S.

description: Was very pleased today, Ton Kiang dim sum Sunday was excellent!  The quality was fresh and tasty. So happy!
author: David B.

description:
WHITEST DIM SUM PLACE YOU WILL EVER GO TO. 

We got 2 items and tea before we decided to get the hell out. It cost us 12 bucks before tip. Go to Yet Wah instead. It's just down the street . Unless you can't eat dim sum without the cheater menu.
author: Joyce Man H.

description:
Good but not great.  That's the feeling I left with.

First feeling you get when you walk in is a warm inviting feel as wait staff is friendly and the place is clean and polished (but doesn't have a new/aseptic feel as in too sterile, but an older traditional clean feel).  Table cloths are white and has a upscale without being haughty ambiance.  Most of the clientele here were westerners (not a lot of Asians), and the menu somewhat reflected it.

Waitstaff was friendly and polite, but not too helpful in selecting dishes.  But food did come out fast and hot.

The dishes were good and tasty, but lacked the fresh ingredient taste I appreciate with living on the coast.  We ordered their seafood hot pot which did come out good, but again tasted as if it was taken out of the oven just a bit premature (food was cooked well, just lacked the taste throughout all the ingredients).

Vegetables were tasty and cooked very nicely, and probably was the best cooked dish here (hollow heart vegetable or on-choy).  The rice here was excellently done and came out hot and fresh for us.

Prices were a bit on the high side, but I think they can justify it due to the name recognition this place gets.

Overall a good Chinese restaurant that you'll probably get what you came for, but given the tons of other options in the area I'd personally prefer to go somewhere else.
author: Andrew Y.

description: Absolutely delicious...highly recommended! A relative did heavy research and this is reputed to be the best Dim Sum in SF...and it was. More like...Dim Yum!
author: Alex M.

description: A must do Comfort Dim Sum place when in SF.  The people are terrific,food is fresh and always tastey! The daily items circulate and you choose as they pass.  If you want something special, just ask & they'll make it to order, just for you.  Today my favorite was a chicken and spinach dumpling.  Not too heavy for dumplings and very flavorful.  Dim Sum day and night!  Love it.
author: Mimi C.

description: I don't recall every Chinese meal I've ever eaten (including movie and Chinese on Christmas) but if this wasn't the best it was damn close. Recommended by a friend and cannot thank her enough. Best $45 I can ever recall spending on dinner for 2. Shrimp crepes, steamed BBQ pork buns, sizzling rice soup, onion cakes, Mongolian beef and Chinese donuts. All fantastic. Well worth the $30 uber ride from union square.
author: Jordan C.

description: What a gem of a place tucked away on Geary.  Get the pork buns, shui-mai and the snow tipped peas for sure.
author: Natarajan S.

description: What happened to this place?? If you want something more closely resembling authentic dim sum, head to Hong Kong Lounge a few blocks away.
author: C K.

description:
I am not sure I understand all the criticism.  Overall, I think this is the best place for dim sum in the entire Bay Area.  The quality of the food, atmosphere, service, etc. are far better than Koi Palace, places in Oakland Chinatown and elsewhere.  And the prices, while not super low, are much better than Yank Sing.

Minus one star for the terrible parking situation.  I'd recommend that you park far away and take the No. 38 bus.
author: Jane D.

description: I love this place for dim sum.  I have been eating here for years.  Some of the food can be a little too oily but if you pick well you will have a great experience.   I especially enjoy almost all the dumplings, stuffed eggplant, fried whole shrimp and pea pod tips.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Like the 2 stars text: Meh, I've experienced better.

I seriously think Ton Kiang is overrated.

My friends and I came here on another friend's suggestion one early afternoon. We walked in and were seated in a few minutes. We got to our seats and I found the first indication of Meh-ness. There was a little card in the middle of the table explaining what each dim sum dish was. Call me an elitist Chinese dim sum eater, but that card with the explanations just destroyed any cred this restaurant had in my mind.

The food itself was okay, I'd give it 2.5, maybe 3 stars. The xiao long bao wasn't juicy enough and the shrimp har gow was dry, that was extremely disappointing. 

After we had a few dim sum dishes, we decided to order some beef hefen. I ordered in Chinese to the waiter because I think in Chinese in Chinese restaurants. After I said what I wanted, he gave me this look like I was crazy and said, "Sorry, I don't speak Chinese. I'm Korean". Um....

Normally, I'd have to say that service must be good for a place overpriced like this. No, service was pretty bad. We could never find our waiter, he was totally MIA when we needed to order. The restaurant was clean, but the combination of high prices, poor service, and mediocre food overshadowed that.

Go to Chinatown or Oakland instead.
author: Viola L.

description:
I do not understand all the good reviews of this place.

I went here expecting decent dim sum and was immensely disappointed. The food was way overpriced, very small portions, and not good. Also it is perhaps the least authentic Chinese establishment I've been to in SF: they give you water without asking, charge you for tea (and make you ask for it), and lay out forks on the table for guests before they arrive.

What?

My recommendation: do NOT go here if you actually like Chinese food. If you have no idea what Chinese food or dim sum is like, you might like it until you go somewhere else.
author: Brian O.

description: I can't believe I've never heard of this place! Dim sum place that doesn't close to 2:30 or 3.. awesome. They also have an extensive menu. But best part is that they are open all day. Oh, and their food is pretty awesome. The crab claws were wowamazing. We ordered several from the menu and also flagged down servers walking around with trays of dim sum. Very satisfied and will definitely be back!
author: Vol T.

description: Came here today, and it was delicious.  Constant streams of food offerings, the best were the shrimp & chive dumplings, and shrimp & scallop dumplings.  The BBQ pork buns are really good, too.  Worth the trip out to the Richmond.
author: Mel G.

description:
So, I really wanted to give Ton Kiang 5 stars. I mean there was like a whole birthday party of authentic-looking Asian folks upstairs and the first floor had only one table of caucasians (besides myself of course, but I don't count). The problem was that halfway through my supper, two MORE groups of white people walked into the restaurant in succession, so that ruined everything. zero stars.

Now that I've summarized 90% of the yelp reviews for this restaurant, let me just say that the food here is pretty darn good. I should mention that I've never actually ordered Dim Sum here. I usually stick with the seafood options, and they're all great, especially the squid. They used to pair that up with hot peppers in szechuan sauce, but I like the XO sauce/snow pea option that shows up on the menu now instead. The clam, fish and prawn dishes are all pretty amazing as well.

Yes, the prices are a touch higher than your typical place, but that's a reflection of the quality of the ingredients, especially the seafood. And you won't see any "NO MSG" signs anywhere.

I realize that this is not one of the trendiest restaurants in San Francisco (thank you, Michael Bauer), but if you're more interested in getting tasty seafood than name-dropping restaurants on your match.com profile, give Ton Kiang a try.
author: Owen R.

description:
One of the most popular Dim Sum restaurants in SF, and a favorite of my family for many years. Unless you come in early, there's usually people waiting outside on weekends.

All the wait staff speaks English. And most (+90%) of the customers are non-asian (don't let that deter you). In the past most servers were bilingual (chinese/english), but recently I found that many of the new servers don't speak ANY chinese. This could be a problem for customers that don't speak much English.

Prices are expensive, and all Dim Sum items and portions look small (demure) in comparison. But the quality of the ingredients is usually much better (sometimes less greasy) than many other places. I'm not going to say that every dish is the best, because that's not the case but most have been good. I find that it's also a good place to bring people who have never tried Dim Sum before. Note that the most expensive Dim Sum plates are the vegetables (long beans, chinese broccoli, asparagus, etc.) because they are supposedly the most tender hand picked pieces. They also have a regular menu in case you want to add items like chow mein, roasted duck, etc.

In my opinion this is a good choice to celebrate special occasions. We came here to celebrate Mother's day last Sunday. The criteria used to select this Dim Sum place was:

- don't want sticky tables
- don't want to squeeze thru narrow spaces or constant bumping into people
- nice decor and clean location
- professional and pleasant service AND good tasting food

Most asian customers prefer to go to places like: House of Banquet, Lee Hou, Tong Palace (all on Clement street), because of their cheaper prices and more authentic experience. I really like all those other places, but they didn't meet my criteria for this occasion.
author: Luis C.

description:
Is this review just an excuse for me to brag that I met Ming Tsai here? Maybe. And if I hadn't, I might have rated Ton Kiang four stars--I didn't sample enough really to rate Ton Kiang five stars confidently. But I'm going on Ming Tsai's word that this place is better than Koi Palace. 

Anyway, so yes, as other reviewers have noted, there were an awful lot of white folks for a good dim sum restaurant. I mean, when I'm more Asian than most people, that's a bad sign. I also saw Ton Kiang featured once on Martha Stewart, the whitest woman on the planet, and that did not bode well. BUT, it was 3pm. A time when no self respecting Cantonese is going to go for yum cha. (It just fit my schedule to meet a non-Asian friend then). Because it was so late, we planned to just order off the all day dim sum menu--and did, before we realized that the server was STILL coming around with dim sum plates. I was impressed. I've been seated at Koi Palace at around 1 (having arrived sometime hours earlier) and had them stop coming around with dim sum. And what we did have was good. Unfortunately, there were just two of us, which meant we tried fewer items. I particularly enjoyed the don tot and cha sui bao. 

In case you are not as big of a Ming Tsai fan as me, he's the chef owner of Blue Ginger in Boston, one of the original Food Network chefs before the Food Network stopped caring about trained chefs and invested only in home chefs with a taste for diner food, and now has a PBS show called "Simply Ming." He's also a contestant on Next Iron Chef. Anyway, after he sat at the table next to ours, I got up the courage to go up and say "hi" (without having the courage to ask for a photo) and in the minute or two while I stammered something about my mom being a big fan of his and trying for years to get a reservation at Blue Ginger, I learned that 1) Blue Ginger just expanded to double its size and 2) Ming Tsai really enjoys the dim sum at Ton Kiang and prefers it other popular places in the area. (On his way out, he stopped by our table and said, "Say hi to your mom." That made my mom's day). 

Parking is also good in the Outer Richmond (although you'll need to get up to feed the meter) and I found the prices reasonable.
author: Susan S.

description: This place is terrible.  They use way too much salt and I think some dishes might have been frozen before since there was way too liquid in the dumplings.
author: Dani H.

description:
I had one of the worst Chinese dinners in my life here last night.  Panda Express would have tasted and looked better, and would have cost 1/5 the price.  The Mongolian beef looked like some sort of brown, gelatinous, meaty blob.  The walnut shrimps had not been deveined.  The pot stickers, well, I never knew you could have such dry, chewy, skins.
Never got fresh tea. Was served water glass but it was never refilled.  They took away half of the appetizer plates and left the other half on the table for 2 courses.
I've been coming here for over 20 years for dim sum, since I was in high school.  Used to be so fresh, delicious and beautifully prepared.  It's such a shame.
Never coming back. Stay away and save your money.
author: Deann F.

description:
Exceptional dim sum...and family friendly to boot! 

My family loves this neighborhood, and I suggest getting there before 11am on a Sunday for on street parking.  

Like the other reviews mentioned, there appear to be a lot of tourists here (like my family), but there also appeared to be a good mix of locals as well. 

The 2nd floor seems geared toward larger groups, and those containing children..we felt welcome here, and the servers were all friendly, and would gladly explain in detail what each dish was..also, the wait staff were helpful and efficient.

Now onto the food: very fresh, flavorful, and well presented..we had:

- sticky rice
- various shrimp dumplings (of which the best was the spinach & shrimp)
- hot fried shrimp
- sesame balls
- meat dumplings
- fruit cup (a nice offering in dim sum for the kids)

This was more than enough food for 4 people, and the bill came to about $50, excluding the tip. 

Highly recommend this dim sum, and a nice place to take out of town guests.
author: Marie C.

description: Worst dim sum place ever. The shrimp dumplings smells rotten. Everything else was miniature. Dont come here
author: Ernie P.

description:
My sister in law introduced me to this place when I loved to SF. Best to go at a slightly off hour as peak hours draw insane crowds and you'll be waiting in line.

Do it like this. Whatever it is, REFUSE the first three dishes that come your way because what happens is you tend to fill up on stuff and then other things come that you want after you're already full. So pace yourself. The Spicy Shrimp is a must try.

The only reason it loses a star is because the pricing system is rather bizarre. I had meat dishes that were reasonably priced at $3 a plate but steamed asparagus was $6! how does that work? You can end up with a big bill that way!
author: Ash S.

description:
What is this.....dim sum for ants?!?!? 
Their har gaos and siu mais are a little too tiny for my taste. 

I came here by default, because there was a 1-2 hour wait at HK Lounge -  probably for good reason. Arrived here and got seated right away. Certain dishes were good (the foil-wrapped chicken & the shrimp-stuffed eggplant). Everything else was just mediocre.

To top things off, a fresh batch of deep-fried taro dishes came out just moments after my mama had already asked for the bill. I literally had been waiting for those the whole time. This is why I much prefer places that allow you to check-off your order rather than have carts and trays of dim sum wheel on right past you...... Needless to say, I left disappointed.
author: Denise L.

description:
There are 2 secrets to enjoying Ton Kiang.
SECRET #1: Eat a very small breakfast or don't eat breakfast at all so that you can go early and skip the ridiculous line! I'd suggest 10:30-11 am and go on a weekday if you can.
SECRET #2: Don't let them seat you upstairs! It always feels like everyone downstairs (near the kitchen) gets all the prime pickings!
---Follow these simple instructions and you'll be sure to love your Dim Sum and return for more!
author: Tessa R.

description:
I went to this restaurant for lunch today, and ordered tea, chicken curry and chicken and pork fried rice from their main menu.
   The service was very slow indeed and the food was watery in the extreme. They serve your dishes on large dinner plates but give you a side plate to eat off. Spoons are provide but they seem to resent being asked for a fork. The staff and in particular the head waiter were rude and ignorant.
    I left the restaurant without eating anything.
    One of the worst restaurants in San Francisco - and I advise people to avoid it rather than subject themselves to poor food and bad service.
author: Robin O.

description:
Good dim sum in a comfortable location.

Came here with a friend early on a Saturday morning after going to bikram yoga class nearby and had a nice dim sum brunch experience. I was researching for a close location which would be open earlier in the morning and found Ton Kiang. There is another dim sum restaurant right next door which seemed more popular but my friend out-voted for this one.

You have the option of ordering from their menu or selecting items from the servers who bring items by. We ordered a few items off the menu including classics like: shrimp dumplings, beef rice noodle, shanghai dumplings, and steamed bbq pork buns. We also ordered the lotus rice wraps but they were not able to prepare them in time for us. I wanted to try a few other items that I saw circling the restaurant but we did not want to stuff ourselves that morning.

We got there early so there was no wait and service was solid...but as we sat there the restaurant started to get packed. I always recommend getting to dim sum when the restaurant opens to avoid excessive wait times. 

The dim sum was pretty good but the selection was not that wide and unique which I would appreciate more. I would return for a well-rounded pleasant dining experience but not for any particular dish. 

I actually want to try the restaurant next door next time :)
author: Lisa M.

description:
Good dim sum at a reasonable price.

Chicken feet could have been steamed a bit more, but they were tasty!

Service was efficient and fast. Not sure what more you could want from a dim sum place.

Good selection. Pai good wasn't to my liking but I have seen other places serv it like that before. Spicy fried calamari was awesome. Har kau shu Mai were the same as everywhere. Pork buns we're yum! And the sesame balls were piping hot and tasty tasty.
author: Kym P.

description:
This review isn't about the food. What I managed to get was fine, perfect for what you expect of dim sum.

This review is focused on the service. My friend and I arrived before the big lunch rush on New Year's Day. I expected busy, and a wait, but what I didn't expect was that the servers would consistently and repeatedly bypass our table for the other side of the room where there were large tables of 6-8 people. A couple of stops there, and they'd scurry off with an empty tray. Every time we ate something, we'd have to wait and wait for a server to pass with something we wanted to eat (that wasn't donuts, egg custard tarts, or mango pudding!). Eventually, we managed to order a few dishes, for which we waited over half an hour before giving up. Over the course of more than an hour, I don't think we had more than 5 dishes. The steam baskets (with dumplings and bao) kept passing by and around us, so we mostly wound up with veggies and fried shrimp.

I'm not sure if this is a consistent flaw here, or just one driven by a busy day, but having been in the city as long as I have, I know that Ton Kiang gets huge lines on weekends, so they should be accustomed to busy days.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Last time I went to Ton Kiang they had lap pat dok comin' round on the carts. Burmese fermented green tea leaf salad, only one of my favorite dishes of all time! Such a happy surprise!

I like the food at TK better than Yank Sing as far as your swank dim sum goes, it just seems cleaner, lighter and healthier.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
We were here right as Chinese New year was starting and it seemed to be THE place where all the locals brought their families to dinner. The place was packed and as soon as a table emptied it was cleared and another family instantly appeared. This seemed to hold true for the upstairs and downstairs dining areas.

I was bordering between three and four stars on this place. The food was delicious and the quantities were great once we finally got it. They were busy and our table definitely got forgotten for some time after we were seated. 

Not your typical cart style dim sum experience, but overall worth checking out.
author: Jessica K.

description:
I haven't had a bad experience at Ton Kiang. We're usually seated fairly easily, the prices are definitely fair, and the food's good. 

Best dim sum in the world? Well, no.

But pretty good? Yes.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Thinking about this place makes me laugh, this is not a place you go to eat Chinese food and frankly, the recommendations in restaurant guides this place gets baffles me. Sure, i've eaten here and while the food is not inedible, i do not recommend it. The food is overpriced and is a poor representative of what Chinese food should and can be. Their ingredients are poor quality and they put more fat than meat in their items. 

Overall, i would say don't come here. If you don't see many chinese people at a restaurant, that pretty much says it all.
author: Iknowasianfood C.

description:
Funny isn't it, that people  in San Francisco are thought to be culturally and Gastronomically avant guard, and yet when a dim sum place is a bit different, and includes Hakka foods, it is thought to be  - GASP- too non traditional.

Well lah di dah!!!

Let us put aside these petty critic,  and give praise for --
speed of service, cleanliness, and yuminess.

I particularly linked the Eggplant stuffed with shrimp and the crisp asparagus  and the dumplings stuffed with spinach- oh, I could go on.....
author: Elle C.

description:
One of my friends looooves this place, but my other friend and I found it really lacking.  Their selection is so small and when we went, the dim sum didn't taste freshly made.

I don't know if it's because we went at a later time, but there were no carts rolling around.  We had to order everything off the menu.  For me, part of the experience of having dim sum is to anticipate what's behind the curtain.  I admit I usually get the same things, but sometimes I'll see something that I haven't seen before and that I'll immediately have to try.  

It's like a shopping sale.  You see that cart coming, but you see it stopping at other customers, but you want that item, you're anxiously waiting to make sure you get that item, but you see it's going like crazy...and oh oh and AW YEAH!  Score!!  TIme to devour!

There was none of that here.  In fact, it was kind of dead.  So in conclusion, this place is a pass for me.
author: C A.

description:
OVERATED

Expensive dim sum. $5 for a plate of shrimp rice roll. 

Dim sum is not that great, there are sooo many places better than this place.

I haven't eaten dinner here but my dim sum experiences are so bad I rather not try.
author: Erica L.

description:
Yes, you will have a difficult time trying to find parking.
Yes, the wait on a weekend can be frustrating.
Yes, the key is arriving at around 2-3pm on a weekday to get quick seating.
Yes, sitting by the door is not ideal - you will catch drafts; your food will get cold quickly.
Yes, service is almost nonexistent - and you will need to target those servers who seem the most pleasant, and the most genuinely interested in helping you out. Good luck.
Yes, you will have to ask for things 2 or 3 times, including: water, tea, take-home boxes, and the bill.

Yes, the dimsum is tasty, and worth all of the above most of the time.
author: Claudine C.

description:
I've been going here with my mom forever, usually on weekdays b/c weekends just get so crowded and crazy. We always get the same things: a vegetable dish and the special: salt baked chicken. you MUST MUST MUST try this chicken!!!! moist, soft as a cloud, and salty. mmmmmmmmmmmm you MUST try this at least once!!!!

also, im chinese, but you must know that the people who eat there are usually white. why is this? b/c they got a food review many years back that made them very famous with the white community (or so my mom tells me). whenever i come here, we are usually one of the few asian diners. maybe b/c the price is a little steep and the place is too fancy for a casual night out. on weekends the place is more busy and more chinese families come. overall, very clean, quiet, great atmosphere, and all the waiters speak english. lovely place to relax. if you come in a little after lunch hour on weekdays, i can guarantee that the place will have about 5 tables full and you can eat your yummy food in peace and quiet
author: Vicky T.

description: Love this place for dim sum. We travel from Palo Alto just for the Shanghai dumplings. Everything is delicious, fresh, and prepared exceptionally well. We take out of town guests here for a true dim sum experience and everyone has loved it.
author: Jennifer A.

description: Terrible service!  LONG wait to order, LONG wait for the food to come out, and half of our order was forgotten all together. Btw... They were busy but not slammed, plenty of open tables. My husbands meal got to our table 10 minutes after mine, we were so hungry by this point we shared mine. Overall, worst service I've had in SF.
author: J C.

description: An absolute 5! I love their dim sum and the pork buns are especially amazing--they seem half fine french, buttery bread and half delicious savory (with a hint of sweet) barbeque pork. I also love and recommend the calamari, the pork (and ginger?) dumplings, the greens, and surprisingly the donuts.
author: Sharon G.

description:
Not bad for a dimsum place. Nice location aka plenty of parking around it (although it's metered). The food's yummy and the prices aren't bad. My only downside to this place? The odd service. First, they have you order off a menu (no problem there) but then they don't bring out your order. Instead, waiters who carry around items will set down what you want if it's on your ordering sheet. Otherwise, you just have to wait. So all I ask is, what's the point of pre-ordering if I'm just gonna wait until the ladies come around with their trays? In the beginning, we had a small wave of food that came. And then nothing....for a while....until we asked...and waited...and asked again, and waited again. 

Maybe I went on an off day but when I eat dimsum, I like to have a plethora of choices in front of me. Waiting around for more dimsum while picking at what's already on the table kinda makes the whole experience a little less fun.
author: Diana Y.

description:
We came here for a post-funeral dinner.  The food was OK, a bit over salted.  The white-chopped chicken was rather bland.  I liked the jellyfish and meat slices appetizer plate but not some of  the other dishes which tasted tad oily, too much gravy. The yee-mein (noodle dish) which arrived near the end of the meal was very tasty.  
I've been here in the past to try their dim sum which wasn't as good as Yank Sing's and I can't seem to comprehend why this place made it on Mike Bauer's SF Chronicle top best Bay Area restaurants in the past.  I don't think the food is that great when you compare it to other restaurants on the list.
author: Ry T.

description:
While my wife and I were in San Fran we definitely had it on our to-do list to get some  great dim sum.  While there were many places to choose from, many of the highest rated places were take out style establishments that really looked like a hole in the wall.  That's all well and good but we wanted the sit down experience.  We opted to try a place called Ton Kiang which was on the way from our hotel in SOMA to Muir Woods were we planned a hike.  The place was easy to find and we got there right after they opened.  After we sat down we were really disappointed to see that this was a "no cart" dim sum place.  We decided to be good sports and ended up ordering from the list of dim sum left at the table.  The food came out quickly once we ordered and WOW was it great.  I've never had dim sum as fresh as what I tasted at Ton Kiang.  As we got through our first course of both steamed and fried shrimp and pork dumplings, we noticed that people were steadily streaming into the place.  As the place got busier, so did the servers.  They started bringing out platters of dim sum and offering (with an explanation) what they had.  This was sort of a mini cart style service to me.  I noticed that much of the food offered on the platters was not on the menu.  Together with what was brought on the platters and what was on the menu, Ton Kiang offered much more variety than what it seemed when you look at the reviews and menu on the internet.  

The quality of the food was so great we ordered a lot more than we needed in fear that as the place got packed (and it's a small place) the service and quality would go down.  This never happened.  We noticed that every dish was carefully inspected by an older gentleman that sat near the kitchen door.  He later turned out to be the manager and clearly had an eye for quality and made sure that everything stayed on par as the crowd picked up.  The servers stayed attentive which is not always the case at most dim sum places.  

The prices were reasonable especially considering that we were in San Fran and the level of quality the food was.  

While there are several larger, and much more crowded dim sum places in the city that are popular with visitors I really can't stress enough to not overlook this little gem of a place.  You will not be disappointed.
author: Michael L.

description: Tdim sum tasted like Costco appetizers.  No wait, that's being too hard on Costco appetizers.  A couple of things were pretty good-the vegetable crepe was good with fresh vegetables and the shrimp dumplings.  Everything else mediocre to downright terrible ( the crab claw-a big chopped-up tasteless fried nothing).  So disappointing -limited time in SF-came because I saw that t was one of the "best in the city"-  feel very cheated out if a great meal in a great food city.
author: Nina B.

description:
Food was decent to good, but there was a poor selection of Dim Sum. We were there during what should have been a peak time (just before noon on a Sat.) and there were times when for 5-10 minutes nothing came out of the kitchen. The Dim Sum trays also routinely passed our table without stopping by. One waitress was very nice and asked what type of dumplings we were looking for and then found those dumplings for us, but another server was not as pleasant. It also took more than 10 minutes to get the check back after laying down our credit card. 

Not sure what has happened to this place, but it seems It's time to end our yearly tradition.
author: L And E.

description:
Yummy but expensive.  Oh and small portions.  Oh and it's far from where I live. Oh and parking's a pain.

So where was I?

Oh that's right.  It's yummy. Well, ok. Most of the time. On some of their dim sum (like on the pagow) they put a little too much roe on top -- probably to justify their prices. I dunno.  I'm not convinced that Ton Kiang is all that great of a place.  It's a place to impress guests with higher end dim sum.  But it lacks in the making me happy department and that's what's most important of all.
author: Henry L.

description: My daughter and I came separately the end of July and thought the items not as good as the past and way more expensive...making it not a delicious value lunch any longer...The veggies are mostly $6.95 and one quickly gets to over $25 for 3 items even if eating alone. I have been there many, many times over the years but times change.
author: Sue Ann R.

description:
Quite simply the best dim sum i have found in SF, and i am very picky about my dim sum. And at around half the price of Yank Sing, it's worth trekking out to the avenues for this one. I took my friends from out of town and they are still gushing about this place. Watch out for the prawn and eggplant ones, and the pork chung fun. The snow pea tips with garlic are also great. The prawn chung fun is the only one that's not quite up to scratch.

And they deliver after 5pm!
author: William C.

description: The food is fresh, the service swift. I will definitely come back. The only issue is the price, they are a little pricey for lunch but a special occasion and the awesome food counters that
author: AJ H.

description:
I'm not sure whats up with all the negative reviews of this place..  I've been to alot of dim sum places and I think Ton Kiang is competitve with most of them. I've never really had a bad dish there.. and they always have such a wide variety of things. My favorite thing there is the egg custard cakes.. no one makes them better than Ton Kiang.

Food : 7/10
Service : 8/10
Ambience : 7/10
author: Henry W.

description:
Always good.  I know people think it's too Americanized, and the tea leaf salad is an odd addition, but order traditionally and you'll get the real deal.

The steamed pork belly with mustard greens is an oily mess of fall-apart, dark meat layered with equal amounts of fat and skin.  And it's delicious.  If you would eat pork belly at a new-American restaurant, try this salty, unusual dish.

Honey Walnut Prawns, my absolute favorite food at certain restaurants, are not overly mayoed or cloying, and served with a pile of walnuts on the side.  Crisp, mild and solidly good, just not exciting.

The Peking duck is reassembled to a rough duck shape, beak-less head included.  While this is slightly unnerving, and the meat is a little too soft, the skin is crisp and the flavor is good.  Our buns were under-steamed though, and doughy in the middle.

The famous pork buns are a little sweet for my taste, but the filling is real meat in larger pieces.

You can order dumplings all day, and there's mango pudding.  When we ordered donuts at 9:30, when there were few others in the restaurant, the eggy, almost hallow, granulated sugared balls still came out hot.

Fed 8 people (plus days of leftovers) with Peking Duck for about $200 (including tax and tip!)
author: Laura S.

description:
We went to Ton Kiang with our friends who live nearby for lunch while visiting SF. Coming from Colorado dim sum, it was a great experience. 

The service was fast, the food was hot (for the most part, our green onion pancake was cold which made it doughy and cardboard-esque) and our water glasses were always refilled.

I must say that I wish Ton Kiang had one of those red light/green light batons that they have at Brazilian grill houses to indicate that you are FULL for the moment and to please stop slanging dim sum, especially after you just asked us not 2 minutes ago if we want what we just declined!

I digress. The actual dim sum were great. The Shanghai dumplings were hot and delicious, Chinese donuts were yummy too. I don't know all the names for the dumplings but the shrimp, veggie and pork were all fantastic. 

I don't know that Ton Kiang would be my first stop for dumplings in SF.  Next time I visit I'll do a little more research and see if there is another place that has better reviews.  All around a good experience but certainly not a 4-5 star.
author: Rachael B.

description: Was in the mood for some dim sum and decided to try this place out for the first time. The service here was extremely slow, we were seating at our table for about 15 minutes before anybody came and asked for our order. Servers walking around the restaurant holding plates of food going around each table asking if they wanted some of whatever they are holding and they would always skip our table. It got to the point that we just wanted to get up and leave. Ive had way better dim sum and for way cheaper. I should of known this restaurant was going to be terrible when I only saw Americans and not one Asian person eating here.
author: Julie F.

description:
Hakka cuisine is not Cantonese cooking! People who are calling this Cantonese do not know what they are talking about!  If you expect Cantonese dim sum you will be surprised at this out of the way Hakka cuisine restaurant. The food has a  taste that was original but not Cantonese.  Hakka is Fujin. They do not speak Cantonese. 

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hakka_people

They are called "outside people by most Cantonese. " This is the equivalent of hillbilly in American slang. 
The initial immigrants from China and Hong Kong to San Fransisco were Cantonese. But more recently there are more Fukienese  in San Fransisco and they have learned to cook Cantonese dim sum but not authentically. Kind of like a Mexican making sushi in NYC but not exactly. 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinatown,_San_Francisco

I would give it 2 and a half stars but because it is in San Fransisco I give it 3. For those who are not native New Yorkers FYI New Yorkers believe San Fransisco is the only other sophisticated city in the US. So we have respect for San Fransisco. 
Having said that this restaurant is not in China town. New York City has 4 China towns and one new one developing. I really do not like any of them. Manhattan's China town is okay but I love the China town in San Fransisco. It is much cleaner than ours and more picturesque.
 I was not frequenting Yelp when we went and I had checked other food guides for the "best dim sum". This was listed. We had much better in China town in San Fransisco. So I suggest if you want true Cantonese dim sum to stick to China town in San Fransisco. The food is good don't get me wrong but it is not classic dim sum or classic Cantonese. 

"There are only two questions about food. Is it good? And is it authentic?
We are open (to) new ideas, but not if it means destroying our
history. And food is history"
- Guiliano Bugialli
author: Pinky And The B.

description:
After passing by this place numerous times and seeing the crowds, I would have thought it would have been well worth the wait.  I couldn't believe how dissapointing the dim sum here was.  Some of it wasn't very fresh and most of it was not authentic.  Mayflower, Koi Palace, Dim Sum King... I can name soo many more places that have comparable prices and wayy better quality dim sum!

To name a few.. The shrimp rolls were pretty mushy.  The potstickers didn't seem fresh.  The Shanghai dumplings were not very fresh and lacked the soupiness inside.  They were pretty dry.  Although I didn't try the hot and sour soup, my friend got a bowl and barely even touched it.  Everything was very average or worst.  The little bowl of fruit was good, but did I mention it costed over $6! 

I would never come back here again.  The service and atmosphere was decent, but the food was pretty bad.  

Maybe for someone who doesn't care for authentic dim sum or wouldn't know the difference, this place would be okay.  But having tried many places, this is definitely a waste of time and money.
author: Tramy V.

description:
My Ex would say that this is hands-down the best Chinese food in the Richmond District (and there are a lot...). I used to think it was greasy and over-priced, but I have warmed up to it over time.

We used to get take-out from here once a week. They have excellent shu mai and Hong Kong style chow mein with BBQ pork. The Dim Sum here is the best for sure. YUM!

Yeah, I'm going to say that this is definitely one of my favorites in the area. I always think about straying somewhere else, but end up right back here.
author: Rachel G.

description: This review is from me, a neighborhood Lofan (yeah, I know the word. haha) Good restaurant but no CHOP SUEY. What gives? We Lofan love our Panda Express and Chop Suey. AMIRITE?
author: Mindy H.

description: Ok dim sum but the entrees are not good. Bad service.
author: AK K.

description: No carts but people bring trays around. Egg custard rice cake was great. Sesame ball was only OK.
author: Joel G.

description:
I eat a lot of dim sum in quick chinese cafes and sit down places and would say that Ton Kiang is one of the safer places to take friends who are new to the experience.   I mean you can take them to Yank Sing and turn them off dim sum by the high prices or to Koi Palace and never get in (why the wait's so long I still don't understand), but if you take them to Ton Kiang you know you'll get some great tasting food without breaking the bank.  

Definitely go earlier to avoid the crowds, or drop off your friends at the front to put your name in while you drive around endlessly looking for parking in the Richmond.  In the end it will be a solid meal and after that you can take them to more adventurous places.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Pretty good dim sum if:  pricewise, you watch what you eat and you are not looking for anything very authentic (i.e. curried foods, chicken feet, etc).

good place to take those who are new to dim sum.  It's clean and has pretty good service.  Portion size is small, though.
author: Shinny L.

description: I used to come here all the time. There would be a long line. Today, no line no wait. Something is wrong. There was nothing to eat. No chicken feet no tripe no nada! I asked where the food was and the Waiter said customers dont order that. I didnt understand what he was talking about when it dawned on me that we were the only asians in the restaurant. Now I understood. A whole new clientle. Food was terrible but service was good. Goodbye to a once favorite place.
author: Rod W.

description: Here again for a birthday party with 15 people - had a wide variety of food and potions - everyone enjoyed the food and the ambiance of the restaurant
author: A M.

description: Late lunch on a Saturday, & the food seemed to be better than I ever recall it. One of the keys, if you're a novice, is to *not* say yes to every dish that comes along. Be selective. They probably will be back with more of the same (and it's best while it's hot!). We started with tea & the best Green Onion Pancakes I've ever had. Great flavor, wonderful texture, not greasy at all. Perfect accompaniment to our dishes to follow, which were: shrimp dumplings, shrimp & snow pea dumplings, shrimp-stuffed mushrooms, & shrimp-stuffed eggplant. (Sense a theme here? We don't usually eat poultry or red meat.) We also had a nice plate of asparagus. We finished this incredibly satisfying meal with some egg custard tarts (these, as well as the sesame balls & mango pudding, are great little, light desserts.)
author: J R.

description:
I love it here. I crave it!

I first went here with family and ate, and ate, and ate .... and ate!

Not much has changed since then.  I almost view Ton Kiang as two separate restaurants.  It is great for dinner after a long day at work and it is great for dim sum for a cheeky Saturday lunchtime. 

Highlight for me is definitely the pot stickers - I wish I knew how to make them at home.

I've never come here in a rush, but I've also never felt like I've been kept waiting.

Try it for yourselves!
author: Richard G.

description:
We came to this restaurant at 9:00pm on our last night at San Francisco. Initially, we were thinking of having dinner at some other restaurant which we didn't end up finding. After 40 minutes of walking, my legs gave up and god, was I hungry. The bf knew we had to find a restaurant soon because I completely shut down when I'm hungry...I don't talk or smile...I zone into space.

We got in and there were 2 tables having dinner. We thought to ourselves, "Let's be the 3rd table because three is a crowd..." We ordered 3 things: 

- Crab Maw Soup ($9.50) which was very good. The soup was pipin' hot and the crab meat was not soggy. It was good meat. This crab maw soup was also different from the other ones I've tried...this one was extremely colorful. It had yellow corn, green onions...it made it even more appetizing. Love, love, love. 

- Ginger onion crab ($30). Here in San Fran with Chinese restaurants, the crab/lobster is based on unit while Vancouver is based on weight. No big deal but I like noticing these differences. The crab meat was rich and abundant. The crab was fresh but man oh man, lots of oil. 

- Braised E-fu noodles with Enoki mushrooms ($13.50) - I love e-fu noodles and mushrooms...come on, who doesn't like mushrooms? If you don't, don't tell me...I'm not going to listen. Anyway, this was not what I had expected. The saunce was different from the types I eat at home and was quite bland. The noodles were different...they were like rubber-band type of material. Definitely didn't go well in my mouth. We didn't end up finishing this and it wasn't worth the ~$14. Lame-o. 

3.5 stars out of 5.
author: Polly C.

description: I unfortunately did not enjoy my experience here (great company, bad food.) The food was oily and tasteless.  The only dish I did enjoy was some sort of wilted spinach which would not be worth the trek out there.  Skip it.
author: Leigh W.

description:
Yuck! What happened to the good quality food? We came today for dim sum (which I was so looking forward to) and all we got was grease and more grease with a heaping of salt. All of the items, even the pea sprouts were covered in this shiny layer of grease. The only thing I liked was the white rice and the steamed pork buns (because it wasn't fried). 

Checked off my list to go.  Very disappointing.
author: Natalie S.

description:
For Dim Sum this is one of the best places around---I take friends from out of town & they love it.  Not the cheapest place around, but it's great for Dim Sum.

But one of their best-kept secrets is the Salt-Baked Chicken.  I don't know why it's called that because it's basically steamed chicken--just melt-in-your-mouth moist.  It comes with a ginger-garlic dipping sauce.  Yum!
author: Jerry R.

description:
Should you "dim-sum-it-up" @Ton Kiang? OH YESSS!! This is another SF 7x7 recommended spot crossed off the list....and the food is good!! Double score! 

It's located on Geary Avenue, right across the big church. The restaurant is fairly big, very clean, and airy open-spaced. Patrons can opt to dine on the first or second floor.

Dim sum here is fast and gooooood. My Yelper bud & I shared about 7plates easy. The food was tasty & the company was awesome that I forgot to take pictures of the food! Oh well, I guess I'll just have to return & dine there again soon.

Some of the memorable dishes we shared:
*breaded crab puff balls (very meaty)
*garlic asparagus (nice fresh veggies to munch on w/ your dim sum) 
*shrimp stuffed eggplant (eggplant, my fave!) 
*shrimp & green chive dumplings
*bite-sized egg custard tarts (golden, flaky, w/ just the right amount of creamy custard) 

Bottom line: I will definitely be back for more dim sum!! It cost us about $20+ each. It doesn't quite break the bank like Yank Sing does & it's just as yummy!

Tips:
*It tends to get crowded, especially on the weekends, so opt for early dining.
*Parking is metered so be sure to bring plenty of quarters.
*If you are doing the SF 7x7 list, Ton Kiang is a few steps away from Aziza & Tommy's Mexican Restaurant. Drop by Tommy's for their signature Margarita!
author: Joy A.

description: This is a common stop for us. I do love it. It can get a little pricey but there really isn't a better place I have been to for Dim Sum. Whenever company comes to town, we seem to end up here.
author: Bob R.

description:
