Came here last fall with my cousin and her family.  They suggested a family dim sum at this restaurant.  My aunt did all the ordering and though none of it was the familiar standard dim sum, it was all really good.  A lot of seafood was ordered, but that makes sense as that's what it's known for.

My aunt and uncle were both really happy and since they're both Chinese and she's a really good cook and critical restaurant eater, I took that as a good sign.

3.5 stars

Probably the nicest dim sum in the city.  I think the food is better than Yank Sing and it has a less "corp lunch" atmosphere.
author: Jean K.

description:
Good dim sum! I'd love to break it down for you, but I can't remember the name of anything!

Great service, very friendly and helpful waiter.  We were a loud and obnoxious group of bachelor party-goers, but they just smiled and kept in comin'!  

The ambience, however, really sucks. It feels like I'm at the set for the "Wedding Singer". It's got that sort of hotel-ballroom feel that made me feel like my meal would be followed up with some pillow mints and candy almonds. I'm sure that's what they were probably going for, but still, it felt plastic. 

Good food though!
author: Richard G.

description:
The good:
Sizzling rice soup was fantastic.  So was the eggplant with shrimp.

The bad:
The tinfoil chicken was gross.  Lots of chicken fat and very little meat.  The pea shoots were tasty but greasy.  The duck was too salty.  The rice was slightly undercooked. The service was cold, impersonal and rushed.  

It was Christmas day, so everyone was trying to get in.  I get that this is probably an unusual situation for this restaurant.  It would have received 2 stars, but I want to give it the benefit of the doubt.
author: chad H.

description: I went there for Dimsum sometimes, My dad loves here so much and he always talk about it. I personally love roasted duck cuz the skin is so crispy. The dumplings are great. The service and cleanilness are way over chinese restaurant standart.
author: Ben C.

description:
It was Chinese New Years and so what better way to celebrate it than to eat dim sum!!! My friend told me their was good dim sum in the Richmond, so we headed to Ton Kiang. 

I have eaten a lot of dim sum in my life, so when I ordered my usually dim sum feast I went into shock... Everything was like 1/2 the size of regular dim sum places - WTH!!! It was like eating midget dim sum... So after eating a lot of tiny tiny dishes, which was like getting us half full we decided to get out of there. After ordering my usual amount of dim sum for two, I never pay more than $20-30 tops. Here the bill was like $50 for midget dim sum - OH MAN... Really... I could have gone to Koi Palace instead for that price.

Is there good dim sum in the city without having to travel to Millbrae - NOT!!!
author: Minh V.

description: Favorite place for dim sum in SF.  Prices are reasonable, service is fast, and the wait staff isn't pushy.  It's zoo good. Parking can be tough, but it's doable.  Mostly metered on-street parking.
author: Kenyon S.

description:
PROS:
- The food tastes OK. I had the sticky rice wrapped inside banana leaves which was OK.

CONS:
- Unlike other comparable dim sum places, this one didn't have carts with food going around. Instead, you have to order from the menu without the benefit of seeing the food beforehand.
- I came to this place on my trip to SF because I saw it on a must-eat list in a newspaper. I have to say it didn't meet my expectations. 
- There is only street meter parking.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
not bad for a chinese food...i like their salty chicken...the steam fish...the other two dishes that i ordered i forgot...

CONCLUSION = RECOMMENDED!!
author: Aris L.

description: My husband and I come here for dim sum.  It's really our favorite in the city. The quality is really good, the service is fast, and we always leave satisfied.  Our favorites are the various dumplings.  We order one of each!  It can be hard to find parking here during peak dim sum time on the weekends.
author: Julie P.

description:
Summary: Decent but expensive dim sum. Overrated.

Higher-end dim sum place with nicer decor and higher prices, but similar food to many other nearby dim sum places.

I wouldn't go back unless I had a good reason to, e.g., if a business associate wanted to have dim sum and we happened to be out in Richmond. Otherwise I'd rather go somewhere better value and closer to me.
author: Gary Y.

description:
a little pricey than what it s worth but if you dont want to be disappoınted when you go there thıs place is the one you can count on..at least they are not sometımes good and sometımes bad but always good...
parkıng may be a hassle sometımes..
author: Ali D.

description:
Had dim sum here and was very disappointed. The food isn't fresh, over steamed and the duck was extremely salty. For the price I paid here, I'd rather add a few more dollars to the bill and head over to Yank Sing for a fresh and delicious dim sum breakfast.
I had dinner here once. While the food wasn't bad, it was an Americanised version of Chinese food.
author: Prague G.

description:
My family LOVES LOVES LOVES dim sum (me included), so it only holds that whenever they come and visit me we ALWAYS go out to DIM SUM. We usually go to Yank Sing or some place in the Asian Market  in Emeryville. We decided to try Ton Kiang after it was recommended to my father by some of his co-workers.

The crowds really weren't that bad and Ton Kiang gets points for being closer to where I live but while the food is quality, its not up to my standards.
author: Sarah S.

description: Dim sum was amazing. A constant flow of yumminess flowing to your table. Get there early though as the queue gets long very quickly.
author: Yannick L.

description: I appreciate Ton Kiang because, for the most part, they get their dim sum right - and they're everything Yank Sing is not.  In fact, the quality of the dim sum here is probably comparable to Yank Sing (maybe slightly better and fresher), but I don't get that rip off feel that comes with dining at the FiDi.  Though I end up spending the same amount, I tend to get better value, more bang for my buck.  The pork dumplings here are really good, as are the pork buns.  Actually, I don't remember ordering anything I did not enjoy.  Service was also excellent.
author: Angel S.

description:
Came here for dinner last night. We ordered sticky rice (bleh) and pork and shrimp dim sum (pretty good).

Next we ordered crispy combination noodles. They weren't my favorite but they were pretty good. Once the sauce soaked in the dish was good. The boy loved it, I was indifferent.

Friend rice was good. Perfect fried rice.

I will be back. Glad to finally have found decent Chinese in the city, apparently I've just got to to the Richmond to get it.
author: sierra s.

description:
yay i'm a fan of this place!!!!!

i don't really enjoy dim sum and not a particular fan of it until....... this place where my friends took me to. WOW!!!!!!

having had dim sum here, i am now a fan; but only here. any where else i will not set foot in. 

this place is unique and special, at least to me! :)

it's a very prestine and clean atmoshpere which i love! the service is excellent and the food is to die for!!!!

from the deep fried calamari to the eggplants with shrimp all the way to the sticky rice and the green tea salad. need i say more.....

try this place out cause it is a totally wonderful place to have dim sum!!!!!
author: Mae M.

description: Not bad for standard Chinese food but on the pricey side for what they serve.   Their banquet offerings are on the high side so you can order ala carte and get a pretty good meal for a large group.  For Thanksgiving we came by for a 2 pm meal for 9 adults.  It was crowded, perhaps with others looking for an alternative to the traditional Thanksgiving meal.   Fortunately we had reservations.   We ordered a variety of dishes including standard stuff like sweet and sour pork , stuffed tofu, walnut prawns, Peking duck.  Some of the dishes were very fresh and tasty.    Some were average.  Some were heavy on the salt.   Clean and pleasant surrounding and attentive service above your average Chinese restaurant.    Prices were on the high side so this might fit for a special occasion.
author: Bad News S.

description:
This place is actually pretty good.  The service is great and they are constantly coming around with different foods.

It is very difficult to find parking around the area and the prices are a bit higher then the usual dim sum places ... but you get the quality so it's an even exchange.

You can also order from their regular menu with dim sum, or just do one or the other ... you choose.
author: Pia V.

description: Really solid dim sum place. Fast service and tasty food, and doesn't feel like a dive at all.
author: Rosalind O.

description:
I think I remember having good food here many years ago, but this certainly isn't the case now. 

I should have taken the hint when I walked right in and got a table immediately without any wait on a sunday morning. The cha siu bao had very little pork filling, the lia wong bao were so over cooked the yellow custard was like the yolk in a hard boiled egg, the crispy pork was mostly bones, and most of the dishes where just flavorless. I can't remember if they ever had full carts of food here but now the servers walk around with trays that have very limited choices. The only cart I saw was for congee. Maybe they're cutting corners or maybe they're catering to a non asian crowd. Either way there's decent dim sum in SF and this isn't it.
author: Mark R.

description: Decent to good dim sum. Plus side = you can decide to go on a random late weekday evening after trying dim sum at another place that someone suggested and fails (starts with an H). EXCELLENT for a first-timer, just OK for those who've grown up eating dim sum in all sorts of places around the world (pretentious much?).... Definitely a good idea to stop here if you're in the area and craving dim sum.
author: Asha S.

description: Came here only b/c it was on the 7x7 list, but I have to say I was disappointed... not sure why this dim sum place is that special, but I didn't think the dishes were better than other places I've tried.  The service was really nice though...
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Always a must visit when I'm home visiting family. 
Favorites: 
Rice wine squid with pickled veggies
Salt baked chicken
Seafood claypot


Definitely NOT my go to place for dim sum.
author: Tania C.

description: Greasy yummy dim sum goodness.  Cleanliness uncertain. But still. Much love for Ton Kiang.
author: chloe w.

description:
I used to go to Ton Kiang when they were a hole in the wall approx 20 years ago.  Ever since they got all that publicity from Yan Can Cook, they've gone Hollywood and the experience hasn't been the same.

If you have to go, make sure you sit downstairs.  I made the unfortunate mistake of taking my mother there and they sat us upstairs right smack in front of their windows.  Yeah the view was good but we didn't get served!  It appears that they walk limited dishes of dim sum out by tray so by the time they get to us, they usually ran out.  After about 30 minutes, my mother cussed out the maitre d in chinese about the lack of food coming our way (the only stuff that made it to our table got bypassed because they were Ching-lish dishes).  So finally they asked us what we wanted and delivered it to us.  Very subpar dim sum.  I liked it better when they were middle class hole in the wall!
author: Wendy H.

description:
Nice pretty clean dim sum place in the Richmond District.  The dim sum is the shittiest of all time.  I been to shitholes in chinatown that have dim sum that is 100x better.  Ton Kiang use to be good like 5 years ago maybe.  I just went recently and the food (all the food) were cold.  And the people were rude.  Come to downtown SF and go to Yank Sing.  

I wouldn't eat at Ton Kiang for dim sum again even if it was free.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Ton Kiang is the most over rated dim sum restaurant in San Francisco. 

On any given Sunday, you will see huge crowds outside waiting--but you barely ever see Chinese people waiting. (no offense.) The Chinese locals in SF are presumably good judges of what makes good dim sum. I suggest Mayflower or Yet Wah just a few blocks away from the over priced Ton Kiang.
author: Carol Y.

description:
We visited Ton Kiang last Sunday at lunch and I realized why it became less popular than it was couple of years ago as mentioned in SF Chronicle recently. It is not because people want to try new restaurants. It is because service is not good any more in Ton Kiang. You don't hear 'please' or 'thank you' from waiters, they don't pay attention that your tea kettle is empty. When we asked our waiter about tea it took him 15 minutes and a reminder from me to bring a full kettle. He didn't even say 'Sorry'.   Next day our guests that came from Europe ate lunch at Ton Kiang. They had shrimp dumplings which they liked and ordered 2 more portions. 20 minutes later only one portion was delivered and it was completely cold.
Our guests didn't realize that tips aren't included in the bill, they paid the bill and left. Waiter ran after them to the street and created a scene trying to explain what happened and insisting on tips. Our guests couldn't understand what the waiter wanted from them due to the lack of English. It was embarrassing and unpleasant.
I wouldn't recommend Ton Kiang to anybody any more.
author: Laura B.

description: This place is great. A little on the pricy side but its a fun place to take people if you want a great quality meal. Delicious dumplings
author: Jason G.

description:
Bee-sus, was I led astray on this place. Chowhound, Yelp, 7x7, they all recommended this place as one of the best dim sum joints in SF. We walked in for dim sum, and no offense, but when you don't see any chinese people in the place, that's a big red flag. It's not cart service, so you order everything using a menu. I'm fine with that, but when the dim sum comes out, it should be hot, right? Negative. We got the shrimp and chive dumplings, which are supposed to be a specialty, but they were average, at best.  Everything else was mediocre, and a lot of the things were pretty small portions.

The place is fairly spacious, so it would be good for a group, and also very clean. I dunno, but i'm used to dim sum places being chaotic. With the constant pressure of ordering, fighting for that har gow, everyone yelling for their favorite dish, I think there's something missing if I walk out of a dim sum restaurant not feeling like I've been assaulted. It's the chinese way.
author: Saunders C.

description: Expensive, poor service and mediocre dim sum. I don't know why people love it here so much.
author: Helen F.

description:
The first thing you need to know about this place is that the dim sum for two is really for 3 people.  You get 9 dishes and it includes 3 pieces each which is way too much food.  

The only things I really enjoyed here were the pork dumplings, fried rice, and the egg tarts.  

What I didn't like were the BBQ pork buns (way too sweet), pork steamed in rice and tea leaves and the shrimp balls...these dishes just didn't have the right flavors and textures.  

All of the other dishes were quite forgettable.  I would try someplace else in San Fran for dim sum.  

P.S. it was also really expensive for what you got!
author: Lindsey W.

description:
What to do on a late Sunday...drive to Outer Richmond and grab dim sum. 

-shiu mai
-bbq pork bun
-har gow
-shrimp/scallop dumplings
-mustard greens
-chicken & corn soup
-fried calamari

Everything but the fried calamari was great! Something about the calamari tasted as if they fried it in old oil. Ugh
author: Lola D.

description:
I had a hankering for dim sum and we moseyed into this joint.  I came here a long time ago, when this place was popping, but the glory has diminished since then.  We were promptly seated, but was tucked away in a quiet corner to be disregarded by most of the passing waitresses.  

We specifically ordered baked pork buns, which took forever and a day to arrive. We hypothesized the order was lost or disregarded and wah lah it arrived.  It was fresh off the oven! Hollar! A joyful moment came when steamed shrimp and leek dumplings were placed before us.  I was delighted because most restaurants carry the pan fried version. 

We were enticed by a Burmese dish; green tea salad.  There was nuts, tomatoes, shredded vegetables (cabbage?) and green tea paste of some sort.  The waitress mixed the concoctions before us causing a smile of anticipation that easily fell away from one bite.  It was simply edible.

I didn't pay much attention to the bill until the egg tarts arrived.  My mouth flew open in horror to realize a mini egg tart cost a whopping dollar! They weren't even the famous egg tarts, nor were they regular size!  This place is pricey!!! I could hear my Chinese mama yelling at me now. 

The unisex bathroom topped off my experience. I walked in and could not for the life of me lock the door. I pressed the button a few times, but gave up because the need to pee was urgent.  My pants were around my ankles, when a lady tried to find her way in. I screamed as she apologized and I pressed the button once more. BINGO.  It locked from that angle. Annoying. I needed to get out of this place!

This place was disappointing and the food was eh.
author: Amy L.

description:
My favorite dim sum place. The food is well prepared with quality ingredients. No overly greasy.  They offer a great variety of items. Don't overlook the vegetable dishes...they are delicious. 

Biggest drawback is that it's usually crowded so you should expect a wait, especially during the weekend. 

My favorite dishes from today's meal:
-roasted duck
-chinese broccoli withoyster sauce
-steamed asparagus
-sesame balls

Pricing is decent.  Our party of 6 ate pretty darn well for about $95.
author: Rita S.

description: Used to be the best Dim Sum in town with lines outside every weekend. No lines anymore. Enough said.
author: Tom J.

description:
Been coming here for years, on and off, and now it's about time I finally reviewed it. In the past, we'd never learn and foolishly come on a weekend, waiting forever for a table. Now, older and wiser, we ate here on a weekday during normal dinner hours and got seated immediately.

Getting to the point, the dim sum here is top notch. Sticky rice, assorted seafood dumplings, foil wrapped chicken... and when the sesame balls are fresh, they're fantastic. The seafood soup with bamboo shoot pith and the rock cod with black bean sauce are pretty damn good. You can get a bunch of quality Chinese food for less than $20 a head. Deal.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Went back to Ton Kiang today and felt the need to add a star. Maybe it was just our lucky day, but the first 3 items offered were exactly the 3 items we didn't want to miss (sticky rice, shrimp and chive dumpling, shrimp noodle). Yum.

Also apparently we were just pigs last time we came here and spent $40... this time our bill was just under $30 for two people.
author: Emily C.

description:
Solid dim sum, but small portions.  Very high prices.  Long wait.  Hard to find parking.  

I've been here twice, and I've always gotten to a point where you are afraid to order any more (because you've already spend more than you normally would spend on dim sum anywhere else), but you are still hungry.  I think I should be able to leave STUFFED and not spend more than $15, but that is not the case here.

All added together, 3 stars.
author: Cindy C.

description: I was a little weary at first but then I was pleasantly surprised.  Staff's English is not so good.  Pot stickers are to die for.  Hint of Ginger.  Bean shoots & asparagus was cooked perfectly!
author: Mikel A.

description:
I came here based on some 7x7.com list suggestion.  I was blown away.  Not by the food, but by the service!  For whatever strange reason, Ton Kiang has decided to train and employ dim sum servers who are extremely polite, always smiling, and attentive.  C'mon, we all know authentic Chinese food has to be served by someone who looks like they're in a rush to get somewhere!

Also unfamiliar to me was the set up of the restaurant, which was very spacious.  Tables were very generously far apart and the restaurant was on the quiet side.  Definitely no tables with multiple groups of people.  It was a pleasant surprise to the typical dim sum experience, which at times can be stressful in the heart of Chinatown (especially if you're used to Chinatown in New York).

Overall, the food was decent, which I judge based on the staples I grew up with (that includes chicken feet, turnip cake, tripe, etc.) but I think the biggest negative was the price.  The overall bill for 3 people came out to over $60.  It was a respectable amount of food, but I just can't justify paying $20/head for dim sum.  Something about that seems strange to me (I'm also looking at you Yank Sing).  Wait: Okay taste, expensive, and clean??!?!  Yes, yes, bai ren (guei?) love it. ;)
author: Mitchell L.

description:
Recently I've been on a quest to find a dim sum sit-down restaurant with good prices and quality and fairly easy parking.  We saw a write-up in Zagat that said Ton Kiang was a good dim sum restaurant and we decided to try it. It was adequate and appeared to cater to tourists and Westerners, but it is probably not someplace I would want to frequently visit. 

We arrived about 1100 on a Thursday morning and there was adequate seating. It quickly filled with patrons.  We noticed that customers did not appear to be locals, but tourists and light-weight eaters.  The restaurant is clean with white tablecloths (probably a mistake on their part).  The waiter came by and brought us tea ($1/person) which was essentially a pot of hot water with a few pieces of leaves. It was pretty weak tasting.

Servers were woman who carried trays and announced the offerings in both Cantonese and English.  Most of the items were in the $4 to $5 per plate item.  We started off with the typical har gow (shrimp dumplings) which consisted of 4 pieces for $4, siu mai (pork dumplings), also 4 pieces for $4, and baked pork buns 3 pieces for $4.  The dumplings were good.  The baked buns had a sweet glaze on top, which they could probably do without, but not much meat filling.

Our second round consisted of noi mai gai (sticky rice and chicken with lotus leaves).  This consisted of 3 small pieces for $5.  It had a smoky flavor (probably from the lotus leaf), but the filling consisted of mostly rice with small pieces of unidentifiable meat.  The server stopped at our table with some egg custards, but they look pretty dinky and we passed.  We finished off our meal with chive dumplings (shrimp and green onions), 4 pieces for $5.  They were round and pan fried and then steamed.  This was good.  However, it is a little misleading as it advertised chives, but consisted of green onions.  This dish was flavorful.

All in all, this place is okay - rather blah and sterile.  I would stick with the dumplings as that seems to be their best dishes.  We are still looking for the ideal dim sum restaurant.
author: Robert J.

description:
I came here several years ago, so maybe it has changed, but I doubt it 'cause when I went here they had posted a review for them from an American newspaper.

Their portions are TINY, super skimpy and EXPENSIVE. It is not worth it. It doesn't taste bad, but it's not good either. I have definitely had better and for much lower prices. They don't push around carts and you just order off a paper that has everything in English. The waitresses are all Chinese, but they speak to you in English even if you look Chinese. Their accents are horrible so you can't understand them anyway, even when they're saying the names of the dishes.

If you want good (but also expensive) dim sum, might as well just go to Tai Wu. I think a lot of American people go there too. You can always just point to what you want no matter where you go.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Although I haven't given up searching for the best Dim Sum restaurant in San Francisco, this place has taken the number seat thus far. Really good food and run Cantonese style, where the carts are continually making their rounds. The plates never stop. This is a good thing. 

There's also a lot of Asians in the two-story restaurant. Be prepared to wait a little. This is also a good thing.
author: simone H.

description: I can't give this place a fair review. A few years agoni came here all of the time  and loved everything from the dim sum to Chinese broccoli. This past time I went here I had a special diet I needed to follow. They were very nice to take a special request of just plain steamed veggies with nothing on them. It was good for what it was. The people I was with who were able to get more elaborate thought it was absolutely delicious and would for sure come back. I would for sure come back as well.
author: Natalie G.

description: Great dim sum. Service was a bit off though. Didn't know the ingredients, which was a problem because my wife has medical restrictions on what she can eat.
author: Brian R.

description: Hands down great dim sum. Great quality ingredients and fresh as can be.  I go here whenever I am in SF
author: M R.

description:
My experience with Ton Kiang can be summarized by a short Chinese phrase "Ngack gui lou" which loosely translates to "tricking white people".  That is the only explanation for how this place seems to end up on all the top ten lists for Dim Sum in SF.

The food is not tasty, not fresh and not authentic.  It doesn't taste like Dim Sum is supposed to taste.  I would avoid at all costs.
author: Alton L.

description: My favorite dim sum in the city.
author: Marcus K.

description:
I love dim sum and was so glad to be introduced to Ton Kiang by a friend. I liked it so much I went twice during my week-long visit.

The food is better than Chinatown dim sum and almost as good as Yank Sing. A few standouts: softshell crab, fried scallop and shrimp, steamed shrimp and chive. I had many many more :-)

The ambiance is more Chinatown than Yank Sing.

The price is more Chinatown that Yank Sing too - thank goodness.

Ton Kiang will be my new dim sum haunt when I visit SF!
author: David S.

description:
The premier Chinese restaurant! 
 I was introduced to to Ton Kiang by our Chef Instructor teaching us foods of Asia. And I don't ever think I've had better Chinese since! 
 Chef arranged for a sampling of dim sum and table foods. And since our class was a mix of all ethnic groups, everyone seemed to really enjoy-especially the only Asian in the group: me! 
 The courses were presented beautifully, not greasy, and made with amazing product! 
 Ton Kiang is always a must for me when in the Bay Area!
author: Troy H.

description:
So... we both have been a fan of Ton Kiang's forever... I probably went for the first time 10 years ago and been there 5 times over the years. We were a bit worried when we checked on yelp to find the reviews had turned lukewarm. This place used to have lines so long in the weekend mornings that if you didn't get there before 10am, you really should anticipate a 45min wait. But, we had to see for ourselves if the reviews were really correct. 

Oh man... we weren't even seated yet and my gal pal was already frowning. She is Chinese so she's our authority in the dim sum category... first of all, there was a line - not as long as memory recalls but that's good for us. However, the lady taking down the order of diners took another guy out of order in front of us and then just assumed we were with the guy. She was miffed. Then she called him first after she had corrected her and they followed her along their merry way. Nice. It kinda went downhill from there. We probably waited about 20 minutes. 

So to check out if the food is great according to Asian standards, one must look for the number of natives, ie: heads with black hair. Sad to say, the ratio of Asian folk to non was about 10% vs. 90%. The food was just ok- I'd give it a B. We had a variety of dumplings - shrimp with chives, shrimp with scallop, shrimp with something else, and shumai. Gai lan was good but who can screw that up?? Little spareribs with black bean, salt and pepper shrimp and finished with mango pudding. I don't know if they just don't put as much care into each dish anymore but it was just okay. Doesn't justify the prices either. 

We're sad to say we agree with a lot of the reviewers in that it's just not as great as the days when they were featured on the Martha Stewart show. Those days are gone.  

There was a long line on our way there along Geary at some place with an orange awning called Hong Kong something so maybe we'll go there next time.
author: Kuishingal F.

description:
We came here as it was listed in Frommer's as one of the best dimsum places in San Francisco.

When we entered it seemed like the place was filled mostly with tourists. (read: no Chinese customer in sight)

There are no rolling carts of dimsum but rather waitresses carrying trays of dimsum.

We had the hargao & siomai, which were pretty good.  The deep fried sea bass wasn't good, it seemed like it was fried a long time ago and then just reheated as it was extremely dry.  The deep fried prawns were also so-so as the shells were hard to remove from the prawn, seemingly stuck to them.  I think this happens if the prawns aren't as fresh.
author: Rossini P.

description:
So yes, this place caters to a more American taste, without getting into gross friedness and oyster sauce that every American-ized place does.  The crab claws with shrimp (Hai kim?) are the best in the city, I think.  The rice noodles with beef are delicious (the one's Ive had at "authentic" places are usually chewy and flavorless and overly greasy.)  The steamed pork buns are fine, though Ive had the same quality at half the price elsewhere.

Id recommend this place for someone new to Dim Sum - its clean, friendly, and everything I order is good (NOT the case in most "authentic" dim sum places).  That said, it is about twice the price of most dim sum.  :(

So while I wouldnt give 5 stars, and even 4 is pushing it, I think all the 2 and 1 star reviews are just people who hate Chinese food that non-Chinese have discovered.
author: Cassie P.

description:
Ok....so I've finally figured it out. Dim sum in San Francisco is just like Toronto....ya don't go dim sum in San Francisco proper, ya gotta get yourself out of dodge, (Daly City) in SF, (Scarborough/Richmond Hill) in Toronto.

But, if you're okay with mediocrity or just have that craving and can't make it out of town, then I guess you're stuck with Ton Kiang or Yank Sing in SF. 

Bummer. Ton Kiang is a very non-descript, small restaurant in Outer Richmond (west side). It is mostly frequented by non-Asian's who want to experience dim sum but perhaps don't want to deal with the bustle and commotion and abrupt service that most quality dim sum places have.

Nonetheless, the dishes are carried out on trays. The waiters, who are quick to give an English name, seem confused when I had to ask what it was in Cantonese. Most of the stuff is cooked fresh but it is not high quality (read possible previously frozen). Your staple har gow, siu mai were just barely ok. Nothing really to say but just disappointed because I expected something half decent given the raving (written by non-asian) reviews. 

I don't want to be too harsh but I want to make sure my fellow dim sum loving brethren don't get fooled. It is what it is.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Clean... Bright.. Open.. Plenty of seats... Lots of items... Affordable... Nice staff...

I am not sure what I can complain about....

I am sort of on a diet so I couldn't try everything... 

Everything we did eat was hot, tasty, and really good....

I would go back...... And have a smile on my face...
author: Joe B.

description:
We had dinner at Ton Kiang last night - all of us family members celebrating Chinese New Year. We had reservations, but had to wait about 10 minutes for our table. That was the last "down" note of our experience there.

We ordered a large variety of dishes:

Fish Maw With Crab Meat Soup
Golden Fried Squid
Ton Kiang Seafood Clay Pot
Braised Oxtail Clay Pot
Ton Kiang Crispy Noodles with mixed seafood and meat
Spicy Whole Crab
Dry Fried Whole Crab
Sauteed Rock Cod Fillets
Long String Beans
Some dim sum dishes - the usual stuff

I thought everything tasted pretty good, but I was wondering if my positive vibes about the place was unduly influenced by the fact that I really liked their oxtail. However, my wife - who likes oxtail but is not as big a fan as I am of the dish) said that she thought everything tasted good. For me, that is a huge endorsement, because I have eaten some meals that I thought were pretty good, but then she points out a few things about the food that I had overlooked.

Service was also good. The wait staff were always attentive to refilling our tea pots and glasses of water. They were prompt in responding to any of our requests (like an additional serving spoon or plate). When the waiter asked if we wanted dessert, I responded with a question about house (free) desserts. He brought back their special walnut cookies for everyone, then gave us more when we went through them like a whirlwind.

So to sum up, we WILL be back!
author: Alan Q.

description:
Overall, decent dim-sum.

More Americans than Chinese ppl.

Love their mango pudding, which has chunks of mango in it.
author: Mi-tan M.

description:
My girlfriend commented "wow, this place used t always have a line..." Maybe there are reasons they don't any more. Dumplings the consistency of school paste were a first indication. 

But my big NEVER AGAIN comes from asking the waitress about mushrooms in the different items, and being assured they only occurred in the one item on the menu that lists them, and then finding them in two other unrelated items. I'll eat somewhere else, rather than risk a hospital trip from restaurant staff who don't know their own food.
author: Too Much S.

description:
BEWARE !!  This was the worst and most amateurish, badly made food I think I have ever had. The dim sum was almost completely tasteless, didn't seem all that fresh, prepared in seemingly awkward ways, and worst of all, the dough was raw!! 
We had to send it back to the kitchen because it was inedible. We left the restaurant disappointed feeling sick from the raw dough that was in our stomachs and still felt really unwell hours later at home. I almost contemplated making myself throw up at home just to get it out of my stomach. 
We've had such lovely dim sum before in other restaurants but in Ton Kiang it was not up to standards at all and I felt it was a disgrace to the customer. Never again!!
author: Markus Q.

description:
I really, really enjoy Ton Kiang. I would grant there are probably better Dim Sum restaurants in San Francisco, but in my opinion, it's great. You can gorge yourself silly if you don't monitor your choices. If you come for lunch, you have the added benefit of having the dim sum brought around in the bamboo steamers for you to see & choose on the spot. The Beef Chow Fun is to die for. The hot tea is pretty good, too!

Altogether, a great place to go for tasty, moderately priced Dim Sum!
author: Megan P.

description:
GOOD: 
- Everyone walks around with food and speaks ENGLISH ( Good if you don't speak Cantonese or or lack dim sum expertise). Nothing is spoken in Chinese and their English is fluent and not fobby. When I asked things in Cantonese, they always replied in English so I think they are instructed to speak English. Personally this irked me but whatever. 

BAD:
- The food is not very good, limited in selection, and heavy on fried offerings. It isn't terrible but they obviously cater to non-Asian customers. 
- The prices are also above average, which makes their average-at-best dim sum less appealing. 

CONCLUSION:
- I wanted to walk out as soon as I noticed that 90% of the customers were not Asian (not a good sign for an Asian restaurant) but my date picked the place. If you have experience eating dim sum or are not afraid of more authentic places, you should not eat here. Hong Kong Lounge a few blocks away is much better.

If you have never had dim sum before and are a timid eater, this place will be good for you because they have fluent English speakers to walk you through your meal and their menu is limited to the less "exotic" dishes so nothing will freak you out (except maybe the chicken feet).
author: Alex P.

description:
Full Disclosure: This was my (our) first experience at a dim sum restaurant where they walk past with all the options in a very "Cigars! Cigarettes!" style. I liked the immediate gratification of sitting down and putting food in my mouth 30 seconds later, but the constant flow of options was A) really hard on the diet and B) difficult to have a conversation around. 

That said: Everything we had was good, but 90% of the other patrons were white people, which is never a good sign.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Ton Kiang is where we go for a special lunch of Dim Sum. The food is delicious! It is great fun to go with a group of people because you can try more items. It is also nice because they allow reservations for large parties, (or at least they did the last time I tried.) But I also go with a small group of 4 and if we go early enough during the week (by 12:00) we get in pretty quickly. There are certain dishes we love so we ask for them instead of waiting for the cart to arrive -- for example we like the fried taro root dumpling. 

We also go for birthdays, Christmas Eve and when a special friend is in town for a visit. Those days are usually weekend celebrations, so we sometimes hit a line.

I also like to go to Ton Kiang at night alone or with a friend. The dinner hour is for regular dishes from a menu. My favorite dish is the chicken and okra which is fantastic! Be sure to try it.  At night you can also order Dim Sum -- no carts -- but that seems odd to me. Dim Sum is for the day time to my mind.
author: Anne F.

description:
Decently priced and mostly delicious....

This place is super far from Chinatown but it's still so good! The wrapped rice noodles were some of the best I've ever had, but the Shanghai dumplings were beyond disappointing. The foil-wrapped chicken was surprisingly flavorful and delicious! Also loved the pork buns and the shrimp dumplings.

Overall, we ate well and hearty and the bill still only came to about $26 for two. I'd recommend this place if you need some dim sum in your system (and who doesn't)
author: Amrita R.

description:
Good service, lots of selections of dim sum -- constant options while we were there. Clean place. A little noisy since it was so busy. A little bit of a wait outside since some people seem to come to the restaurant and just sit and stay.

Parking can be hard -- the city should allow for multilevel building parking lots. Or tow cars that do not have permits, licenses,.
author: John G.

description:
3.5 stars.

We had some standards including shrimp noodle roll (good), siu Mai (good), har gow, chicken feet (great), beef balls, spare ribs, and xiao long bao (don't order). Sauces were provided and service was nice. Not everything was great, but it was surprisingly cheap, tab was $30.
author: Derrick V.

description: Very good Dim Sum At very reasonable prices.  3 people, 12 dishes for $50/-.  Keep it that way as people will keep coming.  Noisy similar to Hong Kong DimSum restaurants. Liked the food and will go back.
author: Ayaz L.

description:
a friend of mine summarized this place as an introductory class to dim sum. and he's totally right. they have an ILLUSTRATED dim sum menu. you don't have say i would like a white round bun thing with fluffy top and some kind of meat inside. you can just point to the menu! 
but the food was a bit underwhelming. and they are lukewarm because they are not on a cart like a typical dim sum place.
author: Te R.

description:
On a quiet Wednesday afternoon, it was my duty to take my boyfriend to his first taste of dim sum.  How can someone live 26 years without having tried dim sum??  Clearly this was an important moment and I chose Ton Kiang to change the rest of his life.

Going to dim sum with a dim sum newbie is awesome because you get to do all the choosing and the newbie will eat whatever you tell them to. My dim sum plates of choice at Ton Kiang are as follows:

-har gao (shrimp dumplings)
-siu mai (pork dumplings 
-fried shrimp/crab claws
-scallop/shrimp dumplings
- and snow peas!  don't forget the snow peas!!

dim sum YUM
author: Sarah Z.

description:
hm. did i come on an off-day? or have the owners changed since this place was listed in 7 x 7, travel guides, etc.? cuz i don't get it. really. not even close to what good dim sum should be.

half of the dim sum they offered were egg/custard based. i've really never experienced that before; it was like they stocked up on custard at ranch 99 and it expired the next day or something. nothing was great--the best dishes were the vegetables (really? when the vegetables are the best dishes, you have a problem).

just a note: the dim sum places with hoards of asian families waiting outside are probably the places to go for authentic dim sum. not the empty ones, like ton kiang.
author: stefanie h.

description:
When youre craving Dim Sum in SF... its hard to find a nice CLEAN place. But this place was great! I love the Dim Sum there!. They dont have the metal carts they push around, but the waiters walk around with the food on plates. The food is usually pretty fresh.

It is a bit pricey, but what do you expect youre in SF!

Love the dumplings! Loved the pork buns!

Overall great place and great food!

But the parking is sometimes hard to find...
author: Linda L.

description: Everytime I come to the Bay Area from the East Coast I have to go to Ton Kiang for Dim Sum and they never disappoint. The food is delicious and the staff are very friendly and attentive.
author: Joy S.

description: The owner here makes this restaurant 5 stars. I didn't have enough money for take out and she just said its ok. How often do you come by this kind of generousity these days ? I felt terrible I didnt carry enough money with me so I am doing this review in good faith and I will be going there for the dim sum. It is a little expensive compared to other chinese spots in the city but they are the cleanness HANDS DOWN which is PRICELESS !!!
author: Jasmine L.

description:
If I were in the area, this is a solid choice. A bit greasy, and you have to be prepared to sit a long time if there's a dish you really want to eat. Case in point, we waited what seemed like a long time (but was probably only about 20 mins) for nor mai gai to show up, but it was waiting in the steamer queue behind the bao so we decided we didn't need it that bad.

Despite all this, we still ate plenty, just other stuff. I think it came to about $27 pp, which is roughly twice what I usually pay but probably also twice the quantity of food I usually eat. :)

Their xiao long bao didn't have much juice, which was sad. Refreshing, though, that I didn't have a chance to burn my tongue, which usually happens at other places when I order this.
author: Edward C.

description:
It's the real deal!!!

You sure can tast the difference... freshly prepared, quality ingredients, delicate, and delicious.
author: Jake S.

description:
I went here for dinner with my sister.  We felt like eating dim sum at the time, so I looked places up, and we decided on this.  We got the 9 items for $38.  Not the cheapest dim sum in the world, but $20 for dinner is acceptable.  We ordered shrimp dumplings, shrimp stuffed crab claws, scallop & shrimp dumplings, sticky rice, egg rolls, shrimp balls, pork dumplings, shanghai meat dumplings and sesame ballls.  This was the perfect amount of food for us both to be stuffed!  

We both thought the dim sum was good.  We eat lots of this so we've had the best, had the worst, and then some.  I did find it funny that when I asked for the hot chili sauce they brought Sriracha, but other than that everything was good.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Ton Kiang: the Queen of Dim Sum Alley, one of the Dim Sum Big 3 (along with Yank Sing and Koi Palace), favorite of the Food Lover's Guide, and a perennial entry on Michael Bauer's Top 100.

Too bad it's the least tasty Dim Sum I've had in the city so far.  Oh, and the most expensive, by a factor of 2 (and in some cases 3).  Sure, the interior is slightly more polished than average, but otherwise the popularity baffles me (at least there was no wait when we went).

Indeed, every time I proposed Ton Kiang to my friends, they warned me of the undeserved high prices.  But the publicity this place gets was too much for my curiosity, so I finally managed to bring some unsuspecting out-of-towners here.  Their dim sum is "order by sight", not the giant checklist menu which I've grown to prefer.  And for some reason they're not as dumpling-centric, introducing slabs of chooped spare ribs and duck, or tea-leaf or fruit salads.  But the real kicker is how lukewarm a lot of it was.  Now that's just not cool, especially when you're paying a premium.

So take my advice and go down the block to Lucky Fortune, or to any of the other Dim Sum places I've reviewed.  And that goes for you too, Mr Bauer--I think you've let Ton Kiang coast long enough.
author: Wes M.

description:
I've had dim sum here several times.  The quality is terrific and tasty.  It has some unique dim sum you don't really see anywhere else.
We have ordered take out from here many times.  My hubbie is picky about his Chinese food; he loves Ton Kiang's dishes!  Every item we have had has the right amount of spices and kick for an enjoyable meal.  It can add up though and it would help the delivery man to invest in a navigation system as he always seems to get lost finding our place.
author: Kekumukula N.

description:
MmmMm i love this place!  I always come here with my whole family when we have big celebrations.  We usually order the longevity noodles, jelly fish appetizer, fried rice, and the walnut prawns.  The service is really good here...maybe that's why i enjoy this place so much.  The best part is the dessert!!  at Ton Kiang, you don't get your normal chinese desserts...red bean soup, tapioca, fortune cookies, or oranges.  you get these really good cookies and buns filled with egg custard.  I LOVE these desserts.  Everytime I go, we get something different every time.  

The only negative thing about this place is the parking.  terrible terrible parking.
author: Kristen T.

description: WHAT, THAT'S IT!!!  Ok, I've grown up with dim sum and this place is catered to white folks.  Sorry, but the more complicated dim sums that are usually served at other places were not found here.  The use a 4 x 6 placard with black and white illustration of the dim sum they offer and that was it.  They didn't have my dumpling with  peanuts, nor my bean curd wrapped fungus.  Waddup with that, waddup with that. . .as they would sing on SNL.  They have someone bring a tray out to surprise us on stuff thats not on the menu occasionally, but that was it.  Quality was so-so, pricing was little high, but not that much. . . .I suggest you to go to Golden River next door.  Cheaper, more variety, but yes, more crowded and little Chinese ghetto, but trust me, you will be more satisfied in the tummy.
author: Janice F.

description: Ton Kiang is the best Chinese food ever!! The best dim sum, the best service and the best Chinese food over all.  I have had lemon chicken many times in the past, but not quite like they do it here.  TO DIE FOR!!!  Finger licking good.  So far, every dish that me and my famil and friends have tried is exceptional!!  The only complaint I have is parking, it can be difficult, but you will always find a spot somewhere within walking distance.  If you haven't tried them, GO NOW!!!
author: Betty S.

description: Service is awesome and the place has a really clean and welcoming vibe. Looks to be upscale, but we were in loungy, comfortable, post Hardly Strictly Bluegrass garb and were treated no differently than others who were dressed upscale. Some prices are a little higher than i've seen; however, both of us ate for under $40 for 4 dim-sum orders and a shared entree. The vegetarian pot stickers are amazingly full of flavor and filling (and you get 6 of them in one order!). We shared a chicken with cashew and snow peas entree and it was deliciously fresh.
author: Aundrea L.

description: This place is open till 9pm and serves dim sum till them, how can you hate on that? I've been here quite a few times over the years and it has always been consistent.
author: Danielle G.

description: Ewww, no no no! Ton Kiang is a complete rip off. I'm from Hong Kong so I know real dim sum, and believe me when I say that this place serves shitty ass dim sum. Everything is Americanized and overpriced, totally not worth it. What's more is that the service is horrible! Ugh. If you want anything even close to authentic dim sum, I'd recommend Mayflower on Geary or Yet Wah on Clement.
author: Christine A.

description: I came here with a friend on a Sunday afternoon at 1pm. After waiting about 20min, we were seated. The wait staff was very friendly and helpful. Unfortunately, the food was not up to par. Over the course of an hour, the dim sum staples (cha siu bao, sui mai) were nowhere to be seen, and in the end we resorted to ordering them. Even so, the cha siu bao never came. Instead, an impressive array of fried foods continued to circulate (and, we suspect, re-circulate). The biggest shocker was the siu lung bao, which were individually steamed in tiny pie tins and contained a shapeless meat mass but no soup inside. Ton Kiang is probably a comfortable introduction to dim sum for beginners, as the staff speaks English and the tables come with illustrated guides to the different types of dishes. But it fails the Asian quotient rule - by a long shot - and unfortunately the food fails as well.
author: Phoebe K.

description: We got the pork and shanghai dim sum and it wasn't that great. The garlic chicken was pretty good but the Mongolian beef was just ok. The price was ok for what you got but I wouldn't go back for the dim sum. I would be willing to go back and try there other menu items.
author: Charles A.

description: I agree with the other reviews on here. Yeah, it was great there wasn't much of a line - but that certainly comes with a price. Service was poor.  The food was ok, at best.  It was bland, and not what you would expect during dim sum. There are so many great dim sum locations in the city, I would check something else out.
author: Julie F.

description:
I've been going to the restaurant since I was a toddler, back when the restaurant was in a different location. They taught me how to use chop sticks for pete's sake!

As an adult I don't get out there as often as I'd like but it's always going to be the number one chinese restaurant in my eyes. Their beef chow mein is the best, it is the standard for which I compare all others. 

I know now they're big on dim sum now but I grew up on their won ton crispies, beef chow mein, fried rice, won ton soup and my dad loves their fish ( I'm not a seafood fan in general). Aside from nostalgia it's a really great restaurant with amazing food.
author: Mokee B.

description:
If you are looking for a classic Cantonese style dim sum place....this is your spot.  There are dozens of carts flying around at all times with endless options of dim sum dishes.

Some of the things I've tried here are really great...others not so good.  The char siu bao (steamed bbq pork bun) were BOMB.  I could have eating 2 dozen of these.  The green onion pancacke....not so much....tasted like raw playdough.  

Overall though this is a solid place.  Good place to bring friends or family visiting the area who want to experience San Fran dim sum.
author: Dan L.

description:
I give Ton Kiang five stars because I was very impressed with the service, simple yet elegant tablescape, and the crowd.  Yes, the crowd.  You can tell this restaurant is top-of-the-line when it is bursting at the windows, doors, and walls.  Hakka Chinese cuisine boasts a sweet to savory array of deliciously authentic dishes, without a hint of doubt.  If you are craving these treats from the East in the best of the West, read the following suggestions:

-Wherever dim sum is served traditionally, be mindful of having to wait your turn.  In any business, that's just the way it is!

-Food a bit costly, yet you actually do get a lot!

-Crowds, crowds, crowds.  You may need to think twice before ordering dim sum during lunch hours as Ton Kiang tends to be subject to outside queues at this time; on Saturdays and Sundays, you have a full half-day in which you can enjoy other tasty wares, so what's the rush?

-Everything is made from scratch using only fine ingredients, such as meats, seafood, and vegetables.  The ma-po tofu, though spicy, is definitely a must-try as it is healthy.

-The building is uniquely San Franciscan; however, inside is a whole new story: the atmosphere is exotic and serene as are the wall murals.

Don't complain if Ton Kiang becomes one of your favorite restaurants!
author: Mancala P.

description:
18 months after first moving here and I finally have my first true dim sum experience. better late than never, right?

to be honest, I'm not as big of a fan of dim sum as is what feels like the rest of the world. what i DO like, though, is that you can gorge yourself on enough food to feed a small country and pay less than $15 per person. i'm pretty sure I ate my weight in steamed pork buns and shanghai dumplings (my favorite of them all) and the total came to $12 a person (there were 5 of us). i found the bbq pork to be too sweet for my taste, and i'm too much of a nov to go anywhere near the more eclectic dim sum offerings. but overall it was a far better first-time experience than many other things ;)
author: Laura C.

description:
Quality of service and menu depends upon customer's ethnicity.

A large group of us ate here. Our friends who recommended it normally got a complimentary dessert, which didn't come at the end of our meal. When they asked, they were told that there were "too many white people" in the party so we couldn't have the dessert, even when we offered to pay for it. We've talked with others who have had similar experiences, so ours was not an isolated incident.

It's San Francisco; we can do better.
author: Tony Q.

description:
I've been to Ton Kiang before and was so disappointed that I switched over to Yet Wah a couple blocks away. After my last disappointing meal at Yet Wah (can we have some consistency puh-leaze!) I headed back to Ton Kiang for a second shot. 

Although they didn't have the variety of dim sum that I grew up with in Hawaii and San Diego, the dishes we did sample were delightful: shrimp stuffed mushrooms were awesome as were the shrimp rice noodles. Dim sum staples of pork shu mai and baked char siu bao were tasty as well.

The food wasn't greasy or gristly like some of these places in Chinatown but you pay for that quality difference. I guess I will return the next time I have a hankering for dim sum in sf.
author: Nikki B.

description: This has been my families favorite chinese spot ever since I was a little one. Ton Kiang and Yet Wah were my two favorite Chinese spots..but since yet wah closed it's been TK ever since. Food is always on point!
author: Allen K.

description:
For my first time at a dim sum restaurant, I was highly impressed.  Okay, so I'm not Asian, but does it help that I was accompanied by 4 Chinese women (and others)?  I love this place.  I loved the feeling of it; I loved the food; everything I had was good and with that said, I am definitely coming back.  I have to give it the highest amount of stars based on the fact that I am somewhat picky and tried 99% of everything that was on the table (I hate bean curd - not their fault), fell in love with their dim sum, was COMPLETELY satisfied and left full.

We are coming back for next year's holiday lunch, yay!
author: Gina G.

description:
Great dim sum and I've been pretty lucky the last couple times I've been there I didn't have to wait in line.

Extra bonus for serving dim sum all day (special order off the menu) so if I don't make it for some reason during the normal brunch/lunch rush, I can get my fix. 

I've been going to this place for years and it's been pretty consistent. There is one elusive item that I've only seen once and I don't know the Chinese word for it. It was a vegetable (green leaf almost like young spinach?) that was sauteed in oil with garlic. Maybe it was seasonal, but if anybody knows what I'm talking about, I'd love to order it again.
author: Jane L.

description:
This place is great!  I am a dim sum newbie but I was thrilled with the food, price and service at this place.  I went with a friend who is also trying to bang out as many of 7x7's top 100 2010 eats and we're down to like 92.  

My favorite was the eggplant shrimp, hers was the pork buns.  Too much food for $20 apiece.  Sold!
author: Matt S.

description: My favorite Dim Sum place but still not perfect... the Shanghai soup dumplings are not soupy enough. And too tough. Order the taro balls! And fried pork puff. The pea shoots are super yummy too. Avoid most of the fried Americanized stuff and the fruit cup (that is silly.) The wide noodles with gravy on top are DELISH. Service can be spotty. Go early. Get lucky. And hope they refill your water... Oh and order Oolong Tea or Jasmine!
author: Aaron W.

description: MMm as a white boy who grew up in New Jersey I never had nor heard of dim dum ... its amazing and I love this place ... no long lines ... the food is right at your seat as soon as you sit down .... good food and a nice price what more can be said.. its clean and fun ... a great experience all around ... come in hungry and leave full ... but definitely bring more then one person plenty of food to go around ...
author: Anthony S.

description:
3.5 stars really but I can't round up because more than half our meal was just mediocre.

The best items were:
1) Steamed Noodle with Shrimp - VERY GOOD - Soft and light noodle with a bit of bite.  Flavorful and sweet whole shrimp.
2) Sui Mai - VERY GOOD - fresh tasting with crunchy, sweet shrimp and delicate wrapper.
3) Chicken Feet - VERY GOOD - deep dark braise with 5 spice flavor... some of the best I've had.

The mediocre items were:
1) Beef ball - ordinary flavor and texture - go to Mayflower instead for this one
2) Har Gao - ordinary wrapper lacked chew and the shrimp filling was just average
3) Soup dumpling - very whack actually, no soup, dried wrapper, very whack
4) Spare Ribs - very ordinary with little black bean flavor - it was served with a vinegar worcestershire mix
author: Calvin N.

description:
Im totally not asian, but I like Dim Sum.

Out of all the dim sum places that Ive eaten at (10 or so), Ton Kiang rates among the top so long as I travel the safe path.
In order to "be safe" at the Kiang, I only order the shao mai, and a variety of dumplings and greens.
The BBQ pork bun is also really tasty.
The service is also a point of interest in that it both adds and removes points from their score.
I love the little carts and all the choices contained upon each cart, BUT, if you request something specific, often that request is fulfilled waay later.
Also,the line can be a bug, so go early or late.
author: Jbot S.

description:
Came here for lunch this afternoon and it was very yummy. The bbq pork bun was amazing. The veggies were good. The sui mai was nice. The sesame balls were good, but not warm. (Maybe they were when they were served, but not when I got to eating them.)

This place is yum. It was busy but not packed, I'm guessing because it was a Monday afternoon.
author: Kellie P.

description:
Tasty, Westerner-friendly dim sum. I liked that the dim sum was not very greasy. On the other hand, I really like authentic dim sum and I think grease comes part and parcel with that. Prices are higher than a more traditional dim sum establishment. I did enjoy what I had and it helped me recover from a bad hangover so I can't complain. 

I am not a huge Chinese dessert fan but I did very much enjoy the warm custard-filled pineapple buns we had to complete our meal. Not to be missed.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I've been to this restaurant quite a few times, maybe 6 or 6 times because my family is particular to Chinese food that is served in a relatively clean manner, however this place has terrible service. The food is decent, I wouldn't say it's spectacular but it does have unique flavors that you can taste are fresh.

Now on to the service. We always make a reservation at this place because the first time we were here, we waited for an hour and 15 minutes just to get a table. After we got a table we sat there for another hour and a half because of the slow waiter service. We learned out lesson the first time.

On holidays or special event days, this place is PACKED and even with a reservation at 7, you will wait and HOUR and A HALF in order to get a table. A dinner you thought was going to take and hour turns into a 2 or 3 hour affair. It's quite annoying. But the Chinese customers don't seem to mind. I guess you have to drink some of their low quality cheap wine or beer you pay a premium for before your meal.
author: Andrew O.

description: This place has great mix of dim sum options... But you better grab what you want when it comes by because you may never see it again.  Shrimp and chive dumplings are my favorite, and the pork buns were so warm and fresh...
author: Jeff N.

description: We eat here every time we visit family in the Bay Area. The dim sum is always tasty and plentiful, although I still prefer the noisy places with the carts. Its a bit pricey for what you get, but I always seem to leave here very full and very happy...
author: Séamus C.

description: The dim sum at ton kiang is solid, but it definitely wasn't worth the hype.  I heard such great things about the dim sum here and it was definitely solid food, but it wasn't amazing.  We got the steamed pork buns, shrimp dumplings, pork and shrimp dumplings, and rice/meat cooked in a leaf.  Everything was definitely tasty and solid dim sum, but I'm not sure I would come all the way out here again just for dim sum.
author: Lisa C.

description:
This used to be a good restaurant 3-4 years ago and it's really gone downhill. Very greasy and not so fresh meat and seafood dishes coupled with extremely sluggish customer service. 

Came here with a large group of people and they've made us pay 18% tip. There was no compromises or questions on whether they even deserve a tip. They felt as though it was "required" and stopped us when we were about to leave. 

Please spread the word about this place. This is the last time I'm coming here.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description: Every time I come here the food is delicious. Service is ordinary and trying to find parking can be hell, but in my opinion it's worth it.
author: Anna F.

description:
A friend introduced me to Ton Kiang several years ago, and I still think it's one of the best places for dim sum in the Bay Area. It's also my favorite place, hands down.

I remember thinking that the portions were smaller and the prices higher than other places when I first went there, but quickly decided that paying a little bit more was an even tradeoff for the freshest tasting dim sum I'd ever had. I love the sauteed pea shoots, gai lan, scallion pancakes, and, above all else, the siu mai. I judge a dim sum place by its siu mai, and Ton Kiang's is the best: a good, flavorful and succulent blend of pork and shrimp. I could be very happy eating only the siu mai, but it would be very difficult to pass up the chive and shrimp dumplings, char siu baked baos, foil-wrapped chicken, and spareribs in black bean sauce. 

Prices are still higher than other places and portions have seemed a bit smaller the past few times I've been, but it's still worth it--even if I have to circle around for 15 minutes trying to find a parking place.
author: Julie K.

description:
On a Sunday morning, a friend and I wanted dim sum. Our choices were my staple Golden Mountain in Chinatown or something new. He suggested Ton Kiang since it was Hakka cuisine and we wanted to try something different!

First off, the parking and the wait are major drawbacks. I dropped off my friend to get a table since there was a sizable crowd waiting outside the restaurant. I circled the neighborhood for almost 30 minutes before finding a spot, only to show up and wait another 10 minutes before we got a table. Apparently the restaurant staff had told him the wait was only 20 mins, so double whatever time they tell you.

Second, as a Chinese person, I tend to take stock in the crowd at a restaurant. It was pretty much all non-Asians dining at Ton Kiang. This made me slightly hesitant, but I also noticed that the restaurant was clean, spacious and bright and the staff spoke pretty good English, which is probably more helpful for non-Chinese people who want dim sum..

Then I finally got to try the dim sum. It was alright. Not bad, but certainly not the freshest or best dim sum I've had. There were very few "different" (Hakka) dishes and there were quite a few white-washed items like fried calamari (which tasted bland, so don't order it). My favorite was the shrimp and chive pan fried dumpling.

So Ton Kiang wasn't bad, but it wasn't good and it was quite pricey ($45 dim sum for 2). I'd much prefer my Chinatown staple which has waaaay better dim sum. I wouldn't come here again for dim sum, but I'd be interested in trying the Hakka dishes at dinner.
author: Wendy T.

description:
If anything - have the dim sum. 
The clay pot we didn't like at all. I especially dislike it when a dish is supposed to contain chicken, fish and tofu and it contains TOFU with little bits of something that is so tiny that I honestly couldn't tell whether it was fish, chicken or something that is neither fish nor chicken. 
Also I wasn't impressed with the service. Since we didn't like the clay pot, we were still hungry after 3 different dim sums. Only the dim sum server decided we had enough and did not return to our table. It was also extremely hard to get the check.
author: tal n.

description:
EEEH.

The last time I was here (years ago...) I came with a bunch of girlfriends and we sat down and saw prices for the dim sum dishes and immediately got up and left. I should have remembered that when my friend suggested we eat here....

Selection of dim sum here was okay; not bad but not really good. My friends mentioned they were missing some of their normal staples (some stuff I personally dont eat) like tripe, bean curd, etc..  Tried the shanghai dumplings and they were hooorribblleee... thick skin and no juice (what gives?)...  man the dim sum just wasn't all that.... Service was spotty; had to ask for everything twice from assorted people. 

If you want to pay alot of money for sub-par food then go here for dim sum. If you want a REAL place for dim sum go somewhere else.
author: Julie F.

description: Very good dim s experience. They come around with dishes on trays, but not explicitly a 'cart place'. Shumai, Pan-fried pork buns are excellent, as are the Chinese donuts (never had them before, almost a custardy taste. Only disappointment was the shrimp and spinach dumplings.
author: Alex L.

description:
Not a good place for dim sum.  Not fresh at all, it tastes kinda funky.  I only liked the dim sum dessert - Chinese donuts and Lotus Paste Sesame Balls.  Those were really good.  

My friend highly recommended this place because of their Ton Kiang Salty Chicken.  I tried it and it was okay.  The other dishes were okay.  I wouldn't go out of my way to come here again.
author: Alice C.

description:
Everyone once in a while I go to San Fransisco for a get away.  A very good friend of mine lives out there and is very culinary minded so I trust her judgement when it comes to food.  She recommended this place to me.

Today was the second time I've eaten at Ton Kiang's.  It was clean both times I was there and the food is super yummy.... Everything seems to be very fresh.  I am used to roving carts but this place has servers that walk around with trays, but they are pretty steady.  It is hard to get water but if you remain persistent you will get your water or any other condiments that please your pallet.  

If you are a dim sum addict, as I am, you won't be disappointed.
author: Pamela N.

description: Second time having dim sum and I really liked it here.  Their mochi egg tarts are so delicious.  *drools*
author: Carol K.

description:
How the heck is this place on the SF Chron Top 100 (along w/Yank Sing) for top Chinese food/dim sum??

This is a no no. There are much better, cheaper and more authentic dim sum places in the city. You are in the Richmond district, for goodness sakes - go someplace else.

Stopped by for the first time last Sunday. Walked in, sat down, looked at the English menu and then looked up at my fiance and said, "No no." Tried three dim sum items, asked for the check ($15 total - and each item had four pieces of dim sum) and walked four blocks down to Mayflower, where we proceeded to stuff ourselves on seven dishes for almost the same price that we paid at Ton Kiang ($20 total).
author: Adrienne C.

description:
Dim sum in Southern California (Rosemead, Monterey Park, San Gabriel) is way better and much cheaper!  

They have a huge variety, but the food is not that great.  It's pretty expensive, but not nearly as bad as Yank Sing.  What's up with San Francisco and their over priced dim sum?  Will never be doing dim sum in SF again!
author: Sunny A.

description:
Ton Kiang is one of my favorite Dim Sum places. I would give it 5 stars but I think it is a bit pricey. The food is 5 star quality. They have rolling carts too. If you do not see an item you like, you can order it from a waitress. 
I LOVE the salt and pepper shrimp, salt and pepper squid, Ha Gow shrimp dumpling),  to name a few. 

My husband loves pork and he loves the Shanghai Dumpling, porks bun, etc.

Everything here is good. My advice is to go before noon. I try to get there by 10:30. Otherwise there is a line. If you go on a sunday there is no meter to pay too.
author: Heather W.

description:
Where da Chinese people at??!?!?

That was my first thought.  I didn't see one Chinese family there.  Uh oh... why? how come?

My non Chinese friend recommended this place.  I should have known....

Had the following:
*Har gow: didn't like the taste of the shrimp
*Siu mai: tasted better
*Char shiu pastry: tasted good
*Long bean: yummy
*Baby bok choy: tender and good
*Egg custard: I've never seen it that small. Smaller than a 50 cent piece! I could have shoved all three in my mouth with no problem. 
*Congee: Thousand year old egg, pork, but no flavor
*Three different types of steamed dumpling: Wow... tiny and tasteless.

The servers were polite and thanked us for each item selected - even got a "thank you very much".  

Now I know why there weren't any Chinese families - items are made small and it's EXPENSIVE!!  

For two people, it was $65.00!!  The least expensive dish was $3.00 each.

None of the dishes were very unique or tasted awesome to to warrant the price.  At least Yank Sing had lobster har gow. 

This place is a good for people who had never had dim sum. Safe and clean.
author: Ling K.

description: Amazing. Absolutely amazing. We went here on a recommendation from two locals who are also chefs. After my terrible dim sum experience across town the previous day, this was a breath of fresh air. Went here for lunch after the Japanese Tea Garden. The interior is nothing to write home about but the food sure is. Everything we ordered was delicious: steamed shrimp dumplings, scallops dumplings, vegetable dumplings, xiao long bao (shanghai meat dumplings), salt and pepper prawns. It seems like it's not a lot of food, but it definitely fills you up. The cart wasn't going around anymore at 3 when we got there, but the waitress let us order straight from the kitchen. Everything was fresh, tender, and delicious. Dumpling skin was soft and nice without being too thin. Meat was perfectly seasoned, especially the shrimp/prawns. And everything was so cheap! $35 bucks for two and tons of food to fill us up. Tea was excellent as well, and only $1 per person. Only qualm was how long it took for them to ring us up and get us out. Overall, this was the dim sum experience I was looking for.
author: Erica S.

description:
You get better dim sum in great eastern and yank sing. 

$$
Decent dim sum. 
available all day
author: Nifty G.

description: Very, very good. Some of the comments about occasional cold dishes and a relatively high price are accurate, but it is an excellent Dim Sum experience. Always happy and down for a trip to Ton Kiang!
author: P L.

description: Way overpriced, very bland, tiny portions (smallest egg custard tarts ever), food coloring in the battered items, forks on the table (a good sign the food is NOT very authentic), expensive expensive expensive.  Ok, it would alright if it was expensive and the food was great, but it isn't.  Maybe they are tricking us by putting those reviews in the window because those reviews are wrong.  I agree wholeheartedly with "Brian O." , he hit the nail on the head.  Be warned!  if you know what good dim sum should taste like this isn't the place for you.  I LOVE Chinese food, can eat it everyday, but will never go back here.
author: Rona M.

description: This used to be my go-to place for dim sum, but it does appear to have gone downhill.  I was generally happy with the dumplings, but other favorites appear to be different.  I used to love the salt&pepper shrimp but they're now completely different.  The crab claw puff was also way too greasy.  The entire ball was saturated with grease, the exterior was only slightly crunchy,  and the plate had a pool of oil.  This tells me that the oil was just not hot enough to properly deep fry something, and I couldn't finish it.  I'm not sure I'll go back. :(
author: Beef B.

description:
I'm biased, I went here for my 5th birthday because I loved it then as much as I do now. Originally I would go here for mongolian beef, beef chow fun and moo shu pork. More recently my family and friends started going for dim sum as well.

As for the dim sum it is delicious. The lady's are not too pushy, which can occur in some of the more hardcore places. My favorite items are shui mai, ribs, whatever veggies they have, a few other things I dont know how to say and the donuts. Try the donuts if you feel like indulging and they are available.

Parking can be a little difficult about half a block down and across the street there is a lot you can park in.
author: Mike I.

description: Dim sum (Hakka style) is very good and dinner is great. Dim sum is different than typical Hong Kong style, and it's not greasy like some places.
author: Nathalie C.

description:
I really like this place!  Like many other reviewers have noted the parking is TERRIBLE!  Public transit is the way to go, you'll spend just as much time transferring on buses as you would driving around and around looking for a parking space!  The one thing you can't avoid is the line or the wait if you hit it at the right time.  Good things are worth waiting for and dim sum can turn over tables fairly quickly!

The beef curry pastries are my favorite!  They have all the standard dim sum fare and the price is reasonable.  If you go at an off-peak hour for dim sum you can easily order off the dim sum menu.  It does negate some of the dim sum cart experience but you won't starve as some of the more interesting delicacies (read: the ones I am too timid to try) keep passing you by while you wait for the bbq pork buns or shumai you have been craving!

They also have clay pot dishes that are part of the restaurant's Hakka region cooking.  I read in a travel guide somewhere that Ton Kiang is the only place in the U.S. that serves Hakka cuisine (in addition to their regular Chinese menu) which sounds neat though I haven't had a chance to try it yet.  It's hard not to fill up on their great dim sum!
author: Matthew T.

description:
Just went there for my grandmother's b-day. Came in and the waiter took our order. He was somewhat rude and was not eager to accommodate certain requests (ie. serve the cake, provide shot glasses). Instead of shot glasses he brought wine glasses. I figured he didn't have shots but later saw them on another table. 

Service was painfully slow. We weren't in a hurry but  it was impossible to get hold of a staff member. Food was served in a very odd order. Walnut prawns were among the first and steamed rice was one of the last. The food however, was delicious. Great egg rolls, dim sum, and reasonable portions for the price.

 When it was time to cut the cake, they didn't have a spatula but served it with 2 forks holding each slice from either side. As it was a very soft cake, this method completely destroyed the majority of the slices. My plate literally looked like it was the discards of the other pieces.

The restaurant was full and was incredibly understaffed. But even taking this into consideration, the service was simply atrocious. 

 4-5 stars for the food but 1-2 stars for the service, or lack thereof. This averages to the 3-star review.

Try hitting this restaurant when it isn't busy and you should be quite happy.
author: Maksim K.

description:
I apologize if this sounds racist but if you walk into a dim sum restaurant in SAN FRANCISCO and you are the only Asian person there besides the waitstaff, RUN AWAY.  As far as you can.  Because almost guaranteed the food there is going to be 1) overpriced, 2) not great.  

Ton Kiang was both of these.  

Their food selection was pretty standard as I recall, but man they were stingy with the meat in their har gao and siu mai.  Also their rice noodle-wrapped shrimp (my fave dim sum dish) was just tiny and the rice noodle was not as chewy as I normally like it.  Sigh.  Still looking for a great dim sum place in the city but nothing has blown my socks off yet.
author: William S.

description:
Christmas at Ton Kiang's is wonderful.  There are large group of families, small groups of friends and the BEST dim sum!  

We came in from the cold after finding FREE PARKING (how cool is that?! I ask you, when was the last time there was free parking in SF?! --maybe when you had to use a whip and a pooper scooper!).  We had walked down the other side of the road to get some goodies from the Russian Bakery, which we stowed in the car.

Walking into Ton Kiang's was a warm blast of humanity.  The head waiter sized us up and sent us upstairs.  We got a table in the corner and said yes to just about everything that came our way:  foil wrapped chicken, plates of green beans and rabe, beef stuffed noodles, shrimp stuffed mushrooms, sesame balls, egg custard cakes, shrimp stuff crab claws, mango pudding (ok, twice).
