I know I am forgetting something, but I was busy slurping and chewing and enjoying the scene.  The tea was a jasmine that got darker as we went along.

Servers kept coming by with more, but at some point we got a little pickier and said no to the tofu dumpling and crab and pea cakes.  Finally there was no more food on the table, we had slurped down the second and last mango pudding and we decided that we had to leave before we exploded.  Luckily, we had enough time for a walk at Sutro's before getting in the car to leave.  

One of the things I like about Ton Kiang's is that although the price is higher than most other dim sum places, the ingredients are fresh and of much higher quality.  It does make a difference.  If you have ever had a char-sai bow (pork  bun - not in evidence this afternoon, but I probably could have had some if I had requested them) here, you will never be satisfied with them made anywhere else.  They are so fresh, they need to have their mouths washed out with soap!  ::Laugh:::

My family loves to eat at Ton Kiang's and there was the night of DIM SUM MIRACLE where my brother Pat and Dr. R. found a place to park Pat's Expedition (not a small feat in and of itself, but it was towing a uhaul trailer AND it was that drizzly-cold night).

I take off a point because of the prices (but hey, fresh is worth it) and the spotty service (but hey, it was Christmas afternoon).
author: Kelly B.

description: Went here on Wednesday because I was craving dim sum.  This place is really nice for your typical dim sum place, and isn't super rowdy and loud inside.  It was actually filled with all white people, and my friend and I were the only Asians lol.  The food was pretty bomb, we ordered the clear shrimp thing, shu mai, chicken feet, bbq pork bun, shrimp and leek dumpling, and the bbq white long noodle thing.  I think it ended up being around $30, which is kind of pricey for the small amount of food we had, although it was delicious!
author: Liz W.

description:
That was pretty good! Do they use MSG here cause it taste like you could get addicted to this place...hmm...dare I ask.

About the food:
I had pork buns that Kermit D. Frog would be die for. They were pipin' hot and to my liking.
I also had the won-ton soup and a couple orders of shrim shumai and some veggies..The tea was good..

My roommate and I went right before the Chinese New Year parade and it was not busy at all so I guess that was cool...but, when it's not busy it means you're not going to get things out to you as quickly. Still no complaints. We stiill got great service.

I would like to try this out on a busier day I guess...I'll go back for sure...and maybe I'll update the review.
author: June C.

description: Horrible food! Shrimp dumpling taste like microwave food , waste of money! I wish I can give minus 5stars !
author: Vivi W.

description:
Hell to the yes, bitches.

This place is full of my Jewish brethren ready to get down and dirrrty with a plethora of non-kosher products for Sunday brunch.  

Sunday.  That's Jesus' day, suckas.  Welcome to no holds barred Moses free Sunday.  The Yarmulke has come off.

Jews already did their praying and repenting on mother effin' Saturday and are free to stuff face with sweet, sultry, sinfully forbidden pork.

Pork Dumplings.  Check.  Pork Buns.  Check.  Pork Spareribs.  Check. 

Keep the pork coming, dim sum lunch ladies.  Don't you dare stop.  God is busy today, and he ain't looking at me.  

Do I want chicken feet?  Fuck no.  What do I look like? Jews don't eat that shit.  

We get enough flack for Gefilte Fish.
author: Rachel G.

description:
Stereotypes. Let's not delude ourselves here; we all have them. They are more-or-less an unfortunate byproduct of efficient cognitive processing. It all boils down to the fact that we're hardwired to be lazy and use as little information as possible to make daily decisions and judgments. Can you imagine the otherwise "paralysis through analysis?" For many, some of the operative stereotypes when choosing a Chinese/dim sum restaurant are:

- Lots of White folks eating there? = Bad
- Does the place look sterile? = Bad
- No dim sum carts? =  Bad
- On the pricy side? = Bad

My brain immediately activated these thoughts as I walked into the bright, pristine dining area of Ton Kiang with its huge, pretty red signage. However, since I trust the taste of my companions, I tried to cast these heuristic traps aside and judge the food solely on its own merits. Fourteen different orders of dim sum later, I was able to independently conclude that this was some light, tasty, refined dim sum. Others have alluded to this, but it's worth repeating. You may walk out stuffed, but it most likely won't be that heavy, greasy, "WHY do I do this to myself?!?" feeling.

Now, I will freely admit that I have never earned my Chinese card, despite my quarter-blood Chinese heritage, so I don't have a hard-line standard for authenticity (or much facility with the "real" names of dishes. Bao = round things. That's about it for my repertoire)...but I do know "yum" when I taste it. I appreciated that Ton Kiang had a wide variety of dim sum, with many items a change of pace from the usual fare at your standard Cantonese joint. Here are some standouts of this dim-sum-a-thon:

- Sticky rice and meat wrapped in banana leaves: this is one of my favorite dim sum dishes. I get it every time. My friend, who is a much more legit Chinese person than I am, shared that this is one of her benchmarks for a restaurant's dim sum quality. What is the texture of the rice? Proportion of rice to meat? What did they stick in there? Ton Kiang's version passes the test, using a wonderful glutinous rice that allows each grain to be differentiated, yet coexist amongst each other without becoming too mealy. Not only was the chicken/pork mixture tasty, but they included salted egg! Joy!

- Chive & shrimp dumplings: it is wonderful that the robust chives are the star of these dumplings and do not play second fiddle to the shrimp. 

- Scallop & shrimp dumplings: it's a fat shrimp wrapped by a huge scallop, served with a light oyster sauce and peppers. Damn, this is like dim sum livin' large.

- Eggplant & shrimp: I love eggplant. I love shrimp. With that tender, fiberous eggplant wrapped around that plump, juicy shrimp watch out because I might steal your share from you while you're not looking.

- Foil wrapped chicken: would've passed this up if it weren't for the urging of another friend. Glad we didn't because this sizzling hot chicken was tender, yet crispy with a strong garlicky marinated taste. 

- Mango pudding: refreshing, with plenty of fresh mango chunks. Perfect palate cleanser.

- Egg custard rice cakes: held in the palm of one's hand, this tiny, warm, pliable package evokes images of childhood - of innocence - of safety and comfort. Upon consumption, the rice cake gives way to cascading custard creaminess, eliciting grunts and groans from every one at the table. Close your eyes and take in the full glory of this unassuming but rapturous dessert.

Not every dish was as much of a visceral experience, and though none were really "bad," I feel a Yelper responsibility to note a few misses:

- Scallion pancake: cardinal sin of scallion pancakes - too gummy, not flaky. 

- Duck: skin was a bit thin and chewy, not crispy. Order is quite large, but the unimpressive salty taste isn't really worth the stomach space. Skip it.

- Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings): ok, it's not a Shanghainese place so expectations should be low. But we were a table of social justice-oriented psychologists trying to shatter stereotypes, so we decided to give a try. There wasn't even any soup inside the dumplings! (it had all been soaked up by the meat). Wrapper was floury and gummy, meat inside nothing to write home about. Blech.

After some rousing discussion of lighthearted lunch topics such as racism and Asian American identity, we all agreed that, on the whole, Ton Kiang is the kind of establishment that defies some people's stereotypes of what a "good" dim sum restaurant should be. Good food is good food. Remember: stereotypes are powerful b/c we tend to pay closer attention to information that confirms our preconceived ideas. So, next time you come across a place that doesn't seem to fit the "mold" of what is "good," it might be worth it to give it a shot. Continuous, conscious efforts to seek out information that contradicts our preconceptions are the most effective way to break down stereotypes.

Thank you for your time. *steps down from soap box*
author: Steph P.

description:
I haven't seen this many little white kids in one place since "Annie" was in town. Snap! 

But I guess that's the thing with Ton Kiang? It's always full of white people. Which is the urbanite's time-honored snub of any ethnic restaurant. But you know what? Last I checked I was bubbling in the "Caucasian - Not of Hispanic Origin" bubble on the scantron form so I really can't bag on Ton Kiang. The food comes out hot and it's tasty, they're generous with the portions and, for the weight watchers crowd (another big guai lo party), you can get your garlic sauce prawns not battered, and a giant plate of steamed mixed vegetables. If you're someone with more self control, feel free to order the cha siu bao. They're delicious.
author: Megan W.

description:
The place for the best Hakka food in the Bay Area (until I'm corrected). 
Having grown up in HK with Mui Kiang and then Mtn View with the same, this is the closest thing.
Easily the best Bacon and Greens...(disappointed by the one many claim is better further out). Not to mention the excellent Sea Bass, the Roast Chicken, Shark's Fin Soup (when it existed here), the Noodles with Dried Scallops and Chives and the Tofu Vegi's. Gotta have the Green Chili and GInger-Oil Sauces. The previous Red Chili Sauce was more authentic than the one now, but still good.
Summary: Excellent, uptown Hakka-Chinese Restaurant. My choice for many celebrations since the 70's. Good Dim Sum as well. Clean and classy and lively
author: A K Y.

description:
I remember Martha Stewart featured Ton Kiang on her show years ago.  I must say that I was quite disappointed.  It's not worth the wait or the inflated prices.  However, it might be a good place to take out of town, non-Chinese guests because it looks like an upscale restaurant and the food is visually appealing.  They might be impressed with the crowds. The first time I went, I had a cold and I couldn't taste anything.  

During my second visit, I realized the food just isn't as good as it looks.   The scallion pancake was downright greasy and soaked with oil rather than crispy and chewy.  The shrimp items (har gow, rice noodle rolls) featured small shrimp.  Given how Ton Kiang is more expensive than average, there's no excuse for such small shrimp.  For dim sum, I prefer Koi Palace.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I came to Ton Kiang recently for my step-grandmother's 88th birthday. I had been several times before and knew what to expect from a dim sum banquet. It meant I was going to be fucking stuffed! If there's one thing I love it's dim sum. The only thing I love more is dim sum when someone else is buying. Well, besides the wife, kid, family, blah blah blah. Anyway, back to the food.

We started off with a kind of Chinese antipasto platter which was made up of cold sliced meats, a jellyfish salad and some little brown things which I couldn't identify but ate three of in an attempt to convince myself that I liked them. I'm half Chinese, dude. That means I have a genetic predisposition to eating weird shit that's dried, salty or generally considered inedible in most cultures. Can you think of any other cuisine that utilizes chicken feet? Yeah, I didn't think so. What followed were courses that are typical of Chinese banquets; gai lan, pork spare ribs, Peking duck etc. Although these dishes are ubiquitous at Chinese restaurants I found their preparation at Ton Kiang to be more refined and elegant and devoid of excessive grease and gluey cornstarch-thickened sauces.

My uncle came around to the table near the end of the meal and asked, "Hey, did you like the duck tongues?"

"Huh? What?"

"The duck tongues. Those little brown things on the first course."

Well, actually, no.

The dim sum is the real star of this place and if you prefer the instant gratification of pointing and grunting at the passing carts then you won't be disappointed. This stuff is delicious. Ton Kiang is fairly clean and a little pricey which makes it accessible and inviting to most white folk. DON'T BE PUT OFF BY ALL THE WHITE PEOPLE, the food is actually really good.

As much as I like eating dim sum I usually don't opt for Ton Kiang as I am half Chinese and therefore cheap. Oh, and yeah, you can probably pass on the duck tongues.
author: Josua P.

description:
Chinese might not go here because the prices are easily twice what you would pay for the same amount of food at cheaper dim sum places, like Mayflower further down Geary. The difference however is quality.

The key to dim sum is the feeling you have after you leave. Cheap Chinese dim sum will leave you feeling heavy and bloated. Good dim sum will leave you wanting more. Ton Kiang definitely falls into the latter category.

Most Asians will knock down stars for the price -- hell, for my dad, the cheaper dim sum is, the better it tastes to him... Some Chinese will knock down stars for them not being Cantonese. Unlike most other dim sum places in the City, Ton Kiang is Hakka, versus Cantonese. (Both come from the same province in China, but they're distinctly different peoples.) Hakka cuisine can be differentiated -- it's less fried, not as heavy and greasy. "Dim sum" is a Cantonese phrase, but they hardly monopolize dim summery -- not by a long shot.

The biggest problems with Ton Kiang are the lack of parking and the waiting: an hour to an hour and a half on the weekends. If you show up by 1pm, forget it -- the selection will be very limited by the time you're seated.

Many of these reviews who give Ton Kiang low marks I think have a Cantonese bias, and Ton Kiang is definitely not Cantonese in flavor. Some also knock Ton Kiang for having a very large percentage of White patrons -- I assure you they only discovered this place after some slanty-eyed fellow like myself dragged their pale butts in here and made them eat. So they get a few Best Of's in the papers. The quality of the food has not suffered much.
author: Perci N.

description:
This place is racist.  I went here for Chinese new year with a big group of Asians and non-Asians.  Some of both subsets could understand Chinese.  The host, who was Chinese-American, ordered.  The waitstaff kept calling people at the table "whitey" and would not serve us dessert because we had to many white people at the table.

None of us in our party were rude or loud or anything.  Our host did not tell everyone else what was said in front of our backs until we left the restaurant.  Needless to say I will never eat there again.

The food?  Does it really matter?  I thought it was a bit bland, but not horrible.  The decor was ok.  parking in that area is terrible.

In any event, should we be giving this place our money and supporting this behavior?  If it were a white waiter talking crap about an Asian customer, how long would that place last?  Even if this place had awesome food i would (and i am) taking my business elsewhere.
author: Nessie V.

description:
Trusting in SF Gate's 100 best restaurants was a bad idea. 

Not only was Ton Kiang praised by the Chronicle, it was recommended by family and friends. Well guess what, they were all wrong! I don't know why I ever trust Chinese food suggestions from non-Chinese peoples. But it was a lesson learned. 

First glaring hint should have been the fact that Ton Kiang is miles from China Town. It's pretty much on the opposite side of the city. But lucky for us, it wasn't crowded. We came on the day of the Bay to Breakers hippy run thing and I guess all the fart smellers were out prancing around instead of eating dumplings at 11am. 

We got some veggies, some dumplings, pork buns and a few other random good "looking" items. None of it was stand out good. Most tasted like something I'd make from my freezer, which I don't mind, but not when I'm paying a premium price. Another big upset for me was lack of any vinegar or chili type oil to dress my snacks! What gives!? 

Over all, the food was so lackluster and high priced that neither of us took a single picture and we both left as sad little pandas.
author: Eli G.

description:
Spacious. Variety.  Uncluttered.

**Couldn't eat majority of food due to stomach pains*** :(

Authentic and large variety at Ton Kiang.  The large, simple, visible exterior sign hints to a clean Chinese restaurant in comparison to adjacent Golden River's dark, complex sign.

I was hesitant at first as the place was packed at 5:30pm...with white people!  We were the only Asians aside from the staff in this large restaurant!

Wonton soup overflowed with bright green veggies but also wimpy looking mushrooms.  The broth was mediocre - tasted like Swanson's chicken broth infused with some veggie flavor plus a considerable amount of salt and a dripping of oil.  The wonton skins were somewhat undercooked near the pinch.

The steamed and salted chicken looked appetizing in its simplicity.  Not drenched in sauce, not dripping in oil, not deep fried, but naked in it's steamed beauty and served only  with a traditional garlic dipping sauce.

The prawn and okra stir fry looked and smelled amazing, received high praise, and was gone by the end of the meal.

Uni-color Yee Mien looked lack luster, lacking colorful veggies and other goodies I've usually seen accompanying this delicious chewy noodle dish.

Dim sum  - unmemorable - better in Chinatown.

Asians started trickling in mid-way through our dinner :)

$$77 before tip for 4 entrees, large wonton soup, and two dim sum plates!  Not bad for decent, authentic dishes in a clean, friendly environment!  Wouldn't mind coming back here again if I'm ever in the mood to share Chinese with friends.

Know Before You Go:
1. Try to get the more "unusual" dishes as they're probably less greasy and more tasty!
2. Avoid dim sum (the dumplings anyway) as the entrees are the highlights of the restaurant.
author: Jane L.

description:
I am a gluttonous dim sum slut.

Ton Kiang was my first, and I'll never forget her. I even feel like I'm slightly cheating when I eat dim sum elsewhere. The first time I had her I felt overwhelmed by the experience. The carts whizzing past my table. Exotic foods playing hide and seek with my eyes, where you have split seconds to make a choice that you -may- regret later. Once you're full, you can't try it! Being from the midwest I was overly polite, I'd try to politely refuse, but always end up with chicken feet. No time for manners with dim sum! Choose quickly or starve!

Again I found myself with my first and favorite. The hostess treats me special and seated us in the pole position upstairs - right where the food comes out. Proper dim sum seat location is critical to having access to the freshest and widest variety of delectables. You want to be near a lot of people and close to the kitchen.

Within seconds our table was plump with scallop and shrimp dumplings, their spinachy twin, pork dumplings, bbq pork steamed buns, garlic snow pea shoots, hairy shrimp balls, fried prawns, sticky rice, egg rolls and on and on.

Even when completely gorged I still want more - especially dessert. I get both kinds of custard treats, don tah and nai wong siu ben (pastry vs. rice cake) along with the chinese donuts (dripping in greasy deliciousness). And as always, I close the deal with the best mango puddin' in town doused with sweetened condensed milk. Mmmmmm.

One tip... playahs like me show up after 1pm. Sleep off that hangover, nab some parking easier and find a table sooner.

(4.5 * stars)
author: Brady K.

description:
Be prepared to drop some $$$ at this place. The food is tasty and service is great and attentive, but it's very expensive for a dim sum place.

I went to dim sum this morning with three friends and the sister/boyfriend of one of those friends. We arrived a little after 11 and our party was seated in 10 minutes. The first thing I noticed was the cleanliness of the restaurant--white linen tablecloths, porcelain teapots, forks as well as chopsticks, and a great variety of dim sum that was vastly different than where I usually go. They had all the staples done quite well (char siu bao, ha gow, siu mai, etc) among other things I haven't seen before (shrimp stuffed mushroom caps, amazing green beans, amazing chili pepper clams, mango pudding for dessert)

The dumplings were much smaller than I'm used to... I think that's the only drawback. The ha gow were great as were the shrimp chive dumplings (not too many chives) but they were all so tiny. The egg tarts were delightfully buttery and the sesame buns had the perfect filling to rice ratio.

Yet the most impressive part of the morning was the service. (aka, we actually got service). The waiters all wore suits, our water was always full, and everyone was friendly. I think this is a first time experience for this sort of thing in a chinese restaurant.

The food is really good, the service is fast and the ingredients are fresh, but I was not anticipating spending $20 per person for dim sum (and that's if you left a meager tip too). I'm used to going to the "no ambiance and you're obviously a bother to all the people here and you'd better speak Chinese or you're screwed" places for about $7 per person. But I suppose it's nice to treat yourself from time to time. I'll still go to my cheap dim sum places, but this is good to remember for a time that I'm not paying.

Warning: parking is extremely difficult.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
After signing the lease to our new flat we decide to get some dim-sum. My roommate suggested a place but didn't know the address for it.  "It's a place that's green tiles in the front. They serve food in those little push carts, and there tons of Asian people in it." Thanks that wasn't vague at all. We only have to look at every single Chinese restaurant on Geary and we'll find it. Parking was almost impossible to find but after 15 minutes I found one, 5 blocks away.

 I spot a line in the distance. I don't understand why but when I see a line I have to lineup. Kind of like in Soviet Russia where people would just line up and didn't know what they were getting. There wasn't a lot of Asian people in it, but there was a line so it was good enough for me This placed made me realized that just because there a line outside a building doesn't mean it's good or I should lineup for it. 

It was about a 10-15 minute for a table. They tell you what the stuff is in English, unfortunately for me I only know them in Chinese. Shrimp Dumplings? What's that? This is not a cheap place for dim-sum. It's about $3-$6 per dish. We got some Calamari that was cold, when they toss in some asian spices in it that instantly makes a dish Chinese. We were short on time because my roommate and I wanted to make it to the Yelp Cupcake Event, so we ordered some dim-sum off menu. Here where I'm pissed, every time I go to a dim-sum place I always order Sui Mai, well this was the first time I didn't get it. I asked one of the waitresses for my order and she said she would check up on the kitchen for me. Another 20 minutes later she serving some Ha Gao, WTF WHERE MY SUI MAI? Anyways I told them to cancel the other and just give us the check. So about 7 dishes, comes out to $36.

Thanks Ton Kiang for making me miss my Cupcake Event with your crappy Dim Sim. Should of knew something was wrong when there weren't enough Asian people standing outside
author: Kaven T.

description:
If you're in SF and you want to know where to go for dim sum, Ton Kiang is your place. It might just be the best dim sum in town in terms of quality and price. Now, to be honest, I am a Yank Sing fan. Big Time. I think the quality is equal, but Yank Sing is more pricey. Hence the long lines at Ton Kiang.  The dim sum is absolutely delicious and I've always had great service. It's good for a huge party or just for two. 

Now, there's 2 tricks: go early when they first open their doors and beat the crowds (although they might not have all the selections available yet) or go in the late afternoon. Otherwise, you'll be waiting...and starving as you smell the delicious food. It's an unpleasant experience, I assure you.  

Damn, I miss this place.
author: Aimee G.

description: I have been to Ton Kiang's before for a wedding rehearsal dinner and post-baby shower family-style meal.  Both were pretty good, but not particularly memorable since I can't recall what stood out as I write this.  I know it wasn't bad though!  Today, I went to try their dim sum with a girlfriend.  With only a few carts, most of the waitstaff came out with dishes on trays.  All the food we selected came out warm and freshly cooked.  Everything was tasty and pretty authentic, including the shumai, chinese broccoli, warm tofu dessert, and egg tarts.  My favorite was the chive dumplings though they could be pan fried a little crispier.   Downsides:  the scallion pancakes were "mealy" (best word I could find to describe it), the cost was high for dim sum--our bill was $30 each not including the tip, and I would have liked more variety of dishes--they probably rotated about 20 or so dishes when there are so many more options out there. I missed having radish cake--they didn't have it.  How do you not have radish cake at dim sum?  Verdict:  a-ok standard, reliable, dim sum fare, but not exemplary.
author: Karen J.

description:
HOW THE EF DOES A PLACE LIKE THIS GET 3.5 ON YELP!?!?!?

I found most of the 2 and 1 star reviews to be pretty much true.

I've never felt so ripped off in my life. Usually I don't mind getting ripped off for food if it was at least good, or the portions were hearty, or the ambiance was better than average, or if the service was exceptional, but this place did not excel in any of those categories. 

After going to the Chihuly exhibit at the de young with some friends, we decided to get some Sunday dim sum. We wanted to go somewhere close by, the only dim sum places I knew of that was near by was mayflower, ton kiang, lucky fortune?, shanghai dumpling king, and yet wah..... 

Parking: its kind of hard to find parking in the part of town on a Sunday morning b/c (1) there are two churches (2) clement street  - high density of chinese people (3) geary - high density of dim sum places. We managed to find a spot on 28th. So we had to walk like 5 blocks to go to ton kiang.... Mind you we walked PAST mayflower, which is like a HUGEST regret of my life. -___-

Service: this is the quickest I've ever been seated at a dim sum place ever (that is not a good sign). So the dim sum is carried around, and it's not made to order which is fine with me. What really was a huge shocker as that my friend (who has like the worst canto-chinese ever) was asking the waiter for a menu, and he said "hold on I don't know how to speak Chinese (ok, this guy's English had a Chinese accent....which was so strange that he didn't know a lick of canto) so he grabbed this lady to come and talk to my friend. I'm Korean, and even I was super confused. We were laughing our heads off.

Atmosphere: the place is way cleaner than a place like shanghai dumpling king. Probably not as loud as most of your canto-ed out dim sum establishments. Lots of natural light in the dining area upstairs and the place is not crowded.

Clientele: we look around and see why everything was so off base here. There were groups of white folks everywhere, or there was one token white guy who happened to have a Chinese wife, and the family decided to go have some Americanized dim sum. Or a group of friends together but then they have a couple of token white washed Asian friends. I'm assuming that this is their niche (dim sum for non dim sum eaters) b/c at your table, they have these 2-D line drawings of the dim sum plates with the Romanized pronunciations of the dim sum. Seriously most bizarre experience ever.

The food: portions where small, prices were high (most plates were like $4-5), there was NO SOUP IN MY XIAO LONG BAO!!!!!!!!!!! This place gets an F for allllll eternity in my book. Absolutely black listed. $4 for 3 potstickers (that were cold)?!?! we were still hungry after we finished our dim sum, we had to get the menu and order a plate of gravy noodles with beef and veggies ($11.50 and it was SO salty). i felt so raped after I left this place. 5 people and our bill came out to $116 before tip. Worst dim sum I've had in my life for the highest price per person I've ever paid in my life. And what's up with the calamari being passed around as dim sum? That was a first. 

Then the long walk back to my car, and we notice all the happy Chinese people still lining up at mayflower, eating their yummy dim sum, and probably not getting ripped off either. Walk of shame. 

P.S: The napkins at ton kiang were exceptionally thick. Maybe that's why the dim sum was so expensive....
author: Irene C.

description: The BEST Place to get your dim sum !!!  Good and fresh all the time really good service...... every time I go the city we go there .... AS GOOD AS IT GET'S !!! See u soon !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Boris M.

description:
Primarily I am not the biggest fan of Chinese cuisine.  For me it's always an overindulgence of in-your-face sauce.  The spicy fried prawns were delish, but why not drizzle the sauce over them so the prawns keep that nice golden crunch instead of becoming a soggy, oversaturated thing?  Same thing with the eggplant and rock cod.

Maybe it'd be more fair to say that I'm looking for Chinese-food-deconstructed?  In this case, less would definitely be more.
author: Chris G.

description:
I don't care that the food here is "americanized" and not "authentic" because it's still really , really great dim sum. 

My friend and I come in on the weekdays and get the Menu 1 special: 9 pieces of dim sum for $38 bucks (about $20 bucks a person...its not that expensive for all that dim sum.) We usually get:
- shrimp stuffed crab claws
- BBQ pork buns
- sesame balls
- custard tarts (for dessert)
- green chives & shrimp dumplings
- ha gao-the regular shrimp dumplings (2 orders)
- sticky rice wrapped in leaves
- pot stickers

It's freakin awesome food. That's all there is to it.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
My family has gone to Tom Kiang since I was a kid. My mom also orders from Tom Kiang for pick up when she has company over and doesn't feel like cooking. 

For my grandmothers birthday we choose to dine in and had a great experience and meal.  When I was first to arrive I was seated upstairs and the waitress offered a vase with water for the roses I had brought for my grandmother. The service was excellent and the food was better.

First off I love any restaurant with a lazy Susan. With any kind of family style restaurant it is a must. We started with a some dim sum, won-ton soup, and the Tom Kiang seafood platter. My mom normally mixes the won-ton soup and seafood platter together when at home but both dishes are delicious separately. We ordered up 6 of the hot dishes and enjoyed every one.

The total was very reasonable for the amount of food we ordered up. I would recommend this restaurant for dinner for two or a large party.
author: Frankie F.

description:
I know Ton Kiang has been reviewed to death.....but I can't stop myself from adding my two cents. I've been eating here for 15 plus years (we used to go to the old location as well) and have had many a wonderful meal. 

Others can argue all day about whether it's authentic or not, too many white people or not, expensive or not and on and on, but I could care less - the food is damned good! And how can you beat being able to order the your Dim Sum favorites at 8:00 at night? It's Dim Sum on demand!

What works for me is to go in the evening after the dinner rush has died down, sit downstairs and order all my favorite morsels. No lines, no crowds, just me, my family and friends and some Dim Sum love.  I tend to stick with the shrimp and chive dumplings, shrimp and pea tip dumplings,  sui mai, baked or steamed pork buns, shrimp and rice noodle, and the BBQ pork and curried beef pastries, which are not actually on the evening Dim Sum menu but can be ordered by those in the know. I also love the desserts - the flat custard cakes, egg custard tarts, walnut cookies, and mango pudding (with extra condensed milk of course).

The regular food is also good. I know this is going to sound like the most whitebread comment, but they make the best sweet and sour chicken I've ever had! The chinese broccoli and other veggies are usually tasty, and the minced chicken in lettuce cups is always a crowd pleaser. Their fried salt and pepper squid is horrible however, I wish they would figure that out because that can be a truly great dish when it is done right. We ate there tonight and tried the onion chicken with chinese sausage in claypot dish and enjoyed it a lot. My mom is a Peking duck fiend (we get the half order) and it was particularly good tonight with extra crispy skin, steaming hot soft buns, and crunchy cucumber and green onion. (This is beginning to sound like food porn).

We usually get good service, but that may be because they know us by now and are used to the massive amounts of food we order. As far as the authentic argument goes, I lived right off Clement Street for 10 years and tried every hole in the wall Dim Sum place, and there is much to be said for the cleaner environs and much better food quality at Ton Kiang. I don't miss the lovely sensation of biting into a piece of mystery meat gristle or seeing a whole piece of vein in my sui mai that I've experienced many a time at the cheaper Dim Sum places. And you absolutely see large Asian families eating at Ton Kiang - especially at night when the fuss has died down. To all you Ton Kiang haters - go ahead and feel morally superior about your authenticness - it just leaves less crowds and more Dim Sum goodness for me!
author: Laurel F.

description:
The food is so good at Ton Kiang, you can't just eat it. You have to rub it all over your face. Well, maybe not the wet stuff, but they make these steamed dumplings filled with custard that are so perfect and soft that you just have to pat them against your cheeks before you eat them. Don't ask me why. Maybe it's because they are like baby cheeks, so you want to pinch them and cuddle with them. But that doesn't explain why you want to pull them apart and eat them.

OR DOES IT!?!?

P.S. All the other food is good too--The beef pastry thing? What the heck? So good. Best in the city!
author: Tim S.

description:
First of all, I am Asian and eat Dim Sum a lot. I've been to places in SF, Boston, New York, Los Angeles, and Taipei. 

I can't believe the reviews for this restaurant. I agree with Bill S. 100%. Why are people complaining when a restaurant is clean? When the food is creative and delicious? It seems that the reviewers who give this place anything 3 stars or under have the following problems: it's not as dirty as what they're used to, the service is actually good, the food is not as predictable, and the price is a little higher because guess what - they use better ingredients at Ton Kiang. I've been to at least 10 dim sum restaurants in SF and none of them were good. I was thrilled to have found Ton Kiang and drive across town, spend 30 minutes to find parking, and wait an hour to get a table here. It's THAT good. 

Now that I'm in Boston, I can't wait to fly all the way to SF to have another meal at Ton Kiang.
author: Nikol K.

description: Best dim sum I have ever eaten. Prices are pretty reasonable, too. Go for the weekend specials, where the carts come around all the time and the food is always fresh. The asparagus is especially delicious.
author: Steve L.

description:
I see Geraldo Rivera on TV and wonder why he's famous.. I mean WTF is this guy known for other than the goddamn Al Capone Vaults and getting a broken nose by a KKK guy? Then I drive Tong Kiang and wonder why there's a line for this crappy joint. 

This is one of the most expensive dim sum places I've ever been too. The dim sum is sub par at best. But why are people waiting to eat here? If it was located in the middle of Arkansas I'd understand? But not off Geary? There are so many better options nearby.. 

For the price you can do better. I've been here a few times and never left thinking I had a good meal and definitely never was happy for how much I paid for it. 

So you're probably thinking if this place is so terrible why is there  always a line at the front door. Well I find Geraldo disgusting and he's claims to be a womanizer... so who knows..
author: Dan T.

description:
Great service, great food. A little on the expensive side of dim sum, nothing like the prices in Phili Chinatown or Flushing. 

The servers thank you even if you don't order anything from their tray.

They also served us immediately right after we arrived, which was awesome.
author: Bootylicious J.

description:
Went here on a recent Sunday morning. We were lucky and were immediately seated upstairs. When we left, there was a line out the door and down the street. To the staff's credit, despite being unbelievably busy, our group never felt rushed to finish. The service was excellent, and only suffered one dim sum black hole where the trays of food stopped coming around. It only lasted 4 or 5 minutes, and we were so busy eating we hardly noticed. 

We wound up spending about $30 per person on dim sum, so we sampled most everything that was offered. The high points were the sugar pea greens, the shrimp stuffed crab claw, the mushroom and shrimp dumplings, and the sticky rice w/ meat wrapped in a leaf. 

I've been coming here for probably 10 years now and it has always offered good service and solid, fresh, non-greasy food.
author: Sam F.

description:
Sadly, Ton Kiang is not what it used to be. I've been coming every few months for many years, and  the quality has gotten progressively worse in the last 6 months. 

This last visit we were 5 for a weekday lunch. We ordered 18 dishes among us. Overall the food was bland, stale and not tasty. Whoever's managing the kitchen is not doing a good job. For example:
1) the shrimp in the har gow was chewy, surrounded overly starchy wrapper
2) pot stickers were dry
3) the rice in the Lotus leaf was dry and the meat inside was gristly

Overall the service was mediocre: one has to repeat requests several times before getting the items, and the trays often come by in clumps.

Very disappointing to see the decline, especially since San Francisco doesn't have many good Dim Sum restaurants left. At least there's always Yank Sing -- though pricey -- and good places on the Peninsula.
author: Daniel S.

description:
I can't believe i havent wrote a review about this place, i go there all the time w/ my Grandpa. Standard favorites are well-represented, such as perfect pork buns and steamed dumplings stuffed with delicate fillings like scallop, shrimp, green chive or pea tips. The waiters rush right bye you so if you need something raise your voice and holla!!

its soooo dam good, you will go back for sure!
author: Rachel L.

description:
Seriously, can I get a WHAT???

I was craving dim sum for my last meal in SF. I didn't really know why, but thought, hey, it's one thing I haven't tried here yet, so let's do it! Of course we didn't really get the show on the road til about 3 pmish, which in DimSum hours is pretty last call, but we figured this place was open so let's give it a go. 

With that, we rolled in and grabbed a lazy Susan table and tried to figure out what we wanted based on the illustrated little menu of goodies. Immediately I saw the shrimp crab claw and for the drawing alone I had to have it. I mean, cummon, it's like a crab claw sticking out of a deep friend shrimp ball....how can you not.

In addition to the crab claw ball, I also spotted the shrimp and scallop dumpling and thought that sounded yummy too. Of course the two specific things I wanted, weren't being passed around, so we had to special order them...or at least attemtp to order them over the next 20 minutes of comedic genius. There must have been like 12 servers that we tried to order these specifics from and each one would either say okay or no or let me check or something none of us could understand with a giggle and then the next one would come and say it wasn't written down and then another one would come and say yes, then a no. It was dim sum ground hog dammit!

I left more confused than when I started, but it made for a great laugh and a damn good time with friends :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
I don't know that I'll ever have bad dim sum. Seriously. How can you go wrong with sticky rice, sesame balls with bean paste, broccoli rabe or assorted seafood dumplings? I know now all dim sum is not created equal. But as far as my tummy goes, it could care less. BRING ON THE CARTS!!!

Everyone had raved to me about Ton Kiang. Touting it as the best dim sum in SF.  Hmmmmm.  Big words. And it may or may not be true. I still have yet to reach the far edges of the earth when it comes to dim sum. But I'm on a mission.

The food here was tasty for a lazy Sunday afternoon treat with a bunch of cute, smarty pants boys. Service was consistent and fast. I'm kind of in awe of how huge the restaurant is.  I like it and hate it at the same time. I'm a much bigger fan of smaller spaces, but then, where would the carts roll? 

I'd go back here again, but probably wouldn't brave the mega-crowds on the weekends.  I'm sure there are other places to dim sum in the city. Time to make me a big 'ol list and hit all of 'em...I'll report back of course (probably with an additional 20 pounds of sticky rice weight).
author: Stephanie W.

description: Love this place!!! We were so hungry it was 2pm and the dim sum started coming....the waiter who is from Burma is soooooooooo sweet. I love it and my nephew and his gf from Philly (first timers) said they loved it too.
author: Ann P.

description:
It might sound a tad bit cliche to say that the service here was pushy; I know that it often can be in at a dim sum joint, but I've really haven't encountered anything as pushy as this before.  

We were ordering dishes as they came by, but a few of us wanted to order off the menu. They kept insisting that we order two of whatever we wanted off the menu, and when we explained that it would be too much food, they bargained down to 1 and 1/2 orders. Rather than continue the discussion  we agreed to 1.5 and of course out came piles of food that was way more than any of us could consume. (surprising in a way, considering that the dumpling portions are on the small side.) There was just way too much, and it was frustrating and wasteful. 

If I were to  go again, I'm would stick to my guns. But really, I don't think I would go again, as everything was only average, and the price was above average.
author: Dixon T.

description: very good dim sum. one of the few places in the city that serves dim sum during dinner hours. I brought a friend here who chefs at a resort in Aspen. he had an awesome time. he's from Italy and wasn't really exposed to "little bits of the heart (dim sum)."  I don't think Aspen has too many dim sum spots either.
author: Jeff W.

description:
I'm going with 5 stars. Why?? Because I LOVE dim sum. I go through these phases where I become obsessed with a certain type of food and for a long time it was dim sum. I love that they will serve dim sum for dinner. No carts then but still tasty and fun. I love the shrimp stuffed eggplant, sesame balls, BBQ pork buns, all of the shrimp dumplings, the beef rice noodles, and sooo much more. Go with at least 4 people to enjoy the most variety of dishes. 

Yum... now I'm craving dim sum!

Plus my friend was teaching me some cantonese and would make me order in cantonese and they didn't laugh at me. The lady said, "Oh! You good accent for white girl!" If only they knew how often I listened to my old neighbors yell in cantonese. Right before they killed a chicken in our shared yard. Yeah... I'm not kidding. This really happened. It smelled like chinese chicken soup for days. 

Yuck! Now I'm not craving dim sum. At least ones with chicken in them.
author: Ali R.

description:
I eat here every time I visit the Bay Area regardless of the time of day....because to me, any time is a good time for Dim Sum.  You can tell that this is a favorite spot, whether you are a local or a visitor, by the long line of hungry hungry hippos even with similar Dim Sum/Chinese restaurants nearby.  Trust me, it's definitely worth the wait!!!  

Even though I looooove dim sum, I'm not all that adventurous when it comes to ordering.  I don't order beyond shrimp har gow, shrimp siu mai and this particular soft rice noodle dish that contains...ummmm...how do they refer to it again...oh yes, shrimp.  

Everything here is fresh and made with quality ingredients.  I bet even the chicken feet have clean toe nails and the crab claws just had their nails did....
author: Marianne M.

description:
I've been to Ton Kiang on a number of occasions and I like:

1) The sugar snap peas. Garlicky goodness will prevail above all others
2) BBQ pork buns
3) Eggplant and shrimp
4) Mango pudding
5) Quick service
6) Dim Sum all day every day! 

It's a simple place to visit. The food is absolutely fine by my standards - not 5 star quality but I enjoy what i eat when I go there. Plenty of dishes making the rounds so you are not left wondering where everyone went. When I am in the Richmond district, it is always a safe option to take friends.
author: Catriona C.

description:
My brother took me here for the first time yesterday and let me first say that any line you wait in is definitely worth the wait! (I've heard that if you could before 11 am, you're less likely to wait...)

Picture this: 2 floors of wall to wall dim sum and great waiting service. Yup, both at once! Any of the dumplings with shrimp are delicious, the siu mai is yum and the fresh fruit plate is some of the sweetest fruit I've tasted. The spare ribs dish was a bit too chewy, but everything else we tried was GREAT!

I've had the dim sum at Yank Sing in SOMA and it's not as authentic, and much pricier! At Ton Kiang you're really eating with locals! There's something about that which makes your experience more authentic than eating dim sum with a bunch of rich bankers in the Financial District (Yank Sing).
author: Lara D.

description:
My mother in-law and her family frequented this place for years.  You know, you walk in with her on family events and the boss-types seem to know who she is instantly.  You'd think that's good.

"They've gone downhill" griped my mother in-law.  Really?  I had no way of knowing, being new-ish to the City.  As an ABC, I felt the premises were cleaner-than-average for a Chinese restaurant.  By the way, funny how Chinese restaurants are the benchmark for non-cleanliness?

I think the final straw was when at one family dinner at Ton Kiang, my wife's grandfather was becoming unresponsive and looked "really sleepy".  Awake, but just super-drowsy looking and not responding to verbal commands.  

My mother in-law used the house phone (landline) to call 911, which is always the preferred method.  The guy behind the counter raised a big stink about that.  "Cell phone!  Cell phone!" he kept repeating.  Why?  You've got 4-5 phones back there!  Spare one for like 60 seconds or less?

The manager followed my mother in-law out to the entrance to meet the SFFD crew.  He tried to persuade her to call it off.  Maybe it's bad for business.  "Ambulances are expensive!  Why not just take a taxi?" he pleaded.  

My wife's grandfather has a known cardiac history.  Sorry buddy, we're not messin' around.

SFFD arrived within mere moments with no fewer than EIGHT crewmembers.  They grabbed an unused folding partition to give my stunned extended family some privacy from curious onlookers as they packaged up the patient and got him to the ER via the back entrance.

All this time the servers kept piling food on our table from the order.  Nobody was eating at this point.  At least they're persistent.
author: Andy C.

description: Yummy, plentiful food, fast service, doesn't get better for brunch!
author: Joe R.

description:
My favorite Dim Sum restaurant in SF.  Yes, it is way out in the Richmond, but it is so worth it.  They have delicate flavors and handling of the the food.  Not gummy and thick.

I love the black bean short ribs, eggplant, chinese broccoli, garlic pea sprouts, geen dui, lotus custard yummy thingy, har gow, the steamed pork and shrimp dumplings, and almond or mango or coconut jello.  

Love dim sum at Ton Kiang.

It is usually a long wait on the weekend, but patience will win you a satisfied dim sum experience.
author: lonnie l.

description:
There are certain stereotypes you must respect and that is.. the more Caucasians you find in a chinese restaurant, it's inversely proportional to how great the food is.
 
Take one innocent Sunday afternoon when my friends and I decided to try Tong Kiang.
 
The moment you step in, you will find a staggering amount of caucasians inside the restaurant. "Whoa, why are there so many white people inside?" I'm not saying white people cannot judge good or bad chinese food but..okay Yes, I am saying that. Jesus.
 
Take for example, the shui mai, the pork itself isn't tender and the flavor is overpowered by the mushroom taste. Hint of mushroom is what you're looking for, not the dominating flavor I tasted that fated afternoon. Pork? You should look for tenderness and juiciness. Finding both of those in Tong Kiang is like finding waldo with your eyes closed.
 
Next, shrimp wrapped in rice noodle, or should I say, wad of rice noodle with something in the middle. The shrimp had no taste, it's just filling. "But what about the soy sauce?!?!" says the masses.. err....yeah that has taste but ..why even bother putting any meat in the middle if you can't taste it? MASSIVE LOSE.
 
Beef Balls, (meatballs), I am too angry to address this item. (breath in....breath out....breath in...breath out..)
 
Foil Wrapped Chicken, ..I am at a lost for words. I have never seen such an item on a Dim Sum menu. Not here, not Hong Kong, not China. In its defense, it was the best item I tasted there.
 
In conclusion, please don't visit this place if you like dim sum. You're just wasting your money. If you want to say you visited chinese restaurant, go ahead, but there are much better places out there.
 
I do not know why so many give it a high rating. It borders on false advertising and you should be ashamed of yourselves.
author: Rex K.

description:
I like this place because you can get good dim sum in a peaceful clean environment where the servers are polite, friendly, and can speak & understand English.  A bit pricer than most dim sum places but worth it for the environment compared to the usual busy noisy Chinese restaurants. It's not the best dim sum but at least it's not greasy or gooey. 

My favorite thing is their miniature egg custards. You can just pop them in your mouth. Too cute!
author: Van C.

description: Great dim sum spot, especially for newbs! It's a little pricier compared to other dim sum places, but the place is very clean and the food is not too greasy. My favorites here: roast duck, shrimp and scallop dumpling, stuffed eggplant, and deep fried squid. And the mango pudding dessert here is one of the best I've had!
author: Meesh N.

description:
Not to be a hater, but when everyone in line is white... 

Conversation with a waiter: 
me: "Is there MSG in the dim sum?"
him: "No. No MSG."
big pause
"Except in the dim sum."
author: Anna B.

description:
We went a bit late for dim sum on a Sunday (Around 2 pm) and had to wait for a table (about 15 minutes?). Not terrible, considering the crowds I see outside of it. Parking was luck-of-the-draw (on Sundays, good luck in the Richmond).

So, one asks, why the crowds? I think it's because this place is just not intimidating like other Chinese restaurants can be. There are pictures. There are English translations (that are not in Chinglish). Enough said.

BUT, you can also get the hardcore stuff too (or at least what I consider hardcore.). See the chicken feet below.

Shrimp and Chive Dumplings: good. But at $5...? ehhhhhh

Chicken Feet: yay! (Apparently, I am super Chinese. Even my mom won't eat chicken feet.). These were done pretty well. Pretty easy to figure out that they are not on the menu (intimidation factor, remember?), so I had to ask for it. Of course they made a few of them, gave one to us, and then tried to shill the others out to the rest of the tables, with no success. And then they came back to our table, asking if we had ordered more.

Beef Balls, Pork Spareribs: Standard stuff.

Soup Dumplings: where did the soup go!? Also, I really hate the red vinegar (something off-putting about it) but I will forgive in this circumstance. Overall, mediocre. 

Beef (Long) Noodles: I don't know what the translation is, but in Chinese it's "Long Noodles." The rice noodles are wrapped around beef. I like these better than the others in general (shrimp, dried shrimp with green onion, etc). Again, pretty run-of-the-mill.

Fried Taro/Pork: There was a serious lack of ground pork filling in these. 

We didn't get a lot of the standard stuff (ha gao, siu mai, etc), but that's because I have limited real estate in my stomach and there were only two of us. Food was about average overall...I'd say a 3. Service was good, especially for yum cha/dim sum. The servers spoke English (actually, most of the time, they didn't even bother with the Chinese).

The thing that really got me: They charge $1 per person for tea. I'm sorry, but how do they get away with this? I think it's ridiculous. Is it just me? Serious minus points here. AND they didn't even bring the right thing! I asked for a 50-50 bol le and heung peen. I don't know what the translation is for the first, but the second is jasmine, and they brought bol le only.

We paid about $17 per person. To me, that's way over the top. More reason for me to stick to my Chinatown hole-in-the-wall. I guess that's what you pay for clean bathrooms and white tablecloths. 

But plus points for accessibility. I'm glad someone is taking out the mystery of yum cha/dim sum. However, if you ask me to go with you, I could do the same thing, and for half the price.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I simply fail to understand how anyone can tolerate this bland assault on their taste buds!
The staff is polite & reasonably attentive.
The place is clean.
Took some out of towners here for dinner recently (as several folks agreed that it seemed popular) and was so incredibly embarrassed for my fair city by the time we left.  How could this have climbed up even close to "recommended" status in THIS city?  Unforgivable.  And NEVER AGAIN.
author: Vandana N.

description: For many, many months I have been ordering dim sum from Ton Kiang. Not necessarily because it's that good, but because Shanghai Dumpling King has gone from bad to worse and because Ton Kiang delivers. So, for all these months I've been specifying that I don't want any MSG in any of my food and they've been saying OK. Last night I placed my order and the guy says that all of their dumplings are already made with MSG and there's no way to remove it. Umm. OK. So for all this time the Ton Kiang people have been lying about their food on the phone by telling me I wasn't getting MSG in my food. No more, Ton Kiang. Not only is the food barely mediocre, but they serve shark fin soup--a definite no no for anyone who has any sense of moral or sustainable eating.
author: Amy B.

description:
Personally I prefer Yank Sing but my mom has got a thing about Ton Kiang and so when she is in town we go there at least once.  

Ton Kiang might not have some of the more complex dishes that Yank Sing has but I must admit that they do the standards well and once undeniably attractive thing about Ton Kiang is that it is cheap.   

Order away!  No need to hesitate before you say "better take two of those"   Say yes to anything that looks like it might taste good.   In the end you will be surprised how little the feast cost.
author: lisa g.

description:
So my lover asks, where can we go for some good Chinese food?  Duh!  San Francisco is half Chinese already!  

We look up Chinese food on the web and start looking for something in the neighborhood -- no need to go downtown.  And up comes Ton Kiang, with a top rating.   22nd and Geary was not too far away.  

After the parking angels worked for us we found ourselves comfortably seated at a window table.  The service was "leisurely," which was OK.  Why eat in a hurry?  

Good food.  Hakka cuisine.  We had some war wonton soup, sweet and sour prawns, chicken with mixed mushrooms, and BBQ pork fried rice.  All of it was good.  No sticky aftertaste, so I know they went light on the cornstarch.  An hour later the plates were almost clean, and the tab was about half what I expected!  

This wasn't a place I would go out of my way to find, but it was definitely a place that I enjoyed.  I was right, there's no need to go to Chinatown to find good Chinese food.
author: David D.

description:
We've been going to this restaurant for two years now and have not been disappointed in the least.  The dim sum side of the menu has a great selection and very delicious!  The rest of the menu has enough variety that in two years time we have not tried it all and we're in the city often! Service can be spotty at times but overall it's not that bad.

For those not familiar with dim sum (steamed pillows of delectable madness in flavor and ingredients!), it is spelled out clearly here so novices take note and come on down!  

One of my fave Chinese restaurants on Geary!
author: Beth W.

description:
Came here for brunch and glad the wait was really about 15 mins as stated, comparing with Yank Sing that could be well over 45 mins.

Overall Dim Sum was pretty delicious and on the lighter side (not as greasy as some other local joints) but wish they were a bit hotter and steamier. Also they don't have all the different kinds of tea, such as my favourite Ti Kuan Yin. The layered pastry style egg tart was my favourite, even they came in only 3 small ones.

Good place to go if you don't want to go all the way downtown or Chinatown for some authentic Chinese food.
author: T L.

description:
OK this is my favvvvvvorite place to go for dim sum.

Parking is sort of the worst part. There isn't a ton of parking in this area of the outer Richmond, at least not while dim sum is being served at Ton Kiang. But trust me when I say the 20 minutes you can spend circling the block is totally, completely worth the food. 

Somehow there are always a boat load of people here, but we never really have to wait. I prefer to sit upstairs in the main dining area round tables, as they have the best light, and the lazy susan, perfect for sharing. 

If you're there while they are serving dim sum, you are in for a treat. Typical to any dim sum, they walk around serving specific dishes and you can choose if you'd like it or to pass on it. It's really an experience, especially if it's lunchtime on a weekend. 

My favorites are the bbq pork buns. To die for. But everything you can get here is delicious. I am not a big sea food fan, but everyone who is seems to particularly enjoy it here. If you're not there during dim sum, order the chicken chow mein. Also so yummy! 

The only other con is that, when it's busy, the actual wait staff is spread thin, so getting refills/beverages/ordering anything can take some time, especially if you're in a corner. 

Overall, this is one of my very favorite spots in SF. A must try for anyone.
author: Amy B.

description:
a while ago, our family would come here regularly for dim sum and dinner. the hakka chicken, the fried crab over longevity nooles . and  the boiled fresh shrimp were our favs. 

nowadays, i rather sleep a little longer rather than drive over and wait for a table.
author: Victor G.

description:
It boggles my mind as to why people actually wait in line for a place like this. 

From what I remember, this place is pretty disgusting for dim sum...cold and bland and expensive. so I'm pretty surprised to see all these yelpers...probably sf transplants...screaming praises about their food. If I (being Chinese and born in Hong Kong) were to ever suggest going to Ton Kiang, I'd probably get scoffed at and subsequently bring shame to the family. And that's only hypothetical, because I have yet to meet anyone who has the audacity to even suggest this place.

I live less than 10 blocks away from Ton Kiang and I'd still much rather drive to Koi Palace in Serramonte for some decent dim sum.
author: Jeremy F.

description:
Went here for some dim sum this morning with my brother-in-law and his mother. The clientele at Ton Kiang this morning suggests that it caters to all kinds of people, not just Chinese/Asians. I don't know about the price/value of the food, but the portions seemed to be decent for us. Normally though, I feel like most dim sum places feature foods that are bigger than what Ton Kiang had.

However, it was open earlier than most dim sum places in the area, which I give points for. And hey, dim sum all day, every day, plus free delivery for dinner. Pretty sweet deal.
author: Helene K.

description:
Hot dim sum! Okay, that sounded really corny. But hey, hot tamale, hot dim sum! Never mind. The dim sum here is hella good. Just thinking about what I'm gonna write is making me hungry. I can just see the carts right now. I want one of these, and one of those. And two of those! Oh hell, just leave the cart here. I'll bring it back when I'm done with it. 

Anyways, get there early, because the downside is the wait. Unless your Robin Williams. I saw him there one day, and you know he didn't have to wait for a table!
author: Jonathan P.

description:
I've been coming to Ton Kiang since it first opened in the space next to where it actually is now.  It's a place where my family congegrates to celebrate birthdays, promotions, and other special occasions.  The owners are genuinely friendly and they treat us like family whenever we're there. They've seen us grow from lads to old folks over the past 
20+ years.

The dim sum rocks!  My favorites include their onion pancakes, shui-mai, shrimp dumplings, and pork buns. Even Martha Stewart loves this place. She had the owner, William, on one of her episodes of Martha Stewart's Living several years ago.  This is the only place I know in SF that serves dim sum in the evenings too. Interesting to see folks eat dim sum during dinner time.

I highly recommend gathering a group of friends and/or family and try  a banquet style dinner. They have various menus which will surely accommodate everyone's tastes, from vegetarians to those who don't mind trying delicacies (i.e.  jellyfish, sharks' fin soup).  You wouldn't usually eat rice with your meal when eating banquet style. There's about 10-12 items in a set menu, with a fancy type of fried rice or noodles to finish off.

Great place to take guests who are visiting and if you wanna stay away from the chaos of Chinatown.
author: Jonny M.

description:
So many white folks eating dim sum in the same restaurant made me flinch and yes, I'm a white dude. How was the food? read on..

We came in for some good dim sum and weren't disappointed. Nothing jaw dropping or earth shaking, but there were a few items floating around that you typically don't find during dim sum. Like what? Uh, calamari and various meats dishes to name some. Kind of nice to see something different jumping in between the old favorites.

The service was quick all the way until check time , at which time my coworker began waving furiously whenever the guy would turn our way.

The restaurant is pretty big, has an upstairs, but gets busy. Parking is on the street and the prices seemed normal to me.

So, go, stuff your yourself silly and try to ignore a few minor things that might bother you at first.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I've never been to this restaurant, but heard the dim sum there wasnt bad. So, my sisters and I brought our mom there today to try it out. 

I have to say I was pretty disappointed because the majority of the workers/waitresses there could only speak English when walking around serving dim sum. It sucked cuz my mom couldnt understand and to be honest, neither did my sisters. It would be waaay better if they can communicate in Cantonese. In addition to that.......what's up with that restaurant serving soooo many different kinds of shrimp dim sum??! What happened to chicken, beef and etc?! Anyways, I wouldnt recommend this place if you want a true authentic dim sum experience. The prices aren't worth it for the quality of service and variety of dim sum. 

Too bad, but I think there are plenty other dim sum restaurants in the Richmond area that worth your time and money. I probably won't ever go there again....
author: Christina T.

description:
Non-dim sum review.  I've eaten at Ton Kiang a handful of times, and each time, I am always reminded that I wish I went to San Tung.  Yes, the menu is totally different, but Ton Kiang is always more expensive than I want it to be, although the service is much better than San Tung.  The servers at Ton Kiang take care to scoop your rice out in little bowls for you (unlike most chinese restaurants that let you dish it out yourself).  They create your peking duck wrappers with a dab of sauce and some juicy pieces of duck and serve it to you individually.  They cut your birthday cake and serve it to you all nice and pretty.  Even though these are all great things, it takes a long time to eat dinner with a big group at Ton Kiang.  The servings are also oddly proportioned for certain items (a serving of green beans is really small yet the eggplant is really large).  

I will say that the peking duck is delicious, as is the mongolian beef chow fun, the veggie chow mein, the potstickers, the walnut prawns and the spicy eggplant.  Parking in the area is also pretty difficult so leave plenty of time...
author: Mitzi C.

description:
Food:  C
Value:  C-
Service:  C-
Decor:  small typical Chinese restaurant
Return Rate:  Maybe
Best Time To Go:  Don't know yet

Okay, so this is the last lap of the "dim sum run."  Even though we were sharing all the food, we were so full by the time we got to Tong Kiang's dim sum.  Again, we bought everything to go and ate in the car.  By now, we could only eat half of a dumpling each.

First, I raced to the counter and passed the packed dining room because I was on a mission to order just a few dim sum plates (and what I mean by few is two).  But when I read the menu, I was tempted to try some plates that I have never heard of before.  I gave them an extra star for originality.  I'll definitely have to give this restaurant a fair try again when I'm not so full.  But, from what we tasted ... the dim sum tasted average ... and the price can burn a whole in your pocket.

Here's what we ordered ($17):

* SCALLOP & SHRIMP DUMPLINGS: C

* PEA TIPS & SHRIMP DUMPLINGS: C

* GREEN CHIVES & SHRIMP DUMPLINGS: C

* SHRIMP STUFFED EGGPLANT: C

My friend read a review that highlighted the shrimp and spinach dumplings ... I'll definitely have to give it a try next time.  You can find their menu on-line:

tongkiang.net

Here's the funny part:

We took the leftover dumplings with us to Napa because we had reservations for dinner at Ad Hoc.  Yes, we're foodies and proud of it.  I've left food in the car for an hour or two before with no problems, but this was a rental car.  After dinner, we came out  to a car filled with ants who had a preference to Tong Kiang's dumplings ... go figure.
author: Susan H.

description:
Perhaps, the most gwailo-friendly dim sum establishment in all of San Francisco. As good as Koi Palace, Harbor Village, or even the vaunted Yank Sing? Sure, but each spot has its strengths and weaknesses. The tripe is usually excellent as well as the chok [rice porridge], but the table wait can be horrendous.

Is it worth the sometimes long ass lines? No, but you'd be hard-pressed to find another dim sum spot where waitstaff speaks as proficient English or provide as friendly service (on the westside). Not that it matters to me since it's all about the food in the end - I'd wander the backstreets of Kowloon and eat at a dingy hole-in-the-wall where the staff could berate me in lacerating Cantonese as long as the dim sum was excellent.

Hyperbole aside, Ton Kiang is a definite 4-star.
author: Be N.

description: This place is usually awesome and friendly. They open at 9 AM, but beware, they open before any food is ready. Definitely come at 9:30-10, or you won't get cart service or any of the more "interesting" items - at 9, you have to order off the small, basic menu. Once they get going though, this is the best dim sum in the neighborhood!
author: Gavin S.

description:
I've had a couple of dishes during dinner. Although the food was decent, and the seating was fairly comfortable, there are better choices elsewhere.

I would give them a star for the relaxed seating, and another star for the availablity of dim sum servings at night.

Also they had tried to play off a billing "error" by adding a desert that we had never received nor ordered. When questioned they didn't say anything and adjusted it. Little service issues such as this doesn't warrant a repeat experience.

And remember check your bill at this place.
author: Scott S.

description:
i dropped the ball big time in suggesting ton kiang over emporo taste for dim sum with my family. while the environment is nice and the service is good (most of them speak some english too), the quality of the food was disappointing and the prices were totally inflated. 

the biggest red flag was the proportion of asian to non-asian customers. especially when loads of tourists started coming in... i guess ton kiang is now a stop on a tour?! 

onto the food:
1. scallion pancake wasn't flaky or fresh, texture was more like a pita. 
2. gao choy gao (their special dumpling): the wrappers were already broken on a few when we got them! and they continued to fall apart...
3. some un-authentic offerings just bugged me: artfully arranged fruit salad, roast duck, some type of beignets w/powdered sugar
4. wu gok (taro & pork fritter) wasn't fried well -- had none of the characteristic flakiness on top and tasted old.
5. only redeeming items were the baked pork buns... soft and chewy bread, and the filling was just right: juicy, savory and sweet. my mom ordered more to go! 

for all this mediocrity, our bill was $150... even though we had 10 in our party, that's still ALOT to pay for dim sum, especially when we didn't order that much AND nothing special from the kitchen.
author: Jacquelyn S.

description:
I wasn't impressed, but I wasn't disappointed either. I don't get why every Chinese person in SF recommends this place. I think it's because they grew up eating here, but I'm not sure.

The wait is ridiculous, and the prices aren't cheap either. Get here early, and make sure your wallet is packed!

Service is standard, and the decor is whatever. If you're looking for great dim sum, try elsewhere. If you happen to be close, have money, and are hungry, then swing on through.
author: Charles K.

description:
I found it a bit odd that a restaurant served dim sum until 10 p.m., but the opportunity to have dinner with a friend who had a hankering for dim sum was not one I wanted to pass up.

It was not your traditional dim sum.  No carts were being pushed around and they had a limited selection.  Me wonders if they opened the restaurant in the Sunset to give it an "authentic" feel even though it felt like they were not catering to the Asian crowd.

It was not horribly bad.  Service was decent, but if you want the real deal, go elsewhere and not Yank Sing.  They don't cater to the folks want the real thing, Baby.
author: Annalynn C.

description:
After the SF half marathon my friends and I wanted some greasy carbs so we decided to get some dim sum at Ton Kiang. We chose Ton Kiang because of the proximity to the finish line and the fact that it was open at 9AM on Sunday. The dim sum experience was a bit different in that there was no little asian ladies with matching outfits pushing carts with yummy chinese food. Instead you had waiters come around with trays. You could also order the plates off the dim sum menu. It took a while for the food to come out of the kitchen. They kept coming around with a tray with one asparagus dish which was probably left over from the day before...bleh. The food was okay. The steamed bbq pork buns were pretty average as were the shrimp dumplings and sui mai. I was NOT impressed with the potstickers. It tasted like the frozen ones you can get at Costco. They also skimped out on the red bean inside the fried seasame balls. 

Overall this place is mediocre at best. The service is good and the place is relatively clean but food wise...kind of a bummer.
author: Debbie C.

description:
My taste in dim sum is slightly skewed because I am from Seattle.  We don't really know about good Chinese eats up there.  My girlfriend grew up with many fond memories coming into The City and going to dim sum.  This was always her least favorite place growing up.  But apparently, it is also the last standing of the great dim sum houses of old.

If you are from out of town, you should visit Ton Kiang to get your fix.  Unless of course, you know and trust someone to show you the future.  And if you find something better, you should tell me.

That said, I was a big fan of the fried calamari dipped in green sauce.
author: Joshua G.

description:
The line outside says it all...reasonable prices for delicious dim sum.

Just come off hours!
author: Jc C.

description:
My return visit this week to Ton Kiang after a first visit 10 years ago, together with other Yelpers' comments, indicate Ton Kiang's heyday has passed.  While it was exceptional in earlier days, it is now mundane.  
The ordered dim sum (not from a cart) were OK, not exceptional.  
The Hakka clay pot dishes were brown and salty and not differentiated from each other except for a title ingredient or two.
Service was pleasant and efficient.
Parking is a huge drawback.
author: Anne J.

description:
As previous reviewers have also noted, Ton Kiang is one of those Dim Sum joints that has an alarming white : asian ratio. Alarming in that there are too many of us silly white people around. Usually, when that happens in asian eateries, I have found that to mean that the quality of food is poor. However, that is not the case in Ton Kiang. The food, though not authentic, is really quite delicious. Yes, it is Americanized style food, but so what? 

Ton Kiang is more one of those "uppity" Dim Sum restaurants in the vein (and shadow) of Yank Sing and other such places. Not quite as pricey, nor as tasty. However, delicious food for moderate prices. 

Word to the wise: don't come near opening time. I was there once quite early, and it was freezing for the first 30 minutes.
author: Frank B.

description:
Way overrated when you consider the long wait (at least 30 minutes), the bad luck (if you get the table next to the entrance, or at the very end of the little room upstairs), the very bad service (you need to ask at least two or three times to get things... or not...).

Dim Sum are very good though!

I'll try next door Lucky Fortune next time!
author: Mimil H.

description:
two words: spicy mustard.

other important words:
rice noodles with pork
steamed pork bun
chive and shrimp dumpling
sticky rice

i even tried the chicken feet, which i dont think i was quite ready for.
author: Jamie J.

description:
Does Ton Kiang need their 314th review?  Hell no!  Am I going to write one, hell yes!  

At the suggestion of fellow Yelper, Jeff W., we went here for dim sum.  Quite frankly, I was doubtful about this place, having read fellow reviews.  

Maybe it was the recent storms which scared people away, but we were sat within ten minutes and upstairs which was great.  

The dim sum was excellent!  We began with a dish I've never had or seen in Chinese restaurants, green tea salad.  Jeff W. correctly identified this dish as being Burmese in origin.  It's delicious!  A mixture of fermented tea leaves, chopped tomatoes, toasted sesame seeds, peanuts and finely shredded cabbage with garlic and green chilies gives this salad heat and taste.  The sticky rice is also very good.  We feasted upon veggies like dao mao (sweet pea greens) and gai lan (Chinese broccoli).  The roasted barbecue pork was a tasty mixture of fat and pork.   Other dim sum dishes like the shrimp and spinach rolls were hot and yummy as well.

Usually I skip dessert at Chinese restaurants as they're just bad.  This time, a server went by with walnut buns.  Think a triangle shaped bun, golden brown with a half walnut in each side.  Inside, is a delicious walnut paste.  One bite and we ordered two more of these dishes to take home!  They're that good.  Another surprise was the mochi with custard inside.  The mochi has been lightly fried so on each side, it's golden brown and filled with custard which is warm.  The sweet chewiness of the mochi along with creamy custard made for a great mouth feel and taste!

Service was fine.  I find that in dim sum places it pays to be attentive and directive with the servers.  We always got what we wanted and then some.  Water and tea was refilled without our requesting it.  They even brought us fresh plates without asking.  Perhaps they're reading Yelp?

I'd definitely go here again.  Best of all, I was treated. Thanks Jeff!
author: Scott S.

description:
I love the dim sum at Ton Kiang.  I was a regular customer when I lived in the Bay Area.  My husband and I along with my friend and her boyfriend would venture all the way from Oakland to have dim sum here.  The key was to get here as early as possible to beat the crowds because this place does get crowded.

All the dim sum standards (ha gow, siu mai, cha siu bao, etc.) are here and they are fantastic.  I also love their pea vines, shrimp stuffed crab claw, fried shrimp balls, and egg tarts.  But my absolute favorite is their glutinous sweet rice cakes with custard in the middle.  When the wait staff brings them out, you have to get them when you see them because they will be gone in a matter of minutes.  

I think the service here is good.  Staff is friendly and attentive. The only drawback to this place are the crowds and the wait which can be up to 45 minutes.
author: Rowena D.

description:
I don't understand how this place was able to get the San Francisco Focus award for best chinese food in 1998.. Well, there might be one reasoning... I don't believe that any Chinese San Francisco residents know that a "San Francisco Focus" existed.  

Seriously.. Best Chinese Food in  the whole city?!?!     The food is okay, the servers speaking broken chinglish that even the best chinglish experts can't even understand..
