Most of the time, I was just staring at the server with a wtf expression on my face.. and then look at the Foil Wrapped Chicken and go.. "OOOooh Foil wrapped chicken!.. no thanks"

Service was eh....   Parking was Geary St. Parking..   Would I come back here?  probably not..
author: Herb C.

description:
If you are actually Chinese, do not bother.

They have really basic dim sum, and it's really not that great either. I felt like I was going to some dim sum 101 class. All of the dumplings tasted the same cuz they were all just some kind of seafood.  Dim sum is about variety.... and there is not enough here.

It doesn't taste terrible really, I just don't understand the huge line outside. 

I mean, I guess it's cuz they speak exclusively in english so that it's not intimidating... And it's nice and clean.

I guess I'll just have to think of them as doing really smart business... creating a safe enviornment for whiteys.... okay, i'll be nice and say "Non-Chinese" ...to eat dim sum.
author: Bonnie H.

description:
3 1/2 stars overall. 4 stars for the food.

Now I know y'all think of this place as just for dim sum but I decided to come here for my wedding banquet. With about 100 people on the list this place was just the right amount of space for my "small" (by Chinese standards anyway) dinner. I had looked at a couple of places prior to coming here and they were just so damn big for what I needed. Imagine only taking 10 tables in a place that has 30 or more. It's a weird feeling. 
 
The banquet manager was nice and friendly. His English skills weren't bad but once he found out I could understand Cantonese he switched to that. They have a nonrefundable deposit policy to hold an amount of tables for a date. If you don't end using them you will receive the deposit in the form of a gift certificate for you to spend. Not a bad thing.

With the help of my mom we switched out a couple of things on the menu. We went with the classic wedding set menu and switched out the whole steamed fish for fried fish pieces (she says that a lot of people don't like the oil/soy sauce that it sits in, too greasy) and the squab for something else I can't remember (everyone likes to say "that's just a fancy word for pigeon!"). The food was all very tasty and there were quite a few very picky foodies there who said the same. That made me happy. 

What didn't make me happy was:
1. they only had 2 servers assigned to us and only one of them was "offically" ours. So that meant service was slow.
2. the kitchen seemed to have their timings off. The head table (us) wold get something and the last table would get it roughly 20 minutes later.
3. the parking just sucks ass! Nothing new there I realize but because it sucked so badly we started an hour later than we had planned. 

But really despite all that, it was nice and it went off well. I would happily go there for dinner again but with a much smaller group of peeps.
author: cyndi L.

description:
I heard all the reviews about the place so I decided to take my parents here. From what I heard I expected something that was close to what you would get in Hong Kong for dim sum with a great variety.

We got there and the wait wasn't too long. About 15 minutes. The decor looks much better than most dim sum places I know. 

Ton Kiang primarily caters to non-chinese patrons. Most of the servers don't speak Cantonese which was difficult for my parents since my Dad doesn't speak English. This added to a weirdness in the ambiance for me. 

The selection of dim sum that they have is very limited to the standard items. The size of the dim sum is very small, but you can tell they take time to work on the presentation of the dim sum. 

Overall the dim sum is ok but pricey. I also realized I miss the typical ambiance I would expect in a dim sum joint and also a chance to flex my cantonese. I think that you can easily go to another place with equally good dim sum and more variety for a cheaper price.
author: kimy l.

description: The food here is always good. They specialize in seafood and lots of items have crab. We sat in the upstairs back room on our last visit, so didn't get as many servers going past as in the larger rooms. But, you can ask a server for a certain dish and they will bring it, although it may be awhile. Dim Sum for two without beverages was about $50.00, which seems a bit high.
author: Neil S.

description:
I'm biased because I'm Chinese and grew up in the Bay Area, where there are a lot better options for Hong Kong banquets and/or dim sum.  We came here for my friend's graduation this weekend, and she ordered one of the fixed banquet menus. Standard fare including mayo shrimp + cashews (my favorite!), shark fin soup, fish, deli platter, etc. The food was pretty good, but disappointing considering I had heard that it was one of the best Chinese places in SF. 
With Chinese food, you want good food but you also have to decide how you want it served -- you can go somewhere cheap or pay a premium for a fancier environment. 
If you want a nicer, somewhat Americanized experience (dim sum or banquet), I'd recommend Yank Sing.
If you want a nicer, more authentic experience, I'd recommend East Ocean in Emeryville -- granted you have to cross the bridge, driving down Geary to Richmond is just as painful for some of us.
If you want a cheaper experience, I'd just go to the place next door (I forgot the name) or one of the places in Chinatown.
author: Shirley L.

description: Went here for my brothers birthday and the dim sum is amazing. Dont listen to the bad reviews, its the best dim sum in the city hands down!
author: Irina M.

description:
Regardless of whether it serves authentic Hakka cuisine or not, Ton Kiang does serve some really good dim sum.  My family was here recently for a dim sum lunch and we walked away pretty full and happy with our choice of restaurants.

I did miss the rollicking atmosphere of most dim sum places, where there's steam carts full of hot foods ready to run you down, pushed by old Chinese ladies yelling out what they have.  There's nothing like it here, where the old Chinese ladies and steam carts are replaced by trays handled by young Chinese ladies genteelly listing what they have to offer.  OK, so the clientele is also not what you normally see at dim sum places - along with one other table, we were the only Chinese people there.  But, really, the food is what matters right?  And the dim sum here at Ton Kiang is pretty darn good.

To start off, we had the ha-gow, which were a little on the small side, but filled with a good-sized whole shrimp, and the siu-mai, which were also small, but good.  I like the fact that the pork fat, which can sometimes be very evident in the fillings, were not really detectable here.  We then ended up getting things like spareribs, chicken feet, deep-fried shrimp balls, shirmp stuffed crab claws, stuffed eggplant, crispy calamari, deep-fried scallop/shrimp balls, shiao long bao, shrimp rice noodles, and sticky rice.  The chicken feet were excellent- very tender and flavorful, as were all the shrimp items.  The only disappointing items were the calamari and the shiao long bao, which had no soup at all inside, and the filling was a little mealy, rather than being firm.  The calamari was crisp, but oily and missing the kick that usually comes with the diced jalapenos served with it.  

The service was good- my water glass and tea (the one we ordered, hurng peen?, was really good) were always re-filled promptly and the food came out in a nice, steady pace.  Yes, the portions all tend to be on the small side and it is a little pricey, but the food was good.  Nothing was really overwhelmingly fatty or greasy, even with all the deep-fried items we had.  I just wish that Ton Kiang would have a larger dim sum variety, such as tripe, beef stew, daikon cakes, and pork blood, which admittedly is hard to find and would probably freak the non-Asians out.

Overall, a good bet for dim sum.  Parking was not difficult, at least if you get there early and we were seated as soon as we got in.  I'll definitely be back for more dim sum, as well as to try the dinner selection of Hakka specialties, to judge for myself, whether its authentic or not.
author: Angela H.

description: food is generally pretty good.  However, wait is ridiculous and so is the parking.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Yummy dim sum is all I have to say.  

Everything is good the service is good, it's clean, we still go seated today even during lunch time and I always walk out of here full to the brim.

Everyone is always going to have a complaint about a place.  

Love this place.  Not the cheapest but not the priciest either.  That prize goes to Yank Sing.
author: Denise B.

description: Seriously, I don't get why this place is so popular.  I got the most terrible scallion pancake in my life here.  Most staff were pretty good, except for one waitress who was super unfriendly.  I almost felt like it was my fault to ask her to order stuff for me.  They don't have traditional dim-sum carts; they bring out the food with a tray for you to choose.  it's a bit slower than the dim-sum cart way since you don't have enough variety to choose from each time.  You do have to ask the server to order the food for you.  Will not go back!
author: Elena L.

description:
I'll keep this simple because it doesn't need a whole lot of explanation:

1. Average dim sum and way overpriced.

2. Dirty spots on the table cloth where we were seated.

3. Everything was bland and under seasoned.

4. Will I go there again? Not likely.
author: Foodie F.

description:
I sound harsh but seriously this place is WAY OVERPRICED for dimsum! Where is the menu? It's this tiny piece of paper with 12 different types of dishes. 

They do a nice job removing your finished plates. Presentation was nice. A+ on the napkin quality wow. 

Not worth it. So many white folks go here. No offense but I rather go to the real chinatown in downtown SF for dimsum
author: Eric E.

description:
I've always enjoyed Panda Express' orange chicken but at the same time, I've always had two questions in regards to the chicken.

1.  Is Panda Express' slogan "Gourmet Chinese Food" really appropriate?

2.  Is Panda Express' orange chicken really the best?  

To answer these perplexing questions, I had a chance to try the gourmet (the waiters wear fancy shirts) Chinese restaurant, Ton Kiang's, orange chicken tonight.  Finally I would be able to at least know if Panda Express' orange chicken rang supreme, and if it truly had the same taste as gourmet Chinese food.

The Scorecard based on Gourmet (1. Freshness, 2. Quality) and Taste (1.Texture, 2. Flavor) was as followed:

                           Panda Express          Ton Kiang

Freshness                                                  x

Ton Kiang tasted like it was freshly made where I've seen the Panda chicken sometimes hang out in the tray for about as long as it takes me to run a half marathon, and no, I'm not Kenyan.  Panda's orange chicken occasionally tastes like it has been sitting in the tray for some time as the sauce is no longer a smooth glaze but rather almost entirely absorbed in the chicken.

Quality                                                         x

Again, this is one of Panda Express' weaker categories.  I'm not saying the quality is bad at Panda's but I don't get the impression that it is good quality either as it's probably best to eat the chicken with your eyes closed instead of analyzing the type of meat inside.  Ton Kiang served quality slices of chicken that appeared to be all white meat.

Texture                        x

This is where Panda turns it up a notch.  I like the crunchy texture of Panda's orange chicken.  It's like KFC popcorn chicken meets sweet orange flavored sauce and has a beautiful child Orange Chicken Jr.  Ton Kiang's texture was a let down as the chicken was too lightly breaded and the chicken swam in the sauce.  Panda's more heavily breaded orange chicken absorbs the sauce enhancing the flavor of each bite of chicken, breading, and sauce in unity.

Flavor                          x

I liked Panda's sauce a lot better.  Ton Kiang took a little creative license and made a spicy orange sauce but the mixture of spice and orange didn't win me over.  On the other hand, Panda takes a sweet orange sauce approach to their dish that is delicious.



Final Results:  

Which is more gourmet?

Panda's Express' slogan "Gourmet Chinese" food seems a little far fetched since Ton Kiang just seemed much more gourmet, and it wasn't just the fancy shirts the waiters wear at Ton Kiang.  The restaurant scored significantly higher in both the freshness and quality categories.

Which tasted better?

As far as taste, Panda Express' orange chicken still ranks supreme with me scoring superior in the texture and flavor categories.
author: Josh K.

description: Man this place is overrated!  The dim sum is ok - but NOT  for the $$$ price. The regular menu items are so Americanized and bland they remind me of my Mom's canned "Chung King" creations.   Sad in an area where excellent Chinese food abounds.  Roll over to Mayflower up the street for the 'real' deal.
author: Julienne G.

description:
My friend recently hosted a baby shower at Ton Kiang. I thought the food was very tasty, however, the service....not so much. 

They were not very accommodating to our large party and were very short with the host's of the baby shower when talking with them. When it comes to service in this industry, being accommodating should top a restaurant's list. This was not the case. I wish they could have been nicer, after all, our party was giving them A LOT of business (40 people). 

The food: Goodness, there was so much food. I thoroughly enjoyed the bbq'ed pork buns, hearty pot stickers, and shrimp and spinach dumplings. I also highly recommend the foil wrapped chicken, which I ate last time I was there. Ton Kiang is a good place for dim sum, I just wish they would be a little more friendly and accommodating.
author: Laura D.

description:
As this was my first Dim Sum experience, I can't really speak to the Authenticity.  What can I say, I'm a reasonably Anglo Jew who doesn't eat a whole lot of Chinese food.

Anyway, the experience was interesting.  The food here was enough to send even non-Jews to hell.  I think everything on the menu was a mockery of  the very concept of kosher.  Pork this, crab that, shrimp EVERYTHING (or so it seemed)... but the food was reasonably tasty, and while it was overpriced for what we received, the experience itself was fun.  In retrospect, the food was like most other greasy Chinese take-out places I've tried.  Certainly nothing to write home about.

Most of the dishes ranged from $3 - $4.75, but a few were $5.75.  One of which included some wok-fried baby bok choy.  How in the hell does a pork dumpling cost $3 but some green veggies cost double?  Someone clue me in on that one.  The total cost of our meal for three, including two hot tea orders was  $54.  Ouch.

I'd go back if someone took me and offered to pay, but I think based on reviews I've read, I think I'll seek out more authentic dim sum next time I go out.
author: Daddy O.

description: Love this place.  Chicken feet delicious!  All dishes were piping hot and very good.  Service was fast, and servers were very attentive.  Which Chinese restaurant changes your plate without requesting it.  Highly recommend.
author: T. C.

description: It was good but I don't know that I'd go back.  We went for dinner there at 5.  The dim sum menu shows drawings and the selection from that menu isn't that great.  The ambiance is just ok.  No carts or waitresses with trays - we had to order straight off the menu so the experience was lacking.  The food was good but I've had comparable dim sum at the bakeries on Irving for much less.
author: Juliana X.

description:
All i have to say is, what dim sum place have servers that don't speak chinese!!!! so annoying!

i ate dim sum here for mother's day with my sisters and we were totally confused cuz the servers were announcing their dishes all in english. I speak english but i know my dim sum in chinese. we asked the servers to tell us what they have in chinese but she looks at us confused in return. because she doesnt speak a work of chinese! not in cantonese or mandarin! how werid is that. i understand their main target are tourist or non chinese speaking customers but c'mon! it's a dim sum rest. I mean there were a few that spoke chinese but i would say a majority of them did not.

The food was not oily like typically dim sum but i just can't get over the previous fact.

I wouldn't recommend this place for people who are use to regular chinese speaking dim sum restaurants but i would probably recommend it for those who don't speak chinese.

I finally understand how my non chinese-speaking friends feel at dim sum rest where they have to look at the dish before deciding on choosing it or not....super weird!
author: Bevo T.

description:
Dinner for my buddy's 30th birthday bash was here at Ton Kiang.  I hear from people that parking is a pain in the butt, but lucky me, I found baller parking right in front!  Hahaha...

Anyways, we had the following:

Westlake Beef Soup - pretty good.  Tasty and lots of ingredients in the soup.
Stuffed Fried Tofu - a bit too crispy for my liking.  Usually it's crispy on the outside, and soft on the inside.  
Dry Fried String Beans - the beans tasted a bit chewy.  
Salt & Pepper Spare Ribs - lots of flavor, and not too battered.  Pretty good!
Some Fish and Veggie Dish - didn't try it as I was already stuffed.
Sweet & Sour Pork - looked good, but didn't eat that as well.
Boiled Chicken with Ginger & Scallion dipping sauce - the chicken was cooked to perfection.  Not dry at all!
Walnut Prawns - good, but not as good as Yat Sing in Redwood City!

Service was actually pretty good.  We had three out of the four tables upstairs, and the waiter was very attentive, and would get whatever we needed pretty quick.

Seemed a lot of customers downstairs were eating dim sum.  I think I may have to come back and try it.  

All in all, we had three tables, about 30 people, and we each paid $31.  Not bad at all!  Good job Pam L.!!!!

A side note.  Ton Kiang seems like they cater to non-Asian diners, but the food is pretty authentic!
author: Daniel M.

description:
As I read through some of the other reviews, I noticed a consistent correlation between low scores and dim sum - interesting. Here's the thing - I don't really eat dim sum. So my review has nothing to do with that. Nor have I ever actually been to the restaurant, so I cannot speak about the decor, food presentation, or crazy lines. I'm a straight-up Chinese take-out kinda gal, and that's what this review focuses on.

Positives: Large selection of dishes spanning many categories (plus veggies - try the asparagus!), including the usual suspects and originals; Not greasy; Cooked to your style (ie: sauteed vs. steamed); Consistent.

Negatives: Fairly pricey; Minimum 45-minute delivery (and I've experienced MUCH longer)

But since food trumps almost all else when it comes to my delivery joints, it's an easy 4 stars. Thank you, Ton Kiang, for saving me from Andy's Excellent Chinese Food. Yes, I used to order from there. Sigh.
author: Kiesha R.

description:
We are from Hawaii and lack decent dim sum. Ton Kiang is a must for great dim sum and any thing else that comes out of the kitchen that is not on the menu.Listen to your waitress's reccomendations. 
Service is very friendly, fast feels like being home.
author: Joy K.

description: This place used to be pretty good for Dim Sum.  It appears that it has gone down a little in the rating.  Not sure if I will go back to try them again given the higher prices and yelped lower quality of the food.
author: Jim J.

description: This place has really gone down hill.  Shanghai dumplings had completely collapsed all the soup absorbed into the wrap, which made the wrap soggy.   The other stuff we ordered was mediocre at best.  My advice is don't go.
author: Carmen S.

description: not sure how this got 3 stars. great value, solid and fast service. will go back. ordered a 9 item meal for two for less than 40 dollars before tax and tip. this is a neighborhood gem
author: Frankie S.

description: I dont understand the negative posts but I personally thought the place rocked...The variety and frequency in which the choices came out was impressive.It seemed like every other minute a new,tasty looking dish came by the table-it was hard to say no! the dim sum was solid...very good quality and not that expensive we had a TON of food for 3 adults and 1 kid and it was like 65 bucks...I for one will be back!
author: james m.

description:
It takes two buses and over 40 minutes to get to Ton Kiang from where I live, and it's usually followed by at least a 20 minute wait for a table but once inside, any hassle is immediately forgotten.

The dim sum here is certainly not the best in North America - Lai Wah Heen in Toronto currently holds the top spot in my book, but I'm not about to take a 5 hour flight just to get some of their heavenly dumplings. 

However, as dim sum restaurants in San Francisco proper go, it's a perfect balance of quality and price. I've never had a bad piece of dim sum there, and the mochi filled with coconut custard is one of my favorite desserts regardless of cuisine.

Standout dishes: snow pea shoots with garlic, rice noodles with char siu, crab claws in seafood mousse, shrimp with snow pea shoots, har gow, mango pudding and the mochi-custard. The Pu Erh tea is good, but not outstanding.

On top of that, four of us ate until we almost burst and it only cost us $20 a head, half of what we would have paid at Yank Sing. Expect a wait, but it's worth it.
author: Avery G.

description:
Dim Sum. You lose some...money that is. The food and selection here was amazing!!! When we got our bill, it was definitely higher than normal dim sum prices. Amongst four people, our bill came out to $107, not including tip. 

I have to confess though. We did order massive amounts of food. We probably each ordered 4 dishes each, plus 3 cokes, and one extra pan fried seafood noodle dish. 

I like this place b/c they had variety in their plates. It wasn't your normal shrimp this, shrimp that.  Normal dim sum houses only carry shrimp dumpling, shrimp rice noodle, etc. but this place had soft shell crabs, clams (the most amazing clams ever), turnip cake, tofu ginger dessert, bbq pork rice noodle - they usually only carry beef or shrimp rice noodle, sauteed spinach with pine nuts, and every combination of dumpling or shumai you can imagine.

I would totally recommend going here, but just expect to pay about $25-30 per person.
author: cynthia b.

description:
Good food - but not "authentic" dim sum. You will see that 90+% of the customers is non-asian. You will be asked questions in English. You don't have to combat your way to get the pieces you want. But despite of the non-authentic feelings, I think that their dim sum tastes really good. Their specialty is seafood, so almost every dishes include a piece of shrimp. And there are a lot of fried dishes, too - nothing against that, just an observation. 

Between my brother and me, we stuffed ourselves and drank as much Bolay tea as we wanted, and paid $42 + tips. Not the cheapest stuff, but I enjoyed it very much. 

Oh yes, you GOT TO have the sesame ball right out of the kitchen. Superb way to end the leisurely lunch.
author: Mio S.

description:
When we moved to SF we were told this was 'the' place for dim sum.  Maybe because we went in expecting so much we were very disappointed.   We went back 3 more times really wanting to like this place but it was not to be.  The hargow has no flavor the shrimp chung fun is too puny compared to the best dim sum places we've been to.  The crowds and 30 minutes it takes finding parking doesnt help either.
The dim sum at Yank sing and Koi palace is a step or two up in comparison.
author: John P.

description: As for dim sum, i'd say Ton Kiang was average. Then again, I haven't had too much experience with dim sum, but I often go to Yank Sing since it is my dad's favorite place.. and I'd say they're definitely better. This place was definitely not bad though! I enjoyed my time. The servers were very friendly, nice, and quick. There were also a bunch of tourists in here as well, I'd say about 40% which was pretty shocking! I'll be back though.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Honestly, You can tell this place is not authentic.
All the good reviews are from people outside California and from states known more for their lack of Asian population than for.

That being said, it's not horrible food, it's just not authentic and there is definitely much better, more interesting flavors elsewhere.

It's good for an Americanized dim sum.  The onion pancakes taste more like pizza dough than real onion pancakes.  The black sesame filled mochis just have a hint of black sesame instead of the ooziness, the soup dumplings arent juicingly watery, so yes, all the Asian flavors are there, but it's just doesn't have that oomph that really makes it pizazz and say "wow, that's dim sum!"
author: Cathy U.

description:
We went to Ton Kiang for the first time today, and will definately be back again!  The absolute best Dim Sum we've ever had.  We had Shrimp dumplings, scallop dumplings, spinach, egg rolls, pork dumplings, steamed and baked pork buns and more.  Everything was tasty, hot and served quickly.  The place is small enough for service to be good, but large enough to hold plenty of people.
Can't wait till we go back again.
author: Sandra M.

description: dim sum until 10 pm?!  what's not to love about this place.  My husband's fam and I stopped by last night and they accomodated all 12 of us without a reservation.  I loved it. the food is delicious and left me wanting more.  My husband and I will definitely be back.
author: Christine P.

description:
You know a place has to be good when it brings out mass racism.

"I bet all the shillers and die hard non Chinese fans who line up here before opening like those who camped out overnight for Garth Brooks..." -Ken K.

"The moment you step in, you will find a staggering amount of caucasians inside the restaurant...I'm not saying white people cannot judge good or bad chinese food but..okay Yes, I am saying that." -Rex K.

"...if mainly frequented by caucasians... then those are the warning signs! "  -J.W.

"(packed) with white people!...We were the only Asians..." -Jane L.

...I never realized that by being white (not just non-Asian but WHITE), my eating at a Chinese restaurant 1). offended people, 2). made the food served there inferior and 3). hurts the reputation of a Chinese restaurant because white folk lack the proper heritage/sense/taste.

How many of these folk of Asian heritage have actually BEEN to Asia, I wonder? And I can't help but ponder the reaction I'd get if I came up to a couple of Chinese descent in some random diner and told them their presence was a clear indicator of crappy grits or subpar fried chicken?

Racism sucks, kids. Ton Kiang though, was good food.
author: Bill S.

description: Best dim sum in SF. A bit less exotic then yank sing buy fresher flavors, and at 30% less
author: David B.

description: It's alright, not memorable to me. Pretty much taste like all other dimsum places, but it's a LOT cleaner. The younger generation seems to go here.
author: Stacy C.

description:
DIM SUM IS NO FUN. for me at least. I don't like most Dim Sum dishes, especially not before noon. 

However...
Their dumplings and egg rolls are awesome and the service is so fast that the wait to eat quickly vanishes from your mind. 

I also maintain that it's better to go to busier restaurants for Dim Sum because the food they bring out is more fresh and not luke warm (which is disgusting). 

But there are about 50 other places along Geary and Clement that are about 500 million trillion times better (and cheaper) than this place.
author: Ali L.

description: Ton Kiang is pretty good for dim sum, however the wait is a bit disheartening. The service most of the time is fast; a few times I went it wasn't so, but it's on and off. Most of the dumplings come out steaming hot  as well as the porridge and other noodle dishes that you can order off of the menu. When I go with my family we usually order pretty much everything on the dim sum menu, give or take a few items. I know for sure there are other places in San Francisco that probably have better dumplings, but for a neighborhood pit stop, Ton Kiang hits the spot.
author: Mirabella C.

description: Ton Kiang is one of the unfortunate casualties of the recession. In its heydey, it would have a long wait out the door for its scrumptiously delicate dim sum that came hot of the kitchen. The last time I experienced that level of food was in June 2008. Sadly that is no more. There is no wait and because of that, the same food rotates among the one floor (not the usual two floors) that is open. The selection is significantly limited and gone are the special items I raved about such as the large steamed oysters and the fried tofu. I have moved on to greener dim sum pastures where the dim sum quality makes up for the long wait.
author: Gwen L.

description:
I've had the pleasure of having dinner, banquets and dim sum here and enjoyed every experience!  Their dim sum is my favorite and I'm willing to make the drive and wait outside for 40 minutes to enjoy the delectable delights that are waiting inside for me.  

The banquet we went to here was great.  Good service, excellent quality of food for such a large party (the sea bass was incredible - a true delicacy).  I love the way that they prepare their fried rice, it's more moist than the other fried rice dishes I've had at other restaurants.  

This place is always packed, but it's a two-story restaurant which makes the restaurant deceptively larger than it seems when peering into the window.
author: Amy T.

description:
My very first dim sum experience!  My friend took me here because he figured it would be unintimidating.  He was right--clean, English-speaking, blah-blah-blah.  Now that I know what the food is like, I am eager to find something a bit more authentic!  

So we ordered the dim sum for two and here's my run down:
--Cha Siu Bao (barbequed pork buns):  Something familiar and didn't disappoint.  
--Sung Jin Bao (vegetables & pork buns):  Same as above, though I prefer the former.
--Gao Choy Got (green chives & shrimp dumplings):  Not my favorite.  Somehow, the texture was really funky.
--Wah Tip (pot stickers):  Pot stickers--what more do I say.  Wasn't fabulous but at least familiar.
--Dao Miu Gao (pea tips & shrimp dumpling):  My favorite of the night!  Like a shrimp potsticker--flavor was amazing!
--Chun Gun (vegetarian egg rolls):  No good.  Could not have paid me to finish them.  Greasy!!!
--Don Tah (egg custard tarts):  Yummy!
--Jin Doy (sesame balls):  So sweet! 
--Nai Wong Siu Ben (egg custard rice cakes):  Surprisingly, my fav.  Like little spongy pancakes, sweet and funky on my tongue!

We also ordered the Mongolian Beef, cuz I was craving some.  Great flavor but the meat was fatty for my taste.

Overall, it really was a great place for a white girl like me to try out something new.  Looking forward to trying new places (and hopefully saving a bit of money!).
author: Melissa Q.

description:
BOTTOM LINE
Yum yum. Great place for a group of friends and to sample a wide variety of Chinese dumplings and such. Love the foiled chicken.
author: christopher r.

description:
Fresh. 

The best pot stickers--homemade with just the right thickness in the dough. 

Their pork won ton soup (with chili oil added) has staved off colds.

They deliver ($20 min). Tip your driver and you'll eventually get your food hot. 

If you go for dim sum, go early. Rice wrappers can get soggy at night. The sauces are excellent. NO MSG. The shrimp & snow pea pod : p
author: Blue R.

description: #71 on the Stuff White People Like list (Being the only white person around at an ethnic restaurant) was definitely not followed for this place, so that can't possibly bode well for its authenticity.  When the food finally rolled around, I wasn't proven wrong.  Most items here were mediocre at best.  The har gao skins were breaking upon contact, the sui mai meat was pretty heavy and dense, and most dishes were unremarkable.  The only good thing is now that I've gotten this place crossed off my 7x7 list, I won't have to come back anymore.
author: Gary L.

description:
So Dr. B and I went here for lunch cause HK Flower Lounge was killing us with the wait.  We got seated quickly upstairs where there were only 2 other tables in use...nice. Dim sum ladies were pulling out the good stuff right off the bat. The shrimp dumplings were delicate and really tasty. I got the shanghai dumplings which were heavy on the skin and not enough juice T__T...not like the ones in Hong Kong. I like the foil wrapped bbq chicken, that was really yummy. I really love the bbq pork puff pastry. The pastry was really nice and thick. I applaud Dr. B for taking a chance on the braised chicken feet which was spicy and delish. I have friends who'd scarf down pig's intestine and ears but not a chicken foot? (They're not true foodies).  The shrimp, chives and mushroom dumplings were good, but we both really liked the veggie and pork buns...those were awesome. 
A couple of times, Dr. B. kept looking longingly after the asparagus or long green beans dishes...but we had lots on order and we can't possibly eat all that food...there's always next time!

We had quick water/tea service and the food was tasty. We'll be back for the duck which I heard was also must eat.
author: Pauline L.

description:
I haven't had dim sum in a long time. With that said, I really enjoyed the food that I ordered. There was nothing that I didn't like. They had a wide selection of non-dim sum dishes, as well as dim sum dishes. 

Me and friend did their special for 2 people: 9 dishes of dim sum (2-4 servings per dish) for $38.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
I live across the street, so I have the ability to beat the crowds and get there right at 10a on a Sunday morning.  My friends favor the fast-food dim sum and the more inexpensive dim sum places (like Golden River next door), but those other places are just not as satisfying for me.  
What does Ton Kiang have that the others don't?  Shrimp stuffed eggplant, shrimp stuffed crab claw, egg custard rice cakes, shrimp balls and the mango pudding ( with the little bits of fruit floating in the middle).  Perhaps the others do have this same selection, but when I go to Ton Kiang, I never have to ask for it special.
author: Gail O.

description:
I love this place.  The dim sum is reliably delicious and there is usually a large selection of dishes coming out of the kitchen.  It's great becuase some of it is really traditional and some is simply palatable to whiteys like me.  
Left off one star because it's really expensive for dim sum.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I wanna talk some shit about Ton Kiang!
I have to give it three stars only becasue it is such good dim sum dude!  But i hate when people I am about to give all money to are treating me like poo.  They are so rude here....everytime.  It makes me soooo mad becsaue they know i will come back for the amazing food, and there is nothing i can do about it becasue who doesn't love this place. UGH
author: Rachel P.

description:
I could not tell you what Hakka cuisine is.  I am a proud banana, so don't expect me to be of any use here.  But I do know my dim sum!

Ton Kiang has never failed to please if you are lucky enough to be seated during peak dim sum hours.  The waitstaff is very friendly and speaks English a lot better than one would imagine.  The man behind the counter operates like a pit boss, counting money and ringing up checks efficiently and with barely a word.  The dim sum comes out of the kitchen piping hot and ... damn, I just ate dinner and I'm hungry again!

Simply put, there is no more heavenly dim sum experience than the crab claw with shrimp dumpling at Ton Kiang.  Eating these was most likely how Buddha got fat.  The $6 order consists of two claws (not sure what kind of crab, not Dungeness) dressed in a generous globe of chopped shrimp, and a lightly breaded, delightfully deep-fried coating.  The first bite gives one (ME!) the perfect contrast of sweet crabmeat with savory shrimp, and upon my last visit for some to-go dim sum, had me happy tooling down Geary Street with steering wheel in one hand, napkin in the other, and crab pincers coming out of my mouth (have you been to this area?  I fit right in).

Ton Kiang has some of the most amazing dim sum, at also sometimes the most amazing prices.  For those of you yeller-fevered 'low fans' trying to impress your date or your girlfriend's parents, at least try and get them a table here, OK?

A tip: get a table downstairs, because you'll get the food straight out of the kitchen.  It seems that the waitresses do themselves a favor by lightening their load before heading up the stairs.
author: Wayne Q.

description:
DIM SUM, which means "small heart, " is at the heart of this review.

My mother, my teen son and I were having dim sum at about 10:30 AM on Sat, Sept. 4, 2010.  Suddenly, my son developed hives all over his face and neck.   We assumed that it was something that he ate (he hadn't eaten anything that day until the restaurant).  I rushed him to a drugstore for benadryl.  After taking it, we returned to the restaurant.  I approached the owner--he is the one who stands at the cashier area--and told him I'm a frequent visitor to his restaurant.  I told him what happened and asked him about the ingredients because it would be good to have some idea of the allergen, e.g. was it the shrimp, do they use oyster sauce, do they put crab meat in some of the diim sum items?  He seemed put off but answered my questions.  He didn't ask exactly which dishes we ordered, which could easily be done by checking our bill.  (I had to ask him to look at our bill to see what dishes we ate.)  I was shocked that he never expressed any concern about my son, and even though I asked him to talk with him directly about what he might've eaten (my son was sitting with my mother in a booth), he refused to leave the cashier area.  He said, "he can come to talk to me."

He didn't show a shred of concern about the health and welfare of a customer.  We will never return to this restaurant and I will be sure to share this story with friends and colleagues.  The literal translation of dim sum is "small heart."  In this case, they demonstrated their lack of any heart at all.
author: Liana T.

description: Dim Sum was a priority on our list of must-eats while visiting SF after moving to the Pacific NW. We're so glad we re-visited TK where the service was good and the dim sum more than satisfied our craving. We took a cab from Union Square so you could say we paid a pretty price for our dining.  But, hey, we were on vacation and it was so worth it. Pork buns, shrimp and scallop rolls, Jin doi, name it we pretty much paced ourselves so we could savor every dish.  Read other reviews about the concerns for freshness, but we had no problem with that.  Perhaps because we got there when it first opened? Only downside:  duck was fatty and too oily
author: J F.

description:
A friend and I had dinner here last night before going to the theatre.  I was surprised to see dim sum on the menu at that time of the day so I couldn't resist choosing a couple - a shrimp and spinach dumpling and a tofu skin roll - both tasty - however, I think the dim sum at Koi Palace in Daly City is more palate pleasing!.  I had an an order of the jelly fish which my friend would not even allow on her side of the table....it wasn't bad but , again, I've had better

For our main courses, we shared a seafood basket of squid, calamari and prawns, sweet and sour pork, and chicken and baby bok choy - all quite good -  but not really what I would consider great.  I guess 
I was expecting more with the Gourmet and Zagat signs posted.  

Of course, they do have an extensive menu with shark fin soup, abalone, lobster, banquet offerings, etc which sounded quite wonderful.  Our budget didn't allow for those.

By the time we left, the restaurant had completely filled - no Asians among us.  Staff were friendly - though a bit slow...we had to ask for the Sprite we had ordered and the sweet and sour pork arrived late in the meal.  Nice and clean.  If I were in the neighborhood, I might go back again but there are so many other places in the area that I like better.
author: Carmen H.

description:
Ton Kiang is an excellent "Introduction to Chinese Food" restaurant for those not initiated into the more eclectic and bizarre regions of dim sum eating.

Food is fine.  Dim sum is better then average. but a little pricy.  I'm more of a cheapy, mediocre "I got two dozen har gaw for $1.50" kinda person so this is not really my style.  (The Costco mentality:  I bought a gazillion microwave Pop Tarts for $3.75.  Death by Pop Tarts ensues.)

Anyways, everything is pretty decent.  If you know dim sum, you'll go for what you like.  Nothing really jumps out at me though.
author: Aron L.

description:
When I know that I want really good dim sum in SF and I am going to drive all the way out there from emeryville to get some... Ton Kiang is the place!  I love taking friends and family here, and they always come away wanting to return. 

The stuffed crab claws, har gow, siu mai, and fried shrimp balls are excellent!  The service for dim sum is quick.  And the long lines are worth the wait (I try to get there earlier to beat the crowds... but honestly, by doing that you might be missing out on the good stuff that rolls out later towards the noon hour).

I judge world class cities by it's dim sum.  I guess TK would make SF one of them.
author: Alex D.

description:
My favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco. Every time
I try another one, I'm sorry I did. I've been eating here for
more than 15 years, and the food is always consistent
and delicious. The vegetables are never overcooked.
Every dish that I've tried is good, buy favorites are the
salt and pepper squid or shrimp, their Hakka style
eggplant, and their Mongolian Beef. They are the
only restaurant that knows how to cook okra right.
author: Winifred D.

description:
I haven't done the Dim Sum thing here (yet), however coming in for regular Chinese Dinner the food was solid, although a bit on the bland side.  I especially liked the winter melon soup.  Service was great and the whole thing was easy on the wallet.  

Kirin is still the favorite Chinese restaurant of this neighborhood, but Ton Kiang ranks as a good backup.
author: John H.

description:
I'm sorry I thought i was going to go eat at a Dim Sum place where id get good food. I'm used to loud, poor service Chinese restaurant where the redeeming factor is the cheap price for some great grub. Sadly NEITHER of those manifested! Loud waitress? Check! She was loud when there wasn't a sound in the place!! Hot food? Nope I'm sorry they didn't serve that!! Some cheap delicious morsel to warm my heart? Nope, rather we were given some expensive tiny thing with no taste.

I will pay for good Chinese food, i will suffer loud environment with poor service for good food, but if the food can't keep up with the crap they sling they should just be called Ton Kant
author: Brian Y.

description: This place is good.  Me like.....droooooooool.
author: Brian K.

description:
4.5 stars
Two friends brought us here. Let's just say I didn't have high expectations since they weren't Chinese / Asians. How wrong was I. This place has a great variety of authentic good tasting, high quality dim sum... more variety than my favorite spots in NYC's I dare say. Only thing is they are just a tad pricey - $100 for 4 peeps. Sure it's only $25 each but dim sum doesn't / shouldn't cost this much. There are economies of scale at work here! 

I love the char siew buns and various shrimp items. OH MY... it's OH SO GOOD! Dainty and high quality dishes (repeat 100 times).
author: Laur T.

description:
When I first arrived for lunch, there was a wait -- always a good sign at any restaurant.  The restaurant is relatively large, so we were seated quickly.

The food was good, hot and made to order at request (if one of the waitresses doesn't bring what you want you may order things not on the menu).

Some criticize the number of whites -- I did notice the Asians were seated downstairs and predominately whites upstairs.  I'm not one to judge a restaurant by its clients, but, rather, its food and service!  As a non-Chinese speaking individual, I can under stand the draw for other non-Chinese speaking people.  The waiters and waitresses all understood English and I didn't feel I benefited from having my Chinese sister-in-law with us.  At other dim sum restaurants, I felt at a loss because of the language barrier.  Not so here.

This is a bare bones, clean establishment.  It was not overly friendly service, but it was extremely fast (other than that we had to wait for our special order).  The food was good, the tea was excellent.  We stayed and talked after our meal and didn't feel shuffled out of our seats.  Prices were great.

I will return for dim sum!
author: Sarah T.

description:
Came here with a big group, for my friend's company dinner on a Thursday night.

I'm not sure if they serve dim sum in evenings or if they just did it because we were in a big group and pre-ordered our dishes, but we started with a bunch of small appetizers/dim sum and then went on to the bigger meals.

My favorite were the pork buns, I've never had them before! The service was great and very attentive, my water glass was never empty.

The place is definitely a drive from where I live (hayes valley), but I'm going to return for round two (soon, very soon). It's also a little tricky finding parking. 

(disclosure: I didn't pay the bill or even ever look at a menu, so not sure how the prices look)
author: Radha S.

description:
Perhaps it's the hype, but I was less than impressed.

This was way too overpriced for dim sum. I've had better dim sum at less than half the price.

That's not to say it wasn't good food; there were a few items that stood out in particular. But all in all, I suppose there's a good reason why there was a 2-hour wait at Koi Palace this morning and no wait at Ton Kiang.

I'm realizing more and more that the SF Chronicle top 100 list is extremely hit or miss, I've had amazing meals at some of them (omg Aziza and Foreign Cinema), and lousy meals at others (Hog Island Oyster). But as someone who can't go to all of them, I really just hope that I have more hits and misses....
author: Mark A.

description: This is the best dim sum I have ever had and believe me, I have had a lot. Their big, fat shrimp balls are fab-u-lous. They have more vegetables that the average dim sum joint. Not cheap but worth every penny. Even the desserts are fantastic - especially the custard filled rice disks when they are still warm.
author: Marco M.

description: Ton Kiang Restaurant at Geary Street is a wonderful dim sum restaurant. I have been here for lunch. Ton Kiang Restaurant may look small on the inside but I have to say their dim sums that they have is one of the best and not to pricey.
author: William B.

description: This place was pretty good for dim sum, its a SF staple that I highly recommend.
author: John Z.

description: The dim sum here used to be top-notch but I think it's losing its credibility. It is still decent but nothing to rave about.
author: Lia C.

description:
Ton Kiang to me is that one restaurant reserved for random family visits or for random special occasions like your graduation but you didn't have time to make reservations for some other place.

The good quality has never failed me, though the price points are a bit interesting.  I don't mind the service, as I've received far worse from lesser places, though I often receive excellent service when I do go.  I tend to go on the weekdays when there's not much of a crowd and parking is more ample.

Dim sum service is like any other sit-in dim sum places.  You have to practice your stern game face and say no when you really mean it.  But when you get your desired plate, boy was it worth it.

Despite its up and down reviews, I still regard Ton Kiang as one of my favorite San Francisco restaurants.
author: Frangelo A.

description:
My husband's favorite dim sum in San Francisco. Parking is miserable. Afterwards, stop by one of the nearby Russian bakeries, such as Moscow and Tbilisi Bakery 5540 Geary Boulevard 
(between 19th Ave & 20th Ave) San Francisco, CA 94121, (415) 668-6959, for black bread.
We eat here when we're on our way to see the 16th Ave Tiled Steps Project or on our way to the De Young museum.
author: Vena V.

description:
I'm Chinese and I still think Ton Kiang rocks for immaculately-prepared, fresh dim sum.  

You can special order any traditional dim sum items you're craving from the kitchen.  (True their normal cycle of dishes are 80% shrimp of some sort.  That's for the white people.  Special orders, baby!)

It's NOT that expensive!  No, it's not 35 cents like in Chinatown, but it's not a shithole either.  They're well-staffed, and it's clean and efficient.  You get what you pay for.
author: Melanie C.

description:
I love Ton Kiang [for lunch]. 

The dim sum that comes table to table is awesome and I love that you can get mango pudding and Chinese donuts.  

This place is fabulous but I prefer going for lunch when the small portions are offered to each table as the server passes by.

Dinner [after 4ish] just doesn't offer the same flair, it's served family style which is not comparable, which kinda takes away from the whole experience.

Still I love Ton Kiang.
author: Kat R.

description:
If you want to pay more for your dim sum and want to eat amongst non-Asians, then this is the place to be.  The restaurants serves dim sum and Hakka cuisine (Ton Kiang is named after a river in China where a majority of the Hakka people settled).

Food:  2 stars.  For the price you pay (most dim sum platters averaged around $3.50 - $3.75), I expected more from the bol choy gao (shrimp & spinach dumpling), siu mai (pork dumpling), ha gao (shrimp dumpling).  The worst was the don tah (egg custard tart), which wasn't even mildly sweet.  The most decent dim sum was the dao miu gao (pea tip & shrimp dumpling), mainly because I have a thing for pea shoots.  I liked the greasy but delicious crisp-skinned duck, though. I wanted to suck those duck bones dry, but didn't think that was appropriate given the amount of non-Asians sitting around me.  

Service:  1 star.  The difference in service on weekends vs. weekdays is like night and day.   Don't expect good service on busy weekends.   You're bound to see dishes repeat themselves (shrimp dumplings came by about 20 times) and there wasn't enough variety.  On weekends, it's tough to get any attention from the waiters who take care of the checks and any other special requests.  It's the complete opposite during the weekdays when the crowds come in at a slower pace.

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  This is a good place to introduce a non-Asian (who is a bit squeamish about food) to Chinese dim sum (chicken feet is not on the menu).  I think the place could be cleaner, though.  It's time to do a little remodeling.  The non-Asian clientele is primarily mid 20-to-40-somethings from neighborhoods outside of the Richmond (the locals probably go elsewhere for their dim sum).

Hits:   Crisp skinned duck, dao miu gao (pea tips & shrimp dumpling).

Misses:  Don tah (egg custard tart), parking really sucks.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Yank Sing, R&G Lounge, City View Restaurant
author: Keith C.

description:
Ton Kiang is disgusting.  If you're asian, make sure you go extra early because you're going to have a longer wait.  I just came back from there and is now writing this while sitting on the can with severe food poisoning.  

First and foremost, we waited 45 minutes for a table while other parties that came after us were called in first... big and small parties alike.  They were all caucasian.   Apparently, you can make reservations now for dim sum..... when did that happen? Or did she just tell us that so the hostess can sit others first.

After hounding the hostess, we were seated upstairs.  The place was filthy.  The carpet was old and smelly.  The tables were wiped down with some tea.  I'm Chinese and has been to my share of disgusting tea houses, this is one of them.  

The food.  Perhaps, this experience can be salvaged with the food.  The chicken feet was actually pretty good.  Everything else was garbage.  The chicken sticky rice tasted like it had salted fish in it.  The shrimp in the fried rice was slimy.  The filling in the bbq pork fun was grayish in color.  

It was also pretty darn expensive.  Granted it is xmas, so they can jack up the prices.  The shrimp fried rice was $18!  Everything for 6 people who doesn't eat much.... a whopping $105, not including gratuity.  

Needless to say, I'm not going back to Ton Kiang ever again unless I absolutely have to.
author: Stan V.

description: This is a great place with great service. You cannot beat their Dim Sum, ok well maybe someone can, but it is great.
author: Michael B.

description:
When it comes to Dim Sum, my old standby is Gold Mountain in Chinatown, but when a friend came to visit and we wanted to try something new, we gave Ton Kiang a try.  It was definitely worth it.

Ton Kiang is more upscale than Gold Mountain.  It offers a somewhat more diverse selection and a larger bill at the end of the day, but given the quality of the food, it remains a good value.

Check it out!
author: Mitchell F.

description: Excellent dim sum, but parking can be difficult on a weekend night.
author: J T.

description: Nearly as good as Hong Kong itself!  Informal enough to drop by for a meal without thinking about it.  The more friends to share the better.  Decently priced as well, expect to spend about $15 for lunch, tea & dessert.
author: Vanessa R.

description: GOOD dim sum and that is not common surprisingly in SF, but this place is very popular, you will have to wait and pay the price. mwahahaha. Desserts are yummy too. Oh, also they will try to bring the same dishes around and around to get rid of the not so popular ones, and it's like a treasure hunt for the desired dishes... no I don't want the egg custard, where are the shrimp and chive har gao?!
author: Lily G.

description:
--3.4 Stars--

First things first:  GET HERE EARLY!  This place seriously packs up quickly.
Second: Prepare to drop down some $$$.  It's quite expensive for the Dim Sum here compared to what I can get here in the San Gabriel Valley, Rowland Heights, Irvine area.  
Third: The food is good.  I love Dim Sum, but it didn't have that big WOW-Factor I was anticipating from all reviews here. 

Enjoy though.  It's pretty good stuff if you're in the mood.  

Itadaki!
author: Edmund I.

description:
Having just landed back from a weekend business trip to Denver, I was driving home this morning craving Dim Sum.  I've not been to TK in several years but suffice to say it has always been an old standby for my family, greatly appreciated and enjoyed.   As I sat myself down for a much anticipated meal, I cracked Yelp to glean some current commentary which I now know was a silly and useless move.  I was bothered to see a number of more recent and harsh 1 and 2 star critiques that makes the present day incarnation of this restaurant seem as though Rome has fallen on Geary Street.  I  write this review as I eat my meal, and for the first time ever (regarding Yelp) feel the need to counter the aforementioned opinions with just-plain-fact.  As I do so, I'm reminded of two universal and ever-more-apparent truths: 1) Democracy is best executed without involvement of the masses, and 2) Opinions are like a**holes. Everyone has one.  

Here is the truth.  The restaurant serves food today that is as tasty and high-quality as in ANY previous incarnation / dynasty.   I have eaten here off and on for many years, and know of what I speak.  Further. The service is stellar, with kind waiters and servers eager to please and respond. Turnaround is quick.  Lastly. for all the negative reviews which I assume has helped to direct the hoards away from TK to Hong Kong Lounge nearby (lines used to be out the door, with 20 minute waits not uncommon,) one now has a chance to be quickly seated and enjoy a meal that remains stellar.  The negative whining reminds me of why the opinions of many current San Franciscans - on ANY TOPIC OF IMPORT - should get a unanimous half star vote as it's own Yelp category.   Give these guys a break.  EAT HERE.  You'll be glad you did.
author: Brad S.

description:
Delicately nibbling away at the shrimp-stuffed crab for dim sum to reveal the claw?  So satisfying.  I always end up taking home more pork buns than I could ever eat. Yes, it's totally White Folk Dim Sum, but it's never failed me.

Edit:  I have to take back one star -- now that I've found my favorite breakfast dumplings -- and since I've been sworn to secrecy, well, that's that.
author: Melissa G.

description:
Me to friend, "Hey, have you heard of Ton Kiang?  My cousin's boyfriend is having her birthday there?"

Friend to me, "That's on Geary, right?"

Me, "Yeah.  Is it good?"

Friend to me, "Don't know.  Never been there, but I think there are a lot of white ppl there."

Okay, so I was not completely shocked to walk in to see full tables of non-asians.  that's okay, it's not like when i walk into a club and see a lot of asians, i think to myself, "great, there's going to be a fight later."
okay, so maybe i do that sometimes...  so I was ready to give it a chance.

To be perfectly honest, this place is not all that bad.  steamed fish, chicken, walnut prawns, all pretty good.  Also, for a chinese restaurant, the service was awesome.  i felt someone reaching over me and i looked up bewildered and it was actually a waitress filling up my glass of ice water!  she may as well have broken out into opera while she took our order.  i was that bewildered.  

Anyway, a pleasant experience, but I don't think I will be back there.  You know, the parking in this area is so bad, that i think i will avoid geary between 18th and 25th forever.  i parked 5 blocks away after 15 minutes of circling.
author: Scott Y.

description:
I only make it up to SF once or twice year, but you'd better believe we don't leave town until I've had my dim sum fix at Ton Kiang. Parking is a BITCH, but I'm motivated, so we come early. Ha Gao, Cha Siu Bao, Siumai, xiao long bao, jin doy, fun got, and gao choy got (OK I think I have a Dim Sum problem, as I am not Chinese) are delicious and the servings are just the right size. So cute! I love that you get to chose the type of tea that will be served and the tiny little tables. The dipping sauces are lovely, not what I'm used to getting down in San Diego. 

Sad to say, we went to Ton Kiang twice in one weekend the last time we were up in the area. We must have impressed them with our ability to consume "mass quantities", they gave us mango pudding for free (or was that a desperate ploy to stop the insanity?) Hoping to head back up in October...guess what my first stop will be?
author: Marie G.

description:
Im just NOT nuts about Dim Sum, but when my buddy wanted to go here for his birthday, I thought I would give it another go, and well, I am not complaining about spending too much money cause it was my bud's birthday...BUT, I spent TOO much money on dim sum, for sure!  

First we had the fried shrimp balls, nice texture tons of shrimp, BUT..that steamed flavor has got to go!  I just hate that "meshed all together " taste and aroma from Dim Sum....then we had the steamed ones and again that flavor of I don't know what. We also tried the fried shrimp with HEADS on them!! YIKES!!!!!!! 

The ONLY thing I recommend here is the Spring Rolls, and the potstickers, they are too die for!  But, way over priced and it feels like a flea market the way they walk around with the bamboo steamers.  They are not too happy if you turn them down.  I have decided way overpriced, and I JUST do not like dim sum, and this place is NOT the best, I do not think.
author: Bahvee V.

description: I love the seafood dim sum here. I think it's one of the best dim sum places in SF and I have lived here for a long time. The only problem with it is the awful parking situation but I guess it beats going to Chinatown. It's probably best to bike there, take the bus or arrive really early like 10am. Otherwise, you'll be standing in the cold since you're in the Richmond district...and in SF. (I also wish there would be a sign at dim sum places that says you had enough food and would like to wait...something along those lines. It's just a general comment.)
author: Kelly N.

description:
Today is a Sunday and I just came back from eating dim sum here. We couldn't decide between this restaurant or Hong Kong Lounge. We haven't tried either before. We drove by Ton Kiang and saw that there was nobody waiting outside the restaurant, which we thought was a bit strange at 10:30am on a Sunday morning. We decided to drive over to Hong Kong Lounge and there were about 30 people waiting outside, mostly Chinese. We thought, "Hong Kong Lounge MUST be good if there were so many people waiting." However the wait was 1/2 hour-1 hour so we decided to just go back to Ton Kiang since it got good reviews on Yelp and we had to be somewhere else by noon. We were seated immediately at Ton Kiang. As soon as I sat down and looked around, I already had a bad feeling....

1) I am Chinese and realized that we were the ONLY table of Chinese people seated on the upstairs level. And that is not an exaggeration. 80% of the tables were filled with Caucasians, while the others were Japanese, Filipino, and Hispanic. I don't have anything against other ethnicities at a Chinese restaurant but when there are NO Chinese people at a Chinese restaurant, ESPECIALLY a dim sum restaurant, that is a red flag...aka TOURIST restaurant. 
2) We would see the same food every 10 minutes.
3) The waitresses shouted out the food names in ENGLISH. BIG red flag. This is the first time I've seen this at a Chinese dim sum restaurant and another sign of a tourist restaurant. How weird to hear things like "Soft Shell Crab and Tea Leaf Salad" which are not traditionally dim sum and not even traditionally Chinese.
4) There was a limited selection of dishes, maybe only 20 different dishes, so I had to special order some that were typical dishes such as taro cake, shrimp dumplings, egg custard tarts, and service was VERY slow to bring out those dishes. We wanted egg custard tarts for dessert and I had to ask 3 different waiters to remind them, and half an hour later and still no tarts, we were impatient and decided to just ask for the check. It wasn't until after I had received the check that they brought out the tarts so we said forget it.
5) They took away our entire teapot half an hour before we left and never brought it back with tea. It wasn't until the busboy started to clean our table that he noticed we had no tea at all.
6) On our way out, we noticed that the downstairs level had more Chinese people, so we wondered if they seated on the English speaking customers upstairs where there are English speaking waitresses who shouted out dim sum in English *shakes head.*


So how was the food? It was only okay and I've had a lot better. The Xiao Long Bao, or the Shanghainese dumplings did not have any juice in them, the onion pancake was underfried, and the shrimp cheurng fun had tiny pieces of shrimp. I have had better dim sum from a dim sum bakery. 

Price of dim sum: $3-$6 per dish. We ordered about 12 dishes and our bill came out to $43 pre-tax.

Would I go back? No, probably not. Going to try Hong Kong Lounge next time.

Would I recommend this place? Chinese people would be disappointed. I suspect this place has a lot of reviews and many which are good because the people here on Yelp are not elderly Chinese grandparents who've truly eaten and know good dim sum and the qualities of a good and authentic dim sum restaurant. Tourists or people who don't speak Chinese would probably enjoy this restaurant a lot more. By the time we left the restaurant at 12, all the tables were full but still no wait for tables.
author: Erika C.

description:
3.5 stars

I really enjoyed this place, though it didn't blow me out of the water.  So better than okay and almost a fan, though I will defiantly go back there again.  

Went there with a family of 6 plus me, making it 7 people and I got to sample at least 9 things including some pot stickers.  All were pretty consistently good, but not being a huge Chinese food fan, it was a bit harder to judge.  All I know is that I was really full at the end!

My favorite was the sweet and sour chicken-- that was great.  Super flavorful and it went like crazy.  The chicken and mushroom was good too- lots of flavor but too much sauce.  We got one order of dim sum which I would like to come back and try again.  I really would, especially because of all the reviews of the dim sum here.  Another dish that was tasty were the pot stickers.  

All in all, the food was good, not great, but I will defiantly be back to try some dim sum!
author: Cara D.

description:
No rating would do this place justice... I understand people can have this place overhyped and then be disappointed.  Works for me, the lower the rating the less likely my table is taken.  However, don't be mistaken, weekend brunch here is phenomenal.  Say what you want about Yank Sing but I take Ton Kiang everyday of the week, you can just tell the difference in the customer base.

Shrimp balls, dumplings, sticky rice w/ meat wrapped in banana leaf all blow my mind.  Their seafood is fresh and tasty and I love that it is off the beaten path and somewhat of an excursion.  Like I said it's a very different feel than some restaurant downtown or in the marina.

I have loved Ton Kiang for more than 10 years and I will never turn my back on them.  Thank you for being such an integral part of my life.  My favorite dim sum by miles.
author: Cole W.

description:
I kinda have mixed feelings about this place.  Where do I start?

First of all, you know it's strange when you go to a dim sum place and half the patrons are white.  That's a bad sign already.  Usually, you know a chinese place is good when it's filled with asians.  Not to be racists, but Chinese people such as myself -  1) Know good chinese food and 2) are cheap and will go to places that are either a good value or so good that they can overlook the price.

When I go out for dim sum, I want good food at a decent value.  I don't go to a place because I hear that it's the happening place to go for dim sum.  That said, the dim sum at Ton Kiang is actually pretty good.  The prices are pretty outrageous for dim sum if you order individual items ($5 to $7 a dish), but it's more affordable if you pick their set of 9 items for $38.  You get to select any 9 items off their menu, and it even includes items not on the standard menu, but then you have to ask for them specifically.  For example, chicken feet and shrimp rice rolls and included, but you need to ask for it.  It's still on the pricier side for dim sum, but it's do-able.  Definitely go with at least the 9 course, because you'll need to eat at least that many dishes to be full.  The portions are pretty small here.  The har gow (shrimp dumplings) taste good, but they're only half the size of Hong Kong's Lounge's same dish.  The other dumplings and dishes are the same story; everything is tasty, but a smaller version of Hong Kong Lounge's dishes.  Some things actually taste a little bit better here, but I kinda feel gyped when it costs more here and is smaller.  After all, there are also other dishes that are better at Hong Kong Lounge.  

Other than the dim sum, we also ordered half of a Peking Duck.  The skin and meat of the duck tasted very good, but there were so many crushed bones everywhere!  I don't mind bones, but when it's all crushed and chopped, it's hard to separate it from the meat and inevitably I bit into a few bone fragments.  Last time I had Peking duck somewhere else, it was boneless, and for a place like Ton Kiang that caters to Caucasians, I expected the duck to be boneless as well, lol.
author: Tyler C.

description:
I just dropped $50 here on a date last weekend.  

The crummy economy is working for me!  No wait and parking nearby.  I liked it all but was transported by the hot egg custard dessert. Yum-Oh!

I dunno why people are not loving the service, I thought it was fine.
author: Sugar E.

description:
Why write the 251st review of Ton Kiang? Because there were 250 people waiting outside for dim sum on a Sunday? Actually 75 is more accurate. This place is popular on Sunday. Really popular. And I'm not sure I understand why. 

3 stars. Solid. Fast service so if you don't want some weird scary dish, you can get your favorite selection. But if you scan the reviews here, you can see very uneven reviews from great to lousy, and there are some reasons why.

Principally, the servings, for dim sum, are small. Some of the dumplings are outright tiny, and my Eat-Like-a-Bird wife spotted this first. The quality is solid, but nothing made me want to write home, or sing, or simply rip my clothes off.  The translucent dim sum -- my favorites -- were all well prepared, fresh, and light. The sesame pancake was yummy although greasy.

Ton Kiang merits 3 stars for solid dim sum, but that's about it.
author: Jeff W.

description: Go early!  Ton Kiang is good and the line of late risers is evidence.  The downstairs space seems dedicated to smaller groups while the upstairs is for large tables.  As with nearly all dim sum joints, service is minimal to non-existent.  If you need something not being served by a dish walker, be persistent.  Forks are hard to come by and require extra effort to get.  The Burmese tea leaf salad was one of the highlights.  They mix it right at the table.  But their more traditional dim sum are average--not bad, just not outstanding.  If you're in the city and want a sit-down dim sum experience, Ton Kiang is fine.  But if you're willing to do take-out visit Good Luck Dim Sum on Clement.  And if you're from the South Bay, go to The Joy Luck Place and save yourself the drive.
author: QuodE D.

description:
Excellent dim sum and reasonable price!! 
Many shrimp dishes which we love so we were happy
author: Patrick Z.

description:
I am a Dim Sum junky who is a now dating a loyal Ton Kiang patron.  As a result I have been there for lunch or dinner no less than fifteen times.  After extensive sampling I can say that while the dim sum is good (light, not super greasy and usually hot), it is really expensive.  A basic lunch for two is now running us almost $40 with tip and tax (ouch).  Sadly I am addicted to their egg custard rice cakes and haven't found anything like them anywhere else in the city.  (Anyone know of any place else, please feel free to pass that information on!)

With the exception of the wonton soup (which is excellent) dinner is barely above sub-par.  There are lots of better Chinese food place for dinner.  

Overall I give Ton Kiang three stars instead of two for their rice cakes (darned addictions) but Ton Kiang better step it up a notch if they expect us to wait half an hour to forty five minutes to pay $20 a head for dumplings.
author: Jocelyn B.

description:
I LOVE Ton Kiang.  They have amazing dim sum - try the BBQ Pork Buns, Shrimp & Chives dumplings and the Siu Mai.  

Other entrees on the Menu to check out:  Chow Mein, Clams w/ Black Bean Sauce, Snow Pea Tips.

A little pricey for Chinese food but well worth your $$.
author: Natalie S.

description: I've been here twice in the past couple of weeks for Dim Sum. Both times I was impressed with the selection available for someone who doesn't eat poultry or red meat. They also have quite a number of steamed options. I've often walked away from Dim Sum feeling over-greasy but both times here I felt great and even healthy. The price is right, the tea is great (and it just keeps coming).
author: Stacey C.

description:
This is by far the worse dim sum place ever!!!! EVER!

Everything there is way too salty. Even my friends from Canada, where they don't get a  lot of dim sum places think Ton Kiang is bad.

Bottom line, go to this place if your tongue has no taste buds!!!. Otherwise go else where.
author: Paul W.

description:
This is the McDonald's of dimsum, if that makes any sense.  

Finding parking is atrocious, and if you come after 11 am. (who eats shrimp on a weekend before 1pm?) the line is pretty bad too.  That being said, it's relatively cheap and pretty good... kind of like McDonald's.  Mind you, I only get a Mickey-d's craving once a year...

I will say, this is the only dimsum place I've been to that makes a deep-fried crab-claw stuffed shrimp.  SO worth every bad calorie!  

You can also order a la carte on non dimsum cart toting days if you aren't a big fan of hailing down your food.... it's just less exciting.
author: L. K.

description: I reached there close to lunch time and was surprised that there is still space left for me and my friend to sit. Of course, I tried the dim sum where I heard is their specialty and it is no surprise that is incredibly delicious. They have a variety of dishes served there and the best in my opinion is their chicken feet mix with spicy sauce. Yummy!
author: Mei Kim P.

description:
Came here three weekends ago for a surprise birthday party and then came back again this past Saturday for some dim sum with friends. And surprising, both times, NO LINES! Perhaps, around 11am or noon, the lines die down. 

The food is decent. Not too much of a vegetarian selection. The service is ok, although I wish they would have a sign you could put up at your table that said something like "No more. Please move along." It gets kind of annoying when you no longer want any more dim sum, but the ladies keep coming by. 

Parking here is a pain. 

Total bill with tip: $105 (And this was "light" eating for our party, meaning we didn't stuff our faces full of food! Pretty expensive for dim sum!)
author: Caroline C.

description:
Horrible horrible horrible.  Did I mention this place was horrible?  If you like dim sum do not eat here.  I must admit I was drawn by the lines on the weekends waiting to get in, but the day I decided to try was the day I realized there were a lot of confused taste buds out there.

Ok, I will say the establishment is clean and the menu is very picturesque.  However my gut and more importantly my taste buds are telling me they are catering to the pretend dim sum crowd.  If you want a cheap burger go to white castle, if you want pretend Mexican go to taco bell, if you want Americanized Chinese mall food panda express is your calling and if you want to tell people you had dim sum (but didn't really) then Ton Kiang is your ticket.

Also The bill came to ~$60 between 2 people and 7 dishes.  Any other place that would be ~$25.  Save your money and go to a real dim sum place or eat something else if you do not have the stomach for dim sum
author: Steven T.

description: Not much selection. Ive been here for brunch dimsum and for dinner... not a fan. Food is decent but not proportional for the price. Its clean and large but I go out to eat not stare at a bunch of paintings on the wall.
author: Amy S.

description: What is better then Chinese food on Christmas day....... SANTA BRINGING ME A GIFT. Personally it is a tradition. I wanted good food and I got it here, But the service was awful and the atmosphere was if I was at the airport. Overall decent maybe it was a bad day for the staff, I'm sorry bu a hit or miss.
author: Chris H.

description:
Not my first choice because of the parking and the food. Maybe I just like Yank Sing, and it's my point of reference for all dim sum, but this place pales in comparison. I found the non-beef/pork items to be lacking (I only eat things with less than two feet and fins, call me a weirdo).

Ton Kiang feels like a place that was probably super fly in the 80's but never really changed much since then. Rough on the edges, a bit antiquated and even outdated in some spots. Sort of like David Hasslehoff.
author: Charlene L.

description:
Ton Kiang in three:

1. Small dumplings

2. Big flavor

3. HUGE bill.

Go to Good Luck Dim Sum on Clement - not as good but much better value.
author: Karsten P.

description:
Someone recommended this place as a good dim sum place. Uhm. I think they might've told me the wrong name or I misheard it.

The food I think was sub-par. I couldn't really tell the difference between the dishes I was eating. I mean, isn't fish supposed to taste different from pork, etc?

Anyway, the final bill did not impress either.
author: Mashimaro M.

description: Just ok.  the food was better years ago when they weren't as fancy.  i would still head to the suburbs for better chinese food and dim sum, but not bad if you're looking for a quick fix of chinese food.  i do like the ambiance better than the otehrs in san francisco.  and the service is nicer and less abrasive than other chinese restaurants in the city.
author: Street S.

description: Ton Kiang serves the best Chines food in San Francisco in this price range. The salt and pepper scallops are amazing!
author: Charles S.

description:
I have been eating at Ton Kiang for most of my life.  I am pretty sure they are responsible for my introduction to Chinese food.  My parents used to order delivery from them and sometimes we would go out to eat at the one that used to be on Geary and Spruce (at least I think it was Spruce.  it coulda been Cook).  Anyway, I used to think it was the best.  Not like people say to their friends, "Oh you're the best" best but really and truly the BEST.  Well, as time has gone by since those days and I have become a kind of food addict if you must, I have such encountered quite a few better restaurants that serve my needs in a much more affordable fashion.  

What really sparked this whole need to rant about Ton Kiang without being too specific about their food was that the last time I ate here I got food poisoning.  Not from something you might suspect, like some random meat dish or some crazy fish soup, but hot and sour soup and a pork bun.  Maybe I was just unlucky and got the e.coli piece, but that left me shattered.  

I still love them though, no matter what, because of what they did for me and all food that is Asian.  They got the ball rolling and you can't forget your roots.  I give them 4 stars.  One for the Mongolian beef that screams for me in the dead of night, one for the sweet walnuts covered in sesame buried beneath a mound of mayonnaise drenched shrimp, one for the constantly full cup of tea, and one for the sweet egg custard cookie things during dim sum that always double my check because I eat so many of them (I would get them if I were you).  Take one away for my stupid food poisoning experience because it ruined my Giants game.  I still love you though baby.
author: Charley B.

description:
