I typically go by a general rule w/ Chinese restaurants. 
If the ratio to non-Chinese to Chinese is high.... leave. 

No offense, but think about it... if there aren't any Chinese people in a Chinese restaurant... how good can it be?!

I ended up there for a super early dim sum session by default. Apparently, at 9 am Mayflower (down the street) isn't open. 

I'll be truthful... they serve 230942830948 types of shrimp dumplings. It's not too bad, but after the 3rd tray, I just asked the waitress to bring me out what i wanted. The dim sum food's pretty solid, if you can overlook the random stuff catered towards non-Asians (ASPARAGUS at dim sum?!?!?)  

Tip: just order from the waitress if they don't feel like eating asparagus at dimsum.
author: Angelinaaah h.

description:
Is anyone else perturbed by all the comments about how it's a bad sign that lots of white people go to Ton Kiang?  This shouldn't be an issue.

There are plenty of shitty Chinese restaurants that are patronized mostly by Chinese people.  There are also great Chinese restaurants whose clientel reflect the diversity of the city.  Ton Kiang is one of the latter.

The food is almost all great, although ever-so-slightly on the pricey side.  I like the Wor Wonton Soup with mixed seafood and some pork buns to go with it. 

For Saturday or Sunday morning brunch, be prepared to wait in line for  30-60 minutes.  I think it's worth the wait.  My favorite dim sum item is the stuffed mushroom caps.  Delicious.

***Edit***
Avoid the salt-baked chicken.  The menu claims that it is a specialty, but it's bad.  The chicken skin, which is is very limp and fatty, features much too prominently.  Plus, I hate to be a spoil-sport, but I think they should season chicken with more than a dump truck load of salt.
author: Joe R.

description:
Went for dim sum around 12 noon a Saturday. Got in with no wait and seated upstairs. Generally presentable and friendly wait staff.

Really liked the shrimp and spinach dumplings, mushroom dumplings, and garlic spinach. Intrigued by the crab claw stuffed with shrimp, but this was not as tasty as hoped. Foil wrapped chicken was good, but requires some handiwork. 

For first timers or occasional dim sum'ers, this restaurant is nice in terms of choice and presentation.
author: MandS R.

description:
I am no expert, but I know a thing or two about dim sum. I love the stuff, and have eaten it from countless sources throughout my life. I've had it from street vendors, bakeries, low end dives, and fancy palaces of dining. None come close to Ton Kiang-- the most delicately prepared, tasty, clean dim sum I've ever eaten.

They offer a wide variety. They serve it at all times, so even if you come at dinner time you can order it. They don't have leftovers sitting around, either-- they make it fresh to order.

My online moniker, Peasprout, was chosen due to the deliciousness of Ton Kiang's preparation of the vegetable of the same name.

It can be difficult to park in the area on a busy morning, and you can sometimes be forced to wait some time for a table, but piffle I say. I'd wait twice as long, and walk twice as far from the car to eat this stuff.

I seldom order anything other than Dim Sum, but when I have I've been pleased. The steamed fish, always a good indicator of a Chinese restaurant's worth, is spectacular.
author: Greg G.

description:
Food:
I wasn't too impressed with the dim sum here. After first walking in, I noticed the high percentage of customers who were non-Asian, usually a bad sign if you are looking for authentic chinese. My bf and I took a friend here for her first dim sum experience, and unfortunately, she missed out on the usual dim sum carts that are usually pushed around at other places.

Service:
The service was ok, but they were hurried as the restaurant was full of customers.

Atmosphere:
It was loud and full of people, but as I mentioned earlier it was a mixed crowd of Asian/non-Asian.

Value:
I don't remember what we paid for the dim sum here, but if I return, I may go there to try something other than dim sum.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
Decent dim sum is found quite abundantly in San Francisco. Having said that, there are probably only a handful of places that you can go for dim sum where you don't have to deal with stereotypically curt and surly Hong Kong-style service. Ton Kiang is one of them. Which might go to some lengths to explain the abundance of non-Chinese diners there.

We have been there many times over the last couple of years, and it has always been quite consistently good for us. The dim sum is very good, but I wasn't as impressed when we had dinner there one time. So it is only a dim sum restaurant as far as I'm concerned.

Parking in the Richmond district is simply terrible, and there are often waits for a table at Ton Kiang, but the service is good, with friendly wait staff. The decor is decent, and doesn't detract from the experience.
author: Adrian L.

description:
Waaaaaaaaaaay too much MSG ruins it for me here.   In fact any amount of MSG ruins it for me.  

Creative and fun dumplings but the MSG thing is such a turn off I'll not return.
author: Cinnamon Z.

description:
Hubby's Review:

Went here with the family a while back.  The decor and service was adequate.  The food did not leave one wanting more.  Especially since Wifey had half  of a cockroach in the fresh greens staring back at her!  The waiter's response was that they regularlly fumigate the place. Can't blame them for trying, huh?  Two stars since I know what it's like to run a clean restaurant, hee hee.
author: Mr. and Mrs. L.

description:
This place used to be my favorite place for dimsum. Sadly, I guess the recession has caught up with this restaurant despite how succcessful it is! I went there with the family today and WOW everything is SO much smaller. The hao gao (shrimp dumplings) were super tiny...like barely over an inch long. The crab claws were will a decent size but smaller as well. We ordered a clay pot dish with chicken, tofu, and salty egg and the bowl (not even a huge one) wasn't even full. For $10, it was definitely a rip off. The food still tastes pretty good, but way too pricey for the amount you get. 

I'm sad :(
author: Lauretta L.

description:
Dim Sum for Dim Sum Virgins.

True connoisseurs of dim sum know better. This place is for first-timers who have yet to taste the real thing. The price is a bit expensive for the portion size. The freshness of the dishes are also inconsistent. There are much better places down the street like Mayflower.

If you've never tried dim sum before, you'll have a great time. The menu is clearly printed in Chinese and English with photos. For your second dim sum outing, I recommend you explore other restaurants.
author: Mike L.

description:
My beef: Simply over-priced sit down greasy dim sum. I didn't think the flavor of the usual things was revelatory. Har Gaw and Char siu bao, both baked and steamed are better at the steamed kitchen places on Clement street and at a fraction of the price.

Redeeming: Deep friend sticky rice balls filled with meat, but deep fried sticky rice anything is good.  The e-mein was unusual and good.  You'll like if you like your noodles al-dente but if you don't have razor incisors, you'll be slurping forever, they're hard to chomp into bite size portions with your teeth.
author: Lola Z.

description: When I saw that there were shrimp and chive dumplings on the 2010 7x7 Big Eat SF list, I was excited that I might be able to find an awesome dim sum place in SF, without having to brave the streets (and parking) of Chinatown.  My wife and I went there, and order all of our standard dishes, mostly dumplings and some noodles, but we were most excited when the guest of honor arrived.  Sadly, the shrimp and chive dumplings were room temperature (or perhaps even colder), and were only ok.  The filling had a good taste, but I can't get over the fact that they weren't super fresh.  Everything else we had was also good, but not great, and the food was a bit pricier than some of the other good dim sum places I've been to, all over the Bay Area.  I may give it another try now that I live closer to the Richmond, and I hope I can check-in next time with a better experience (and a better review).
author: Pilan C.

description: Went to Ton Kiang after a long day in the city.   Food was average with above average prices.  At $10-$15 per plate, I expected a little more from them, especially in the city with so much competition.  There was nothing really wrong with the food or service but   I love trying new places so I probably won't be back.  I would consider this place average at best.
author: randy g.

description: Solid dim sum for the Sunset / Richmond area.  The wait isn't too long for the usual fare of a variety fo small plates.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Damn good dim sum here!

Every time we go, (3 times to date) we end up making a complete mess of ourselves, the table, the floor. Why? Not sure what happens to us when we enter this oasis of tasty dim sum, but they probably see us coming and start to swear..."oh man, here comes the piggy family again". 
Anyway, the food is fast, fresh, delicious. There is always a wait for a table, never a convenient parking spot, and still we come back. Why you ask?
Because the food makes all of those problems disappear. And apparently our table manners as well because there are so many puddles, splashes and the like that they most likely have to burn the table cloth when we're done. If there is something you want that is not on the carts, go ahead and order it, no problem. Have some tea, take a break, and start in for round two. Service is a bit questionable at times, but thats not why you come here.
I wish there were a way to make the meal last longer though, but thats what you get when the food hits the table 30 seconds after you're seated. 
Enjoy!
author: Matt T.

description: The pork buns at Ton Kiang had me in a strange trancelike state. I found myself proposing marriage to it,until I tried one baked & that's when I started talking about the children. You really get the feeling you have eaten something great after you eat at Ton Kiang.All else seems so much like a silly compromise by comparison to this land of snaky perfection. The wait staff,was great .Did I mention the barbeque pork bun?
author: Jessica B.

description: The Dim Sum was great and the prices were even better. We didn't even look at the menu for all the food just at the dim sum. I would go back for sure.
author: Melissa O.

description:
If you do not know any Chinese, this is a very good introduction to the world of dim sum.

Not only do they have an easy to read decription of each dim sum dish full with illustrations (no joke) but this is one of the only dim sum places I've ever been to where each dim sum waitress/waitor can translate their respective dishes into English and describe it in English as well. Im-press-iiiveee! 

We went for lunch on a Friday and the place was poppin'. At one point, they had a mini line forming in the front, but they easily accommodated to everyone because of their hidden upstairs seating too. It was neatly organized as well. 

-1 star for lack of vegetarian items (I know, whatever, I'm a harsh grader. ie I'm a biznatch)

-1 star for their service. Little lacking. Coule be because they were busy. Could be because they're a Chinese restaurant and us Chinese peoples are just like that.
author: Peggy T.

description: Do not go to this restaurant, they serve shark fin soup. There is plenty of dim sum in sf....
author: Zack H.

description: The Chinese food here is definitely the best in The City. If you can get over the high prices, the food is of high quality and the staff are friendly. The interior is in desperate need of a renovation; as it looks like a hospital waiting room. Other than that it's a great place.
author: Rob S.

description: I have been here for dinner many times, but the real reason to stop by is the super tasty dim sum.  The quality changes a bit day to day and hour to hour, but I always walk away happy.  I suggest the green pea tips, any of the dumplings, the eggplant shrimp thing and well just about anything except maybe the deep fried plates.  Now if I could only get more mustard and chilis without having to chase down every waitress.
author: Cork C.

description: If you love dim sum... then Ton Kiang has it in spades (and marvelous tasting dim sum, I should add). Yes, the prices are quite a bit higher than what I'd expect from this neighborhood, but I suppose that comes with the excellent quality. It may not be the kind of place I make a journey to every day, but when I do find myself here I am always content with the choice.
author: Andrew P.

description:
**EDIT: IT'S JUST BAD FOOD PEOPLE, regardless of what your ethnic background is. BLAND. Just try some awesome places first, then get back to me, ok?**

Meh. Overrated. 

I haven't been to Ton Kiang in about 3 years, maybe more. Back then, even though it was just as crowded and expensive, at least many of the dishes tasted pretty fresh (the mochi in banana leaves were a particular highlight). This time, not so much. 

I'm not afraid of grease (hello, I am Chinese. Whitewashed, but still Chinese) but the turnip cakes were too greasy even for me. It was like eating grease balls that tasted vaguely of turnip.

The rest of the dumplings were OK, nothing special and WAY too small for the price. There weren't enough traditional dishes or even variety in general. I kept seeing the same foods pass by our table over and over. Which goes along with the fact that I'm liking table service more and more over carts / trays. 

Fruit salad? Seriously? I gave my sister the weird eyebrow look when I saw a tray pass by our table. Who serves fruit salad as a dim sum plate?! Wrong place for me.

It weirded me out that everyone was speaking in English. I don't even speak Chinese but it all felt so wrong and out of place. The wait staff was very nice though and accomodating to child, which is always helpful.

Anyway, I'm over it. If we had to have waited longer than 15 minutes or if we hadn't lucked out with a spot out front, it would've gotten 2 stars from me. I'll stick with South Sea in the Sunset. Or at least try one of the other places on this street. 

Seriously, why does everyone love this place? It really makes me question you Yelpers!
author: Salina Z.

description:
How did it take me this long to post a review for Ton Kiang (insert: waaay to darn long).
This place is a few blocks from me, which means I am here all the time due to my bar studies (not the alcohol kind).  The guys now know me by name and have my fried shrimp balls and shrimp and scallop dumplings out to me before I have to say a word.  
Their dim sum rotation during lunch has been a dangerous trap for me after a crappy lecture so I try and limit myself.  
Granted not everything here is mind blowing, but they do a couple things right.
These include:
Said Fried Shrimp Balls
Shrimp and Scallop Dumpling
Shrimp Rice Noodles
Shrimp and Scallion Dumpling and
Fried Salt and Pepper Shrimp
You can't go wrong with any of this stuff....Please go out with this advice and try this place...you may just like it!
author: Sheila Y.

description: Would probably give one star, but I liked one of my dishes. I like flavorful and spicy food and this food had neither. Won't return when back in San Francisco.
author: Try O.

description: Bleh bleh bleh....never trust a dim sum place with drawings of their dim sum on a lil table top tent....just screams inauthenicity. If it wasn't for the fact that my friends wanted to meet at 9am for dim sum, I would have gone to HK lounge across the street. The dim sum variety was so limited, it just was disappointing. Never again.
author: Topazskye L.

description:
Amazing Dim Sum!

The desserts are wonderful gooeyness.
author: Taylor S.

description: Went here this afternoon for my first-ever dim sum and it was super fun! I have been wanting to try this place for a while because a) it's right down the street from me and b) it's on 7x7's 100 things to eat in SF list.  I obviously don't have much to compare it to but I thought the food was great and the whole experience was a blast.  We had vegis, calamari, oysters, green onion pancakes, steamed pork buns and rice cakes for dessert.  I would especially recommend the pork buns- I could have eaten those all day!
author: Heather D.

description:
What was once filled with Chinese folks is now mainstream and filled with a ton of non-Chinese people.   Great place for dim sum that you can trust, as well as a whole lot of other dishes.  Everything is good and normally the service is excellent.  Don't go on a Saturday morning because the wait can be really long.  
MUST GET, the mango pudding with extra milk on the top!  Good stuff!
author: Jason A.

description:
My 2 cents on how it compares to Yank Sing:
- Yes it is cheaper, but yet not cheap
- Quality is terrific as well

But:
- It does not have all the dim sum vegetarian options of Yank Sing (actually there are no vegetarian dim sum here...)
- It is much smaller than Yank Sing therefore I would not go on the weekends

From the regular menu, we loved the General Chow Chicken.

Voila!
author: Elsa T.

description:
I'd love to give this place higher than 3 stars but I just can't.  While the food was really good, plenty of seating upstairs and downstairs, and the selection plentiful the price was way to high for my dim sum taste.  Between me, my brother Jim, and my friend Alice it turned out to be $80 without tip.  That's pretty pretty pretty expensive for a dim sum place.  

Don't get me wrong.  I'm not saying you shouldn't go here for some dim sum.  I'm just warning you of the prices.
author: David C.

description:
Had dim sum here for the first time this past weekend.  I preferred it to Gold Mountain and to Yank Sing.  The price was about $25 pp all in and we ordered a ton of food.

The chicken bao were light and delicious.  Lots of good veggie choices too.  Chinese broccoli was nice.  Tea leaf salad was unusual, I'd only seen it at a Burmese place before.  Veggie springrolls also a highlight.

The wait was about 30 minutes during prime time on Sunday, not bad.  I wish they had carts - I love that aspect of dim sum, but I can't complain about the great variety of dishes.

Worth it.
author: Aaron T.

description: Yum, but I still love Yank Sing a tad better. Their snow pea shoot and baby bok choy take first prize and these warm rice cake (think manju from japan) filled with egg custard is sublime.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Atmosphere, surprisingly quiet for a dim sum place.

Pros:  Mochi with coconut filling (nai wong).  Worth one star on its own.

Cons:  Their shrimp dumpling (har gau) which I consider the most fundamental core item of dim sum is piss poor.  Spending 20 minutes to find parking here is not worth it.

Summary:  Worth if you dont have to find parking (bus, someone else drive).  Not worth it if you have had dim sum in Toronto or HK or you basically know what good dim sum is.  I've given up hope on good dim sum in the bay area.
author: H C.

description:
After hearing just how great this place was from several people who would know, I was quite disappointed with Ton Kiang. My friend was constantly urging me to go check it out, so one weekend, I went there with my family since we were already in the city.

The restaurant is very nice and inviting. The tables are clean and not sticky; it's well-lit and the walls aren't greasy. There were a few Asians, BUT (and here's the big warning sign) the majority of the people there were gringos.

The shanghai dumplings were good; chicken feet were okay- a bit on the salty side; but the TRUE test for a dim sum place is its har gow and sui mai. This place's ha gow and sui mai sucked ass. the shrimp was overcooked and tough and their respective fillings were not very tasty. We ordered the bbq pork rice noodles and the i felt like i was chewing on plastic- it was terrible! Nevertheless, there were some pretty good things there: Woo-gok (meat-filled taro fried thingies), law-bok go (turnip cake), and law-mai gei (those wrapped sticky rice things) were decent. 

I won't say that this place is terrible, but I doubt I'll go there again.
author: Bernie L.

description:
Setting: 7:30 pm, Wednesday night, party of 6 with a reservation.  However there were tables available when we walked in. Not crowded but busy. 

Ambiance: not so much, the BRIGHT lighting doesn't do much to set a mood, but you can tell how clean it is. 

Dim Sum: platter #2, 12 choices for 3 people. Which as an appetizer was totally adequate for the 6 of us.  The options lack some variety (very shrimp heavy), but loved the eggplant/shrimp dim sum.  The servings varied from just 2 (shrimp ball stuffed with crab) to 4 (pot stickers). They were nice enough to cut some of them into 6 pieces when it was possible. 

Entrees: Spicy Basil Shrimp and Sweet and Sour Chicken. Both delicious. The shrimp was in a light sauce that had minced basil, pepper, etc which coated the shrimp. The chicken was all white meat, slightly crisp, with a good meat to batter ratio. Some of the best I've had.  We also had a War Ton soup which was quite good and vegetable fried rice, tasty as well and not greasy.

Service: kinda slow..the soup came quite a while after the dim sum and then the shrimp entree showed up before the fried rice and then there was a wait for the sweet and sour chicken.  They did bring our sesame balls dim sum at the end as dessert which was thoughtful. 

Wine: 2 bottles of a riesling, fine for the price.

Damage: minimal only $33 per person inc a 20% tip. 

Parking: def a pain. 

Bonus: proximity to Tommy's. Excellent margaritas and sippin' tequilas just steps away.
author: Nikke G.

description:
Best Chinese and Dim Sum I've had in the city, yet.

Parking SUCKS.

REALLY Expensive, but worth it occasionally.
author: Alex F.

description:
I went there a couple of times at lunch time and the dim sum were OK but yesterday we went for dinner and it was, well, meh...

We had to order from the menu and to me this is not the real dim sum experience. The menu for 2 suggests you select 9 dim sum and that is a bit too much. Our picks were from ordinary to OK. 

The restaurant is a bit smelly, the decor could use an update, the service is very pushy and rough and the parking is just terrible in the neighborhood.
author: Lili G.

description:
2.5 stars. Good to see that recent reviewers are noting that this once highly-touted Dim Sum eatery has slipped.

I'm very familiar with TK, having lived in the Inner Richmond for 11 years and the quality of both the Dim Sum and the menu entrees appears to have dropped. Had lunch there today. The Dim Sum is average compared to the many offerings in the city but the prices are definitely higher; no longer worth waiting for a table on a weekend.

What's good: Shanghai Dumplings, Potstickers, Duck, the 2-floors accommodate parties of 5 or more nicely. 
What's average: Siu Mai, Cha Siu Bao (pork buns), Shrimp Dumplings, Steamed spareribs, Moo Shu (found under appetizers)
What to avoid: Any of their entrees. The noodles - even the basic chow mein - used to be good but are now inconsistent.

Golden River, which is right next door, offers slightly better Dim Sum IMHO though it's interior looks like an institutional cafeteria and the prices have risen. Sadly, Golden River is no longer a value alternative to Ton Kiang.
author: Ben S.

description: I love the dim sum at Ton Kiang. It's a great alternative to the usual Sunday Brunch when a group of friends get together to catch up. Eggs are overrated... Shumai is better. Unfortunately, this place is a bit expensive.
author: Sam N.

description: All the times I've been here have been on a weekend for dim sum and had to wait close to an hour for a table. In the end, it's worth it. Yummy dim sum! My eyes are always bigger than my stomach. My greedy little fingers point at multiple things as carts go by, and I wind up eating too much. I've enjoyed everything I've had here.
author: Joel A.

description:
With Ton Kiang, you either love it or hate it really. Everyone's been here at some point or another because one of your friends says, "Oh have you been to that Ton Kiang place on Geary? It's great!"  Your friend is probably saying this because they went there instead of going into one of the gazillion other more authentic Chinese places on Geary.  It's an accessible Chinese restaurant in a Chinese neighborhood. 

Now I enjoy the food here and the Dim Sum mornings are really good. They have this spicy garlic chicken I've never seen anywhere else that I freaking love.  To be totally honest though, you can go anywhere else on Geary and get just as good Chinese food for probably half the cost. 

So, it's a good place but use it as a stepping stone to try some more unique places in the area. In the end, you'll save some money and get some good dumplings.
author: Andy A.

description: I do not know if you could call this Chinese food or crap! Anyway, the food came out cold, tasted bland, and the prices here are exspensive. With all the good  chinese restaurants in this town, this place is definitely out-of-its-league.
author: AL H.

description:
Nice, small dining room with friendly staff serving tasty but not fantastic dim sum to a crowd of mostly non-Chinese locals and tourists. The staff is Chinese, but the dining experience seems less authentic than other options because the room is relatively quiet, free of carts and Chinese chatter. 
If you want a clean place, an easy place to enjoy some good dim sum, then Ton Kiang is a good choice. If you want the higher energy "dim sum emporium" experience, go elsewhere.
author: C K.

description:
Yummy yummy DIM SUMMY inside my tummy! Can't go wrong here. Highly recommended are the shrimp balls, scallop, and shrimp/spinach dim sum. They even deliver it to me, are you kidding!? Now that's what I'm talking about

Also, their regular menu is pretty bomb to!
author: Rouz E.

description:
Talk about EXPENSIVE dim sum.  We spent like 70$ for maybe 12-15 dishes, and I still wasn't super full.  I have never spent over 40$ for dim sum, and that's like family weekend dim sum in so cal.

The food here is very different, not like HK dim sum at all (taste ok).  I guess this is the hakka part, since it's taking the dim sum of HK, but with a hakka taste.  The chili sauce is pretty weak, so drench your food in chili sauce if you want some spice in your day.  Noteworthy, IMO: foil wrapped chicken (not in HK dim sum).  Usually you can tell if a dim sum place is good by the egg tart.  Egg tart here is small, and ok, but not the best.  

Service is crazy, the people come to your table offering food every 2 minutes or so.  Sometimes the same person comes to you so often, I don't know how many times you can say no, I really don't want that.  Other than that, it's good to come here once.  Just come really early or really late to avoid waiting (and ability to find parking).  And bring your $$.
author: Yosie G.

description:
Ton Kiang is a great eat. Yes, you have to wait in line, and yes it could get a little pricey, but if you're really starving, there's a small little Russian place on the corner where you can get some snackage or something to drink before eating your lovely meal.

It's high end, and in terms of costs it's well worth it.
author: Michael C.

description:
I've eaten plenty of Dim Sum in my lifetime...and I had yet to come across a great Dim Sum restaurant til I stepped foot into Ton Kiang... deeeelicious dumplings that taste very fresh...
this beats paying $30.00 per head at Yank Sing.
author: Jennie L.

description:
I agree that the dim sum was salty, but some dishes were the best of its kind that I've tasted (eg. the leaf wrapped rice with  meat, don't know the chinese name).  Had to ask 3 people for water before we finally got some.  The fixed price dim sum was a little on the expensive side.  When I go to dim sum I grab plates til I'm full and it always comes out to 10 bucks a person.  Here it's at least 20.  Will try next door as suggested for cheaper dim sum.
The bright side: once again on a weekend night I score a parking spot right across the street.
author: Scott F.

description:
This is not a hole-in-the-wall Chinese place, so don't walk in expecting dirt cheap prices or the discovery of some awesome and truly unique dish that you can't find any where else in the city. That being said, the establishment is incredibly clean inside, and the wait-staff is kind and helpful. The good service coupled with the restaurant's mention of the Hakka people on their menu (personal bias - I am completely obsessed with the history of this relatively indigineous ethnic group), put me over the line in my internal battle to give the restaurant another star. 

Food recommendation: try their crispy noodle nest with beef dish.
author: Christina B.

description:
Ya, the wait stunk, but... I've been to a lot of dim sum places, but this restaurant gets 5 stars based on its food alone. 

And after the second plate all was forgiven =_=.
author: Dennison M.

description:
Derek says:  This is the oddest dim sum experience ever.....  Everyone spoke English, they had a list of dim sum but didnt have chicken feet on it.  I was afraid they didnt even have it cause this place caters towards non- chinese customers.  The food was average at best.  It was on the pricey side as well.  Janice and I went here after 2 people recommended this place saying "its the best dim sum in san francisco".  Im going to have to stick to Koi Palace as the "Best dim sum in the City"  even tho its in Daly City.  Its even less expensive at Koi Palace.

Janice says:  Yeah.  All I have to say is that whoever rated it "the best in the city" is a non-chinese because this was obviously not a real dim sum experience.  The hostess was nice, but everything was slooooooooow and quiet (the excact opposite for us HK folks).  We didn't even get our tea until we finished 3 dishes.  Ever heard of asparagus or fruit salads for dim sum?  yea yuck, i don't even want to think about it again- too strange.
author: Janice's A.

description:
It was dim sum. I see nothing extraordinary about Ton Kiang dim sum compared to other dim sum I've had in the past. 

The chinese broccoli was tasty. This one dumpling was too gingery for me. The custard desserts were good. I think the tea had some herb that's supposed to aid in digestion. That is all.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Went here over the weekend.  Its okay.  They have a bigger variety then other dim sum places (soft shell crab, prawns, etc) and its clean enough not to scare my white friends.

My fiance who is Irish-German noticed the lack of carts (curse my mom for taking him to dim sum in LA so now he knows this is a tamer version of dim sum because nothing in the carts scared him) and chicken feet.  It wasn't bad but I have to agree that it does not live up to its former glory.  

And the service this weekend wasn't bad, in fact I think the service has improved a lot!
author: Angela A.

description:
The dim sum is quite good. Although I've been sick after eating here in the past, nobody else in my party was sick. 

The place is large  (with an upstairs seating area) and clean with white tablecloths. The last time I was there, Tracy Chapman ate upstairs with her entourage. 

Expect to wait (outside) for a table and leave time for finding street parking.  No, you're not going to get friendly warm wait staff who care about your dining experience, but I've just come to expect that when it comes to dim sum. It's a fast-paced environment often complicated by a language barrier. Know what you want and be decisive.

Better dim sum in SF is Mayflower & Yank Sing; outside the city, I recommend Fook Yuen.
author: Marina N.

description:
Came here this week for a holiday staff lunch (what can I say, we're a small staff).  My boss had chosen it because (in comes the big CAUTION sign) "it's famous and has gotten excellent reviews".  

So I walk in and immediately whisper to my co-worker, "Oh my God, everyone here is white!"  No offense, but seriously, EVERYONE here is white.

We get seated and the waitress asks if we'd like tea.  I ask her in Chinese what teas they offered, ya know, just so she knows I mean business.  The food's decent.  Really, it's not bad, but then again, it's not great.  The portions are small and somewhat lacking in flavor.  

For me, dim sum should be judged on how well they do the staples - har gow, siu mai, sticky rice, etc.  The dumplings were small and not that flavorful.  Not bland, just not flavorful.  

If I could give this place 2 1/2 stars I would, but just because I was the only Chinese person (hell, I was the only one with black hair) there I'll give it 2.
author: Adrian L.

description:
Tasty, but overwhelming amounts of food shoved in your face=pricey.
Side note, chicken feet...somehow not as delicious as it sounds.
author: Lauren T.

description:
I've been going here for years.....been my favorite Dim Sum spot. 

Now, the prices have gone up and parking is even worse! 

But, the dim sum is good and I can never leave without having the mango pudding! 

There are those days when $$ and parking are worth it.
author: Rese D.

description:
I'll give this place one star for being clean.
Another star for being "first time dim sum eater" friendly.  (I've taken 'those' friends here).
The last star is for the chicken lettuce wraps.  (No, the dim sum isn't bad, but it's not the best either).  

But that's about it.  It's overpriced.  I like the hole in the wall places on Clement St. much better, and I know if I go there...I'll get faster service.
author: Meesh K.

description:
All I can say is - "Dim Sum all day!"

This is the only restaurant that I know of that will delivery Dim Sum any time of the day.  And its GOOD.  So are the rest of their menu items.  This is the only place I'll order clams, crab, or any seafood for delivery - its always fresh, but it gets pricey.  

I also fell in love with their Shrimp Balls!!  YUMMY!!!

Delivery takes 45 mins.
author: Gina K.

description:
Solid dim sum.  All the dim sum tastes very fresh, unlike some dim sum places who cart around the same stuff for hours without changing it.

Beef curry pastries are so good!  Pork buns are solid, pork dumplings are very good.  

Never left here hungry or disappointed.

Price is about average for dim sum in SF.
author: Sheila S.

description: I've been here several times and I think I like coming here more with a bigger group.  This last time (Saturday, lunch), I went with my bf and we got a few of our fav dim sum orders but we were stuffed pretty early on in the meal.  The selection they were passing around wasn't as big as I last remembered but it could also depend on the day.  Their Shanghai dumpling totally did not meet my standards at all.  But I did try this walnut "cookie" and it was surprisingly good.  It was still warm and the outer crust was flaky and the inside filled with lotus paste.  I'm not a big sweets person but this was probably my favorite item.  For once, desert was the main focus of the meal.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
now that I think about it, every time I've gone out for dim sum, I've been with at least one chinese-speaker who can communicate with the waiters, and thus we tend to go to legit dim sum places and in turn get better/more authentic food.  but i came to ton kiang with coworkers, none of whom understand chinese, and noticed a larger english-speaking crowd dining here in general.  

so the food wasn't bad, but i felt like some of their options were lacking, and i've definitely had better dim sum at many other places.  their options seemed shrimp-centric, which isn't a bad thing, but i would've enjoyed a wider range.  I did have one scallop dumpling, which I'd never had before (are scallops authentic for dim sum?), which was pretty good.  And their egg custards were good too.  

i'd say skip it if you have other options for dim sum, but if you get nervous at restaurants that seem annoyed when you keep asking questions in english, this is a good place.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
My review:

Had dinner there tonight as this restaurant was recommended by SF guide book.Two Dim sum appetizers were not bad. We had several entrees, the Kung Pao chicken was not very good, the Prawns with cashews and vegetables was so so. The snow pea leaves with garlic was the one excellent dish.

Service was very slow and of poor quality. Would not go back.

My Daughters review:

Sunday is what my family considers to be a day to have an adventure, which consists of going to a new place to eat. We decided to try this place, said to be known for it's dim son and rated high in the best restaurants of San Fransisco. Some points to be noted:

- have a man with you, or you will be noticeably ignored
-if you do not have eight or more people with you, the tables will become a show down for a shouting match as they are very large.
- keep the tea coming to fill you up until your food slowly appears by a robotic waitress
author: Jeff W.

description:
I've been coming here since it was a hole-in-the-wall at their previous location. I use to love the food here. Their quality is excellent. However, they've decided to reach a broader audience and gone upscale. They left out a few traditional dim sum things and offer dishes that appeal to the more upscale diners so I've almost stopped coming here. 

Here's an example of the problem. On my past visit, the table next to us had a few food preferences. No shrimp and no pork.....seriously? Shrimp and pork are more than 90% of the menu. It's dim sum for f* sake. All the dinner and lunch dishes they pass around almost make me puke...it's offensive. It's good dim sum but it's not as authentic anymore.
author: Bruce B.

description: I love the dim sum here. When the place is bustling, and it usually is, you are constantly bombarded with a variety of delicious dumplings and small plates tableside, which for me anyway is much more fun than filling out a slip of paper to order. I have enjoyed almost all of  the other menu items I've eaten here as well, particularly the mu shu pork, and the 1/2 fried chicken. I have probably eaten here 50 times, and have never had a bad meal. When they have an off day, it's still good, and when they have a good day, it's great.
author: Doctor S.

description: Been going to this place since I was a kid and I still love it just as much, delicious dim sum in a more high scale environment without the huge price tag. One of my favorite places to eat.
author: Charlotte P.

description: Very nice ambiance for a dim sum restaurant.  But it's quite a bit more expensive, and the food isn't exceptional.  You're paying for the atmosphere, I guess.
author: Paul K.

description: I used to come here to eat dim sum for 10 years.  It used to be really good but now it's just an ordinary place.  I missed their flavor.  I haven't tried other dishes beside dim sums, so I am going to try some next time.
author: Maki M.

description: Always superb. Rice noodles with shrimp, baked pork bow and asparagus were a big hit.
author: Ali C.

description:
You know what would be cool? Drive through dim sum. What a great
alternative to Burger King. Someone needs to approach the owners of
Ton Kiang and suggest this.
author: Dan Y.

description:
Ton Kiang is pretty good, but $50 for 2 people good?  Not really...

They have the usual spread of dim sum goods--the shu mai, ha gao, nol mai gai, etc., but it's mightly pricey for food that's good, but not addictively superb.

What I do appreciate about it is that the waitstaff makes an effort to communicate the dishes in English, so its not as isolating as other dim sum places. It's a place where I can take my white boyfriend so he doesn't feel ostracized for not being about to speak Chinese.

Plus, you can order the dishes a la carte, so you don't have to sit around all day peering into various steamers to see when the things you want will come around...
author: Desdemona C.

description:
I came here in the hope of searcing for a good dim sum place which is less pricey than Yank Sing but left disappointed and with a huge MSG overload!

Over steamed items, salty foods, slow service - this place lacks quality and delicate flavours.

I am not one to compromise quality over price where food is concerned so I wont be trekking there anytime soon.
author: Teresa T.

description:
No no no no no!

Food was average. Most items weren't overly greasy. Most dimsum items came in 3s or 4s, but the portions are tiny. Each Sui Mai was about the diameter of a quarter. Tea was just fine, but good luck getting refills.

Service was slow. Maybe it was because we got seated upstairs, in the back room. Saw only one cart make its way to the isolated corner we were in, though plenty of ladies with trays came around. Seemed like the entire wait-staff preferred English, and even repeated our Mandarin or Cantonese orders in English, and jotted down our requests in English. Not a bad thing, but just made ordering awkward because they sometimes appeared stunned that I was ordering in Chinese.

Decor was nice. Cleaner than most and pleasantly decorated. Unique looking prints on the walls and clean plate/glass-ware and utensils. I'd give it 4.5 stars. Only attractive wait-staff or a spectacular view could've helped in this area.

Total bill for a party of four was about $70, not including tip. Way overpriced for SF.

Definitely would NOT recommend this place. Although popular with tourists, native Bay Area dim summers will be disappointed. Try Mayflower Seafood during their dim sum hours about 4 blocks away. Or even better, City View closer to downtown. Both far better overall.
author: Edward C.

description:
This was actually my second time at Ton Kiang.  Went on a Sunday morning and suprisingly the wait wasn't too long.  It was pack as usual though.  The 5 of us sat  down and then we were bombarded with food.  They should really space it out more, cuz I felt like I had 20 different dim sum pieces in 2 minutes, and when you're hungry you can't say stop.  The plus side to this was you got a lot of service.  Speaking of good service my  clumsy friend spilled his drink and they promptly cleaned it up.

The last time I came here I didn't I wasn't a fan of it too much but maybe that's because I tried a lot of new things.  This time around we ordered a mix.  The usual dimsum items like hao kao and sui mai and veggies were delicious.  Some of their new dumpling things were okay.  If you like mushy meat, seafood and pork then dimsum is a must for brunch.  Ton Kiang delivered a satisfying meal but at a price.. which is triple the cost of what I'm use to. Thus, I give it  3.5  instead of 4 stars.
author: Manohak S.

description: Couldnt decide to come in here or Golden RIver, which is next door. I peered in here to scope out the place--- filled with people and looked promising. BUT WAIT... this is a dumsim place...WHERE ARE ALL the ASIANS??   So we went next door.. it was EMPTY.   We then opted to go to the busier restaurant and order hai gow and other small dishes. I looked at the bill as they marked the price and it was 5 bucks for fucking hai gow!?  We then ate our 3 dishes and bounced to sakana bune. RIP OFF!  I know hai gow is about  2.50 avg at restaurants and 1.30 at mom& pop shops.  ... 19 bucks for 3 small dishes..  so not right.. WTF
author: Hana ..

description: Haven't been in years but I remember it being a fun dim sum location with plenty of options.
author: Jenny Q.

description: This used to be my favorite place for dim sum in SF, but either it's gone downhill just a little or other places have surpassed it - now I'd rate it 3rd in the Richmond.  Out of dozens of dim sum vendors in the district that's still darned good, and TK is worth a visit from dim sum enthusiasts for a couple of unique offerings.
author: Matt T.

description:
Cheap and delicious!  $15 per person for 5 people, including tip.  Can't complain about that!

Great place for casual dim sum.  They don't push carts around, but that's OK.  We had all the classic dim sum dishes: from BBQ and steamed pork buns to shrimp and pork dumplings to mango custard for dessert.  

Parking was easy to find, although it's metered (and only an hour at a time), but we were in and out before we had to feed the meter a second time.

This place will be my go-to the next time I'm in the mood for Chinese dumplings.
author: Anna V.

description:
For a place that's on the Big Eats list, I expected better. There are at least a half a dozen better dim sum places within a few blocks of this place that I wish I would have gone to instead. 

Took the parents out here, and they were not impressed. My mom is one of those Hong Kong foodies, and this place didn't even come close. Her first comment after walking in was, "Where are all the Asians?" 

The ha gao tasted like it was teamed in bleach water, and the skin wrapper was thick and mushy. A good ha gao wrapper should be thin and nearly transparent. The siu mai tasted frozen and dried out. Gai-lan was ok, but it really isn't that hard to cook that. Bbq pork bun was decent, but a little light on the stuffing. 

Where are all the Hakka dishes? They did have "yong tofu" but it wasn't even close to what it was supposed to look/taste like. 

They definitely cater more to the "white folk" and their prices reflect on it. No Asian would spend that much money on so-so dim sum. At least the service was decent (especially for an asian establishment). Its the only reason it gets 2 stars instead of 1. 

We were all wishing we went to Hong Kong lounge, there was a nice line of "black hairs" waiting there.
author: Henry L.

description:
My favorite dim sum in the city. I love it here and throw a fit if someone try's to make me go to yank sing. Yang sing is yummy but Ton Kiang is on a different level. The best are the pea leave sprouts, I think thats what they're called. I get like 3 orders of them everytime I come. They own on pork buns, honey pork buns, rice noodle, and shrimp dumplings. 

I didn't wish I lived closer because I would never live that far out, but I wish I could just bring it closer to me.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Ton Kiang used to be my #1 dim sum place and I used to go there every weekend
I hadn't been here for a couple of years, so I was really excited to be back.

..... I was so disappointed.
The quality has gone way down, and nothing impressed me anymore. The deep fried shrimps were lukewarm and tasted funny. All the steamed dim sums weren't steaming hot as they used to be.  Everything tasted bland and I felt so bad for my guests because I told them that I was going to take them to the best dim sum in the city...

I am really sad that another my favorite restaurant in the city is gone.
author: Daniel A.

description: Came here last Sat morning and it was half full.  I figure I wouldn't have to wait long for the dim sum but boy was I wrong.  Instead of the classic carts carrying the dim sum around, they have servers walking around w/ half the selection and quantity.  We waited forever for mediocre dim sum.  Service was also lacking as we didn't get our water and tea refilled.  To top off, it's a bit pricey for what you get.  For what we paid, I wished I went to Yank Sing instead....
author: Michelle T.

description: Super yummy! So cool too, I mean immediately when we sat down we got served food! Everything was really tasty. Plenty of food to eat, especially for a peskatarian like myself. The baby boc choy was really good, and the pea sprouts! The deep fried soft shell crab, shrimp stuffed crab leg, scallop and shrimp....the list of goodness goes on... the mango pudding was wonderful too... i could probably it that all day.  It was probably better because it was free for me and I could order whatever I wanted. However, most of these reviews say it is more pricey...so if I had to pay I would probably have to be more concerned about what I was getting. Oh well, fun experience!! Hopefully I can go back!
author: Sonya D.

description:
Yummy yum cha worth the line out the door. Don that (egg tart) is best I've tasted outside of Macau. They also tempted me to the dark side of dim sum; fried food. Excellent soft shell crab and calamari. 

Also a nice plus, much more reasonably priced than the arguably better Yang Sing.
author: Jon I.

description: Fancy dimsum at a fancy price. Food is fresh, and generally well prepared. Some of the dishes are a little oily, but there are in addition to the traditional dim sum a nice variety of small plates including freshly stir-fried veggies and even fruit salad. Egg custards are tiny but very good. I particularly liked the chinese long beans with mushroms. Some big tables for families. Fun!
author: David T.

description:
Would you like asparagus? If so, don't come here because they try to pass off duck as asparagus. I asked several times to clarify what the dish was that they were trying to serve us, and several times, they said "asparagus." Unless I've been sleeping for centuries and they've started calling duck asparagus, by jove...

The food was mediocre. As we were leaving (we stayed at least an hour), then they started serving the food that looked sooooo good! I must say, however, that I did have those little fried sesame balls with yellow bean paste, and those were really good. The rest of the stuff was aight. =/
author: Maria C.

description:
The shrimp dumplings are pathetic. They are the size of a dime and look like they come from the frozen packages at the Asian market. Tiny and shriveled up. Other dishes are nothing special and should not command premium prices.

This place looks and feels cleaner than your average "tea house," but just look at the clientele when you walk in or just look at the line waiting outside on a Sunday. It's another City View, they cater to non-Asians who don't know what's good dim sum. 

I guess it's a good place for people who are intimidated by the real dim sum places. They wil feel comfortable here if they don't mind being spending a bit more.
author: SF N.

description:
If you take a wait that is too long and add it to just-OK dim sum, then just for fun slap on prices that are way to high, you get Ton Kiang.

Seriously, it was like 45 dollars for two people!
author: Mr. G.

description:
As many reviewers have written, there are no carts from which to choose your items here. By no means, however, does that limit the endless supply of super-fresh, incredibly delicious options servers are constantly bringing by your table. And, as a result, the atmosphere is much cleaner and the staff more friendly than pretty much any place in China Town.
Per the norm, the wait can be pretty long if you arrive too late in the day, and it's a bit of a haul to get over there if you don't live in the area. We stopped in after a nice morning run through Golden Gate Park, and had a great time. Just try to keep an eye on all the goodies you order, as the bill tends to grow rapidly.
Definitely going back. Definitely suggesting to all.
author: Justin M.

description:
I find it neccessary to review Ton Kiang after I read someone's bad review.  I like Ton Kiang very much.  The dim sum is great.  The food is not as good as Yang Sings but it is also much cheaper.  I have introduced several friends to this restuarant and they have all gone back.  The decor is nothing special it is the tasty dim sum at a good price that keeps me coming back.
Lynette F.
author: Lynette F.

description:
Parking can be brutual if you come too late for dim sum on a weekend day. 'Too late' meaning, say, NOON. 

However, even though there's a huge crowd out front, it moves relatively quickly, and our party of four had an available table in ten minutes.

Food comes quickly and often; everything was good, and we had a special order of the black sesame balls for dessert. I go ape shit for that stuff, so I'm a little prejudiced.
author: dana l.

description:
OverRATED

Though I have fond memories linked to this place... I've had much better for much less. Really. The food is good, just not great. It's too expensive to be true "dim sum."
author: BrasilPo P.

description:
Been here a few times, the food was great.  When you go to Chinese food, expect great food but not service.  

They need to improve with their service skill.
author: Andy N.

description:
Pricey as far as dim sum goes, but when you have friends from out of town that want the dim sum experience yet who are still kind of frightened by "weird" chinese cuisine, I take them here because I know the food will be solid, and that there will be a large variety of options. 

Sunday "brunch" is probably the busiest (have fun waiting in line), but if you go a little bit earlier/ later, you will get the same food and less crowd. Same tip holds true here as it does at any other dim sum place: give the waiters some time to walk around before you start ordering. More often than not, what you want is something that will come out after you've already finished your meal.
author: Sabine S.

description:
I came for lunch today with my mom. It wasn't the first time but I haven't been here for awhile and wanted to try it again and then Yelp it.
We had chicken feet, hai gui, pork short ribs, spicy mushrooms, potstickers, etc. Overall, I thought the items we had were tasty and fresh. I enjoyed the dim sum and the clean enivornment. The service was prompt and friendly. The only drawback was the price. It is a bit pricey here and compared to other dim sum places. I thought the potstickers were a bit high for this dish. Overall good experience, except for the price.
author: Leon C.

description:
Ton Kiang is best known as a dim sum palace and well it should be.  Fresh, diverse small plates are wheeled about the restaurant.  Point and it is yours, for a price that can build more quickly than your appetite may be sated.  They do a good job on the usual things and a very good job on fresh veggies, fish and roast pork.

In the evenings the place reverts the a larger plate format.  Here the quality of the food is not so remarkable and is less distinguished from the competition.  Best to go early for the dim sum.  In fact, on weekends go super early to avoid the masses and inevitable wait.
author: David D.

description:
They use to make the best barbeq pork egg foo young (just like my Dad's) so I've always gotten that dish when I ate here.  However, they must have a different chef working there.  The egg foo young was horrible - it was some deep-fried mess!  You read that right, not pan-fried as it should be but deep-fried!!!

I agree with other posters - this place has really gone downhill (they may make some good dishes but it's hit and miss - in the past everything was always executed flawlessly)  :O(
author: Lee Ann G.

description:
When I stepped into this joint, I thought to myself "Awesome! Hakka cuisine! My people!"  I've never been to a restaurant that serves Hakka food.  Only authentic Hakka I've ever had was when I visited relatives back in Taiwan or in the comfort of my mom's kitchen!

So what IS "HAKKA" food?!?!

With the help of my mom's expertise in this subject matter, I'll help you understand!!   Chinese cuisine 101!  So different cuisines of Chinese food represent people from different geographic areas.  As most ppl know, Schezuan is an area where the people like to cook things really spicy!  Guangdong food is your well-known dimsum.  Shanghai food tends to be sweet.  So what about Hakka?  Well, Hakka food tends to be salty with low fat/oil content.  Hakkas value simplicity in their dishes so you won't be served a dish with too many ingredients.  Historical reason for this was that Hakka ppl were nomadic and poor so they only could eat simple things and flavor their food with salt.  So for example, a good dish is eggplant w/ fresh parsley.  Unlike schezuan eggplant where it's drenched in a thick starchy spicy sauce, the hakka version has a very light sauce over lightly sauteed eggplant seasoned with salt and fresh parsley.

OK, now back to the food at Tom Kiang.  True hakka cuisine has no dim sum.  Why...is there dim sum here? And why are they known for their dim sum?  My parents were totally puzzled.  Instead of ordering dimsum, we ordered their traditional Hakka dishes.  Beware that not all their entrees are Hakka!  Only a hand full of them are authentic Hakka.  **EDIT UPDATE: Dad came home and was able to help me out remembering some of the dishes.  1 dish was the Braised Meat-Stuffed Tofu.  It's authentic Hakka and it's pretty good.  Another really tasty dish was the Orange Chicken.  It's deliciously crispy, but it's not Hakka.**

My parents and I really liked the food here; the quality and authenticity was really superb.  We all rated this place 4 stars.  My 2 friends who were also with us did try some dimsum (just the shao mai); they were ok.  (What's cute was that for their dim sum menu, they have cartoon figures of the different dimsum items so you don't have to know their names.  You just point and order.)

I have two noteworthy complaints about this place:
1) WAY too overpriced for their small portion sizes.  This applies to both the entrees and dimsum.  You might leave hungry still if you're concerned about not spending much money.  Chinese food is supposed to be cheap; Chinese families are traditionally poor and huge.  Need more food to feed everyone without going bankrupt.
2) Parking sucksssssss.
author: Michael P.

description: Always very high quality dim sum and one of the best selections in SF.  My only knock about Ton Kiang is the price.  Why so expensive compared with other places?  It's almost as much as Yank Sing.
author: Eddie K.

description: Ton Kiang is a great place for vegetarian dim sum. No vegie dumplings, but there are plenty of other choices. I'm particularly fond of the asparagus--which is peeled, marinated, & served cold with pickled vegies, the green beans, the egg rolls, & the green onion pancakes. Veggie choices include vegetables wrapped in rice noodle, pea shoots, bok choy, spinach, & chinese broccoli.I always order the yellow chive chow mein which is wonderfully salty & tasty. And I can't end the meal without the sublime warm walnut cookies.
author: Wan T.

description:
Over-rated. I keep hearing this is one of the best dim sum places in town but it's not worth the hassle if it takes you more than 10 minutes to get here by car. The food is fine but it's not mind blowing. Prices are fair.

Maybe it's worth a 15 minute wait for a table but if it was longer I'd probably walk across to Clement and get something fast and cheap over there.
author: Jeff L.

description:
As a general rule, I don't like Chinese food. Going to college in the mid-west has scarred me with their teriaki stir-fry and vegetables in brown sauce. However, a Thanksgiving Eve dinner at Ton Kiang changed this for me. 

I usually judge Chinese food based on two items, won-ton soup and pot stickers. Very rarely does a restaurant excel at both, and Ton Kiang is one of those exceptions. We had a large group of people and ordered a lot of food. The boys loved the General Tso's, and Sweet and Sour Chicken (I didn't taste it -breaded and fried chicken is not for me but I trusted everyone else loved it because they were just about licking the plates clean). The beef with green beans was great, as was (surprisingly) the tofu and eggplant veggie dish. But my favorite was a dinner special, prawns with sugar snap peas. It was exceptional, and I was disappointed they brought it out last because by then I had tasted just about everything else and was getting full.
author: Lindsay H.

description: Overrated, overpriced Dim Sum place.  Not bad, but not worth going to, unless someone drags you there because "it's the best dim sum in SF".  Go to please them and you'll realize it ain't.
author: John W.

description: This is the oddest dim sum experience ever.....  Everyone spoke English, they had a list of dim sum but didnt have chicken feet on it.  I was afraid they didnt even have it cause this place caters towards non- chinese customers.  The food was average at best.  It was on the pricey side as well.  Janice and I went here after 2 people recommended this place saying "its the best dim sum in san francisco".  Im going to have to stick to Koi Palace as the "Best dim sum in the City"  even tho its in Daly City.  Its even less expensive at Koi Palace.
author: Derek L.

description: We went here on Easter Sunday morning at the recommendation of my daughter's boyfriend who ate many childhood meals here.  I just wanted a typical Chinese dim sum experience, since I live in a town with crappy dirty Chinese restaurants that I would not eat at.  I am a picky eater, so I was very happy with their practice of coming around and showing us what was available, so I could pick out only the things I might possibly eat.  The vegetables and sweets were my favorites.  They were a little slow with the things we actually ordered from the menu, but my family said it tasted good so it was worth it.  I think the prices are about average.
author: Sue D.

description: Dim Sum Yum!  Egg custard tarts are amazing
author: Zen A.

description:
Service sucks, service sucks, service sucks. They fawn over some guests and totally ignore others.  Out of the last three times I went, they completely ignored my table.   They didn't bring tea or table settings until they were reminded multiple times.

I hate to ding them for service.  Wished I can give them zero stars for that but the food gets them two stars. So it averages out to one.

There are way better places for dim sum.  

Wait in line for horrible service?  Not me.
author: D C.

description: Very disappointed with the kind of food they served.  It's not the same and service was so slow.  Expensive and not reasonable!  Will never go back again in this place.  We used to be a fan, but not anymore!
author: Jo V.

description: Whenever we want to wow someone from out-of-town, we take them to Ton Kiang. The atmosphere is clean and classy, and the dimsum is out-of-this-world fresh. Mango pudding is a must. Service is excellent, sometimes have a wait to be seated, but worth it.
author: Jane L.

description:
Good dim sum and staff
But not worth the high prices
Or the weekend queue
author: Patrick T.

description:
I get all giddy as I'm on my way to Ton Kiang's cause I know I'm gonna be well fed and leave happy!

This place is amazing. The service- friendly and fast. I usually like to go early noon on a sunday, the wait is usually about 30 minutes and there are already plenty of peeps waiting outside but go with good friends and the wait will go by fast. 

Once you're in... YOU'RE IN and PREPARE yourself for a culinary delite! Whoopie!

Things are coming around fast and if your not paying attention, you'll miss your chance. I'm half chinese so I'm not once to shy from raising my hand in the air and wave a waiter over to give me some of what they got!

Some of my favorites... Ha Gow (shrimp dumpling), sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaves, and the shrimp balls (heh heh) and crab claws. Lots of the time, there are things that are not on the dim sum menu but that go around, such as perfectly seared scallops with shrimp and sauted clams or spicy fried calimari. Holy Moses... I'm getting hungry just writing this and I just had dinner!

Well.. what else can I say.... go there and experience it for yourself! I promise you won't be disappointed. And for heavens sake... live a little and order something you don't recognize!

P.s. You won't believe it but they also deliver after 5pm to almost anywhere in the city!

Damn, I've said too much...
author: Samantha Y.

description:
Okay dim sum. Not horrible, not great and by no means "authentic."

Perfect, however, if you're looking for something easy, dim summy and good for out of town guests that may not be that adventurous in the food department. Yay!

It's relatively clean and the staff speaks English. They include a little menu on the table with descriptions of what some of the more popular dishes are. There are more white people here than I'm used to seeing at dim sum in Chinatown.
author: Josh O.

description: Average. Ladies came around with stuff, but it was pretty much the same handful of items. Not enough steamed items. I would rather go to Golden River or something for the same food only way cheaper. The fruit salad was dry.  I remember this place being all the rage a few years ago; what happened?
author: k h.

description:
it's alright, nothing too spacial to write about.
It's a decent place to bring your non-asian friends to try dimsum. Less of a wait line compare to hongkong lounge nearby.
author: Christy L.

description:
this is probably the most civilized dimsum experience i have ever had.  that is probably why there are more non-chinese people in here than chinese people, and i didn't have to speak any chinese to get what i wanted.  it is a good place to take friends who are not familiar w/ dimsum, since they put a little cheat sheet on each table which has pictures of the items and what they are called.

the waitresses come around w/ trays of steamed baskets rather than carts.  everything we tried was good, and the food seemed less greasy than some other places.  they have all the standard dimsum items, but one interesting dish i had was a mochi covered egg custard which i had never had before.
author: Helen T.

description: I come here for dinner mostly and their food is decent. I like how it's nice and clean. Staff is friendly too. Highly recommend it for family dinners. My husband's favorite is the salty steamed chicken and honey walnut prawns.
author: Jordan W.

description: Very pricey. But very very very good! I love this place. I highly recommend it. Eat every item on the menu.
author: Val B.

description:
Never in my life have I been so thoroughly disappointed by dim sum. How could something that (literally translated) means 'to touch your heart' end up crushing my spirit? This restaurant is messed up on so many levels. 

1) $3, $4, $5, $6--are these prices for real?  I read that this place was "overpriced," but if I knew I would pay $6 for two servings of lo mai gai (chicken w/ sticky rice in lotus leaf) I would've brought monopoly money because this is clearly a joke. $1.00 for a cup of tea. $.50 for water. WATER. Who charges for water?? I should've gone into the bathroom and drunk from under the faucet for free. 

2) Make no mistake, I am not a cheap-o. This review isn't just about the price. Had the food been DOUBLY good, it would've been worth it. But was it doubly good? No. Was it even good? N-O. In general, the flavor was mediocre. Chicken feet was alright, though excessive use of cornstarch made it gooey. Fried squid was cold. (Isn't that an oxymoron?) Cold dim sum is a nightmare. I was pleased to discover they served wu gok (fried taro), but the meat filling was scant and the taro bland. 

3) Am I a giant, or did the food suddenly shrink? I laughed when I saw the gau choy gwor (chive and shrimp dumplings) because they were about the size of quarters. Cute miniature edibles include: baby tomatoes, brussels sprouts, and mandarin oranges. Never dim sum. It was at this point of my dining experience that I knew I needed to create a yelp account for the express purpose of writing this review. 

Worst dim sum of my life, hands down. And I'm from NORTH CAROLINA. 

I detest how awful this restaurant is.
author: Veronica W.

description:
I don't know why I came here. The dim sum isn't great. They don't even have hot sauce!!! What kind of Chinese restaurant is this???

You know it's not authentic when the wait staff announces what they're serving in English instead of Chinese. It was laughable. 

The bill came out to be more more expensive than my usual dim sum spots and we didn't even get as many dishes! 

Definitely not an authentic dim sum experience.
author: Cassandra T.

description: The best Dim Sum restaurant to take your family too. Exquisite dim sum and food, and a more manageable environment for folks who aren't as familiar with the more chaotic dim sum hall in Chinatown.
author: Shanan D.

description: First time trying Dim Sum and this place was on several "best of" lists. I wasn't very impressed. The staff was confusing, someone would bring something out and mumble something, we would ask what the food was and the waitress would take it away. They also brought out wrong items. I might give dim sum another try, but not here. The place also had no ambience.
author: Anne D.

description: Hands down - this is the BEST dim sum restaurant in San Francisco!!
author: Martine M.

description:
I was rather disappointed with the dim sum.  I'm judging based on a few dishes: 
- nol mai gai (sticky rice) was bland, but the texture was good
- char siu bao (baked not steamed bbq pork buns) had slightly undercooked dough and the sauce was overly sweet rather than savory
- gao choy got (chives & shrimp dumplings) was perfect
- roast duck had perfectly crisp skin, but was so fatty that less than half of the dish was meat
- chinese donuts were just not good.  

I do appreciate that all the servers speak English and switched to Chinese when I responded in Chinese.
author: Cat B.

description:
I love this place for dim sum.  Mainly b/c of the quality but we also had smiling, attentive servers (which is not typically my experience with dim sum restaurants.)  The food was delicious and so fresh.  Dumplings were actually hot.  My favorites are:
- shrimp and chive
- shrimp noodle roll
- potstickers

I took 1 star off b/c the BBQ pork bun was not very meaty and b/c the servers often started on the side of the room opposite to where we were sitting so I had to do some assertive flagging down.  It's pricier than other places but worth it if I get friendly service and solid, good quality dim sum.  They also serve these very snacky, giant donut balls.  Can't go wrong with that.
author: dink f.

description:
i went here maaannyyy years ago (like uhh, maybe 2000? 2001?) and i guess it hasn't lost too much of its popularity, from what i understand. however, i went back yesterday with some work clients. 

three of us went here for lunch on a thursday and we didn't have to wait (i'm assuming weekends are terrible).

i quite enjoyed the dim sum, and that it's not loud and noisy (although sometimes you have to have that in a chinese restaurant just to make it authentic) with servers screaming their wares. one thing that i like is that even though ton kiang seems to have a lot of non-asian patrons, they don't uhh, white-wash the food any.

that said, they have a simple menu with line drawings of various dim sum dishes with their chinese names written (sounded out?) in english so poor ABC saps like me who only know the chinese names of foods but can't read chinese can actually know what he's ordering. bonus!

i'm writing this review a day after the fact and i can't say anything stood out in terms of overly good or overly bad, but i do remember i was unimpressed with the taro dumpling -- i had better today at mayflower in milpitas. (however, the har gow here was better than mayflower.)

maybe not the best dim sum in the bay area (still not sure what that is, but i don't think this is it), yet a solid choice, especially if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Jonathan K.

description:
dimsum here was pretty good, even though the place is so white. everyone around was white! and the chinese waitresses all spoke english, it was impressive and highly amusing. they'll come around and speak to me in english, but i wouldn't understand and i need the official chinese name for it. haha. so it's a very friendly place for people who don't speak chinese at all! and the food was pretty authentic too. they actually gave the right sauces for each dish which doesn't happen in all dim sum restaurants!

i got the:
siu mai, good
hargow, really good and small, the way i like it
scallop dumpling, really good as well
char siu bao, i usually hate this, but this one had a good amount of pork so it made it bearable for me
xiao long bao, ew not good
egg tart, small, cute and yummy, but not hot =/
fried crab, not a big fan of fried, but it was pretty good
fried shrimp, same here, this was actually good.
beef ball, good, they gave the right sauce!
pot stickers, good

favourites: scallop dumping, definitely the char siu bao if you like them.

do not want: the xiao long bao was big and dry. no carts? maybe i went too late (1.30pm on a sunday)

last words: good service, don't have to speak chinese, so great authentic chinese food for non-chinese speaker =)
author: Celine L.

description:
We went there around 2 in the afternoon on a Sunday for Dim Sum.  There was no wait. The food was good, but not the best I've had in the Bay Area.

From the carts, we got Sio Mai,2x Ha Gao, Shrimp balls, Chinese Broccoli and a couple others.  The Sio Mai were good, but nothing special.  Ha Gao were very good, but not the best I've ever had.  The shrimp were the slightest bit overcooked.  The Shrimp Balls were excellent.  (really excellent).  One small gripe I have is that they had no hot sauce at the table, although I suppose I could have asked for it.  I think they also charged us for tea.

From the menu, I ordered 1/2 Peking Duck and BBQ pork fried rice.  The Peking Duck came with ALL the bones in it..  I've only had Peking Duck at a few places before, but it was always boneless.  It was fairly messy and greasy having to peel the meat off the bones before I could make my Chinese duck tacos.  The flavor was ok.  At $14 I'm not likely to order that again if I go back.  The fried rice was excellent.

We ended up paying $56 before tip.  With prices comparable to Yank Sing, they're not quite as good.  I'd even go so far as to say that the Dim Sum place in South SF is as good as this place.  Solid 3 or 3.5 stars.  (rounded down to 3)
author: Adam M.

description: Just ate here yesterday. The dim sum portions were on the small side. Therefore  making this place more expensive. The Shanghai dumplings had a thick dry skin. The service was very good, we didn't need for water or tea refills.  The restaurant is very spacious and we were not rushed even though there was a busy Sunday lunch crowd waiting outside.
author: Spencer F.

description: I was very understanding having previously owned a restaurant when we were asked to move to a smaller table to accomadate a larger party.  I would have expected A plus service from the restaurant because we were willing to move.  I became disappointed when I figured out that that they had lost our order because two tables that were seated after us were served before us.  I brought that to the attention to our server and was assured they would cook our meal next. We still waited for our food and had to ask for the bill before all of our dishes were served as a memeber of our party had to catch a plane.  This was a two and a half hour ordeal.  My suggestion to managment is to hire more staff for the holidays,  seat a little slower so the staff can keep up and have one person running the floor.  I will say if you have plenty of time to wait for the food and don't mind bad service the food is excellent.
author: L S.

description: Wow. A stellar combination of deliciousness and frugality that you will not find elsewhere, I believe. Yank Sing although similar on the food level pales on the prices. Food comes quickly, steaming hot dumplings of yumminess around every corner. Go here!
author: Paul S.

description:
By far the best Dim Sum anywhere in Northern Cali. 
Yes, the wait is long. 
Yes, it sucks and makes you pissed.
IT IS WORTH IT!
GO. NOW.
(a little tip; get up early to get seated. Should be at the door by 9:30. After 10Am...you will be waiting for at least 20 to 30 min.)  :p
author: Poppy C.

description:
Best Dim Sum in town,

     The hidden gem of the place that will take any non-believer into a full-blown addict are the deep friend pork dumplings aka deep fried pork footballs. These do not appear on the menu; you must ask for them specifically. They are incredible, crispy on the outside and moist and warm on the inside with just that hint of sweet in the dough. So mouthwatering and wonderful they'll make you think you're the first dog in space. 

Also the snowpea shoots are a great way to add some delicious greens to a dumpling filled repetoire. 

The fact of the matter is dim sum for me is a niche food. It should be delcious, inexpensive, and quick...dare I say instant gratification. In all these categories Ton Kiang can't be beat.
author: Drew S.

description:
Dim Sum on 7/6

We ordered shrimp dumplings- bland
Fried squid- greasy
Spring rolls- very greasy
Eggplant stuffed with shrimp- ESPECIALLY greasy (actually dripped oil)
Cold steamed asperagus, WONDERFUL
Pork dumplings- average

In total we had 6 dishes and the check totaled $38 with tea for 2. 

Overall- very low quality at a VERY high price. No need to return
author: Art V.

description:
What's with the hype around this place?  The past two times I came for dim sum, it was just mediocre.  Why spend half an hour trying to find a parking spot for average dim sum?  Tell me what to order here and I'll try it again.

I remember this place when they were located by the Bridge theatre.  Back in those days, they had it going on with the Peking Spare ribs, crisp fried stuffed tofu, and on and on.  Maybe I'll try it for dinner one of these days when I feel patient enough with the parking lottery.  This is SF though.
author: optimus r.

description: My mother in law grew up in Singapore, so I was somewhat shocked when she wanted to try this place for dim sum. I'm not much of a dim sum eater, but she was very pleased with this restaurant. She went for lunch with a girlfriend and recommended we order in delivery sometime. The food was pretty good, some of the more decent chinese food I've had in the city. My only complaint is that when we opened up the fortune cookie, not only did we get a fortune, but a big rat poop. So my suggestion...open fortune cookies with caution!
author: Lisa M.

description: Most of their buns and dumplings were frozen -- definitely not worth the higher price they charge here. This place is on the expensive side and its food did not live up to the hype. And while I expect less than stellar service at a dim sum restaurant, I was impressed by their disorganization here. If you're looking for great dim sum -- don't go here!
author: Ross O.

description:
the boy and i were on the hunt for a dim sum place to hit up one sunday morning. i have yet to find THE dim sum place, one that has convinced me to return to it regularly. this place was recommended to us by a (non-asian) friend of the (non-asian) boy.

i should've known.

ton kiang is AMERICAN. look around and most of the tables will be occupied by non-asians. 

the servers come around with trays, and call out each dish by its english name/translation. i'm not chinese, so i always get flustered because the cart-pushers always try to speak to me in chinese and i obviously have no clue what they're trying to tell me, but i've come to expect that out of a typical dim sum outing. it was WEIRD that that wasn't happening here...and also weird hearing har gow referred to as "steamed shrimp dumpling" or something like that. it's just easier for me if you refer to it as har gow.

the food wasn't necessarily bad, it was decent, it was PRICEY - $20/person for mediocre dim sum?

yeah, no.
