i'll be continuing my hunt for THE dim sum spot.
author: Caroline I.

description: Very yummy.... long wait though during the weekend. I will NOT recommend ordering their long beans. Stick with their Dim Sum!
author: Caroline C.

description: The food is okay, nice and clean Chinese restaurant, service is so so.  Typical dim sum restaurant, but i like it clean.
author: tomcat f.

description:
Simple but good.  Go here every time I'm out in San Francisco.  It's a family/local favorite.  It's not cheap, but a ton of fun with a small group of people, sixish people is ideal.  Best to go at lunch to really enjoy the dim sum experience.  
Definitely whatever the green leafy greens are order them!  Yum yum.
The shrimp dumplings are always a hit too.
Ask for extra green sauce.
Don't expect anything special from the service.  Although if it's been a little while and you haven't seen a tray of what you have been waiting for just ask!  Usually they will work on it.
They don't use a ton of ingredients in any one dish, but I've never had anything I didn't like.
Can be a quieter atmosphere so loud talkers like me can feel slightly out of place.
My two year old nephew loves it!  While he was well behave, none of the staff made us feel awkward for bringing him, still wouldn't recomend it for small children.
author: Frances C.

description: I just have to update my previous review. My husband dragged me back to Ton Kiang one day, and the food was actually good! I really like their Dim Sum. But the food off the menu is hit and miss, depends on what day you are there I guess, probably different chefs? We have been coming there for Dim Sum almost every week now for about a month, so far so good. Service is also hit and miss though...one week good, next not so good, depending on the waiter/waitress.
author: Alina S.

description: All food should be served dim sum style- hot and fast! Really liked the crab claws, string beans, roast duck, and barbecue pork buns here. All the different siomai/dumplings were also very good. We didn't have the xiao long bao- not sure if they had it there but that is a different food challenge in itself... Easy parking outside but don't forget to feed the meter in between bites!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Great dim sum worth the wait.  Some of the more basic dumplings were about the same as you can get in Chinatown for like 75 cents, and the batter that the calamari had was really really greasy, but the calamari itself was good.  The pork shumai was fair. Skip the boring stuff and double up on the shrimp-stuffed crab claw.  And the shrimp balls.  And the egg rolls.  

The Yank Sing on Stevenson is my only other non-Chinatown Dim Sum experience, and this was about as good and significantly cheaper.
author: Alex T.

description:
Correction, that's actually 0 stars. Or negative. I could go that way too. There is WAY too much hype for this place. Before I left in disgust, I had four frowny points. It wasn't bad execution, its just bad basis. (note: this review is for people who have had dim sum before. if you have never had dim sum and Asia seems like a crazy exotic land, hey, you might enjoy the dim sum here. As we were walking out, my boyfriend noted to me that the owners must be evil genius masterminds to have had such great reviews, which we verily assumed were written by people who do not frequent dim sum restaurants often...if ever.) 

First impressions and Points:
1. Wow, pretty clean. Wait, is that a wine bar?! What the heck Chinese restaurant sells wine?! hm. something seems off. I tell the waitress two people (in Cantonese no less) and she tells me "Upstairs". No wait? No frantic yelling of numbers and nosy parents peeking at the list? Hm.
2. Sit down at a table, look around. Hm. Is it telling that we're the only table of Asian people here? Where are all the carts?
3. Gah! It's a continual carousel of English-only ladies carrying trays of food. They perch their tray on our table every 30 seconds and ask "Shrimp dumpling? Steamed Asparagus? Tea Leaf Salad?" While trying to hold a conversation we have to keep stopping to say No thanks, no thanks. 
4. After we had ordered two dishes, we were still waiting for someone to ask us what kind of tea. I finally flag down a waiter, and he drops by the table. I say "Tea, please, I'd like to order some Bo--" "Just green tea" and zip he's gone. What the hell? Come back dude, I didn't tell you what kind I want. Green tea?! What?! It took another eight minutes for him to come back with a teapot of green tea and a dish of chinese mustard and salsa verde. What?! Salsa? Where's my tortilla chips? I'm so confused.
5. Ordered a plate of shrimp wrapped in rice noodle sheets. (haw cheung fun). She stamps it in the $5 category. No freakin' way. $5 for a dinky plate? Ugh, plus we found a hair steamed into the rice noodle. We called the manager over and she replaced it with another one. That was nice, but still ew, a hair in the noodle?! I'd expect the same dish maybe $3 or $4 at other places. When you order a lot of dim sum, that dollar difference really adds up.
6. The dim sum was okay, nothing fantastic or terrible. If anything I was mystified by the offerings. Vegetarian egg rolls? Steamed asparagus? Tea leaf salad? (i know burma superstar is popular but really now...) There's standard fare, but the plate of four small steamed shrimp dumplings (har gow) was $4. We ordered five dishes and our bill came to $23 plus tax and tip. 
7. Are they playing bamboo flute music in the background?!

Ugh. I do have to finish up by saying that I don't think these are all awful things. I don't reaaally blame the restaurant. I blame Yelp and the SF Chron, and other food reviewers, and my own gullibility. I was the one who chose to come to this restaurant. I just don't think its the right place for me. I prefer Cantonese Dim Sum places that are boisterous and loud, full of rolling carts and hostesses with walkie-talkies in hand. Delicious dim sum that will totally fill you up for just $8-11 a person. A choice of the tea, and mustard and chili sauce. Traditional dim sum and new innovations for dim sum like shrimp and mango dumplings. 

However, if you do not know dim sum at all, or you want to really slowly bring some new sheep to the fold, or being in a restaurant full of loud Chinese families scares you, this is probably a great place for you. No, seriously. There's a picture menu with the dim sum in english and chinese, there are lots of english-speaking waitresses who come to you, who you don't have to wave down half the room away, and you can pay the high price and feel good for trying something new. 

Just don't go if you're someone like me, who likes the old traditional way of dim sum.

*Granted, I am saying this as a second generation Cantonese-speaking lady who has had experience with fantastic dim sum in the city. Go to Clement Street, or Daly City, or anywhere. Eat more dim sum!
author: Jade L.

description:
Just went there for dim sum this past weekend. Good news is that the wait is not as bad as it used to be. Bad news, the food is not as good as it used to be. From the Har Gao, to pork buns, to any other dumplings they serve, it just doesn't taste as good as it did a few years ago. 

I also think the prices are high for what you get. Overall a disappointing place to go for dim sum based on the high yelp reviews.
author: Andy N.

description:
how sad... today was yucky and I will never go back. the search for dim sum brunch continues. 

and... I used to love this place.

oh! and one more thing..

THE WAS A WORM IN OUR SPINICH
author: Jayne M.

description: This is by far the best chinese resturaunt in the city, my only complaint is that it can get a little expensive
author: Joshua L.

description: Delicious but a bit pricey than I'm used to for dim sum.  I feel like they stuck the American looking customers up stairs and the Asian looking customers downstairs.  carts get pushed around down stairs but they have to bring trays around upstairs :-(.  A lot of the dishes then have to be requested, so luckily I knew what I wanted.  The food didn't seem to have that great of a quality for it to be priced so highly.  I'm also not sure if the servers even understood what I was saying half the time, but I've almost become accustomed to that in Chinese restaurants after moving to SF about a year ago.
author: Ryan Y.

description:
Can I give this place no stars??

I have no idea what all the hype is about this place unless it's coming from folks who know nothing about dim sum. 

Setting:
Very very odd. It was super clean, to the point of feeling sterile. It was also quiet enough to hear a pin drop. We felt like we had to whisper to be polite. Anyone who has eaten *real* dim sum knows the overall environment is part of the experience. It's supposed to be loud...and moving really fast around you. There was no life here...and it was jarring. 

Food:
I can deal with an "off" environment if the food knocks me out, but it didn't here. The dim sum was mostly lacking in flavor - I think salt specifically. The only thing that was good was the chicken feet. Our guess is it was ultra fresh since 95% of the diners were non-Asian and unlikely to order this dish. Sounds stereotypical, but no one had this dish except us, so call it real life market research.  Oh did I mention its a bit spendy too? All that aside, one good dish out of 10+ is really unfortunate.  We were so bummed when we left, we went to a couple places on Clement to get *real* dim sum to make our drive out to the Richmond semi-worth our while. 

Service:
Service was fine, but very strange. The poor wait staff is forced to speak this very uncomfortable English to everyone. My wife even ordered in Chinese only to be responded to in English. WTF? She commented we were being served by Stepford Wives, which pretty much hit it on the head.

Again, I have no idea what the hype is about, and even more confusion how this ends up on the Chron's Top 100 every year. Maybe this is a decent starter dim sum place for those who may feel intimidated or overwhelmed by most other dim sum houses that are way more hectic and frantic? I dunno, but if you know your dim sum, go elsewhere. Heck even if you don't, go elsewhere. You can eat better for cheaper.
author: Mista Dobalina ..

description: Came here on a Wednesday night and it was pretty quiet and low key. Friendly staff.  The barbequed pork buns, shrimp dumplings, crispy noodles, egg custard tarts and sesame balls are all bomb.
author: Jules A.

description: My wife and I heard good things about this place and went for Easter Brunch Dim Sum so-to-speak.   WOW! were we disappointed.  I am a Haole boy and my wife is Chinese who speaks the language fluently. The atmosphere was BLAH! The Dim Sum was tasteless for the most part. They were way over-priced for Dim Sum.  What do people see in this place. We ended up going to another Dim Sum Restaurant (right after!)  after spending $32 bucks just so we could satisfy or need for decent Dim Sum.  Too many good places to eat Dim Sum....Don't waste your time & hard earned money.
author: Chris W.

description: I'm not much of a dim sum fan, but I really like the dim sum at ton kiang
author: Seiken N.

description: I came here once for my mother's birthday. We always saw a line so I decided to treat her to something special. It was very nice decor and the dimsum was ok. It was definitely catering to a more western clientele. Almost every dim sum item had shrimp in it. I love shrimp but sometimes I just don't want it in all my food. It was also pretty expensive for dim sum. I wouldn't go back.
author: Annie P.

description: There's usually a line and the service is a bit lacking... but the food is FANTASTIC!!!
author: Eric W.

description: One of my top 3 dim sum places in the city, unfortunately the most expensive. I especially like that they have take out dim sum since I live about 4 blocks away.
author: Kelly O.

description: I heard that this place made the Chronicle's top 100 list, which is quite simply perplexing.   I should have known it was a bad sign when the Caucasian to Asian ratio was something like 8:1 (particularly a bad sign given the "Asian-ness" of the neighborhood!).   The little juicy buns were an absolute disgrace and frankly, not juicy at all.  The scallion pancake was greasy and tasteless.  The pork and century egg congee was the most flavorless I have ever had.  And it was an expensive meal to boot!  The main plus that this place has got going for it is that it is clean.
author: cherie y.

description:
I enjoy the food very much at Ton Kiang. Yes, the food is more expensive compared to other chinese restaurants but I don't mind paying more for quality chinese food.  The staff is friendly and the place is clean.  

Parking can be a challange, but it is worth the effort.
author: Sydney A.

description:
I was brought here by friends who raved about it and whose judgment I respect, so I was looking forward to the experience hugely.  Alas, I was equally hugely disappointed.  Mediocre dim sum, sloppy service, excessively high prices - in a word, go somewhere else.

The problems started at the door - three different staff people asked us how many were in our party and then disappeared.  After several minutes a fourth person asked us the same question, then took us upstairs, where we stood around for another ten minutes before a fifth person (I kid you not) finally seated us.  Our waiter then took the order of the party that was seated *after* us before taking ours; got said order wrong (bringing both a dish we hadn't ordered and Diet Coke instead of Coke); and seemed to think his incompetence was funny (he had a really irritating giggle which was apparently his attempt to compensate for a limited vocabulary) rather than reprehensible.

OK, it was a busy night in a popular restaurant; much can be forgiven if the food is outstanding, or even good.  Alas, it wasn't.  Not even close.  Several items were fine, but no better than at many other dim sum places in SF, and significantly more expensive; some were not only more expensive but distinctly worse.  I was especially keen to try the roasted oysters (on the regular menu, not the dim sum) because it's a dish I love that I've had many times at my favorite dim sum place (MFDSP), and my friends (who've also had them there) swore that Ton Kiang's were as good or better.  Wrong.  They were almost cold, rubbery, tasteless, and $13.  At MFDSP (oh, all right, it's Happy Garden on Clement), they've invariably been hot, crisp, delicious, and $8.50.

Justice requires that I report that Ton Kiang was packed to the doors the whole time we were there, so they're obviously doing something right by somebody.  Not by me, though.  And, not to play the race card, but nearly all the customers (my party included) were visibly non-Chinese.  If you think there's a correlation between a restaurant's success in cooking the food associated with a particular ethnicity and its ability to attract customers of the same ethnicity, then you may not be surprised by what seems to me to be Ton Kiang's regrettable failure on both counts.

see you at Happy Garden.
author: Steven B.

description: Very disappointed. It used to be high quality authentic HK style dim sum. This last visit was a disappointment. Seems like the selections are now geared towards Westerners and reduced to those Americanized dim sum. The only redeeming point is the desserts which are good & decent but still not worth the trip alone.
author: Wynne K.

description: Line in front of the restaurant so I expected the food was awesome. Nah... It's okay I guess. I had better and it's kinda hard to order food because we had to wait for the cart to come and show us the food (it's Sunday morning so it took a while for the cart to come to us). A bit pricy too
author: Cliff T.

description: Tasty dim sum.  Good variety of choices.  Food nice and hot today.  Prices a little on the high side for some dishes.  Reasonable service.  Finding a parking spot in the area sometimes takes a bit of time.
author: M T.

description:
We went on a slow night, so the carts weren't rolling.  However, we did order dim sum.  As a dim sum virgin, I have to say this did not impress me much.  It was good, but a bit too salty in areas and a bit too homogenized for my tastes.

Dishes were hit and miss, with a couple being very good and the others just average.  The regular Chinese food ordered at the tables nearby looked pretty tasty.  Many of the dim sum items had way too much dough.  Tasted like I was eating a raw bun.  Others, like the shrimp dumplings, were awesome.  

I have to echo what others have said though, I wouldn't be surprised if they use A LOT of MSG here.  I didn't see any notes saying they didn't.  So, if you're starving then go.  Otherwise, I'm sure there's more authentic dim sum elsewhere in SFO.
author: Carl J.

description:
This may not be the worst dim sum place I have even had in the states considering the ones in Columbus Ohio were pretty bad.  But hey...come on...this is the bay area guys.  Of course the standard needs to be a little higher.

The "skin" defines good or bad dumpling.  And I have to say the dumpling skin was not thin, nor was it chewy at all.  Besides, we had no idea what "Spare ribs" was until we actually saw it.  Who came up with this name?  It's like when you walk into a McDonald's and order "French fries" while everyone calls it "Pommes Frites".  WHAT?
author: HoHoHo M.

description: Had dim sum here with friends.  Was not impressed with the food considering the quality of food I'd expect from this neighborhood.  For example, the Sui Mai were pretty small and not freshly made (from frozen?).  I also ordered lotus wrapped rice w chicken and it wasn't very flavorful.  You can find better dim sum places in this neighborhood.  Will not come back.
author: Mike C.

description: The food is good but rather overpriced. It is easy to run up a $30 bill fast during dim sum; for example we got three tiny tarts, and found that they were $4. Good service, food, atmosphere but the same can be had for less elsewhere.
author: Ryan D.

description: ew..not that good..everything was kind of tasteless....In all fairness, I don't eat shellfish or pork..there was not a whole lot for me to eat here. Noticed there were not many asians here....just saying.
author: Bleep S.

description: This place has decent food with decent service but i dont think its worth the wait or the money. I'd rather go to Good Luck dim sum and get the same quality for $2 an order instead of $4/5. Service sucks at Good Luck but their dim sum sure is delicious. Why does Clement/Geary str restaurant's' service SUCK? From Ton Kiang just walk 3 doors down and there's a cheaper dim sum place. OK the service wont be as good but you'll get more for your $$. I also find Ton Kiang too greasy.
author: Marcia B.

description: Just went to this place today But I have been going to it for years. The food is always good but not great. For the price it really should be better. My advice, if you want the experience of Dim Sum (ie white table cloth, tea, travelling carts etc...). Come here but eat first...otherwise you will walk out with a $50 dollar bill for two. If you just want the food...there are way too many places in SF to get 3 pcs for $1.50 that you should head there. I remember the days when they had two locations on Geary. The other location had the best hot and sour soup I have ever had in my life. Even at that time, both branches didn't have the same recipe. Boy I wish I could taste that again...now that I reflect a moment...it was the best soup I have ever had....sigh
author: John D.

description:
my co-workers and i picked this place last night, mainly because they serve dim sum for dinner and we also want a restaurant that is out of our work place radius(we work at burlingame).

we ordered #2 from the dim sum menu which serves 3 people for $46, thinking it was not enough we ask some of the small plates to be double portioned and yet still not satisfied, we got 2 more entree from their main menu.....AND we were right, the portions justly served our hungry stomach.

the dim sum dishes was run-of-the-mill, i didn't find it spectacular..i had better. moreover, the dumplings were pretty small, though tasty and i find some of it chewy. 

the fish dish was passable, the vegetables that was mixed with it was perfectly cooked and the crispy noodles was delicious and generously portioned.

there were more than one servers who catered to us and they were also quick and really attentive.

so, it was a pleasant dinner with awesome co-workers!!
author: Nelle A.

description: The longer you wait for a table, the more underwhelmed you're likely to be. Walk right in? It's terrific. Twenty minutes before you're seated? OK, but not sensational. More than a half-hour? Definitely disappointing.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I don't know why this place gets such great reviews. Sure, the food is good, but for that price?!?!? Must be White folks doing them reviews. j/k!
author: Jonas T.

description:
I went on a date here once and I wasn't very impressed with the restaurant or with the date. Apparently at some point I had mentioned that I like dim sum and he was all up in mah bidness about how he knows this great dim sum place and I'm going to go crazy for it because it's so authentic and no one knows about it, blah, blah, blah... So we get there and he's all "Tah dah!" Um, Ton Kiang was your dim sum hidden gem? Okay.... then he proceeded to insist that every person who came by the table explain in very clear and concise English was exactly was in each dish. That's not how I dim sum. I like to make a quick judgment and then either nod or shake. I really like Yet Wah on Clement so I go there when I'm feeling like dim sum and... um, and when I'm in the Richmond, I guess.

But despite that, Ton Kiang is fine, it's pretty heavy on the white folks and I'm used to dim sum where some lady is screaming at me in Cantonese and shoving a basket of mystery goodness into my face. "Yes! I'll take it! Whatever you say! Just don't hurt me!"  You know what I mean, like, you sit down and you're being all Suburban White Chick with this beatific smile on your face ("Hi! I'm so excited to be eating at this restaurant! I'm adventurous! I like this place already! I can tell we're going to get along great! I'm so enthusiastic!") and the tea lady comes over and slams the teapot down on the table so hard that the water splashes out and scalds your hand and you kind of wince because that water, it's pretty hot, but they don't even look at you twice and if they do it's just to laugh at you, like, Sweet Soft Little Suburban White Girl I'VE FORGOTTEN ABOUT MORE PAIN THAN YOU'LL EVER KNOW!! 

I think I like dim sum for the same reason I like marathons and cute boys. It's pain, but it's sweet, delicious pain.
author: Pumpkin K.

description: Dim Sum so good it is worth waiting for an hour on the sidewalk to get in. Love this place! Carpe Diem! So, desert first: walnut cookies and mango pudding are the best. The shrimp rolls are good, all of them: shrimp and chive, shrimp, shrimp and mushroom, shrimp and pea shoots come to mind. Oh! The sautéed pea shoots with garlic are wonderful too. Dim Sum is fun and this place rocks the house. You've got to go!
author: Lee M.

description:
I've come here a few times for dim sum and it's always been pretty good, a bit higher quality in their food and the dining room is pretty nice and efficiently run so I usually enjoy eating here and it's my regular dim sum spot.
However, when I chose this place as a venue for a baby shower I found them less than helpful. They reassured me that by having the baby shower at 2:30 I would be missing their busy time and they would be able to attend to our large party of 40 people. They also assured me that they would screen off an area of the upper level for our party. Neither of those turned out to be true. When I arrived there only one table was ready for us, the other tables were filled with people still eating, luckily our guests arrived late but it was still stressful and annoying. Furthermore when we went down to ask about why we had not received a screened off area we were brushed off and told it would be screened off "eventually." Rude!! I will probably come back for regular dim sum meals but never plan an event here again.
author: Cathy T.

description: There is not much i can add here to the other reviews other than... this is hands down the best place for dim sum in SF. I've been all over, with Asian and American cohorts, and this is the place. if you're in town, or live in town... you cant go wrong with any of the dishes. my fav is the shrimp stuffed eggplant. soooo goooood.
author: Adam X.

description:
So, when I was 21 I made my first solo trip to the West Coast. I flew to Los Angeles and rented a car and explored sunny California. On my first day of driving aimlessly around, I happened on China Town. "Ooo, Chinese food," I thought. "Mongolian Beef and Sweet & Sour Pork and Eggrolls! " (I am from Indiana, you know) So I wandered into a place and sat down. No one here seemed to speak ANY English, which was fine by me - more authentic that way. I kept waiting for someone to bring me a menu, but instead all of these women just kept coming over and offering me things. Things I had never seen. Things with dubious ingredients that looked much too much like they did when they were removed from the animals they were attached to. Being a polite Indiana boy, I took almost everything they brought me and tried it. Then they kind of stopped coming around and someone brought me the check. HOLY CRAP! How in the hell did I spend that much money on lunch? I thought it was like a buffet - all you can eat for one price! Wow, I guess not.
That was my first dim sum experience. I have since moved to sunny California and embraced the tradition that is dim sum. Ton Kiang is a great, reasonably priced place to go in the city if you want good dim sum.
The food is good- really good. I especially like...well I like a lot of things that I know how to say phonetically, but will not butcher their names here trying to spell them.
If you go, try to sit near the kitchen, especially when its busy. If you are to far to the front, everything you want is gone by the time the girls make it back to you. 
Parking is really difficult. Try to take the 38 bus if you can.
Also, they charge PER ITEM! It is not all you can eat! :)
Check it out.
author: Jamie M.

description:
the 5 stars is only for the Dim Sum daytime serving...at night I'd only give it two.

what's so good about the dim sum? It's very fresh, lots of original mini plates--more like chinese tapas then strictly dim sum (for what I know of dim sum elsewhere anyway)

even the sweet treats are pretty tasty and not as tastelessly sweet as alot of chinese deserts.

must haves: salt rock prawns; shrimp dumplings with mushrooms; stuffed mushrooms; shrimp stuffed eggplant; mango pudding; custard rice cakes; (and some other yummies that I can't remember at the moment)

another nice place to take out of town visitors or a party of people you want to treat (hurts the pocketbook though)
author: Liza B.

description: We went there with reservations on Christmas day... we were seated 8 of us and ordered, after 1 hour 1 dish came out 20 mins later another one and on like this ..other people were complaining not getting their food after almost 2 hours..we were still hungrey and mad... when paying the bill my final dish finally came out..we made them take it off the bill, and give it to another family that waited a long time..food was good, not enough of it ..never ever go back not worth it..should know how to work a crowed..christmas or not...
author: Jacki S.

description: It is Christmas Day, your fridge is empty and you are grumpy because you are hungry. What do you do? Go to Ton Kiang. There is most likely going to be a line, but I have never waited more than 10 minutes. The food is good. Yum: BBQ pork buns. I just love the whole atmosphere...you can look and then you can choose :) And then you usually get a heart attack when you get the bill because you totally pigged out and had more than you would normally eat. However, I think it is worth it.
author: Conny F.

description: I was just introduced to this place the beginning of the summer but just after having my first baby and it made my healing process so delicious!!!!  I have ordered delivery and pick up here but never gotten to eat in.  I have yet to find a dish here that I don't like but any of their seafood dishes top the list.  Fresh & oh so good!
author: Deborah W.

description:
I used to love coming to TK for DimSum.  Before, the food was really good.  Fast forward a few years .. and the food is just OK.  Nothing special.  Nothing stood out as great or delicious.  Everything kinda had the same flavors.
The prices were reasonable, parking OK (street parking), no waiting for a table .. but just OK food.

Suggestion:  try elsewhere until the food starts to taste like DimSum.
author: x y.

description: I see why this place is so popular - it is friendly to the non-cantonese speakers and the dim sum is pretty safe.  The food is okay, but there is something missing from their dim sum.  Can't put my finger on it, but only one chinese long bean dish really made me want more.  A certain level of blandness permeates all of the dishes.  It is a bit pricey but safe for your out of town friends.  Not the place I would take the family (with my kids being the dim sum fanatics) more than once every few years, but I understand why it appeals to some.  The crowds should scare you away!
author: Glenn L.

description: The Dim Sum here is reliable but expensive and never too crowded. Between a friend and I, we ate close to $80 worth of Dim Sum here once. Even at a premium price, that's a lot of food.
author: Scott M.

description: I may not know "much about dim sum" as some negative reviewers state when downing this spot, but what I do know is what food I like consuming and if I enjoy it .This restaurant hit the spot for our families mothers day . I didn't consume one ball or bun or dumpling I didn't enjoy . I recommend this spot highly!
author: Lauren V.

description: I haven't been this restaurant for about 6 months. What a difference in the quality of service and food? First of all, the table is not ready and the owner asked us to go upstairs and stand around and wait for  staff to set it up. No big deal! We have a party of 10 and they want to put the wood dining turntable on it. Not only it is dirty and sticky and wood chip starts falling all over the tablet . She tried to scrub it down in front of us. The waitress told me that it is ok and she started to wipe it down. I could not help it and asked her to remove it and replace it with a new table cloth. I told her that I am not being picky but it is common sense to get me a new one. Food is below my expectation and we ordered 12 dishes for 10 peoples with two small kids. Way too much food. Bathrooms are dirty and can't believe!! Mr. Wong, please spend some monies to fix up the place and re-train your staff. There is a reason that R and G lounge is able to maintain their standard bec the owner is willing to reinvest into something called upgrade and routine maint.
author: eric t.

description: Great dim sum. They serve it ALL DAY LONG! Prices are a little high. Get there early (definitely before 1 or you will be sitting on the sidewalk). I have many many more dim sum places to try out but I expect this to be toward the top of the list.
author: Susan L.

description:
fingercuffs. an ugly game hard to get out of. a few months ago, i would have given four stars, but each dine-in experience has gotten progressively worse. and then there are the issues of bathroom cleaniness, no care for customers, half hour of parking and the warning that whatever you do, NEVER, EVER, ORDER TAKE-OUT. it was 2.5 hours late. and a fiasco. they were so rude on the phone when my boyfriend was saying our house number ("ok, ok, quick, quick!") and then they go it wrong. dim sum is not dim sum after 2.5hrs, and probably should never be done delivery style in the first place. they claimed our bill would be reduced (didn't happen) and the delivery guy is the number one suspect in the my-mysterious-missing-phone case.

so we are forced into ordering again to get a discount-- a promised (after arguing) $20 off next delivery. only they make us order a $40 total. after eating, i feel ill. mr. zagat needs to go back. it's just not that special.

but i'm going to go pick at leftovers now, because i'm poor. fingercuffs, i tell you.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
best value for your $$$. Easier parking than chinatown.

yank sing probably has the best albeit expensive dim sum

this is my favorite b/c you can do large groups. you just have to know when to go.  Just for the yelpers...  don't tell anyone else...

11am on Sat
10:30 am on Sunday

if you go after that, then lots of lines...
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Fifteen dollars for a very forgettable lunch.  The place is nice enough, but the food lacks any real character.  The steamed dim sum is OK, but that's it.  The rice cake was OK, another that's it.  Finally, I tried a traditional barbecued spare ribs.  What can I say?  Yep! (Or in this case bad yelp)

I won't be going back unless someone else wants to pick up the check.
author: Richard C.

description: I went there with two of my friends for the second time tonight and it was great. The staff is alright but their food is just amazing. Their dim sum is especially wonderful. Service is fast and you don't end up waiting for long. They've got the best fat rolls I have ever had. I love this place!!
author: Hassan A.

description: okay I am obsessed with Dim Sum so each place has certain things I like the best. Ton Kiang has hands down the best Chinese donuts in the city I wake up craving them they are so good!!! love love love Yum Yum Yummm!!!
author: Stacey L.

description: A delicious Hakka Cuisine Dim-Sum restaurant in San Francisco. Usually it is hard to enter (long line in front of restaurant shows how popular they really are); mostly frequented by Asians which is also a good sign. Today we were lucky- no line (arrived after 3 PM)... Among other specialties, we liked their BBQ Chicken (came wrapped in metal foil), scallop dumplings, beef wide noodle, and the coconut rice-cake dessert. Unfortunately, we found this place to be a bit pricey, that is why I give it 4 stars instead of 5.
author: Miki M.

description: I love dim sum.  This one is really just fair; not nearly as good as Yang Sing, but is a whole lot better than a dim sum place in, say, downtown Oakland for example.  Although the egg custard tarts are excellent, they don't really warrant the long wait for brunch on a Sunday morning.
author: Rick H.

description:
if u're asian, i m pretty sure u agree with me that this is not the best dim sum place in the bay area.  and that u'd agree with me that it's not worth the wait or the money for their dim sum. 

i haven't been here in ages because their dim sum is soooo small and the dishes are pricey.  if u pass by this place on a weekend, take a look at all the people standing outside and u won't see a real asian standing there.  most asians would go to mayflower or lucky fortune (by 21st/Geary).  (sorry if i offended anyone)

if you want dim sum, i wouldn't recommend this place.  go to mayflower instead.
author: Kapo T.

description: I used to come here with people who were not familiar with Dim Sum and would be intimidated by the hustle bustle and aggressive patrons in the usual Dim Sum places I like to go. It was clean, approachable and had decent selection. Most importantly, clean bathrooms, English friendly and classy environs. That was years ago. Most of my friends are now more adventurous and can handle the tastier more authentic places like Hong Kong Lounge and the Mayflower. In the meantime this place has deteriorated in almost all parameters. We had a couple come visit us from Italy and we brought them here. Didn't want them to get sick on their vacation! I was pretty bummed out. The food was mediocre. The place looks worn out and run down. The service was slow and ineffective. We asked for the fried taro dumplings but they never came. The servers came back over and over with the same stuff. The tea was weak. One of the reasons we came was the lack of a line outside. I ignored this cardinal rule of picking a Chinese Dim Sum restaurant and paid for it.
author: bongo c.

description: This place is always listed as one of the top 3 dim sum places in San Fran, but I'm not entirely convinced.  The food is pretty good -- i enjoyed the siu mai and jin doy, but I felt like the service was a little slow (like getting a water refilled and getting the check).
author: Tim G.

description: Visited for lunch today after a 6 year hiatus. Nothing has changed, it is still one of the better Dim Sum places in SF. The service was prompt and polite. We were the only occupied table on the 2nd floor but they diligently brought upstairs everything they were offering on the main floor. I do not consider myself a Dim Sum expert, but I liked almost all of the choices.
author: Cook S.

description: I used to eat here sometimes for lunch. I knew it was pricier than most places and that they charged for tea, but it was a pretty place. The waiter is always rushing people out the door, which is rude, but I dealt with it. Then I noticed they were PADDING the bill! They have a $15 minimum per person (not indicated on the dim sum menu). If you don't order the minimum, they change your order on the bill (ie: write that that you've ordered 4 items person instead of 3). They DON'T TELL YOU and act insulted that you checked the bill.  SO DISHONEST! I'm NEVER going back and NEVER recommending.
author: Lala B.

description: This is quite possibly the worse dim sum I've ever had.  The food was so obviously not fresh and mediocre at best.   Some of it was even cold.  Maybe this place has gone downhill looking at some of the rave reviews, but it is simply not okay to serve reheated frozen food.
author: Bessie C.

description: I almost want to give these place five stars. Ton Kiang is definitely one of my favorite places for dim sum in the city. Scallop and shrimp dumplings are making my mouth water right now. Wide variety of dim sum and it is served hot.  I give Yank sing a slight edge but I will always love Ton Kiang.
author: Fernand P.

description: We had lunch here today and enjoyed the dim sum.  I feel I have a pretty picky palate and will say with confidence that their dim sum is good.  What I do like about Ton Kiang is that they have a good variety. My husband and I are not in the habit of eating seafood as well as pork.  One may asked, what are you doing at a dim sum place.  The food is fresh and not too oily.  I also like the fact that this place is clean.  We've always had good service.  One may think this place is pricey but you do get what you pay for.  Their portions are small, but it seems that is how dim sum are these days.  Thirty years ago, they were huge, but the style of dim sum were also different in those days.  San Franciscan's palate are usually more cultivated, therefore, you will see non asians at this restaurant, but don't think the food is diluted.
author: Gloria H.

description: This is an expensive dim sum joint  where you'll find Westerners who have never had authentic dim sum drop big money for tasteless food. If you walk down the block towards the Ocean you'll notice a place with real Chinese people waiting in line, be smart and go there instead to spend your hard earned dim sum fund. Michael Bauer has shown that he can't judge dim sum to save his life when he added them to his top 100, that's ok we can't expect him to be our all knowing food messiah for all world cuisines. I vote that the Chronicle hires a Michael Bauer who specializes in Asian food, this is the bay area.
author: Amber L.

description: Was there on 11/8 for dinner.  We had a party of 10 and the service, price and food were great.  Excellent spot for big group Dim Sum.  We tried all the Dim Sum on the menu and they were all fantastic!
author: Big B.

description: Ton Kiang may have once been a good Chinese restaurant, but is now a shadow of its former self. The food is bland and the clientele skews non-Asian; the natives have gone elsewhere for more authentic cuisine. An OK choice if you value cleanliness and English-speaking servers above all else, but otherwise, you can get better food elsewhere.
author: Chris T.

description: My problem with Ton Kiang is that I tend to go when I'm hung over on a Sunday, and the line is out the door, and we have to wait like an hour for a table. I remember once, I was even on crutches and they made me wait, despite other customers offering to let me go ahead in front of them, and then we had to sit upstairs??? The dim sum is, well, pretty damn good, but I couldn't give TK more than three stars because of the (dis)service, sorry.
author: Nish N.

description: OK place, I think it's a little over rated and the dim sum seemed salty.  For an interesting experience, try the place next door which is three times the quality but one third the price.  The place next door definitely prioritizes food over service, so be ready to be pushed around and share a table with some strangers.
author: Mark D.

description: Horrible restaurant!  Reviews are highly OVERRATED!  We went with a cousin who swears by City Search and Zagat reviews...  Now we hardly ever trust his judgment in restaurants.  The food was mediocre at best.  The service was slow and not friendly.  And the prices were ridiculous for dim sum.  Go back to Chinatown for dim sum, more choices and better prices!
author: Michael D.

description:
I eat Dim Sum regularly (weekly) and have for years.  It is my favorite breakfast overall.  I've eaten at Ton Kiang many times. 
Setting: a two story store front on Geary in SF.  It is very clean and has white table clothes.  You can be seated on either floor depending where seating is available.  Parking can be a problem unless the parking god smiles on you.
Service:  Polite and helpful.  Servers vary in their command of English.  There are many competent English speakers who can assist you. 
Food:  I have eaten at Ton Kiang many times in the past and have had good to wonderful food, this was the worst experience I have had.  Nothing was horrible, but nothing was really good.  Siu Mai weren't pork dumplings rather shrimp dumplings with a little pork.  The baked BBQ'ed pork buns were OK but not filled very well, pot stickers were ordinary at best,  My wife felt the shrimp and spinach dumplings were poorly balanced with shrimp overwhelming the spinach.  The Shanghai Dumplings were tough, dry and doughy.  Finally, I believe, because we got there at 10;20am, only the most ordinary of Dim Sum was being offered.  I noticed, as we were leaving after 11am, that the Dim Sum being offered was more varied and more specialty items were being served.
author: Dennis T.

description: SOooooo not worth it.  Its mainly a dim sum place for those that dont know anything about dim sum.  They dont even have the fundemental.  My friend and I had to actually request for spareribs and chicken feets.  THOSE should be the standards!!  and it is way more expensive than other regular dim sum place... other dim sum places that have real dim sum!
author: Janet S.

description: Have been going to this place for over 10 years. Their food is consistent in flavor and taste. The downsize to their food is they use MSG, their prices went up while portion size went down and every time we go not the best service we receive. But its convenient for us because of location, consistent on food that we like and clean overall which is hard to say about most places.
author: Larisa B.

description: For several years I've heard that this place has really good dim sum. I finally went in and was extremely disappointed. The food was average, at best, and the portions were small compared to a lot of other dim sum places I've been. To add to the disappointment, the prices were at least 50% more than other restaurants. I suppose it is a good place to take people who have never had dim sum since they don't bring around intimidating things like tripe or chicken feet. For more "Westernized" and vegetarian dim sum I would recommend Yank Sing instead.
author: Julie D.

description: Still one of my favorite places for dim sum. Mango pudding is one of the best next to Yang Sing, with half the Yang Sing bill. To all those who grouse about the wait...go early on the weekends. Any of the vegetables are good. They could use a little more variety, as sometimes it seems like most of the dishes are 20 different variations of shrimp. Just means that you need to know your dim sum and order it. Wear the old people pants with the elastic so you can waddle out.
author: Arlene C.

description:
Don't even bother going in there!   The shanghai dumplings were dry, and the flat rice noodle was eh...scallion pancakes were horrible (why we ordered I don't know) and the rest was just bleh. I've had better dim sum. 

It's not a good sign when there is more non-Asians entering the place.  I'm fine with spending money when the food is good but this is not worth your money.
author: Sim T.

description: Decent selection of dim sum, love the sesame balls, the shrimp dumplings were also very good- not too greasy. I thought it was cool how they brought trays of dim sum to out table for my friend and I to pick and choose what we wanted. Something new for this dim sum fan!
author: Christy M.

description: Along with Yank Sing, the place to get gourmet dim sum in the city. I could go on and on about how mouthwatering and awesome their potstickers are. I think they are the best I have ever had. The shanghai street dumplings? Heaven!  I also like that they have an extensive menu as well (great hong kong style noodles). I love this place and all the bow tie servers and women who push the food on you. They must get commission. This place is the best...
author: Nick H.

description: Love me some dim sum! Fast and efficient service and the wait wasn't bad either. Love their fresh chinese broccoli, pork dumplings, and pork spareribs. Shrimp with scallops were unique, as were the spinach dumplings. For two people, we had tons of food, and the bill was around $50. A bit pricey, yes, but good for once-in-awhile dining.
author: David G.

description: Ok an oldie but goodie... A friend and I decide to go to Dim Sum last Sunday and I forget in the mists of trying to avoid the city (parking & traffic) in a car tha we have great little places for dim sum. Consistancy is a definite.. love this place but it caters to the non-asian for sure.. still yummy tho...
author: Karen E.

description: I know you're going to think that I just think food is good no matter where it is but this place really is my very favorite dim sum spot in the city. Who knew that a little steamed goodness is all that you needed to spice up an ordinary lazy Sunday. Another amazing feat. . . duck - fast. I couldn't believe it Peking duck without calling ahead. Definitely worth the drive.
author: Elektra D.

description: I've been here a couple of  times, and I don't understand how people can think this is a good dim sum place. The portions are tiny, the food is mediocre at best, and expensive! Do yourself a favor and walk down to mayflower, or down to clement from a dim sum bakery.
author: Drew Y.

description: Dude.  Did you know they serve dim sum here until 10 pm?  Out-freaking-standing.
author: John H.

description:
I should have known than to trust my date - an all-American guy who grew up in Marin.  He told me that Ton Kiang serves "THE BEST" dim sum he's ever had.  I was suspicious at first, but he persuaded me that with his upbringing in Marin, he was exposed to ALL sorts of extraordinary Asian food, and he KNEW dim sum.

First dish he ordered - potstickers.  I knew that I was in trouble.  Not a type of trouble that I could casually eat my way through.  I was in DEEP DOO-DOO.  As I sank deeper and deeper into my vinyl chair, depression set in.  How was I going to get out of this while gracefully convincing him that I deserved a second date?  After all, he was a nice-looking guy who seemed genuinely interested in impressing me.  Sigh, the romantic dance that we all engage in.  Don't really want him, but want him to want me.

Potstickers weren't so bad - IF THEY WERE GOOD.  Unfortunately, they were not.  The little lump of meat inside was securely wrapped in a THICK inpenetrable layer of panfried dough.

If you don't know the difference between a good potsticker and a bad potsticker - the dough is supremely important.  You want the dough to be thin and translucent yet strong enough to hold the filling.  Same for dumplings.  If the dumpling looks like the delicious filling inside is about to burst through its skin, then that's a SUPREME dumpling.  Where is the art in having such a thick dough that NOTHING (not even a hammer) will pierce it?

Long story short - I never went back to Ton Kiang again.  And I couldn't contain myself.  I let my date know that this was one of the worst dim sum places I have ever been.  He never called again.

Well, I guess my heart may want to fool itself, but my stomach always knows the truth.....  :-)
author: Hoola H.

description: This is pretty tasty.  We took my father to a more expensive dim sum place that he wanted to try and I am unconvinced there was any real difference in taste or quality.  Great for Sunday mornings, but get there earlier to avoid the crowds.
author: Tanya N.

description: I'm honestly biased since I live 5 mins away from this restaurant, but Ton Kiang serves the best dim sum in the City, especially during lunchtime. Actually, I do take that back: that applies only during lunchtime, since at dinner you have to order off the dim sum menu and that saps the improvisational fun of ordering food based on aesthetics and the power of smell alone. Either reserve or come early though: the lines will fry your mind and the search for parking will only make you hungrier.
author: Ramon T.

description: My friend and her hubby suggested that we come here for some dim sum when we were in town.  So we made the trek across the bay and finally found parking before heading inside.  Being that it was the middle of the afternoon, there wasn't much of wait for a table.  There aren't any carts at this place, but instead plenty of ladies walking around with platters of dim sum.  My usual favs are the har gow and the shu mai, which were both delicious here.  The dim sum is a little on the pricier side than what Im used to in SoCal, but Im grateful my friends suggested it.
author: Grace T.

description: Went back to SF over President's weekend, and a good friend of mine took me here.  I have passed this place a million times, but I had no idea!  The decor is nice, but I have been to nicer dim sum places, thus minus 1 star, but the food was delicious!!!  And when you see the line go out the door, and people are willing to wait for it, you know it's good!!!
author: Helena S.

description: agree with what i read so far... a little on the pricey side - can get crowded, but if you want clean, yummy, fresh Chinese then this might be your place.  Cha su bow (pork buns) are one of my favorite foods, and these are pretty damn respectable - but i think i am still on a quest for the best pork buns in sf (suggestions welcome).  the seasonal veggies are good - ask what is most fresh when you are in...  damn good egg foo young if you are into it.
author: David F.

description: My man came here before they renovated .......He told me about the braised pork, my man is hecka picky about fatty foods, and he says that this would be the only place he would eat it.......After driving around to find a space for 10 min., we finally entered.  My first impression was this is not our type of restaurant, there weren't any Chinese in there, don't get me wrong, but when Chinese people eat Chinese food, they usually go to places where there are tons of Chinese sitting, eating and jabbing.  So we ordered the braised pork, their specialty chicken, which is frozen chicken and a dish of veggies.......I did notice that the place was kind of packed, and that almost every table had dim sum, I thought that was kind of cool, and this is at 9:30 at nite.  Waiters were same as any other Chinese palces except that the vests they wore were much cleaner...lol, aside from that, this guy and girl waiter were speaking in Chinese saying they charged someone $10.00 for candles and started laughing....I guess they forgot we were there, anyways, I feel sorry for the customer that got stuped into paying that......
author: Leslie Y.

description: The food is wonderful, and there's a nice variety of vegetarian options.  However, you may die of hunger while waiting for a table.  Having reservations doesn't seem to shorten the wait at all, which is curious.
author: Andi T.

description: My family and I always go here and are never disappointed.  It's even worth dodging traffic across Geary.  Well, okay, almost.
author: M. H.

description: My husband is half Chinese and loves Dim Sum. I have never been a fan of most of the items... until I went here. This place makes it easy. They speak English, have a cheat sheet with all the item's names and what they are. The only draw back is parking and they don't come around with the cart. It's just ladies carrying trays, but they are always coming by with a tasty something. I can't wait to take the in-laws when they come to visit.
author: Heather W.

description: Great selection of little bites and edible doodads. Its best to go woth a large group (6 or more) people to experience dim sum. This will enable you to try lotsa different stuff and still walk away full. Wine list is a little thin. Call for reservations on a weekend, this place fills up fast.
author: Mick F.

description: I thought dim sum in San Francisco had gone the way of Harbor Village, but I was wrong! I don't know why I waited so long to check out the dim sum scene here. I was impressed with Ton Kiang's selection and quality. The roast duck in particular (not one of the usual dishes I pick up) was quite tasty and had nice crispy skin. Probably the best dim sum joint in the city.
author: Sunny Y.

description: this place I guess is best known for their Dimsum. On a weekend hungry urbanites line up around the block to get a taste of hakka style cuisine. I have actually never tried their dimsum because the food in this place is much much better. Everyting is very flavorful and the meats are of high quality. If you are craving some Chinese food around the Richmond area, check out Ton Kian - you will not be dissapointed"
author: Christian S.

description:
This is another review I wrote that was originally posted on another site.  Though not extremely recent, I believe that it is relevant. 

Originally Review: 6-13-06

"Took the wifey and 3 yr old after reading numerous reviews raving about how good this is. Was disappointed and underwhelmed by our experiment. Should have listened to my warning bells when we sat down and realized that the restaurant was clearly not marketing to the Asian demographic. The Dim Sum was above average but certainly no where close to being the "best of the city". It lacks true authenicity due to its leanings toward a more Western palate. Service was outstanding, as was the ambiance / dining area. The bathroom, though better than average for a chinese restaurant, did not match how nice the rest of the restaurant is. The restaurant has a premium aire, with premium service, and premium presentation. Unfortunately, it also comes with a PREMIUM price. The 3 of us left hungry after paying $50. Its a good restaurant to come to if you're looking to impress people who have never had dim sum. But for the experienced, this restaurant is simply an expensive meal for only average food."
author: Dennis Y.

description:
I have been a long time fan of this establishment.  However, it has been about a year since I last came and it has definately gone down hill.  The fried calamari was perfectly cooked but salty.  The won ton noodles in my soup(which used to be the best in the city) were smaller and more doughy.  The sticky rice had no essence of the leaf that was surrounded the rice.  It took 1 hour for a shrimp dumpling to come by the table.  I had to actually flag down one of the servers as she passed our table with a cart like we werent even there.  Not a single plate was picked up the whole time we were there and of course the water cups stayed empty.  What a shame that what used to be such a solid dim sum place has fallen so far.  I hope they get the message and clean up their act.  
There are plenty of other dim sum places that have better quality, much better service, and more accesible.
author: victor j.

description:
Just came back from Ton Kiang.  Didn't have dim sum and had a set menu for 10 people.  It was a lot of food.

It is not as traditional but good nonetheless.  I think the chef is trying different techniques and all that fusion stuff.  We got served a large chunk of baked bass, which I have never seen in a Chinese restaurant. One for being baked, two for served in one large chunk and lemon.  The cold plate had beef brisket, seaweed, jellyfish, pork, and tofu.  Very interesting combination.

The environment is very cozy. Service was good.  When they are a little busy, you have to flag the waiting staff down for tea refill.  They are very tentative when there are less customers.
author: D X.

description: Ton Kiang has a larger selection of dim sum than Lucky Fortune, or Chinatown restaurants, including my favorite BBQ pork buns (baked, not steamed!) I wouldn't rate the flavor as highly as Lucky Fortune though, and given the popularity of LF, others seem to agree. But if you want a particular item or a bigger selection then Ton Kiang is probably the place to go!
author: Will A.

description: Yum cha to enjoy with friends and had a bon voyage party here for friends moving back to the East Coast and they chose this place! Brought our own wine, had a great time and very easy to kick back with a large group because the second floor is made available for diners. Originally remembered that they had a great salted chicken, but the dim sum menu has even expanded its loyal customer base. Huge lines most of the time on the weekend, but well worth it.
author: miriam b.

description: This is a pretty good dim sum place with great variety. But waiting to be seated is a pain because of their "seating" strategy (big party has the priority and there are not many small tables).  Reservation is not available for two people.   So if just for two people, a wait for at least 30 minutes is normal during the weekend lunch hour. That is the only reason I take off 1 star.  The dim sum is delicious and worthy of the wait though.  We like the "pea tips shrimp ball" which has snow peas inside the shrimp ball.  IMO, it tastes better than the regular shrimp ball with vegetable add-ins, fresh, crispy and not so meaty.  A few more good choices include "egg custard rice cake", "Mango pudding" (as dessert), "BBQ port bun".  Their dim sum menu is a good combination of traditional and novel items.
author: Ile F.

description: Came back for dinner with the boyfriend - OMFG, the baked char siu buns... I don't know what they put in them but they're ambrosiac. Had a lovely experience in the restaurant; as expected, even nicer than takeout! (huh... no-brainer, I guess...)
author: Marianne S.

description: So we respected the crowds and decided to go to dinner here on a Saturday instead of lunch.  I thought we might take a hit on the food quality but I was still super impressed.  We had to order our dim sum off the menu, so that took something away from the overall experience, but it came out promptly and was great.  I mean everything was super tasty.  They had run out of Chinese broccoli, and waited 15 minutes to tell us, but the bok choi substitute was awesome.  I drive around for 30 minutes to find parking until I finally gave up and found a $10 valet parking lot.  I shit you not.  30 minutes.  And THEN got valet . Ask my girlfriend.  I took it out on the poor rental car.
author: Eugene S.

description: This place was pleasantly surprising. We went with a group of friends all of whom love Dim Sum. I was a little afraid of trying something new, but the food in this place is really fresh and very good. They have a large selection of Dim Sum - don't miss out on the prawns, they are really good
author: Belinda w.

description: I wish I could give it a zero. The service is terrible. The food is even worse. I knew that it wouldn't be authentic, but I wasn't expecting to have food worse than Panda Express. We only ordered 3 dishes and the total was $50! We told the staff that we were very unhappy but they had the nerve to roll their eyes! We didn't leave a tip, but made the mistake to pay with a credit card so they took tip anyway. Never again. This place sucks.
author: Salma L.

description: Yes, it's true, this place probably isn't that authentic (there was a Burmese-type salad), but there were enough pork buns and soup dumplings to make anyone happy.  My main Bay Area points of dim sum reference are Koi Palace (too crowded) and Yak Sing (too expensive), so this seemed just right.  And yes, our table was in a kind of dingy, tiny room upstairs, but with all the good food and tons of steaming hot sesame balls, who cares where you sit?  Plus, we got seated immediately and I actually got water from our waiter, which is a level of service I have never gotten at any dim sum place before.
author: Kim S.

description:
I went to Ton Kiang a couple of days ago with friends who are big fans of Hakka food.  I'd never been there and am not familiar with the cuisine, so I let them order.  (There were three omnivores in our party and one vegetarian.)  We had the vegetarian hot and sour soup, a couple of different kinds of greens-one with some chiles, the other with garlic, lovely scallops, green beans on crispy noodles, a beautiful steamed fresh striped bass (fresh as in it was swimming in the tank in the kitchen when we walked in).  We alcohol-consumers had Tsing Tao.  Dessert was tiny, hot, gorgeous egg custard tarts, sesame balls, similarly hot and gorgeous, and the famous mango pudding.  When the check came, it arrived with delicious little cookies-not fortune cookies.  The bill for all of this (including multiple beers), plus tax and tip, was about $140.  (We tipped generously, and the servers deserved it.)

Oh, yes--they serve a spicy vegetable sort of relish to start off with, and their sauces--cilantro, ginger--are fabulous--great foils for the relatively bland fare.

The food was fresh, healthy, delicious, and it was served by professional, skilled servers.  I need to go back once or twice more to consider adding that extra star, but I suspect that I will, and soon.  A very good restaurant indeed.
author: Earline A.

description:
Excellent, high-quality, Dim Sum.  Not the cheap stuff.  Can be crowded on weekends after about 11 AM.  If you don't lika da crowds go early or after 2 PM.  Great after a night of drinking.  Service is pretty good, though it depends on if you get there when a fresh run of dumplings is headed out of the kitchen.  There is often the moment with Dim Sum where you are dying to eat and then totally overwhelmed by the options.  Steamed shrimp with mushrooms, snow peas leaves, and plain are all good.  The Foil Wrapped Chicken is saucy and scrumptious.  Steamed Pork Buns good, though filling.  BBQ Pork Rice Noodle is a special one you don't see everywhere, and sticky Rice is great.  Taro Root and other favorites are consistently great at T.K.  Best to come hungry with 2 or more peeps.
Parking can be a challenge in this neighborhood, but it's SF folks...
author: Lo F.

description: Best Dim Sum I have ever had. Totally busy and bustling but still not noisy and the servers really circulate that food. Plus if you don't see your favorite, order it and BAM it's there like Emeril's toothpaste! Love the shrimp dumplings, pork buns, foil wrapped chicken, and egg custard tarts. Prices are insanely great for how much I will eat and I don't feel rushed but I never spend long there. It's the rapid fire service."
author: Jill D.

description: Used to be one of the best but now only a little above average and expensive to boot. Parking is very difficult on the weekends, also.
author: patrick g.

description: Yea, my niece took me here. It was Sunday night, no crowds, just good food, I thought was cheap so I don't know about what everyone is saying about expensive. Great service. Would I go back? Heck yea.
author: Brandon M.

description: I was very disappointed with their dim sum. There are nothing special about their dim sum compare to other restaurants and yet they cost twice as much. The charsiew pao was bland, shumai and hargow were mediocre. I like their egg custards but they were so tiny! The only good thing about this place is their service. Fast and friendly (seriously rare for chinese restaurant...) I don't plan to return here despite everyone raves about their non dim-sum food. Sorry.
author: Maria H.

description:
very good.

always a bit crowded, but that's okay.

i really like their garlic pea sprouts.

and their eggplant stuffed with shrimp.

and onion pancake.

and these lotus seed paste-stuffed pastries.

tea is good.

---------------------

what was funny was that the servers would always switch to Cantonese as they passed our table and back to English for everybody else.

-----------------

a bit 'spensive.

i've decided that i can only come here every so often.

i dunno why.

it just seems like a place to get tired of all the time.

: )
author: Inari T.

description: The dim sum was OK. Not bad, but nothing special. Don't know why it was highlighted on the 100 things to eat...list.
author: Ava C.

description: This is a review for their Dim Sum, which I think was pretty good for the price.   the issue with places in SF for dim sum is that they're generally not high turn over enough to have a large selection and really fresh dim sum.  This place was definitely big enough - easy seating for 10+ people.  and there are two levels to the restaurant.  The xiao long bao was bad... no soup, really thick, not what it should be.  However, it tastes fine if you view it as just a dumpling :).  The other dishes were par, nothing was awful and the prices totally rock.  It was $15 a person AFTER tax and tip.  A meal like this at Yank Sing would have been triple the price.  but Yank Sing is better food.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Sooo good! Definitely my favorite dim sum place in the bay area. The service is quick and everything always tastes good. 

Favorite dishes:
Any of the shrimp dumplings
Sesame balls
Egg custard tarts

Get there early, otherwise you'll have to wait! But it's well worth it.
author: Julie H.

description: Its a good place for dim sum but for regular stuff it's eh. I have been here a couple of times and I realized its only good for a once in a while dim sum cause it can get expensive. The dim sum is good but it used to be delicious so I am going to find a better place and more bang for my bucks plus more authentic.
author: Nadia N.

description: My second favorite dim sum place. At least, it used to be. Not 100% consistent experience, but they have some items that Yank Sing (my favorite dim sum place) does not:  calamari, and baked BBQ pork dumplings. The price is a lot cheaper than Yank Sing, and you'll drive/bus farther if you're not out in the Richmond district to begin with. But, generally it's worth the wait for more authentic dim sum in a clean-ish, bright location.
author: Karen C.

description: I used to love Ton Kiang.  But recently, I went there for the first time in over a year and I was a bit disappointed.  The food just wasn't as great as I remembered it.  I have been having dim sum at City View in the financial district at least once a month and definitely think that City View's food is better.  Ton Kiang is too touristy.  The portions are small, the food is expensive, and it just doesn't feel authentic.  I found it very telling that all the Chinese people were waiting in line outside the Chinese restaurant next door and all the tourists were waiting for Ton Kiang!  This is an OK place to bring out of town guests or non Chinese people but for a tastier and less expensive brunch, I'd recommend South Sea or City View.
author: L W.

description: Food is okay... but too pricey for me.  Besides any place with stencil drawings of the dumplings on the table and fancy cut up fruit  isn't an authentic dim sum place.
author: Sheenie L.

description: One of the best dim sums in SF and certainly the best value.  So why only 4 stars?  Well 4 stars is awesome, but after 3 or more visits, the selection starts to get a little tired - Ton Kiang should add some specials here and there.  But I can't stop going back!  Sauteed snow pea greens with no garlic, incredible, so good and good for you.  Rice/custard cakes, oh my word.  Looking forward to my next Ton Kiang visit.
author: Willie S.

description: I was disappointed with my latest visit.  It's not as good as it used to be, that's for sure.  I don't think I can recommend this place for dim sum any longer....but I would still say it is better than Yet Wah on clement st. If you like watery, oversteamed soggy dim sum, Yet Wah will fufill your cravings.
author: Grover G.

description: Wow, Dim sum refuge for the Gwai Low.  Bland taste, expensive too.  Not coming back ever.
author: Ed C.

description: Tong Kiang offers pretty consistently good dim sum.  Almost everything I've tried was good, and the food seemed less greasy than some other dim sum places.  I kind of wish dim sum places this one included would stop dipping their veggies in oil though.  Seriously, I think they would steam those veggies and then dip them in oil...on purpose...and for what?  To make them shiny and *bling*ing?  I've once asked an English speaking waitress for  "no oil".  I simply got a blank stare.  Then, moments later came the oil dipped Chinese broccoli.  The greasy veggie issue is more cultural and my frustration should not be taken out on Tong Kiang, however, as it is generally less greasy that a lot of other dim sum restaurant in the Bay Area.  It is in fact my #1 choice for dim sum.
author: A T.

description: Damn good yum cha action, right in the city! Although this place does get packed and you'll have to wait, it's not on the order of hours like Koi Palace. I like their sweet plates - it's a little better than other dim sum joints.
author: Peter S.

description: A very "Occidental" friendly dim sum restaurant.  Pictographic menus on the table...Not too fond of this spot.  To paraphrase T.D.B. Phi; "...never trust an ethnic restaurant when there are more people there who are not of that ethnicity than who are."  (Just like at another "Superstar" of a restaurant in the Richmond...)
author: Al K.

description: despite some peoples protestations that Ton Kiang is not truly authentic dimsum, it is still delicious.  The dumplings are all very delicate, the rice-outside-part forming a thin wrapper which allows the quality of the filling to stand out. (in contrast to the thick chewy outside other dumplings are prone too)  the vegetable dishes here, especially the peasprouts, are all outstanding and are obviously fresh and not over cooked.  none of the dishes are oversauced, perhaps due the to influence of California -chez panisse style- cooking.  despite the price, the parking, and apparent lack of authenticity, I praise the quality and sophistication of Ton Kiang, five stars.
author: greg B.

description: In the 5 years since I lived by ton kiang they have gone from a great dim sum place filled with chinese to a mediocre dim sum place filled by whites with fat pocketbooks.  I think the clientele speaks for itself in a chinese restaurant.
author: Matt N.

description: Wow, I finally got to eat here today after driving by so many times over the past year! The reason why I never dined here before was due to the massive crowd of people typically waiting outside to be seated. Surely that would have been indicative of how great the food is, but boy, was I sorely disappointed. The dishes were way too saucy, too greasy and for the most part did not look at all appetizing. Although I will give them one star for the sauteed bok choy and steamed pork buns, which were good. The other star goes to the somewhat friendly service, friendlier than most dim sum restaurants.
author: Donna A.

description:
the reason I gave them 4 stars:
       1. The place appears clean. 
       2. They have their own napkin, which is big enough and soft, and with their logo on it.
       3. the food tasted fresh, no MSG, not salty. I am a "no msg, low salt" person. Their food seemed have met the point.
       4. The service is ok... we went in at 8:30pm at monday night. It's not crowed, but still mostly full. We had a big round table in the front lobby, not cold, and easy to get served.
       5. The dessert is fine, too. Not very sweet.
       6. The price is a little bit higher than the average.

Totals up: Food is fresh, tasty and refreshing. Service is okey, but it doesn't match up their price. I mean, people pay $ to get good service, the owner needs to put more attention on training their servers. The parking is easy to find after regular dinner time , otherwise, better take muini, or have to park blocks away....
author: Healthy B.

description: It's quality dim sum but boy is it expensive.  I noticed the late afternoon when I went that there was a dearth of a Chinese crowd here... The service is great (our waitress spoke good English) and the dim sum is brought to you by tray vs. carts.  Ton Kiang is cleaner, more polished than other dim sum restaurants... kind of like the place a Chinese girl would take her Caucasian in-laws from the Midwest or something.  The ppl in the restaurant are more "well"-behaved as in it's not as loud as a traditional Chinese restaurant.  Tableware is nice.  I don't remember anything remarkable about the food other than it wasn't terrible.  The only thing I do remember was my cousin ordering this fresh fruit mix that was built into a pretty structure which cost me $$$ (since it was my treat).  Maybe that's really Asian of me.. to refrain from ordering something like fresh fruit (we're talking honey dew, cantalope, grapes, oranges -- not something mroe exotic or rare) at a restaurant and pay a premium for someone cutting and sculpturing it for me.
author: Alias A.

description: I really wished I like this place. I hear all the time this is the best Dim Sum in the City. My first impression was that this place was elegant, and had a very fancy ambiance.Unfortunately I can care less about how things look, I only care about the taste of the food. I sit down and first notice the limited selection. I noticed that a lot of the items on the menu were very westernized and not what I was looking for. I decided I should at least order the usual, an order of Sui Mai an order of Har Gow and they both tasted disgusting, The portion was small, too salty and almost 5$ an order. When I had enough I told the server I wanted to pay and leave. He gave me and my group a disgusting look and told me there was a 15 minimum. I didn't want to be there any longer and ordered something random to go. They took so long I left without that order and went next door to another Dim Sum place that was more then half the price, bigger portions and far better service.
author: Steven V.

description: I've been here a couple of times, and have not been disappointed. I wish I lived closer, I would go  way more often!!!
author: Court S.

description: This place is way overrated!  Very expensive but the quality of dim sum or service just isn't there.  I could get the same food and service for 1/3 of the price most anywhere else on Geary or Clement.  Why do people rave about this place?
author: Cara C.

description: Overpriced and full of yuppies who think just about any dim sum tastes good so the quality suffers.  It was a lot tastier in the past, but I think the line out the door went to their heads.  This place is on the decline.
author: matthew w.

description:
I grew up in Hong Kong, the mecca of dimsum, and have dined at all famed dimsum places in the Bay Area. Ton Kiang is below average, I would have given it 3 stars if not for the ridiculously expensive price.

Don't get me wrong, Ton Kiang used to be good, the last time I was there (2.5 years ago), it was already going downhill. The first time I went there was in 96, and it did live up to its reputation. Let me go through one by one why it doesn't make the cut.

1) Harkow - shrimp dumpling. As a dimsum addict, let me divulge a little secret of how to judge a good dimsum place. Order Harkow as a test. A good harkow should encompass chewy, juicy shrimp in the RIGHT proportion with bamboo shoots, and most importantly, the transparent skin in which the content is wrapped has to be thin and elastic, so that when you pick up the shrimp dumpling from the bamboo container, the skin MUST NOT break. If it breaks, try another dimsum place next time.

Why is this so important? I am not being snobbish, but Harkow cooking skill is the single most applicable platform for making all dimsums. If you don't get Harkow right, you won't get shiumai right, nor will you get chuengfan (rice rolls) right. 

What happened at Ton Kiang? Harkow is most definitely a disgrace, the skin is broken before my chopsticks touched it. That means, when steaming, the juice evaporates and my shrimp meat loses its flavor! As expected, everything in that arena came out sub par.

2) BBQ Buns - Cha Shiu Pao. What makes a good BBQ bun? The right fermentation to make white, soft, sublimely sweet flour bun wrapping the RIGHT amount of BBQ pork in its own sublimely sweet and salty juice. What can break it? Bad bun that is not properly raised, or BBQ pork that was left over from previous nights. That was exactly what I got at Ton Kiang.

3) Pork and shrump wrapped in tofu skin - this is a category by itself because it involves another type of skill, steaming tofu skin wrap. This  perhaps sounds easy, but since tofu skin has a certain firmness, and if you oversteam it, it tends to fall apart before getting into your mouth. You also need to make sure that the content within the tofu skin is cooked just right, because the textures of tofu skin is obviously different from that of shrimp and pork meat, so pre-treating one element before the other is very important. Hence, when steamed, both the tofu skin and the content inside can arrive the desired tenderness at the same time. Ton Kiang failed in this miserably.

4) Steamed beef ball - This is a highly desired delicatessen if you do it right. The beef should NOT be all lean, some portion of fat needs to be  mixed in to give it tenderness, and careful beating of the beef patty is a requirement to force air into it so that when steamed, the beef ball will expand, allowing more air particles inside to make it taste softer.
