Last but not the least, it should only be steamed to the extent that the outside is fully cooked while the core is just a tad bit red, a tad bit, so that the outside is crunchy while the inside is, well, tender. 

Ton Kiang cooked the beef ball as if the it was boiled instead of carefully steamed.

5) This category will be the least concerns for all non-Chinese. Chicken feet. You dimsum fanatic out there must know what well-cooked chicken feet are. Ton Kiang overcooked them too much that the steamed chicken feet came swimming in a soup of themselves decomposed to the extent of beyond recognition.

I live in South Bay, and I find Ton Kiang's reputation as the best dimsum restaurant in the Bay Area to be completely bogus. We have plenty of much more superior dimsum places in the South Bay, Hong Kong Flower Lounge in Palo Alto, Dynasty and Joy Luck Place of Cupertino, ABC Seafood of Milpitas, just to name a few.

The recent visit I paid to Ton Kiang will very likely to be my last.
author: Jessy S.

description:
My friend took me here after seeing this place on yelp, hope other people don't make the same mistake.

-1 * mediocre taste, nothing to write home about
-1 * way overpriced, why pay more when there are dozens of dim sum places nearby?
-1 * Americanized (take a look around, where are the canto at?) and serving crazy unauthentic dishes to appease their target audience

Do yourself a favor and try someplace else!
author: M. W.

description: Great place to eat alone, with a spouse, or with the entire family.  Busy and the food is consistent and fresh.  Dim sum is reasonable, as are the entrees.
author: Pug P.

description: Born and raised on Ton Kiang since the late 80's. Great people that run it and yes one of the best dim sum houses in SF. Like all restuarants they have had their ups and downs, but from years of experience they are on the upside now. Authentic Hakka Cuisine at its best.  Sorry about the long lines, wouldn't know...how could you blame them, i've been eating there for most of my life.
author: eric w.

description:
UPDATE: It has been over four years since I wrote the below review and I've not been back during all that time.  Today, I decided to give it another chance.  It was even worse than before and I can say without a doubt that I will NEVER go back again.  The absolute worst Shanghai dumplings that I've ever tasted - thick dumpling skin, dry/no soup inside, might have even been frozen/from the store.  Subtracting one star.  

----

It is with some sadness that I write this review.  I've been a loyal customer of Ton Kiang for years.  Today I had, without a doubt, the worst meal there I've ever had.  The recipes for a number of my favorite dishes appeared to have changed - for the cheaper.  There were fewer black mushrooms in the green bean dish and the BBQ pork buns had almost no filling...and what there was didn't have much flavor.  It's almost like someone in the back office finished their MBA and decided to put all that good book larnin' to work by cutting back on the quality of the product in a bunch of "small, undetectable ways".   Well, I for one noticed.  Maybe there is a new owner or they lost their best kitchen staff or something but, whatever it is I'm not going back.  This place has totally jumped the shark in my opinion.
author: Joseph S.

description:
I am picky about my Dim Sum...so was a bit worried when I read some of the reviews.  However, my experience on New Years Day was excellent.  The Dim Sum was very good, the service was responsive. Here's the lowdown:
- Sticky Rice with meat wrapped in lotus leaf -- good quality leaves made the lotus flavor subtle -- highly recommended
- Pork Buns -- very light and tasty, many places get these simple buns wrong (meaning the dough is too heavy, resulting in lost flavor) - highly recommended
- Dumplings: shrimp with chives, shrimp with shitake mushrooms, pork "cups" ---all very fine quality
- BONUS -- the green chile sauce was excellent and they happily made me up a little bit to take home with my leftovers
- dessert -- the sesame balls were good, although I like them a little more "toasted," the rice flour pastry covered custards were fabulous...like little marshmallows filled with custard -- pretty decent tapioca too -- all of this is gravy, since most dim sum places the dessert is best avoided. 
All in all, very good.  I'll be back again soon.
author: Susan G.

description: I'll admit that this was my first experience with Dim Sum, but it was awesome.  The regular dumplings/shumai left something to be desired, but everything else was fantastic (potstickers, pork buns, ALL of the sweet stuff mmmm).  I would definitely go back!
author: Sarah C.

description: Have gone here for decades and USED to love it.  Food is pure grease.  Ordered take out: hot and sour soup was basically water and chili flakes, inedible.  Shrimp with snow peas not cooked through--shrimp felt rubbery and raw.  So bad, I actually brought it back and asked the chef to taste the crap he sold me.  They refused.  Would only refund @ for 2 dishes and shooed me out lest I disturb the other diners.  I'm done with TK and disgusted they don't take customer satisfaction seriously.
author: C R.

description: Tom Kiang is an easy treat. Food is pretty good. Sometimes, a little oily. The waiters... well it's a chinese restaurant, but they're decent. I go there regularly, and will go there again. A little too pricey...
author: yor m.

description: "pretty good dimsum; not amazing, but predictable and quite reasonable"
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I was recommended this restaurant years ago by my old boss--and he was from New York living in Seattle. I have taken all of my family members here and have found the food to always be amazing, and the service to be pretty good. The parking is tough in this area, so be prepared to circle for  a while. But you can't beat being able to get Dim Sum any time or day or any day of the week!
author: Suzanne H.

description: Pretty good Dim Sum place even though I like the Golden River next door more. It tastes better and you have full control over what you get. I felt like here at Ton Kiang when they bring the plates around there is not so much variation. Plus it's a lot of fried food. Plus the lines are usually long and there's a wait. I am no fan of waiting so if I can avoid it, I do.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
I like Ton Kiang--it's my go-to place for dim sum.  Admittedly, there may be (probably are?) better dim sum joints in town, but I go to Ton Kiang.  The food is good, the servers are nice and that's enough for me.  
Today, my mother-in-law and I went for the parade of food and I noticed something.  The second floor dining room is a disaster: a nursing-home stench, peeling paint, unpainted patches of spackle and just an overall rundown appearance.  The first floor is decent, but the top floor is a hot mess.  I was reminded of that wreck of a singer, Amy Winehouse.  She stumbles onto the stage, high on crack and with scratches, bruises and track marks all over her body and then just starts belting it out with this amazing voice.  The second-floor dining room is a little like that: it looks a mess, but the food is still really good. 
Moral of the story: if you're trying to impress someone (but not that much), jockey for a table on the first floor.  If you just don't care and want yummy dim sum and swift service, eat on the second floor.  The food still tastes good up there, too!
author: Lauren M.

description: Delicious dim sum, particularly the foil wrapped chicken and shrimp balls.   However, disappointing service if you ask for anything specific (we waited for 20 mins for something which was not on the current circuit train). Crazy line, so send an early emissary, and cover their lunch. The investment will be worth it!
author: Richard B.

description: So I don't really like dim sum, but in the world of dim sum this place is supposed to be the bomb.  I like shrimp and almost everything has shrimp in it.  Stay away from anything caro, oh, and don't order a softdrink, that's like bad luck at dim sum.
author: Lane K.

description: I  am certainly going to enjoy more Dim Sum after our experience today.  We were seated immediately and had tea and food on our table within 3 minutes.  All of the items that we tried were very tasty.  Loved the shrimp dumplings, potstickers, pancakes?...service was good too.
author: Lisa D.

description: Very, very good meal. Chow fun, 9 orders of dumplings and a couple of beers for less than 60 bucks.
author: Tom D.

description: yummy dim sum that's reasonably priced. get here early on the weekends if you want to get a seat.
author: Tami W.

description: unlike all other reviewers, i don't recommend Ton Kiang for it's dim sum. Ton Kiang is best known to the Chinese community for its Hakka cuisine, not dim sum. it's a waste if you don't order their specialties like Salty-Steamed Chicken or Chinese Bacon w/preserved Vegetables, or their fresh seafood selections. in my opinion, their dim sum is mediocre and overpriced. they sell lots of it cuz its what the Anglos enjoy. it's like going to House of Prime Rib & ordering salmon. so skip the dim sum and order what they're famous for. p.s. dim sum is for lunch only, not dinner.
author: Kris L.

description: Tourist over here, tourist over there. Oh, that's a food critic so and so, and don't forget Martha Stewart already did a review on this restaurant.  I used to like this place, but now it's no longer enjoyable.
author: John L.

description: OK overall. The place itself is pretty nice, but service wasn't very good. Food was tasty, but seemed pricey (went during dinner). Worth the trip if your in the mood for Chinese and live in the area, but otherwise I would look for something in my own neighborhood.
author: Jonathan L.

description: My first SF dim sum experience.  Dim sum is probably not a good food for me, a person with no self restraint, to eat.  When I am offered plate after plate of tasty treats, the only response I can think to give is, Um, Yes?  The only thing that stopped us is lack of space on our table and stuffed stomachs.  However, we still have not made a dent in the vast number of dishes at Ton Kiang, so I need to get back there and try the rest very soon.  That being said, my favorites so far are the shrimp stuffed mushrooms, asparagus, sesame balls, chinese donut, custard tart, and shrimp and scallop dumpling.....
author: L C.

description: There are some good items at Ton Kiang.  They do a very good job with fried squid.  I also like the dim sum sized plates of steamed vegetables, and the plates with fresh fruit.  The vegetables and fruit are a nice contrast to all the dumplings, buns, and noodles.  I am not fond of Ton Kiang's pot stickers, or their pork sui mai, nor do I like their spinach and shrimp dumplings.  The meat in the pot stickers was minced too fine, and seemed  undercooked.  The pork sui mai had more shrimp than pork in its filling.  At every dim sum restaurant, we always ask, and are always told they have pork sui mai, but I have not tasted a real pork sui mai for at least 20 years.  I am not sure what happened to that traditional pork dumpling, but it seems to no longer exist.  I have yet to find a spinach and shrimp dumpling that can hold a candle to the one made at the Empress Pavilion in Los Angeles.  The egg puffs rolled in sugar (they call them donuts here) were served so cold, that I thought they might have been chilled.  Most of the dim sum is acceptable, it just is not memorable.
author: Vicki T.

description: The reputation through the years has meant that the crowds are still flocking to Ton Kiang. However, "the best dim sum in San Francisco" it is NOT. Ton Kiang is more popular with non Chinese or those who grew up outside of Hong Kong or China. It is non-threatening and offers a sort of comforting assurance that if you do not speak the language, you'll still be okay here. What stands out with Ton Kiang is that during dim sum it offers many small platters of otherwise a la carte menu items for patrons to sample. It is easier to just 'taste' a small plate and leave it if you don't like it, but to order an a la carte item you have no prior knowledge of? Many sauces are offered also for your dim sum (definitely NOT traditional, but I guess that's not Ton Kiang's intention). For your authentic dim sum experience in the city, go to Harbor Village at the Embarcadero Center or City View on Commercial.
author: Anita L.

description: this restaurant comes up on some "Best of" lists so when i lived in the Richmond i came here a few times with visiting guests to give them the "best" experience.  i have never found it to be above average.  i guess i was expecting more.  the dim sum is good, comparable to many other restaurants in that area.  and anyone who tells you it is the best really doesn't know what he /she is talking about.  you just drank the cool-aid like the rest of them
author: bucky c.

description:
Craving for real Chinese food, we decided to try Ton Kiang on a cold, windy Sunday evening. 

Parking was hard; we circled around for almost 30 minutes. We were hungry and almost decided to turn around and leave. Finally we saw someone pulled out of a parking spot one block away. We rushed to the restaurant. The first floor was almost full and someone was waiting for a table. The staff asked if we would mind being seated upstairs. Of course we didn't mind. Food was our priority. 

On the second floor: The smell was good; the waiter was professional and friendly; the ambiance was-- extremely noisy. Since it was supposed to be an authentic Chinese restaurant, we chose to ignore the noise. The dim sum menu looked lovely but it was late and we wanted something warm and filling. There were several dishes that looked good at the time; we finally decided on mu-shu pork, crispy gray sole (whole fish), braised oxtail and brown rice. Everything was fine but not great: The mu-shu pork was salty and had a burnt flavor, three of the six wraps were torn before we opened them up (a sign of previously frozen?); the gray sole was a little bit greasy, and the oxtail was too sweet for my taste. I don't know if we were just too hungry or were in a very good mood, even with all the imperfections, we still considered it a pretty decent dinner and plan to go back for their dim sum next time (we think the kitchen might slip a little bit on Sunday night and we were willing to give it another try.) I will update my review after the revisit.
author: S M.

description: This place was the best place for Dim Sum in San Francisco. I've had some amazing food here over the years. The last time I went however the prices had risen by 50% and the legendary line out front was gone.. It's no wonder, though Ton Kiang is still good, it's definitely lost some of it's luster.
author: Stellah D.

description: I cannot give them 5 stars because I hate waiting in line for more than 30 minutes for a table. Especially when it's out in cold foggy richmond, which is awful when it's Sunday morning and you're battling a hangover. BUT once you're in... the food is delicious. And the benefits of dim sum is that you can start eating right away. Just start flagging down the ladies, and point at the plates you want. I love all their steamed dumplings, in their beautiful translucent skins. I always eat about 5 desserts there too. The one place where I need to go with an elastic waistband ;)
author: Marina K.

description: The dim sum is better than most places in Chinatown, but it's also far more pricey.  Try the crab noodles- they're unbeatable.  The major downside is when you order specific items off the list, you'll be in for a long wait.
author: Rego S.

description: I would classify this as fine dining dim sum.  It is very clean, service is attentive quick.  The prices are high though.  There are probably places out in SF that are just as good but cheaper.  But if you want a nice, clean place to eat, this would be a good spot.  On a 1pm Sat, the wait was about 15-20 min, not too bad.
author: Emiko M.

description: The dim sum we had was good, but certainly no better than any of the dim sum I had when I lived in Chicago. With all the hype, I probably had too high of expectations when I got there. The variety is lacking but with what they had, no complaints. A plus was the lack of wait. A minus was the looooong bus ride down Geary to get there.
author: Natalie B.

description: I have been going to Ton Kiang for as long as i remember, my family loves to go there for dinner and yes we have been there for lunch too. Ever since Mayflower on 27th Ave and Geary changed ownership. They started to play favorites.  But aneway imma not here to bitch bout Mayflower.  Ton Kiang has a great assortment of different Dim Sum.  All their other food is just as good.  If you want good Chinese food but not too expensive then u should give Ton Kiang a try.  Another thing if u plan to go there for Lunch be ready to wait.  Especiallly on the weekends, during lunch time is their busiest times.
author: Jonathan W.

description: I thought the shrimp dumplings were good, not small.  If you don't want to wait for a tray to be carried out, just ask for what you want.  The food is okay and we didn't need any reservations for dim sum.  There is a good variety of vegetable dumplings.  This restaurant was chosen because we wanted to walk off our brunch at Golden Gate Park afterwards.
author: Ai M.

description: A popular place, I went on Easter a while back for first time and it's the only place my brother ever wants to go when visiting SF. Two floors, and a crowd of people always waiting outside to be seated. They are quick with their service and start to bring you food as you are being seated. The dim sum is decent and their sweets are tasty, and a good selection for vegetarians. Beware, parking is a pain on weekends.
author: Alyssa C.

description: Great place to find almost Yank Sing quality dim sum for mid-level prices..  not as inexpensive as some place on Clement but it's definitely worth it.  We always bring our friends & family visiting from out-of-town here and it's always a sure thing..  Can be a wait during prime dim sum brunch hours on the weekend, but b/c it's such a big place with quick turnover you can still get in fairly quickly.  The one great thing is htat dim sum is served all day pretty much when all other dim sum places are done at 2 or 3pm.
author: Rose C R.

description: The dim sum is great if you are willing to take out another student loan.  I am fat, so I definitely need a food loan.
author: Fatty A.

description: So sad. The portions and sizes went down from what I used to remember from undergrad...or like 5 years ago. I'd rather drive and wait in line for dim sum at Koi Palace.
author: Cathy H.

description:
I was pretty disappointed with Ton Kiang.

The food was hit and miss.  Some dishes were very good, some were okay, and some were not so good.  

It is also disconcerting to have the servers yell out their servings so close to your ear.  

They don't do a good job at keeping your water glasses filled either.  My husband actually got up twice to get someone to come over and refill his glass.

The prices, though, are reasonable.
author: Karen B.

description:
it's been a few years since the last time i was here.
i'm not sure why it's so popular.
it's nothing out of the ordinary in terms of dim sum.
author: charlotte s.

description:
Ok for starters there are always too types of dim sum places, places with white table clothes and waiters, and the other place where they come around in the cart and you yell for what you want.
This place is the former. It's a pretty large place with an upstairs for privacy and attentive staff. The selection is pretty basic and safe. I like it since I can order here at night calmly. Usually I can't order dim sum without someone with me to ask for my favorites (Chicken feet and noodles with shrimp under them, and turnip cake). But I would recommend this place to anyone who wants to try dim sum but is intimidated. This place has a menu with the pictures and descriptions. 
Don't get me wrong, its not a china town original, but it is not horrible or average. I was told by a friend that you can judge a dim sum place by its patrons, and Ton Kiang's seem to know dim sum.  Warning though, parking is nasty.

I am sort of wondering, there is another dim sum place right next door. It doesn't seem to be the white table clothe type, maybe its the same owner offering the choice of atmosphere. I usually like the other type of dim sum place either but it has to be for breakfast, I think that is what wakes me up :)
author: Greg G.

description:
it's not bad dim sum. they have the basics. they're pretty efficient and bring along what you're looking for. though their selection isn't the greatest and the space is a bit on the small side for a typical dim sum location. 

the service was good and friendly. i would probably go back to just check out their chinese food next time, not for their dim sum.
author: Madhu D.

description: Ton Kiang is one of our favorite special weekend brunch treats (especially for family birthday celebrations with the kids or when we have out of town visitors). It is an absolute Treyf-fest and we love it! Be sure to place your order for the walnut cookies while you're still eating the savories.
author: Jenni O.

description: Stopped by here for lunch after a beach hike; had another mini-hike just to find parking. The Dim Sum was OK, though pricey; I suspect the place was geared towards tourists since the decor was a bit fancy for a Chinese restaurant.
author: vinh t.

description: Admittedly I haven't been to a whole log of Dim Sum places in San Francisco, and tend to go back to the few I have experienced. This is one of them. Reasons being:  the food is consistently good and fresh, if unimaginative...you can get dinner at 10 pm...and the staff is attentive without hovering. I think the prices are fair for what you get, and the portions are abundant. If you're on a budget, just don't go crazy. (One reason not to go for Sunday brunch, where it's too tempting to order everything.) Of course, it is impossible to park in the neighborhood, but that's life in the nabe. For this Chinese-food deprived Santa Cruzan, it's not worth a trip out of town just to go there, but when I'm in town, it's a favorite. Just stay away from the roast duck - it's greasy and flaccid.
author: Chava Libbe S.

description: Decent dim sum and usually long wait on the weekends, go early...
author: Yan M.

description: When I first moved here, the ex used to take me to dim sum at the Yank Sing Kearny location (long gone). Then he took me here once, I guess it's more 'authentic'. I used to be a lot pickier with what went into my mouth back then & the staff at Ton Kiang didn't appear to speak English, if they could, they clearly chose not to. I didn't know what anything was, biting into it was a surprise and not always a pleasant one. Now I'm more adventurous and pretty much know what is in the dim sum I like, so this isn't as torturous an option as before. Unfortunately, there is often a line on weekends and it's a trek. I'd still recommend it though!
author: Colleen B.

description: I had dim sum here today for the first time in over five years.  I used  to "yum cha" here quite regularly, and I remember it as one of the best places in the City.    Overall, the food was fine.   It just wasn't spectacular, and, considering the higher prices they charge, it should be.  My litmus test for dim sum are the stuffed rice noodle rolls (cheung fun).  I had the BBQ pork one.  The rice noodle was the perfect thinness (sign of good quality), but TK used green onion (ugh!) instead of cilantro in the meat mix.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: My friend and I sort of stumbled upon this place as we were walking to the grocery store. She wanted a dim sum fix and I just wanted food. We were seated upstairs in the back room, which sort of sucked because it felt like we were stow-aways at the back of some Chinese restaurant. The servers came swiftly and constantly almost to the point of being obnoxious because I could not eat since I was too busy saying 'no thank you'. The main hostess was very friendly though and was good about refilling our waters. I was surprised by how expensive the dim sum was. But to be fair, the food was quite good for dim sum and I grew up on the stuff. What will keep me from returning? The price. It was just way too over-priced for what we got. There are many other options in Chinatown or even nearby on Clement St.
author: Janelle C.

description: Went here for breakfast on a Sunday morning around 9:30am and it was great! Get there early as it can get busy for the post church crowd. We ordered all kinds of food. Pot stickers were absolutely perfect, not overcooked in any way. Su Mai (spelling?), pork buns, chinese donuts (suuuuper sweet and yummy), shrimp combos and egg tarts. When they get really busy, they open up the upstairs. Service was great and prompt. Not sure the low scores from everyone else. We all loved it and I would definitely go back there again.
author: Theresa N.

description: Tried Ton Kiang on a recent trip to San Fran and loved it. I went during an odd time of the day, around 3pm, so service was certainly fast and attentive. I'm not a huge Dim Sum connoisseur, but I have to say I absolutely loved this place. Loved the selection and food quality.
author: David B.

description: I went last Sunday for Dim sum with friends. The food was great, the costumer service was excellent......GREAT TIME HAD BY ALL. I'll definitely will be recommending this restaurant to my friends.
author: mark l.

description: This  Dim Sum place is expensive but the food is so good and fresh. Prepare to wait in long line and difficult parking area.
author: Sasitorn O.

description:
mine eyes have seen the glory. if i were to die today, may it be face down in a bamboo basket of this place's dim sum. and if i were to die choking on it, may my constricted esophagus muscles loosen enough to allow that last bite to find it's way home to my stomach. 

it's the first place i took my girlfriend on our first date and we've gone on our anniversary (and in between) every year since. i truly have had nothing there i don't like except for this little firecracker waitress who, despite my wild, white boy hand gestures, seemed unable to communicate with anyone. scribbling little stick-figure cave drawings of a waitress bringing more chili paste on the tablecloth didn't help either.

good thing for this review i didn't eat her. but i could have. she was all cute and bite-size . . . . 

but not helpful. 

for two, thier 9 option dim sum is enough. for one, thier nine option dim sum is enough. that's right - if i were to ever go alone, you'd have to carry me out. manners would be out the window and my all-american attitude for consuming enough food to feed ghana would kick into gear. put simply: i'd make a complete spectacle of myself, further heightening any existing tension between our countries.

but it would be sooooo worth it.

go eat thier dim sum or i'll start sticking pins into my yelp-reader voodoo doll. for real - i got one of those.
author: SILAS M.

description: I know there's a lot of reviews touting this place, but in my opinion, it's okay.  Maybe it's because I think most dim sum places are decent, but the friend I went with did think all the food was done well.  The one thing I do have to mention though is the mango pudding was really mango jello with small bits of mango encrusted in it and wasn't very good.  Otherwise, there is a huge variety of dim sum plates to choose from so that may be why people go many times to try them all.  The line was out the door when I left at noon on a Sunday so get there early!
author: Livvy T.

description: This place has excellent chinese food. Whenever I eat here, I always remember the peking duck eatten on a bun. I usually hate eatting duck, because it's so greasy. This place serves it lean and the skin is crunchy! YUMMY!!!!
author: Helen L.

description: Excellent dim sum, second only to Yank Sing in my mind.  On weekends, go early (before 11) or late (after 1:30) to avoid a wait.  The waitstaff are friendly and speak english well.  If you don't see something you want, ask for it!  Look for the curry beef in phyllo dough, egg custard buns or pies, baked pork buns, duck, and the shrimp and chive dumplings - but you can't go wrong here, pretty  much everything is delicious.  Mmmmm!
author: Eclipse T.

description:
ton kiang is a solid pick for great dimsum, HOWEVER...

you can find cheaper prices at lychee gardens on powell
author: Charles C.

description:
save the money, go next door to golden river.  elevate the palate.
chopstick charlie
author: tim y.

description: Sorry guys, I don't like this place. The little dishes are small and the prices are a bit on the high end. There was also nothing I particularly thought was "good". Very expensive for mediocre dim sum.
author: Alton Y.

description: Expensive Dimsum, but well worth it. Quality and taste is fantastic and the method of presenting and serving is quite cool rather than traditional dimsum resturant.
author: David M.

description: Just ate there this weekend and something odd is going on.  The food was still great, really solid dim sum, decent variety, etc. but the service was abysmal.  ABYSMAL.  Try fifteen requests for water, ordered dishes never arriving at the table but appearing on the bill, no tea, etc. The WORST.  I'd like to think the floor manager was out sick or something, because I really love this place and I usually get perfunctory but competent service at a minimum.  Plus the decor is so shabby that my kids can throw crap all over the floor without making me feel guilty, you can make reservations for large parties, and it's cheaper than Yank Sing and easier to park.
author: Margaret F.

description: Long wait, greasy, expensive in the end  but SOOO delicious.   This is the best hangover food ever.   Most other times, I can't stomach it or have to go in knowing I'm going to feel sick all day.  Much better than other dim sum I've had but then again I'm not a dim sum connoisseur.  Go with a group bigger than two and leave the vegetarians at home.
author: laura a.

description:
it is not traditional Chinese dim sum;  but i like to go there to eat because it is tasty.
you should know the price is higher than regular dim sum place
author: Jane K.

description: The best part of most meals is the appetizers.  That's why dim sum is awesome.  Lots of tiny little bites of tiny little foods.  Like shrimp and snow peas.  And barbecue pork buns.  Oh man, those pork buns were good.  Sweet and tangy and meaty and delicious.  Also loved the sticky rice (my friend is a dim sum regular and thankfully knew to ask for it specially, or I never would have experienced this sweet, porky, saucy, ricey goodness).  And the sesame balls.  It's amazing how eating such small food can still leave you so full.  I'll be back when I'm done digesting.
author: Rachel B.

description: This place has had great dim sum since it opened, and not much has changed sinc. Last time we went to Ton Kiang, we didn't have to wait long to be seated, so it worked out real well, and it was a sunday evening too. We couldn't help ourselves, and had the dimsum, I believe it was like 9 different choices for 20 something dollars, I can't remember, and on top of that we ordered a crab, since we love crab so much... big mistake, because by the time our crab arrived we were stuffed with dim sum. That is why I m deducting that one star, because we took it home, and I didn't get to try it, but the person who did said it was dry and not too good. I wouldn't let all the judging up to him, since he is not a crab expert as I consider myself to be. But we will be back, and I will have crab. Keep up the good work.
author: yana Z.

description: Yikes!!  Expensive and not that good.  Ok, a couple years ago...say 6, it was ok.  Still expensive, still not the best, but good.  Now for what you pay for and what you receive, it caters to the lo fan (that means non chinese like me, although without exposure to better yum cha) which means they slide on the product and charge you up the azz.  Anyway...Ton Kiang has a million reviews, but for me,  I use it as a reference point in directing others to better places.
author: Kapeli M.

description: I honestly don't understand why this place is often crowded on the weekends.  Trust me, I only know this because I drive past it (i.e. I would NEVER wait in line to eat here).  There is nothing authentic about the place.  Everytime I eat here, I have to prepare myself for a night of being extremely thirsty.  The food is way too salty and my plate ends up being so oily that I checked to see if I could see my reflection.  Perhaps the only "good" things are: 1.) the thick napkins and 2.) the little cookies they give you after the meal...but I don't know that those are enough incentive for me to choose to go back.
author: Alvina W.

description: This place had below average dim sum at Koi Palace prices!  If you live in the city, it's worth the effort to drive to DC and wait up to an hour for a table at Koi.  Don't waste your time with Ton Kiang.
author: C L.

description:
Ugh. In the ongoing war of whether or not white people can pick a good dim-sum restaurant, I'd like to throw in something a little different. I'm half indian, which I suppose makes me half asian. 
    I am telling you, this place is Not Very Good. Now, sure, you may be reading this, and other reviews here, thinking "hmmm, but the chronicle said..." or maybe you always go to the same favourite dim-sum place? and you just want to try something different? Listen to me. I was thinking these same thoughts before I went last week-end. And I went ahead and tried it. And I was very, very disappointed. Do not go. It is not worth it.
    Let me explain. If you read other reviews here (but don't. Just read this one, and decide to go somewhere else), some people may say "for dim-sum virgins". This is accurate - but just in case you are a dim-sum virgin? Still don't go here. Why would you want to spend that magical time with someone who didn't care whether you had a great time, or even if you ever came again? You shouldn't.
    And for some thing concrete, about the food etc. The food is uninspired, small, lacking in taste or texture. Sometimes it was cold, because they don't use the heated carts, but rather the girls carry trays. The prawns they used were cheap and sad affairs. The dumpling skins were really thick and gungy. Otherwise, it was nice and clean, and the service was good.
author: Andrew I.

description: Meh. I have to give my latest visit to Ton Kiang a solid three stars. Nothing more, nothing less. I took my Asian Mom to Ton Kiang after 1pm over the weekend and she praised the fact that the food wasn't greasy, but was next to irate by the end of the brunch because of the lackluster service and lack of dim sum staples. I swear we ordered shaomai at least 10 different times from 10 different people - and even did so speaking cantonese! - and it didn't come until after we had already paid the bill. earlier in the meal, all that was wheeling around were egg custards and chinese donuts, but by the time we were done eating, all the dessert carts were no longer making rounds. It was like we had wronged one of the many forms of buddha and he had forgotten his own lessons on compassion.  I think the most shocking omission was the absence of chicken feet on a day when we were feeling adventurous (side note: we were hoping there would actually be a platter of feet - pigs feet, duck feet, etc.). Perhaps its advisable to show up on the earlier side for the choice pickin's, and perhaps it is also advisable to give your Asian Mom some Xanax before going so she can chillax on the leisurely pace of the Sunday service.
author: Veronica Y.

description: Grossly overrated by critics.  I was very disappointed in the food, and much worst that it is also overpriced.  One can get this same quality in Chinatown for 50% of the price.  I am not sure what was served to the critics.  We had dim sum and a couple of dishes off the menu.  It cost me $60 for lunch for 2, and we were not even full.  MISLED by critics.
author: N B.

description: Located on Geary street in the Richmond area. This restaurant is so so for their dim sum. Their dim sum is Hakka Style which is nothing from Cantonese style. They take forever also to bring out their dishes.
author: Prescott T.

description: I have to say my experience there was pretty good. Unlike most other dim sum places, it had a pretty extensive vegetarian selection. The service was way above your typical dim sum place.  Easy to park around that area too!
author: Nellie L.

description: It's good quality is that you can eat dim sum for dinner.  However, it doesn't have the real atmosphere of eating dim sum (selecting from carts roaming around the room, and trying different things).  Here, you have to order off of a paper menu with little drawings but come on!  All dumplings look the same in drawing form.
author: Dana C.

description:
i don't care what people say. i love this place, and i'm sticking to my guns on this one. best dim sum restaurant in the bay area. growing up in san jose and having tried countless dim sum restaurants throughout the bay area and throughout my life, i can safely say that ton kiang is the best. people complain about the price points and the long wait, but what do you expect for solid, fresh, excellent quality dim sum? the wait is always worth it. how many dim sum restaurants have you eaten at when you've been able to dissect a shrimp dumpling / har gow and not find one speck of black in the shrimp? the shrimp here are actually de-veined! 

in addition to the amazing food, there's the vast and diverse selection. not only do they have the classics (plump, juicy shrimp dumplings in non-soggy/mushy skin; pork BBQ buns - both steamed and baked; greens with oyster sauce; taro cake; red bean stuffed mochi; stuffed lotus leaf, etc), but they also have the BEST pea shoots (perfectly salted and garlicky, but not too heavy) in town, incredible roast duck (yes, the skin is overwhelmingly aromatic and crisp), fried SOFT SHELL CRAB, asparagus, porridge, fried chunks of succulent sea bass, and so much more. 

you never run out of things to order or try. the desserts alone are deliciously daunting. their "donuts" are like beignets - sprinkled ever so delicately with sugar, their light crispiness yields immediately to a fluffy, airy interior. custard buns. mango pudding. the classic egg tarts. walnut cookies. the list goes on. 

the quality and selection never ceases to amaze me. 

i would go here every weekend were it not for the deterrent financial and physical factors. 

mindblowing dim sum.
author: jennifer y.

description: Oh my god.. how does this place have only 3.5 stars? I'm part Asian and this is my favorite dim sum place.. does that give it any more street cred? Their foil wrapped chicken is freaking GOOD.. Nice smoky intense flavors.. Mm.... and the mango pudding is so silky, and the perfect sweetness when they drizzle the condensed milk on top. Spicy fried green beans are really good, as are the cha siu bao (pork buns), dan tat (custard tart), and my favorite, custard rice cakes. Mm.. pull them apart to reveal the bright yellow custard inside.. GOD.. I love Ton Kiang!!!!!!!!! Oh yeah the siu mai (beef ball/dumpling) is great, so is the ha gao (shrimp ball/dumpling)!
author: O K.

description: On the one hand, I thought the service was great cuz they accomodated our large group which included a baby but on the other hand, I didn't think their Dim Sum was very good.  The steamed dumplings seemed too chewy and the pork and shrimp were overcooked.
author: Jonny L.

description: My favorite dim sum place - maybe it's not "authentic" b/c the dumplings actually look like dumplings and aren't the size of a baby's head, and yes, maybe it costs more than dim sum does in China or Chinatown, but sorry, I like good presentation and I don't mind paying a premium for it.  Absolutely delicious dim sum - my favorites are the shrimp dumplings, the bbq steamed pork buns, and the sauteed snow pea leaves - oh, and the sesame balls!!!!  The only problem is that there can be quite a wait (and that doesn't include the impossible parking) if you go after 10 am.
author: Christina S.

description: A good place to take your out-of-town relative.  The food is good, and the variety will give them something to talk about with their friends who think Chinese food is fried rice and sweet and sour pork.  Call it Chinese food 101.  Then tell them they are now proficient in Dim Sum.
author: brenda b.

description: I have never been impressed with the food on the regular menu here. The dim sum is ok I guess but I would rate the service below average. Usually have to wait for a table. Not sure why.  I gave it 3 meals. No mas!
author: Steven G.

description: Good creative dim sum - different than what you'll find at your run-of-the-mill dim sum shops. I always go for the tiny plates of spicy string beans, & their fried tofu.
author: Andrew C.

description: Friendly place to have some dim sum. Get there before 11 or you will wait! Decent variety of food but not nearly as deep as Yank Sing.  My favorite dish was the tofu stuffed with shrimp.
author: Not M.

description: I thought this place needed more variety since I saw mostly shrimp dishes. I thought har gow was good but here its ridiculously greasy. Not the best place for that but the dan tat had the nice crusty feeling.
author: Jason C. J.

description: I came here when me and my boyfriend were looking for some good dim sum. I wasn't dissapointed, but its expensiver than other dim sum places. The service was ok. The custard tarts were good.
author: christy w.

description: Wonderful. I take all my guests from Europe, all the times. We've had dim-sum at least 50 times there, in the past 7 years. Impeccable and consistently good, although it has become a bit too pricey and competitors are doing better and better.
author: Donato M.

description: The dim sum is very good, much more finesse than most other places, but the prices are a bit outrageous - it's definitely better than the place next door but it is more than twice as expensive, and you will wait for at least 45 minutes for a table on the weekend!  I understand diminished rate of return but this is getting ridiculous.
author: Yan G.

description: I don't have a ton of Dim Sum experience, so not much of a frame of reference.  This place was good, great variety, with some excellent dishes.  Service was super fast and very friendly and responsive.  Price, perhaps a bit too much.  Parking was a bitch.  I may try it again, yet perhaps not.
author: Lolailo Y.

description:
compare to yank sing, i can say that ton kiang has more variety.
personally, i'll just drive down to Millbrae to Fuk Yuen or Hong Kong Flower.
parking is a nightmare.
author: Angie Y.

description:
Ton Kiang has been a fixture in my life since the very beginning, back when it was located in the location next door to its current building. As a child my sister and I would spend the first 10-15 minutes with our noses glued to the fish and shellfish tanks, watching the crabs clamber over each other and the fish swim in circles. Finally we'd be ushered back to the table to settle into our meals, which became quite routine, although we would mix it up from time to time as well.

Although Ton Kiang is classified as a dim sum restaurant here, and it does have excellent dim sum, I mostly have visited it for dinners. The Hakka cuisine has a lot of yummy choices, and they also carry the more 'traditional' (air quotes!) Americanized Chinese dishes, too. Our regular menu includes the delicious Salt Baked Chicken, a nice portion of Won Ton soup with bbq pork (very tender and flavorful) and stuffed tofu. I'm not a fungal fan, but my mother and sister swear by their mushroom plate, and the various sauces (mustard, hot sauce, an amazing ginger dip) help you complement the flavors of the food.

Although it can be a busy restaurant (especially for dim sum), I do find that the service is crisp and generous, but sometimes you feel a bit forgotten upstairs. I prefer to sit downstairs anyways, as that gives you a better opportunity to watch the scene and see people coming and going. Some of the wait staff have been around for 20+ years and still tease me about the glasses I used to wear as a child. Great and personable service, especially if you are a regular (or a lifer, in my case). 

There are a few bumps, but frankly I am not going to let them affect my 5-stars. Nevertheless, do know that they do not take reservations for small groups (I think the cut off is 8+ or 10+), parking can be a real pain (my father once famously gave up trying to find a spot to park after dropping us off, and ended up driving home in a fury instead - he still asked for us to bring home some food for him though!) and there is only one bathroom each for men and women, so there can sometimes be a bit of a wait. Also Ton Kiang is not the cheapest Chinese restaurant in the area, but I have no qualms whatsoever about paying a bit more for this experience. Finally, in response to one of the reviews that remarked on how distant Ton Kiang is from Chinatown (and the presumed impact that this distance had on the food's quality), there is in fact a very large Chinese community based in the Richmond, and in fact it is larger in numbers, if not in national recognition, than Chinatown itself!
author: Richard N.

description: Tried to call and make reservations but they said they did not take reservations but that the wait was short.  We headed that way, got there and there were several people standing outside waiting.  They said it was a 40 min wait so we decided to wait.  After an hour, we finally got seated.  We saw several people that 1) had called and made reservations and 2) came after us but got seated before us because they don't seat in order of when you get there, they seat by table size.  So, if a table that could seat 6 opens, they will seat a family of 6 even if they have waited 2 minutes and the party of 4 has waited an hour.. kind of odd.  Our friends had a plane to catch, we had to rush to eat so that added to the mediocre feeling.  After we had filled up on what had come around, better things came around maybe after 30 minutes so I was disappointed that we didn't have a wide variety at the beginning.  I think I would try other places in the city before going back.
author: Jill b.

description: I don't have any ability to comment on the authenticity of Ton Kiang but I find it extremely tasty.  The line *seems* long but usefully moves quite quickly.  The sesame balls are the best I have ever had.
author: Tim G.

description: The dim sum was okay--a little too expensive for the quality.  I won't go back.
author: Gillian F.

description: I usually go here for dinner.  Most of their dishes I've tried are pretty tasty...a little greasy at times but not bad.  Try to go with a couple of people so you can share and taste all the different dishes.  I've only been here once for Dim Sum and wasn't that impressed...KOI PALACE in Daly City is the best for Dim Sum.
author: Jaki B.

description: J says: Came here for lunch on a weekday so there was no wait.  The dim sum in general is quite good and authentic, although one or two things on the menu (the pastry dishes - one with char siu, another with curried beef) can't compare to Koi Palace or Yank Sing.  Service is friendly, the servers don't mind explaining items to you if you aren't familiar with some of the dishes and I like that the food comes to the table piping hot because the servers bring them out on trays straight from the kitchen (instead of storing tons of dishes on carts for hours).
author: Jen Ken H.

description: This is tasty dim sum in an attractive package - the perfect place to take the out-of-towners who are new to this sort of thing.  They will get the unique Geary neighborhood vibe as you inevitably wait in line, and you can take them for Russian bakery afterward.  Good luck finding parking!
author: Bridget T.

description:
Having been a dim sum fan for many years, I've tried most of the places from the South Bay to SF. 

Yank Sing is the most efficient - all servers have radios to communicate customer requests.  The quality is good, the variety is good, the price is fair.

Ton Kiang has more variety, as good or better quality and commensurate pricing.  The service is mediocre and sometimes you can't always get what you want and the parking is awful.  

Other places like Fuek Yuen, Hong Kong Flower Lounge, Joy Luck can be OK for a fix, but don't compare overall in efficiency, variety or quality.
author: T T.

description: this a restaurant my family and I have been going to for over 20 years.  I've never been let down with their food every time I go.  but we also do not diverge from the list of items we order.  our fav dishes are salt-baked chicken with abundant amount of green chili sauce, clams in black bean sauce, steamed bacon w/mustard greens, and a vegetable dish of ong choy or snow pea leaves sauteed w/garlic.  it's a home run for my family
author: anita c.

description: Paying more attention to the company than the food, I especially recall enjoying the shrimp-stuffed mushrooms, garlic greens, and pork dumplings. There was tons more and while I still think Koi Palace is a bit better but, not necessarily wanting to head to Daly City, this is a great back-up being right on the 38 bus line.
author: Carolyn T.

description:
Took my parent's friends there, actually they took me there but I treated them haha.  This may be the Richmond's Yank Sing.. except the digs are not that hot. Yeah so there's a lot of white patrons. Upstairs is wassup although if you're not by the window. then it'd blow. They have a cool b&w chart with what dimsums you can get

The portions are on the small side.. everything is kinda almost bite sized. Good though, especially the steamed items, other standouts were bbq roast duck and char siu cheung fan 

Good spot for dimsum in SF, though I don't eat much of it (unless the parents visit), Koi Palace still tops for me.. why is it so far (and the lines so long, and the service so poor)

Oh I saw some people have a full on Cantonese meal, looked swanky (they had wine)

Pretty good service. Kinda mad expensive, $80 and then there was tip
author: xo x.

description: I do Dim Sum all over the world.  We were in Hong Kong a couple of months ago for example.  To me Dim Sum is little Chinese ladies with carts and 100 patrons.  This place is tiny and the waitresses bring trays around with small selections.  This is not dim sum to me.  The quality was good but the price was outrageous.  I like to leave a dim sum place still feeling relatively well off financially and with the feeling that I had some fun fending off aggressive dim sum cart drivers.  You get none of that here.
author: Gary K.

description: I came here alone for lunch today, remembering some good meals in the past.  I am not opposed to a white devil chinese restaurant, and I love Yank Sing.  However, everything I had was mediocre: too salty asparagus, gummy ha gau, too much pepper in the shrimp and spinach dumplings.  I did like the sticky rice in lotus  leaves though.  Plus, service was slow, and I was made to feel a bit like a pariah, coming in alone and being shuttled to a lonely table in a corner on the second floor.
author: Hazel H.

description: This place was not what I expected because it was expensive dim sum!  one plate of stir-fried beans, 3 veggie egg rolls, 3 tiny sticky rice in tea leaves, all as dim sum plates, cost $4.75 each. $5.50 for 3 shrimp balls and they even charge for tea!  I was hoping for an authentic, yummy, CHeaP dim sum experience and this place was a horrible shock.  4 plates for $23 and we were still hungry.  It was more expensive than my guidebook admitted.  I should've gone on yelp instead.
author: E S.

description: Some of the best dim sum I've ever had. The shrimp dumplings with a) pea shoots, and b) mushrooms. Are out of this world. The pea shoots one tastes like the ocean.
author: Max B.

description: Love this spot!!! I made plans to invite the in laws before I even paid the check.  I wanted to devour all that passed me by.  I know what I'm about to say is generic but the steamed pork buns were my fave.  Give yourself enough time for parking and waiting in line, but by all means get your little booty over there ASAP.
author: Nada I.

description: Tips: When it's busy, go late. On a Saturday of a 3-day weekend, we arrived at 2:15 pm or so, and were seated immediately, got really attentive and friendly service, and had the carts and plates of food marched by us in a steady stream (no begging for carts of the hargow, etc.); they kept the good stuff coming. Lots of food for 4 people, with tax and tips included, came to $15 apiece. Totally reasonable. I don't think it's outstanding dim sum (Yank Sing and Koi Palace are better), but it's much more reasonable, and it's SO much more hassle free.
author: Ice Cream Truck I.

description: My favorite Dim Sum in the city. The BBQ pork buns are the best.  Pea shoots are amazing.  I don't think anything on the regular menu would get me back in the door - it is really the dim sum that keeps me coming back.
author: Mara K.

description: Delicious dim sum! But I once tried on of their more authentic specials - seafood something in a clay pot. Before this experience I didn't think there was a food I couldn't stomach, at least in the name of culinary experimentation, but I think I found my match. Everything else we had was sublime.
author: Michelle O.

description: $45 for dim sum for two?  That's absurd!  Dim sum is wonderful, first, because it's delicious, and second, because it's supposed to be cheap!  The food tasted good, but I wish I'd saved $25 and gone down the street with the rest of the asians.
author: Helen K.

description: I'm going to have to agree with some of the reviews. This is by far the best chinese restaurant I've been in the bay area. With alot of the asian fusion places trying to be hip and cool with their food, nothing beats this place. It's a little pricy but well worth it.  I've always had an awesome dining experience here.  The parking in the area leaves a little bit to be desired. But once you've had the food, it's well worth it.
author: Spooky B.

description: Great food, service and ambiance.  We had the lobster.  It was really good but not as good as the shrimp with chili sauce and okra.  Attentive staff.
author: Wes W.

description: Dim sum selection is decent.  I am not sure what hakka dim sum is as dim sum is not a hakka specialty.  The lines are overwhelming on the weekend.  If you are stuck in the city, this is not a bad choice.  You will have better luck for quality dim sum in Oakland or down in Millbrae.  Service is fair.
author: Koy T.

description: Fairly good service and food.  They're not as efficient as Yank Sing or Canton, but not too bad - for dim sum.  I had their salt and pepper crab one time and it's good.
author: Pikachu P.

description: Great for dim sum but can get very busy, they also serve really nice dinners.
author: J J.

description: This is a upscale dim sum restaurant, with good quality food.  It's just a bit expensive than other restaurants in the area.
author: mardou o.

description: Bad dim sum and service.  I really don't understand why people like this place.  Normally at dim sum joints they roll a cart around to see if you want what they have, at Ton Kiang the servers carry trays and they insist on DROPPING them on your table (**KLUNK** "You want?")... very irritating.  Also the same servers kept bringing the same (cold) deep fried plates to my table (didn't want it 15 minutes ago, certainly don't want it now.)  The servers looked a little embarrassed.  You would do better with a cheap place on 6th and Clement.
author: Fredricko B.

description: Dim sum is delicious! My family and I have been coming here for years but over the years the food and the service has gone down exponentially. Though the dim sum is great, the dinner plates that my family and I used to adore and love have become quite unsatisfactory. Take out is even worse-YUCK. Used to be amazing but recently- very disappointing.
author: Ashely J.

description:
We had a family lunch here on Saturday.  We always sit upstairs.  

The food here is very good and comes out at a very rapid pace.  Be ready to eat!  The ladies all bring out hand held and in carts and the food is always hot and tasty.  

We had 9 people for $150 which is such the better deal than Yank Sing.  Plus on the bill, it has the prices listed which Yank Sing does not do.  I like that.  No surprises.
author: Brian L.

description: I love the green beans in birds nest...it makes a perfect late night dinner, reasonable and hot...and their dim sum is stupendous....their crab claws are just fabulous!!!
author: M. M.

description:
have been eating here for twenty years and counting
never eaten anything i didn't like this includes the jellyfish and chicken feet.
they serve whole fish right out of the tank which is always a plus for me and Sunday dim sum although a bit pricey is wonderful
author: Adam F.

description: Went here for a Chinese New Year dinner with my whole family after we couldn't get in at R & G Lounge who were, by the way, incredibly RUDE over the phone!!! I decided that I would not patronize a restaurant run by rude people so we went to Ton Kiang! The meal at Ton Kiang was delicious. Most posts for Ton Kiang are for Dim Sum, be we ordered dinner from the menu & were completely satisfied! The food was fresh & very well prepared & the place was spotless. I will definitely eat here again in the future!
author: C L.

description: We have been coming to Ton Kiang for a few years predominatly to avoid going into China Town, however this last time was quite a disapointment. I expect restaurants to be consitent. The food was greasy leaving my palate with a film of oil, the hao gao skin was kinda of thick and chewy as apposed to moist and thin. The fried shrimp in between the eggplant was ruubbery, this was the theme on the 6 items we had unfortunatly.
author: Humberto R.

description: So, this is not the type of Dim Sum place that includes frantic servers shoving different little plates or "baskets" of undefined food in your face moving way too fast to get a brief synopsis of what you just ordered. Ton Kiangs is well organized, less frantic and just as tasty. You also get to order your dim sum ahead of time thus preventing getting something you didn't want or don't like. For the price, I'd definitely go back. It was very yummy.
author: Robert L.

description: I really would love to give Ton Kiang a 5-star rating. I really would. They have a vast selection of dim sum that moves through the dining room with a good amount of regularity. And most of the entrees I've had have been flavorful and not as greasy as some of their local competitors. But...the service has always ranged from neglectful to awful. I've had it take 30 minutes to have my order taken, typically have to remind the waiter of items ordered and not received a minimum of two times, and have been charged for items that (despite my prodding the waiter) never arrived at our tables. And their Mongolian Beef (one of my favorite main courses) has been fatty and subpar enough times that I won't ever order it again. My advice here is stick to the dim sum and the infallable classics -- and get them to go.
author: Miss E.

description: This is the best dim sum out in this area. Geary near 21st. Check it out. If you enjoy fresh dim sum this is your spot. They have a lot for vegetarians too. The location is two stories so you can usually get a seat even when its packed. The wait isn't that bad. ENJOY.
author: santiago g.

description:
My favorite dim sum place in the city.  Ton Kiang is always crowded during the day on the weekends, so I try to avoid going then.  Since they serve dim sum all day, I prefer to go during "off-hours" - during the week or in the evenings.  Parking is tough.

Best pot stickers in town.  The Shanghai soup dumplings could contain more soup.  Good standards - har gao, sui mai, and steamed pork dumplings.  The chow mein is also excellent.
author: Ben C.

description: This place has excellent food!  The staff is a little odd but that's ok, they are friendly enough.  Plan ahead if you are on a schedule as parking is always a challenge.
author: betty r.

description: I have been going to Ton Kiang for well over a decade and a half and it is, and will continue to be, my favorite place for dim sum. Whether you're into steam dumplings, sauteed vegetables, fried shrimp balls or yummy pork buns, you will not be disappointed in your selection. The hot and sour soup is also one of the best I've ever had, and a personal favorite off of their main menu, along with their singapore noodles. Their short ribs are also delicious, as they fall off the bone in all of their meatiness. My family and I most recently went there on Christmas day (and boy was it packed, we were not alone in the "we're not cooking today" mentality) and the service was excellent and the ambiance exceptional as always. Go to Ton Kiang and you will not be disappointed!
author: Lauren B.

description: Good Dim Sum, but it should be at this price! I agree with the other reviewers, the service is sometimes a little non-existent.
author: Gary B.

description: Food is good, but it is way too expensive.  I came here with three other people and dropped $120 - and the interior/service doesn't even warrant that much of a cost.  Head to Clement street and grab some dim sum that tastes just as good but at a fraction of the cost.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Good food, but service for dim sum is slow and a bit pricey.  A great place to take dim sum newbies and picky eaters, as what is being served tends to be the well... lighter side of the dim sum menu.
author: Robyn S.

description:
Food is consistently good. My favorites are the sticky rice, shrimp balls, and the brocoli. The egg custard cake is really good and I can't seem to find it anywhere else in the city. Not the egg custard but the one that is covered in a white encasing. 

The prices didn't bother me much until they started charging for tea ($1.00 per person!)
author: C K.

description: Love the food here!!! It's one of the best dimsum place in the city. I always order the the Steamed BBQ Bun - delicious sweet bbq pork and fluffy steamed bun.  The Pea shoots sauteed with garlic are is wonderful - simple but cook perfectly. Love the Shrimp dumplings with Chives and Har Gao. The chinese doughnuts are also a treat but their so many good choices, hot sweet tofu, mango pudding and custard tart.  Dim Sum at it's best......very clean surroundings and good service ( I have not been cheated with the wrong bill given to me iin chinese as experienced in other Chinese restaurants). Love this place!!!
author: freewill m.

description: My family and I have been coming here for about 20 years back when it was in the little red brick building on Geary.  The food has never failed me.  I always order the cod and the duck when I bring a group of people and everyone is thrilled with how good it is.  T.K. has never failed to impress.
author: Gerry C.

description:
Had dinner here with friends where a waiter took our order; then another waiter brought a small plate (4 pieces) of dim-sum saying "Try this!".  After we were finished with our meal, a $5.00 charge showed up on our bill - apparently for that small plate of dim sum we were supposed to try.

When we queried the waiter as to what the charge was for, he indicated it was for the dim sum. When we told him we did not order it, they brought it to us, and with the comment, it would suggest it was complimentary.

He then proceeded to say if we didn't order it; we should have sent it back!!!  Long story short, they took the $5.00 charge OFF the bill; not sure if they did that for all the other tables who also looked like they got a complimentary dim-sum small plate.  Suggest one is careful in reviewing Ton Kiang's bills as this would fall in the category of unacceptable dining practices.  Doubt we will go back, even though the food was reasonably good.
author: Sunny D.

description: Definitely one of the best Dim Sum spot in the Bay Area. Great atmosphere. A bit high on the price but the freshness of their Dim Sum is well worth it. Better call for reservation because this place gets packed early and stays packed pretty much the entire day. Highly recommended.
author: Johnny f.

description: Ton Kiang is a unique dim sum restaurant in that it is fresh in appearance and caters to a mainly caucasian / mixed family crowd.   This would be a great spot to take a squeamish dim sum first-timer.  I found the dim sum to be good, but a little lacking on flavor.  The BBQ pork buns are the best dim sum item. I'd go back with friends, but most of my friends would prefer a place like Tong Palace or Gold Mountain which have more variety and are cheaper.
author: Kim K.

description: Great dim sum -- tasty baked bbq pork puns, shrimp dumplings...however, more pricey than the average dim sum place in Chinatown. Maybe it's because this restaurant serves more unique dishes than I usually see, plus it's been favorably  reviewed in local newspapers and, as my mom says, is "fancy" because it has cloth tablecloths and cloth napkins. I liked it but my mom whose favorite hobby is comparison-price shopping, thought it was too expensive. 6 dishes and tea for $28.00. Dishes were $3 to $5, compared to $2 to $3 like my mom is used to seeing in Chinatown. I felt bad so I had to stop ordering since my mom was paying. (What was unusual was that next door was another dim sum place, with much lower prices - starting at $1.80). Half the clientele in Ton Kiang was non-Asian, which may have been another clue as to why it was more expensive. I've been to "dive" dim sum places where my friends are the only non-Asians there. Cheaper food but not as clean. (don't want to know about that!)
author: Lulubelle L.

description: The best Chinese food and the best Dim Sum in San Francisco. Have been here several times for dim sum for lunch/brunch, but not for dinner (that's just wrong!). For dinner, it's much, much better to have their Hakka cuisine, which is what Ton Kiang specializes in. Hakka (Chinese pinyin: ke4jia1, literal meaning "guest families") are a Han Chinese people whose ancestors are said to originate from around Henan and Shanxi in northern China over 2700 years ago. Their ancestors migrated southwards because of social unrest, upheaval, or by invasion of foreign conquerors since the Jin Dynasty. They speak their own dialect of Chinese, which is why Ton Kiang, which means "East River", is not written as Mandarin dong1jiang1, nor is it written in Cantonese as dung1gong1. The best dish to order, and my favorite, is the Ton Kiang Steamed Salt Baked Chicken. Order some dou miao as your veggies to go along with this dish; it's not on the menu, but any Chinese restaurant will have it. Or order kong1xin1cai3. That won't be on the menu either. :) Their dim sum is good too, and cheaper than Yank Sing, but of course, I still prefer Koi Palace.
author: Hao L.

description: chinese food for non-chinese people. dim sum was oh-kay.  hit up something else on the rich strip.
author: Ligaya T.

description: This had been our favorite dim sum restaurant for over 20 years but it has really slipped since the early days. Went for an early lunch earlier this week and was completely dissatisfied with the service and lack of dim sum choices. The food was good but many of our favorites were missing, even after special requests were made. This was the third and last try.
author: rick g.

description: Prawns with candied walnuts.  Sounds wierd.  But a food revelation, as were the beef tip with asparagus, the won ton soup (really rich broth).  We had a table reserved for a family occasion so no waiting.  Excellent Value for the money.  Definitely worth a special visit to check this place out.  Tip o my hat to my sweetie Frank, who once again comes through with  a "hidden local gem at a freakishly good price."
author: Mel B.

description: whenever i come to the bay area and i want some dim sum, i come here.  this isn't your usual chinese dim sum place, it's not even located in chinatown, it's really a hole in the wall, but the dim sum is always piping hot and delicious since it's not rolled out on carts and is made to order.  the service?  for a chinese restaurant, it is out of this world.  water glasses and tea always filled without having to ask, that is literally unheard of for a chinese restaurant.  there is street parking only, so if youre lucky, you'll find a spot.  drive around the nearby chinese market, there's usually cars coming in and out of the street parking there.
author: will m.

description: i luuuurrrrrvvvvvv me some dim sum. this place is always packed and it's instant satisfaction when the little carts come around. but it's a bit greasy and i'm pretty sure they use MSG because i always have a semi-panic attack after we leave.
author: Mary V.

description: forget the dim sum. this place has the best fried rice I've ever had!
author: Jade R.

description: I would give it 3 stars if the food was not so salty.  The dim sum is ok but the regular chinese dishes are loaded with salt.
author: the t.

description: their dim sum is yum yum yummy. the price, however, is not so amazing. but if you're willing to splurge, go. everything is good. my personal favorite is the leaf wrapped rice and meat. also, they have these hockey puck shaped sweet egg filled things that are to die for. and i've never seen them anywhere else!
author: selma s.

description: Great dim sum. The service is fast. Before you can sit down there are carts of dim sum to pick and choose from. You can tell that this place is well liked because the sizable crowd outside waiting to get in. Although it popular the wait is no more than 20 minutes for even a large group of 6. great for nursing a hangover.
author: Ralph H.

description: The dim sum here is just okay, but when you factor in the high prices, it's actually quite disappointing.
author: Amy L.

description: The best Dim Sum I have ever had and not as hectic as other places.  Lots of yummy greens, dumplings, duck and veggie options.  GREAT service.  And for 4 our bill was less than $80!
author: D F.

description: Great food for dim sum. Try the chilean sea bass with peppers. Yum. Best time to get in here is early (10 am ish) before the crowds come. Dinner though is a disaster.
author: Olivia B.

description: I was skeptical about this place because, in no offense, but when I went, it was all white people.  Not an asian person in sight.  However, upon tasting the food, I realized that it's actually quite good and tastes pretty authentic.  I went with one other person for easter brunch and we had the shrimp crystal dumplings, shanghai dumplings, shrimp roll, vegetarian egg rolls, pan fried turnip cake, stuffed mushrooms, and steamed pork buns.  All of it tasted a lot better than it looked and I have to say, out of all the dim sum places I've tried in SF, the pork buns here are the best.  The place was also really clean and service was alright for a chinese restaurant, but when we got the bill, we were shocked.  We ended up paying over $40...for dim sum.  That just seems wrong when we could have gone next door and had a dim sum feast for two for under $20.
author: Grace C.

description: Although this place is probably best known for its Dim Sum, I have never eaten it. I usually order off the menu and I am consisently satisfied with the quality of their food. The Sweet Corn Chicken soup is my personal favorite as it reminds me of my childhood. The Fried Rice, Garlic Chicken & Steamed Mushrooms & Bok choy are also very good. Lines can be long, especially on the weekends, so take-out is a solid option.
author: Anon Y.

description:
i would give ton kiang one more star, but i am feeling a little self concious about being another white girl giving this pricey dim sum place five stars. 

my first star is for the moon cakes- real moon or moon-cakes? take the moon-cakes!
the second star is for being close to me
the third star is for my sugar man taking me any sunday i want
the fourth star is for the curry pork puffs that tatse like a thousand buttery bakeries in my mouth all at once

the fith star would be for...
wait, no, the fith star would be for me feeling like a choad. never mind.
author: Maggie Baggie H.

description: There is a lot of hype about this place.  The San Francisco Comical calls it one of the top 100 restaurants in the Bay Area.  Yes, you heard me, not just the city, but the whole Bay Area.  We're talking Gary Danko, French Laundry, Ton Kiang.  The food is good--certainly way above average dim sum.  But it is expensive.  You point to one thing, you point to another...all of a sudden you rack up $25 worth of dim sum...for LUNCH.
author: Nick K.

description: Good food,good service and clean environment! it's pricey than normal place dim sum but you get what you pay for. Definitely come back again.
author: Grace C.

description: yummy yummy yummy. every time i has company in town i take them here. its one of the few restaurants int the area that serves dim sum all day. well, they dont walk around with the dim sum trays all day but you can order the dim sum dishes off the menu whenever you like. All of the dumplings and crepes are extraordinary. the service is wonderful and the food is sooo good i dont mind waiting in line  for a table (which is a common occurance). to agree with one yelper, it is a bit expensive as you have to get a number of little dishes to be  satiated, but i think it's worth it. i was soooo lucky to have born and raised 4 blocks from this Chinese treat!  :)
author: Hillary C.

description: If you've been keeping up with my blogs, you know i love dim sum. San Francisco is supposed to be where dim sum restaurants originated, so of course i had to try one. We went to Ton Kiang. I know everyone wants to eat this stuff in chinatown, but it's pretty touristy over there and besides all around me is like chinatown, so this seemed a better bet. and i was right! i actually went there twice. the first time we got there around 2 and it was very busy. we didn't have to wait long, only maybe 5 or 10 minutes, and got seated upstairs. the second time, we got there probably an hr later, and it wasnt busy. we were seated right away, downstairs. either way, the service was great, people carrying most of the food on trays instead of wheeling them around. there were tons of dishes, lots of variety, and the stuff came very frequently. I do think there was a little bit more variety the first time, probably because we were at rush hour. I've never seen so many dim sum dishes though! Everything was good! We went a second time only because we didn't have room in our stomachs to try everything the first day. Some of the dishes are a little expensive, the oysters drove our bill up the first time (i dont eat those they look scary). I know there are cheaper places here, like there were in boston. Still, $45 for three people isnt that bad. And mmm those potstickers and dumplings!!! Definitely go here. The dishes are not cooked in peanut oil like we've been warned some places might do (me and my roommate are allergic). i'm going to try another place for variety next time but you have to go here if you haven't.
author: Merredith L.

description: Overpriced, crappy dim sum, bad service, what more can I say.  I have no idea why people recommend this place.  Maybe it was better in the past.  We ordered the fish in clay pot, but smelled like rotten socks.  I have a strong stomach for unusual flavors but they should warn you that it is fermented.  The take-out dim sum dives on Clement are better than this.
author: JT L.

description: how can you go wrong with dim sum available 24 hours a day???  okay or at least until they close.  whatever.  i never go anywhere else for dim sum, possibly because i can walk here and it's the only place around here that looks clean.  and, as you may have noticed from my other reviews, i can't help but love the places that know me and give me the special attention i love and crave.  i always get the pea tip dumplings.  and a booth table.  if i ever open a restaurant, there will only be booth seats like these.
author: Janice C.

description: whatever, i know everyone likes to hate this place, but i like it!  what can i say?  it's easy, and good.  we go pretty early on weekend mornings, and usually don't have any wait.  plus, they have all the old favorites, and the service is attentive (unlike most dim sum places).  i will admit, it's a little disconcerting that almost everyone in the restaurant isn't asian... but i don't think it's bc the food is bad.  it's more expensive than most dim sum places, but not as pricey as yank sing.  it's definitely not the most authentic place, and it's not the secret awesome place that you're looking for... but i still think it's worth a visit.
author: Liz C.

description: This is another over-priced joint for those who are afraid of the real thing.  While the food is good, it is nothing special compared to those places just blocks away, at a significantly higher price.  For a better deal in dim-sum, without a sticker shock, head over to Clement street, just a block north, and choose from dozens.
author: Anonymous M.

description: mmm, salivating just thinking of the egg custard mochi thingies and chinese doughnuts - i don't usually have a sweet tooth, but ordering dessert here is a must, so make room!
author: Larissa D.

description:
when they serve you OLD FISH (smelly and mushy (fresh fish should be flaky) and then NEGOTIATE with you, it's all bad.

1. They said the chef bought it today...so!?!  the chef is a bad fish buyer
2. They would not take it off the check...We don't take items back, you don't know what you are talking about.  
3. BOTTOM LINE -- ONE CANNOT SEND BACK SMELLY, OLD, MUSHY FISH -- YOU ARE STUCK WITH OUR BAD FOOD & MUST PAY FOR IT!!!

The piece of fish was $21/pound -- effective price over $30.  

I hope you all vote with your dollars -- we have been a regular customer for over 15 years, but now we will never go back. Clearly, they do not care about loyal customers.  

Good luck to those that venture there.
author: Pamela C.

description: I had my wedding banquet here on July 11, 2009, and some of my Asian friends said it was the best Chinese food they had ever tasted.  I agree!!  I had been to Ton Kiang several times for dim sum, which is also good.   The seabass was amazingly fresh and delicious, and the lobster was perfect.  They were very accomodating on giving us the upstairs for our 10 tables, and the prices were also fair.  A perfect place for a banquet dinner!
author: Connie W.

description: Yucky Greasy food for Expensive price. Don't go here....
author: Tevantheesa L.

description:
food 4; service 3.5; atmosphere 3; value 3
