not as good as city view but if you're in the area a good alternative.  Focus on the seafood dim sum - esp the dumplings and fried oysters.  Parking can be a pain but worth the effort.
author: Stacy N.

description: My favorite place for dim sum when in the city.  Granted the prices are a bit high, the food is great and the service is good.  Try the steamed egg custard bun ! :P
author: Hung T.

description: so stuffed i'm going to die. another white person perishes at the hands of ton kiang
author: Laura A.

description: i think this place is overrated. it's not very uhmmm? good!... it's like every other chinese restaurant, not unique enough. i thinkt he main reason a lot of people like it is because it's more americanized. more ABC or AMericans can go and order without a problem. the waitors speak english to us and i thought it was really weird because i'm used to waitors speaking chinese in a chinese restaurant. the food is normal, with a lot of MSG to satisfy the american taste. parking is also hard to find.
author: Eric Y.

description: It's just okay, service is adequate, the entrees are inconsistent.  the stuffed crab claw was excellent, the egg rolls were average.  there are 3-4 other locations on Geary that I'd visit again 1st.
author: christopher j.

description: This restaurant is always busy.  The food is always consistently good.  You can tell that they use fresh ingredients.  But  the service and atmosphere are just ok.   And the parking is usual not that easy.  However I would go back for the food anytime!
author: JASON L.

description: i have eaten at banquets a few times here, and have absolutely no recollection of the food. while this is partially my fault for having a terrible memory, it's partially their fault for making such forgettable food. over-rated.
author: Lijia X.

description: compared to other dim sum places, the wait has never been too bad. i've never had to wait more than half an hour. at koi palace i've waited almost an hour before. didn't think that was worth it at all. unless you really want tupperware to take home. anyhow, ton kiang has pretty good dim sum and variety to boot. and if you don't like the parking, suck it up and take the bus.
author: Shinn Z.

description: We got lucky and headed over at 2pm on Superbowl Sunday to have no wait thankfully as I was starving. It lived up to it's great expectations as the best dim sum in SF.  Great food, courteous and fast service, but lost a star because my ha gao disappointed.
author: Cbr A.

description: Good Dim Sum but waaay overpriced  $106.00 for four people.
author: Michael F.

description: Ton Kiang is the place to go for dim sum!  Delicious food and quick service.
author: Grace G.

description: everyone raves about it, but i just think it's regular.  it's good, but i don't get why there is so much buzz.  i actually prefer the less hyped mayflower just a few blocks down geary.  it's also on the pricey side.  but the interior is nice and i guess for a dinner this might be a better location.  but for dim sum i say go to mayflower.
author: becky k.

description: i think the dim sum here is pretty good, but i don't think i'd say it's fantastic.  and i wasn't all that crazy about the hot and sour soup.  it was really corn starchy, and not that hot or sour.  atmosphere's sort of enh, and it seems a bit pricey for what it is, but it's decent.  i say you could do better, though.  i mean, if i'm going to drop some bucks on dim sum, why not just go all the way and go to yank sing.
author: brian g.

description: By far one of my favorite restaurants.  I've gone several times for dim sum so I can't comment on other parts of the menu, and even though I admit I'm not a dim sum expert I still think it's delicious!  Loses a star because the service is pretty bad and I'll admit it's a little pricey, but that won't stop me from coming back for the spicy foil-wrapped chicken, barbeque pork buns, scallion pancakes, turnip cake (it looks disgusting but trust me it's delicious) and mango pudding!
author: Mary P.

description: Way over priced for what it is.  The food is average, and the variety for dim sum is way less then most places.
author: John S.

description: i used to sort of not be a fan of ton kiang.. to be honest, the waits are long, and it's a little pricey. but after trying some other places in the city that were just mediocre to appalling, i think you have to stick with ton kiang. their food is the most consistent. the service is always fast, there's always variety, and these people have the art of dim sum down.
author: monkey l.

description: i don't recall the food being this bad.  maybe i just had a bad batch of dim sum, but every dish i ordered just seemed super salty and laden with msg.   on top of that, there was also a long wait at this place.  i did not understand why people would pay to eat here.  even take out on clement was better.  once i looked around and realized i was in the company of nonasian clientele and  tourists w/ guide books, that's when it finally dawned on me why this place was so popular.
author: Dorothy L.

description: i didn't have the dim sum and only went for dinner.   i know chinese food is inherently greasy but the mu-shu was significantly oilier than other chinese food i've had.  i felt sick slightly afterwards. but on the other because my boyfriend enjoyed his sweet and sour chicken and their sesame balls for dessert were amazing!  see if you can get them fresh!
author: michelle k.

description: the wait was insane!  probably why the restaurant was in such disarray.  the food was expensive and below par.  the dishes were too americanized for me.  there are plenty of other dim sum places in the area to try.
author: Big e.

description: Yes, dim sum here used to be very good. I have been coming here for years but last time I was here it's not as good as it used to be They have less varieties now and they seem to not cater for chinese anymore. I've also noticed the wait is not as long as it used to.
author: law l.

description: It's true the service is downright pushy and annoying.  And the dim sum is not cheap.  But it is tastey tastey.  I haven't had many mediocre dishes - most are very yummy.  Love the pea shoots, vegie potstickers and the stuffed shrimp dumplings.  The eggplant also rocks.  This is great for vegetarians and awesome for groups because you get to try lots of different dim sum.
author: Jane M.

description: if you are looking for a great Dim Sum experience, Tom Kiang's is where it's at.  We are locals and this is in no way an overrun tourist trap.  This is not a fancy, trendy restaurant but rather, a restaurant that focuses on the food and service.  My husband, sister and I went on a Friday night and were immediately sat. (This is after driving around the block, up & down Geary for about 45 minutes trying to snag a parking spot) And boy were we hungry when we sat down!  No wait.  We were immediately given the regular menu and Dim Sum Menu.  Husband & I did the dim sum for 2 plate- PLENTY of food.  You get 9 options on the dim sum menu and there are 3 of each item so this was 27 individual items which ended up being the perfect amount of food.  My sister ate the Mongolian Beef and it was tasty and tender meat.  We ordered Won Ton soup for a starter and it easily fed 3 and could have fed more.  Each dim sum item was great- all the different stuffed dumplings, pork buns, and of course the sesame balls as dessert.  We were very impressed with the food and the service was also great.  We asked our waiter to recommend some of the dim sum dishes since we had never had any before and he was helpful and attentive throughout the meal.  The prices were very reasonable as well.  The bonus of this place, on top of the awesome dim sum, is that it serves dim sum all day and night, until they close.  Most SF dim sum places only serve this for brunch/lunch.  The *one*  thing missing this night was the traditional dim sum cart they normally push around but who cares if the food is good!  We left with very full bellies and will definitely return!
author: JR W.

description: Can you say tourist trap? I don't like the food. Been there once, not up to my standards.
author: bob k.

description: I really wanted to find the best dim sum in SF so I could take my out of town guests here, but I still haven't found it. This place is just okay. I ordered the basics: har gow, siu mai, sticky rice, turnip cake etc, and it's really just okay. Not particularly flavorful, not particularly warm. I don't understand how this restaurant has gotten such great accolades (like being named best dim sum hands down on Frommers...how??).  If I lived around the corner I would go, but it's absolutely not worth the drive.
author: Rogue R.

description: expensive but near perfection. don't miss the steamed bbq pork buns!!
author: K K.

description:
very good.
my roommate is always dreaming about this place and when she finally took me, i took my sister the very next week! go on a sat just before 11 am, you won't be disappointed.
author: Sasha R.

description:
I used to often eat at Ton Kiang when they were still at the Geary and Spruce, pre-dim sum location. And I was happy with what I thought was the city's best dim sum when they opened the current space and for a long time after that. In other words, I've eaten well there for more times than I can count.

A couple of days ago, we decided that we'd go there for dim sum today. It had been awhile since I'd been there, so I decided to check Yelp and a couple other places to get the current word on things. The word was unencouraging and we almost didn't go. But we decided to give it a shot since we'd eaten well there so many times in the past. It wouldn't have been fair to them to write them off based on other people's words.

The Yelpers were right, sadly. The meal was not just disappointing, it was awful. The chinese broccoli and pea tips were cooked fine, but coated with a thick and bad tasting oil. The XLB was OK, but not distinctive. Same goes for a couple of the shrimp dumplings and a few other things. Other items were just greasy and bad. At first, I wondered if it was just me, that maybe I'm just not as into dim sum as I once was, which happens to be the case. But then I compared it to things I've eaten at other dim sum places over the last months, places I wasn't even that crazy about, and they were way better. Even some take out that I had from Ton Kiang earlier this year was fine. This was the kind of meal that not only wasn't satisfying from a taste standpoint, it made me feel like I had grease dripping from my pores on top of it. I wanted to turn back the clock and go elsewhere. Not a good place to be.

My wife is convinced that there must be new ownership. The difference is too extreme for any other explanation to suffice.

It'll take some convincing to get me back there, again. What a disappointment. I can't think of many situations where the same place had such a sudden and dramatic fall off in quality. Yuk.
author: Jim S.

description: I blew Ton Kiang off nine years ago because the food was not that good, only to go back recently to find out that that was just a bad day. The food was excellent. The pot stickers are crispy with a wonderful ground pork, onion (instead of cabbage,) and ginger filling. The egg rolls are crispy and greasless with fresh vegetables with a well balanced sweet and sour sauce. The beef with snow peas in house chili sauce is excellent with tender melt in your mouth beef with stewed snow peas as opposed to stir-fried in a tongue tingling but suttle chili sauce. The Ton Kiang crispy noodles are crispy with a plethora of beef, barbecued pork, squid, scallops, prawns, and bok choy in a light gravy. For dessert, the egg custard pancakes are soft and chewy at the same time with a light, sweet, but rich egg custard. The service is very friendly, the waiters explaining what you are getting aned not coming around to refill tea, water, clear dishes, and ask hiow everything is not too much or too little. I will definitely have to go back for dim sum and inner again. So, for excellent Hakka cuisine at reasonable prices with great service in a traditional atmosphere, Ton Kiang cannot be beat. Keep up the good work guys.! Oh,! for those who say that this restaurant is only for Americans and caters to first timers, there were a lot of Asians and the menu is very authentic.
author: Brian S.

description: i had dinner here, ordered a soup with diced wintermelon, chinese sausage fried rice, spinach, and a braised ox tail with carrot and celery clay pot.  they are yummy!  food was made good here.  note that these are more like REAL traditional chinese food.  if you are looking for more american chinese dishes, you won't find them here.  however, one draw back is the parking, it's hard to find.  Enjoy!
author: Charlotte C.

description: This used to be our family's favorite dim sum spot for many years.  We've since moved from SF to the north bay and still return to Ton Kiang every so often for a special treat.  We were there on Tuesday Dec. 29 for lunch and sure enough, there was a line.  I guess everyone had out of town guests!  Surprisingly there were no folks of asian appearance in the line.  After waiting about 1/2 hr.  we were shown to a table on the 2nd floor right in front of the window.  Seeing that there were only non-asians in the restaurant I was apprehensive about what we would get.  Unfortunately my fears were confirmed.  The waitresses had changed to younger, english speaking young ladies who were bringing around trays of pedestrian dim sum that you could get anywhere for half the money.  My son wanted some roast duck and after waiting some time for it to come around we asked for it.  We kept getting promises that it was "coming" and 45 minutes later it finally appeared, when we'd already given up hope and had eaten our mango puddings.  Amazing since the duck is bought/prepared ahead of time and all that they have to do is cut it up.  They never brought around anything but the most common dim sum and we never did see the waiter for our table.  Ton Kiang has gone over to the "Dark Side", that is, they've sold out authenticity and freshness for the quick buck and catering to those who don't know quality dim sum.  They've lost this long time family for good because it's not worth the drive, the parking hassle and wait, and the cost for this mediocre experience.
author: Jenny F.

description: this place sucks!!! I would never eat at this joint no more...too expensive greasy and old food...just terrible
author: Jimy L.

description: this is one of the best dim sum places we've found.  i know there's lots of chinese food available in this city but it can be hit and miss.  this place has been good for years.    It is a huge place with seating on 2 floors.  You can also order from the menu but i never have.  I really  like the steamed buns and spicy beans.  The carts of food come around often and the food is hot.
author: delbert t.

description: above average dim sum though selection is limited to the conventional stuff.  a bit pricey for what you get but you pay for the atmosphere.  i recommend going up a few blocks to mayflower for more authentic hong kong dim sum experience.
author: Tom L.

description: my fave dim sum place in the city.  introduced to it by all my asian friends.
author: gail g.
